BB_1938_title_recto: Madonna and Child
BB_1938_text_recto: Ascribed to Fra Bartolomeo, but the coarse features and the fumbling stroke make it more probable that this drawing is Albertinelli's. The late Mr. Charles Loeser, in the Uffizi publication just referred to, would ascribe this little sketch to Piero di Cosimo. Much could be adduced in favour of this attribution as the likeness in the hatching and stroke between this sketch and others by Piero is undeniable. It can, however, be accounted for by Albertinelli's having been taught drawingin Piero's studio. The round head and deep-set eyes of the Child, so much like my 1852, could be explained in the same way. But, above all, I do not remember any composition of Piero's so close in pattern and contrapposto to both Fra Bartolomeo and Raphael. It looks like a drawing done in 1505 or 1508

BB_1938_text_recto: Ascribed to Credi The folds in this sketch as in some of Albertinelli's paintings (notably the Volterra picture or the Pitti Nativity, n. 365) would tend to prove that Albertinelli was not at the start the pupil of Credi, but of "Tommaso". If, however, "Tommaso" was only a phase of Piero di Cosimo, as seems more and more likely, then he would have been Piero di cosimo's pupil all along

BB_1938_title_verso: Study of man seated, draped across the chest. Below, two feet
BB_1938_text_verso: drapery and hands highly finished, legs slightly indicated. The head on the recto which in different positions Andrea drew more than once, probably was not made, as the Louvre catalogue states, for the Zacharias in the Scalzo Visitation, nor, as might occur to others, for one of the apostles on left in the Last Supper. It is much more likely that Andrea, whose habit it was to make almost no change from a study of a detail to its final form in the finished work, intended this head for that of the old man kneeling before Caesar in the Poggio a Caiano fresco

BB_1938_title_recto: Bust of young woman
BB_1938_title_verso: Slight sketch of same figure
BB_1938_text_recto: I am not acquainted with the original but assuming as we may on Fishel's authority that is an autograph, the sketch on the recto is of great interest. Impossible not to connect it with one of Andrea's finest achievements, the Uffizi portrait just mentioned, And yet the difference is puzzling. The sketch seems to be of a younger person and of one nearer the people than the lady in the picture, who looks mature, cultivated, and clever. dis the artist use a model with fourtuitous likeness to the lady or is the latter only the image, the "Wunschbild" -the wish fulfilment- of the other?
Cataloguer's Comments: BB 1961 Inventory number is handwritten by pen. The wrong number was 34163. Drawing missing in BB 1903

BB_1938_title_recto: Profile to right of elderly man
BB_1938_title_verso: Profile of bald clean-shaven bull-necked middle-aged man
BB_1938_text_recto: inspired perhaps by some version of the well-known antique bust of Homer. Dr. Fröhlich Bum, who first published these sketches, connects the two figures with the Poggio a Caiano fresco, the draped bust with the young man next to the grey-beard who stands erect to our right of the same composition. These last have nothing in common but the action, which is not surprising seeing that this part of the fresco was finished by Allori. The heads have a certain likeness to this or that in his works of about 1520 but identity with none.
BB_1938_text_verso: Dr. Fröhlich Bum, who first published these sketches, connects the two figures with the Poggio a Caiano fresco, the draped bust with the young man next to the grey-beard who stands erect to our right of the same composition. These last have nothing in common but the action, which is not surprising seeing that this part of the fresco was finished by Allori. The heads have a certain likeness to this or that in his works of about 1520 but identity with none.

BB_1961_text_recto: [1959: Malgrado la tradizionale attribuzione ad Andrea del Sarto, il giovane sul recto è così simile ai disegni del Pontormo intorno al 1530, che io lo assegnai all'allievo di Andrea, e proposi che potesse essere uno studio per il Pigmalione dei Barberini. Però John Shearman (Burlington Magazine, Aprile 1959), riferisce il foglio all'"Assunta Passerini" (Pitti n. 225), alla quale Andrea del Sarto lavorava intorno al 1526: egli vede nel recto uno studio per la Santa Margherita da Cortona, genuflessa in primo piano, e nel
BB_1961_text_verso: o uno studio per le mani dell'Apostolo che stringe un'asta, dietro di lei. Il riferimento delle mani sul verso è senz'altro convincente, ma la figura genuflessa sul recto mi sembra troppo esile per Andrea e mi sono perfino domandato se non potesse essere di Battista Naldini]

Annunziata a Firenze. La donna, se non è sua moglie, è una modella che Andrea disegnò ripetutamente. come altre sue opere giovanili, questo disegno di Andrea si avvicina al Franciabigio, dal quale si differenzia soltanto per la qualità del tocco e del modellato

BB_1961_title_verso: Altri nove studi, più o meno rifiniti, di un ragazzo quasi in profilo verso destra
BB_1961_text_recto: Tutti questi studi sono per fanciulli in varie Sacre Famiglie che si possono riferire ai primi anni del periodo mediano dell'attività dell'artista. Il secondo e terzo studio sul recto sono per il San Giovannino nella "Madonna con San Giovannino ed un Angelo" della Wallace Collection (n. 9) a Londra, e sono tra i  disegni più simpatici di Andrea
BB_1938_title_recto: Several studies for boy. In one we see outlines of a boy looking up, in another the head fairly elaborated looking at us over the shoulder, in a third the same head and shoulders highly finished. Yet another study is for the upper part of a boy in profile to right
BB_1938_title_verso: Nine other studies in various degrees of finish, after a boy, mostly in profile to right
BB_1938_text_recto: The two more finished heads are among Andrea's more pleasant productions. All these studies are for the Holy Children in various Holy Families of Andrea's earlier middle years. The two more finished ones are certainly for the infant Baptist in the Madonna at Hertford House

BB_1938_title_recto: Heavily draped youngish man with short beard and hair parted in middle looking down to right with right hand exposed and left extended under mantle - study no doubt for an apostle. To right a youthful nude seated on cloth which drapes his right leg only, his right arm held up and his left grasping the cloth
BB_1938_title_verso: Four studies for entablatures
BB_1938_text_recto: Meticulous and dainty, this sketch betrays in the nude figure the inspiration of Fra Angelico and the young Benozzo. The draped study is as close to Masaccio. As the only painter of note who imitated all those masters just mentioned was Andrea di Giusto, we may propose him as the author of this drawing. But for the Masacciesque aposle, one would be tempted to ascribe it to youthful Benozzo.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903

BB_1961_title_recto: San Matteo
BB_1961_title_verso: San Luca
BB_1938_title_recto: St. Matthew
BB_1938_title_verso: St. Luke.
BB_1938_text_recto: In the text to this publication, A.M. Hind gives an exhaustive account of this sheet, and correctly relates it to the figure of the Evangelist in the ceiling of the Vatican chapel erected by Nicholas V. He pleads that we should accept both sides as autographs by Fra Angelico. These is little trouble in agreeing with him about the Luke, which is ample, free, and natural. Indeed the head reminds one of an abvious portrait in the Stoning of Stephen in the same chapel, and the difference between the crafts would account for the interesting divergence between the freedom of the drawing and the relative tighness of the painted figure. The sketch of thr Matthew, on the other hand, is stiffer, flatter, more stilted than in the fresco, and the draperies take on a more angular twist. For these reasons this side of the sheet may be assigned to Benozzo while working under Fra Angelico.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903

BB_1938_title_recto: Eight leaves of a picture chronicle
BB_1938_text_recto: By a finer artist than Domenico di Michelino or Strozzi, and more delicate than Benozzo and on a level with Pesellino, whom these miniatures most resemble, although almost certainly not by him. There are reminders as well of Domenico of Domenico Veneziano.
Cataloguer's Comments: In BB 1961 is hand written: "2 fogli al Metropolitan Museum". Drawing missing in BB 1903
Cataloguer's Question: See: Sir Sidney C. Cockerell (former). Sotheby, London, 2 July 1958 and collection of drawings Metropolitan Museum

BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane nudo ben proporzionato, seduto, con lo sguardo volto in basso, la mano destra sul ginocchio accavallato e la mano sinistra che tocca il piede inoltre testa di un giovane in profilo verso sinistra
BB_1961_title_verso: Due giovani Santi seduti, uno in posa attonita e l'altro con la mano alla guancia e testa di bue
BB_1938_title_recto: Well-proportioned youth seated, looking down, with right hand on his knee, which is drawn up over the thigh of the other leg, and his left hand touching his foot. Also the head of a youth in profile to left
BB_1938_title_verso: Two youthful saints seated, one with his hands held in astonishment, and the other with his hand to his cheek
BB_1938_text_recto: If one were tempted to ascribe the nude to Fra Angelico, the head of the youth would quickly put one off. As for the nude, it must be a copy by a pupil of a study made by the master, apparently from the model, for an aposle drawing off his hose in a Christ Washing the Feet of his Disciples. It is quite likely even that the original study served for the little picture in the Florence Academy. The present scketch is at all events precious in that it reveals, what perhaps few have suspected, that Fra Angelico practised drawing from nude. A copy of the nude occurs on folio 10 of the Koenigs sketch-book (my 558.B) most of the drawings in which are copies after Benozzo. Yet I cannot believe this is by Benozzo himself. The author of the sketch-book must have copied a version by Benozzo after the same original by Fra Angelico
BB_1938_text_verso: Copies by a pupil after original drawings, perhaps for figures on the left in a Last Judgement. Also the head of an ox - the simbol of St. Luke. It is possible, but not likely, that this sheet is by Domenico di Michelino.
Cataloguer's Comments: Inventory number missing in BB 1961; in BB 1938 the number is: "1895.9.15.437"

BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane Santo paludato, visto da tergo, in piedi sopra un curioso plinto circolare, col capo ricciuto volto quasi in profilo a destra , con un libro in mano
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo di giovane donna in piedi, che porta sul capo una specie di gabbia di sostegno per i veli, secondo la moda del 1440-50; ha una doppia torcia nella mano sinistra e protende la mano destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Draped youthful saint seen from behind but the curly-headed profile sharp to right holding book. He stands on a curious circular plinth
BB_1938_title_verso: Youthful female nude standing to right. On her head the basketlike construction which supported the tall head-dress worn toward 1440-50. In her left hand a double torch, her right spread out
BB_1938_text_recto: Ascribed to Ghiberti, and no doubt closer to him, but in our present state of ignorance it is safer to catalogue it with the following (in the widest sense of the word) of Fra Angelico.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903

BB_1961_title_recto: Un foglio di una cronaca figurata
BB_1961_text_recto: appartenente alla serie menzionata sotto BB N. 164.C
Cataloguer's Comments: Inventory number missing in BB 1961. Drawing missing in BB 1938 and BB 1903
Cataloguer's Question: See: Margaret H. Drey. New location?

BB_1961_title_recto: Cristo davanti a Pilato e Crocifissione
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: Di esse, sette si trovavano a Haarlem, nella Raccolta Koenigs nel 1937: alla dispersione della Raccolta, due furono acquistate dal Fogg Art Museum e la destinazione delle altre cinque mi è ignota.
BB_1938_title_recto: Presentation in the Temple, Christ before Pilate and Crucifixion
BB_1938_text_recto: Three highly finished miniature compositions. Unacquainted with the originals, I can say no more than this: If these miniatures are of the 15th century they may be careful copies by an Umbrian, perhaps Caporali after a series of panels by Fra Angelico, not identical with any known at present but which may have existed and probably in Umbria. The same miniatures appeared at the Mensing Sale, Amsterdam, July, 1927, and are reproduced in catalogue as n. 249 along with a Christ among the Doctors, a Washing of Feet, which, however, may be, as the catalogue says, by a stiffer and it seems to me more Florentine hand. Text of same catalogue says there were ten of these miniatures in 18th century binding with royal crest. (As far as I know there are seven in the Koenigs Collection at present - 1937).
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1938 and BB 1903

BB_1961_title_recto: Figura femminile seduta, rappresentante la Giustizia

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane alto e snello, in calzoni attillati e corta tunica legata alla vita, con una spada al fianco, ed un morbido berretto sulla testa arruffata, lo sguardo in alto verso destra e le mani giunte all'altezza del petto
BB_1938_title_recto: Tall slender young man in hose and short tunic tied in at waist with sword at side, and soft cap on shaggy head looks up to right with hands folded held up close to chest. Perhaps for a figure in an Adoration of Magi
BB_1938_text_recto: Inscribed at top in Baldinucci's hand "Pisello", which certainly is much nearer than the current attribution to Parri Spinello. It is perhaps as clearly by Baldovinetti as any, and if not his it could only be Domenico Veneziano's. It is too substantial and firm, although elegant enough, to be by the Carrand Master.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903 where the number "190" seems to be omitted

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Robusto giovane con la testa in profilo a destra, seduto, in atto di premere un oggetto fra le mani
BB_1938_title_recto: Youthful but rather thick-set figure seated, with head in profile to right
BB_1938_text_recto: This and my 192, 194, and 195 are companions, and may originally have been on the same sheet. Ascribed to Fra Angelico. To what has been said about these figures in the text, it should be added that their folds and hatching connect them with the two sheets after Alesso (see bolow) which have passed for centuries as that artist's own work.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Corteo di minuscole figure che esce dalla porta di una città e si snoda su per scarpate fino al Calvario, dove ha luogo la Crocifissione
BB_1938_title_recto: Study in tiny figures of Procession to Calvary starting from town gate and winding up escarped terraces to Golgotha, where the Crucifixion takes place
BB_1938_text_recto: Spirited sketch closer perhaps to Baldovinetti than to any other known artist, but at the same time suggesting Antonio Pollaiuolo and even the youthful Botticelli. Interesting to compare this with Jacopo Bellini's drawings. The difference between Florence and Venice in the middle decades of the Quattrocento could scarcely be better exemplified. a kindred composition but on a lower level of artistic quality used by the engraver of Baldovinetti.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi

BB_1961_title_verso: Giovane con le mani incrociate, stante, in profilo a sinistra e ragazzo che si piega per raccogliere uno sgabello
BB_1938_title_recto: Two peasants, one youthful with right hand on hip, the other middle-aged leaning with folded arms on club
BB_1938_title_verso: Youth with folded hands standing in profile to left and boy bending to pick up stool
BB_1938_text_recto: These would seem to be very close to Baldovinetti, but are scarcely of a quality to permit the belief that they are his own. More probably they are school copies after a drawing by the master
BB_1938_text_verso: Poorer than recto. May be autographs (1931).
Cataloguer's Comments: In BB 1903 information about verso handwritten by pencil and added in BB 1938 edition

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per una Deposizione
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Deposition
BB_1938_text_recto: The motive is admirable, and anticipates the Cinquecento treatment of the subject under the inspiration of Michelangelo. A careful comparison with the other drawings here ascribed to Baldovinetti has ended by persuading me that this design must be a close copy - and I may add a contemporary one - of an original by that painter.

BB_1938_title_recto: Moses on Sinai and Brazen Serpent
BB_1938_text_recto: Corresponds to a well-known engraving described by Hind. The drawing, although in execution perhaps by Finiguerra, is close enough to Baldovinetti to make one wonder whether it may not be a transcript of a Baldovinetti. Indeed, the question of this artist's relation to the engravers of his time will repay all the trouble that a competent student can give it.

BB_1961_title_recto: Natività con San Girolamo inginocchiato in adorazione del Bambino
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Nativity with St. Jerome kneeling and adoring the Child
BB_1938_text_recto: Attributed by Wickhoff to Cosimo Rosselli as School of Cosimo Rosselli, as which it was catalogued in my first edition. It now seems probable that it was dane by Alunno in one of his more eclectic and less happy moments. The draperies are his, and Jerome's eye is unmistakable
BB_1903_text_recto: The types are clearly those of a follower of Rosselli - the Child goes even back to Rosselli's master Baldovinetti - but the feeble author of this drawing betrays the influence of Piero as well, and the remote effect of Botticelli also. He must have been a painter of the character of those who have left more than one picture on the altars of S. Spirito

BB_1961_title_recto: Caduta di San Paolo
BB_1938_title_recto: Elaborate composition for Conversion of Paul
BB_1938_text_recto: Whatever qualities this may have as drawing have disappeared under the pricking of the outlines. I used to ascribe to Piero di cosimo this design inspired no doubt by the earlier Florentine engraving reproduced on p. 14 of Colvin's Maso Finiguerra, but landscape apart I no longer see justification for this attribution. The types and the action both have the character intermediate between Ghirlandaio and Botticelli which mark Alunno. One is the more disposed to assign it to him as it served for the famous plate engraved by Matteo di Giovanni Dei in the Bargello. A niello print of it till recently in Paul Kristeller's  Collection is reproduced on p. 20 of Knoedler's Engravings and Etchings for 1931. Alunno, as I have long ago insisted, made a business of furnishing drawings to the engravers. i am indebted to Mr. John Walker for pointing out the connection between this Conversion and the Bargello plate
BB_1903_text_recto: Whatever qualities this may have had as drawing have disappeared under the pricking of the outlines. It may, however, have been Piero's.

BB_1938_text_recto: Pricked for transfer. I owe my acquaintance with this drawing to Mr. Byam Shaw. It is attributed to Perugino and is inscribed by a later hand on the cornices of the pillars with the words "Raffaello del Garbo" for no other reason, probably, than that Baldinucci or whoever it was who inscribed it with these words supposed that all Florentine cartoons for embroideries of about 1500 were made by Garbo.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903

BB_1961_title_recto: Epifania
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Adoration of Magi
BB_1938_text_recto: In the first edition I catalogued this delighful sketch as David Ghirlandaio's, saying that if his it was his finest pen-drawing. Not many years later I began to feel that it was at once too Botticellian and too Peruginesque, for David. The type as well as the folds of the Virgin are distinctly Peruginesque, the second king is all but a copy of Sandro, and the standing figures behind are Botticellian. The combination of elements pointed to Alunno. Looking closer I perceived that the faces and the draperies were certainly his. Later still I realized that his drawing must have served for the fresco in Sala V, "dei Misteri" of the Borgia Apartments. Francovich arrived at the same coclusion independently. So did my friend John Walker. The differences between the sketch and the painting are interesting. It would seem as if Pintoricchio found that the design was too Florentine and insisted on bringing the fresco into closer harmony with his own style. The effort accounts for the inferiority of the finished work
BB_1903_text_recto: The general Ghirlandaiesque character of this drawing is manifest, but for Domenico it is too feeble in handling, and, in one or two of the figures on the right, too flagrantly Leonardesque. David, on the other hand, was not shy of copying Leonardo, and nearer the arch one or more heads with wedge-like faces are almost as good as his, David's signature. If his, as I believe, this is his finest pen drawing.
Cataloguer's Question: See Sotheby's sales June 30 1986 (Drawings from Springell collection and Sotheby's June 28, 1962, n. 39 bought by Metropolitan Museum

BB_1961_title_recto: Due volumi di schizzi: vol. I, foll. 1-210 vol. II, foll. 1-190
BB_1961_text_recto: Già nella collezione Granducale di Weimar, poi nella raccolta Koenigs di Haarlem . Sono questi due volumi citati dal Baldinucci (1728) come appartenenti al Cavalier Francesco Maria Niccolò Gaburri, che li acquistò al convento di Santa Caterina a Firenze, dove era vissuta Suor Plautilla Nelli. Nella mia prima edizione (1903) catalogai soltanto i sei fogli che mi interessavano maggiormente (BB nn. 512 e 514-518). Nella seconda edizione (1938), quando i due volumi erano passati a Haarlem, rimandai ad un unico numero (BB n. 390.D). Non ho bisogno di dare adesso un catalogo completo di questi volumi, poiché posso rimandare gli studiosi all'ottima pubblicazione su Fra Bartolommeo del Gabelentz, dove ogni singolo schizzo è descritto e commentato. Mi limiterò a citare i disegni col numero cumulativo 506.A, seguito dall'indicazione del volume (I o II) e del folio.
BB_1938_title_recto: Two volumes of sketches formerly in the Granducal Collection at Weimar
BB_1938_text_recto: In my first edition some of the best leaves from them are catalogued as N. 512, 514-518. I shall, however, not attempt to enumerate them again, and refer students to Gabelentz where each sketch is fully described and discussed.
Cataloguer's Comments: Inventory numbers missing in BB 1961. and BB 1938. Drawing missing in BB 1903.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi

BB_1961_title_verso: Leggero schizzo a matita per la stessa figura, senza drappeggio
BB_1938_title_recto: Kneeling man turning to left draped but for bare shoulder
BB_1938_title_verso: It is a slight sketch in pencil for the same figure without the drapery
BB_1938_text_recto: I used to ascribe this to Domenico Ghirlandaio. Correctly ascribed to Fra Bartolomeo by O.H. Giglioli in Bollettino d'Arte, 1935/36, p. 490. There also the verso is reproduced which was until a short time ago invisible and therefore unknown to me. Both apparently studies for a St. Jerome in penitence.
BB_1903_text_recto: I do not find this study exactly used in any of Domenico's finished works. It comes closest to certain figures in the Epiphanies of 1487 and 1488, and in the Assumption at S. Maria Novella. It may therefore safely be dated as of this time.

BB_1938_text_recto: The studies on the recto, as my 264, 268, 276 and 276 verso, 408 verso, 409 verso, 448, 490 - all among Fra Bartolommeo's most dainty pen-drawings - must have been made in connection with a Christ at the Well which was bought by Girolamo Casio (the well-known Bolognse patron of Boltraffio). From Casio's collection it passed over almost immediately to the Duke of Mantua's. I have never come across it, and am not aware that it is supposed to be still existing. It seems to have been a pendant to the "Noli me tangere" of the Louvre.

BB_1938_text_recto: Not in Fra Bartolommeo's ordinary technique, more pictorial, in short more like Rosso Fiorentino or Beccafumi. Not impossibly copy by a master of their type, though I still think it more likely by Fra Bartolommeo.

BB_1961_title_recto: Sant'Antonino elemosinario
BB_1938_title_recto: S. Antonino giving alms
BB_1938_text_recto: A subject, to my knowledge, treated but once again, and that by the one Venetian whom Fra Bartolommeo so frequently and so singularly recalls, Lorenzo Lotto. The latter's version is more animated and dramatic. The drawing, as befits the more academic traditions of Florence, is clearer and more harmonious in arrangement.

BB_1938_text_recto: The fact that I ascribed this sheet 35 years ago to "Tommaso" is interesting in connection with the problem of this Anonimo's identity. It would seem to encourage those inclined to hold that he was Piero di Cosimo. Other traces of "Tommaso" that appear in early drawings by both Fra Bartolommeo and Albertinelli point to the same conclusion.

BB_1938_title_recto: Holy Family with infant Baptist

Cataloguer's Comments: Inventory number missing in BB 1961 and BB 1938. Drawing missing in BB 1903. Between BB 1961, n. 459.B and BB 1961, n. 459.C handwritten by pen: "New York, Metropolitan Museum, 1972.118.241 (see Northampton). See 433.F: 57.165, 1972.118.239

BB_1938_text_recto: Early idea for the Madonna appearing to St. Bernard. There is almost nothing in common with the finished masterpiece: instead of the ecstasy rewarded by the vision splendid of Heaven's Queen we see a bearded old monk who does not look up from writing because he has not yet become aware of the young woman's tripping approach.

BB_1938_title_recto: Kneeling female nude with right arm stretched out
BB_1938_title_verso: Seated female nude
BB_1938_text_recto: The kneeling figure was probably done in connection with an early work representing the Creation of Eve published by L. Sambon in the "Musée", VII (1924), p. 10, and by R. Fry in the "Burlington Magazine", XLIV (1924), p. 115, also by Venturi, IX, I, p. 261, as belonging to Mme. la Durée, Paris. (Another sketch for the same subject, but done much later, is to be found in the Uffizi - see my 253 verso). The seated nude may have been intended for an Eve spinning. One is tempted to believe the improbable, namely that Fra Bartolommeo had done these figures after the living model. The kneeling nude is perhaps as feminine as any in the whole of Florentine art.
Cataloguer's Comments: Inventory number missing in BB 1961 and BB 1938 . Drawing missing in BB 1903

BB_1938_title_recto: Youth almost nude leaning on highly conventionalized flower-shoot
BB_1938_text_recto: Ascribed to unknown master of Ferrarese School yet this figure is an imitation, fairly close, of Garbo's Resurrected Christ. The type, the forms, and the decorative stem -cf. support of table in Carli's Vision of St. Bernard, in the British Museum - make it more than probable that the imitator is no other than Carli.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Quattro figure nude
BB_1938_title_recto: Four nude figures
BB_1938_text_recto: A composition suggesting a plaquette and ascribed to Robetta, but the types, the forms, the draperies, and the technique point to Carli. Was he copying a Francesco Francia? A niello in the British Museum which Mr. Hind kindly pointed out to me (n. 202 of his catalogue) would encourage one to answer in the affirmative

In questo e nei disegni BB nn. 667 e 669, un seguace del Castagno, se non lo stesso Castagno, ha drammatizzato le solide e franche figure scolpite da Donatello nelle porte bronzee di San Lorenzo, dando loro, allo stesso tempo, un aspetto rigonfio d'aria]

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Figura femminile con i capelli fluttuanti e le vesti al vento, leggermente volta a sinistra, che tiene un arco come se volesse spezzarlo
BB_1938_title_recto: Female figure with streaming hair fluttering skirts turned slightly to left holding bow as if she meant to break it
BB_1938_text_recto: Close to Castagno, but something in the pen-stroke, in the hands, in the feet, and in the way the figure stands, in the way the legs are displayed, suggests Montagna, Giovanni Bellini and Zoppo.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Busto della Vergine leggermente girata a sinistra, che si contorce le mani
BB_1938_title_recto: Bust of Virgin slightly to left wringing her hands
BB_1938_text_recto: No doubt study for Crucifixion. Castagnesque in type and modelling, and yet curiously suggesting a 16th century Flemish Madonna.

BB_1961_title_recto: Figura ammantata in piedi, vista da tergo
BB_1961_text_recto: Agnes Morgan ("Drawings from the collection of C.O.Baer, exhibited at the Fogg Art Museum, 1958) vi nota una certa affinità col Pesellino. A me il panneggio sembra decisamente castagnesco.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1938 and BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Un vecchio Santo in atto di leggere
BB_1938_title_recto: An elderly saint seated reading
BB_1938_text_recto: K. Clark ("Burlington Magazine", LVI, 1930, p. 176) ascribes it to Castagno and but for quality it might be by him. Perhaps it is the pricking that suggests drawings for embroideries and inclines me to wonder whether it is not rather a copy and a faithful one, after Castagno by Raffaele dei Carli.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

At all events, there exists an unquestionable painting by Lorenzo for which both these sketches may have served as studies. It is the figure of a pennon-bearer, usually described as a St. George, belonging to Lord Rosebery.

BB_1938_title_recto: Head of child turned somewhat to our right and looking up vaguely and dreamily
BB_1938_text_recto: This sensitively modelled head can only be an early work by Credi. It is so Leonardesque, however, that Leonardo himself could scarcely have disclaimed it. If it is Credi's it offers a good instance of what a mediocre artist can achieve with the example of a great but kindrer genius before him, if he has the luck to encounter it when this technical training is complete but custom and customers have not yet shaped him into a mould for producing the same article to the end of his days.

BB_1938_text_recto: Possibly this sketch was originally Credi's, but it has been gone over in ink by a later hand.

BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane uomo con naso prominente, capelli cadenti sui lati ed un berretto a forma di turbante, in profilo verso destra in direzione capovolta, mucchio di panni
BB_1961_title_verso: Volto chino, tagliato in alto, onde il sommo della testa è mancante

BB_1938_text_recto: Charming study of the same pretty youth as we have in the Louvre and Oxford drawings.

BB_1938_text_recto: Another drawing for the same monument is my 720.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di giovane con i riccioli che scendono dal berretto fino alle spalle

BB_1961_title_recto: Bisto di giovane, visto frontalmente, quasi grande al vero

BB_1938_text_recto: The same model perhaps in the Malcolm (my 696) and Louvre (my 711) drawing of a youth's head

BB_1961_title_recto: Studi di panni che avvolgono ginocchi

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio di panni che avvolgono una gamba

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di giovane estatico, volto leggermente verso sinistra

BB_1903_text_recto: Ascribed to Ghirlandaio, but an early Sogliani close to Credi.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di giovinetto con un berretto dal bordo rialzato, sui capelli lisci
BB_1938_title_recto: Portrait head of youth slightly to left with lank hair and cap with turned-up brim
BB_1938_text_recto: Toward 1500
Cataloguer's Comments: Inventory number missing

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di giovinetto
BB_1961_text_recto: Ha lo stesso tipo di BB n. 693.B.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1938 and BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane nudo con la mano sinistra sul fianco e la destra che regge un'asta
BB_1961_title_verso: San Pietro che guarda sentimentalmente in basso verso sinistra, con le chiavi nella mano destra e un libro nella sinistra
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude youth with left hand on hip and right holding staff
BB_1938_title_verso: Peter looking sentimentally down to left with keys in right hand and book in left
BB_1938_text_recto: This too may be a studio version of a Benozzo. The hand that did both sides may be the same that did most of the Koenigs drawings. The fact that the nude is a copy of a Benozzo, permits the inference that others of the Koenigs sketch-book and kindred drawings may be studio versions of lost or unknown originals by that master.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Sullo sfondo di un arco massiccio decorato a rosoni, Farisei e soldati vociferanti circondano il Salvatore bendato, seduto sopra un trono
BB_1938_title_recto: Design for Mocking of Christ. The scene is laid against a massive arch decorated with rosettes. Vociferating Pharisees and soldiers surge around the Saviour seated blindfolded  on a throne
BB_1938_text_recto: Close to Benozzo, and not improbably by him. There are suggestions of Pesellino and of Cosimo Rosselli. It corresponds closely to a Florentine engraving forming part of a series representing the Life of the Virgin and her Son, which reproduced compositions by various Florentine artists of the third quarter of the 15th century. There is no reason why Benozzo should not have been one of them.
Cataloguer's Comments: Inventory number handwritten and modified in BB 1961. Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Cristo Giudice, due Angeli, un terzo Angelo genuflesso, in alto, e il palmo di una mano
BB_1961_title_verso: Testa di monaco. Apparentemente un ritratto di Fra Angelico
BB_1938_title_recto: Sheet containing Christ as Judge, and two angels, studies for a Last Judgement. Above, an angel in profile kneeling, and the palm of a hand
BB_1938_title_verso: Head of monk
BB_1938_text_recto: It is worth noting that the angel in the lower left-hand corner of the recto occurs on folio 19 of the Koenigs sketchbook (my 558.B), most of which drawings are after originals by Benozzo
Cataloguer's Comments: Inventory number missing in BB 1961, BB 1938, and BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: San Marco che legge
BB_1961_title_verso: San Giovanni Evangelista con lo sguardo fisso davanti a sé, la mano destra protesa e un libro sul ginocchio sinistro
BB_1938_title_recto: Saint reading
BB_1938_title_verso: Study for Evangelist looking straight before him with right hand out, and book on left knee
BB_1938_text_recto: In the ceiling of the Madonna della Tosse at Castel Fiorentino painted by Benozzo after 1484 this figure occurs with slight variants
Cataloguer's Comments: Inventory number missing in BB 1961, BB 1938, and BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di giovane, quasi in profilo a destra, con la bocca spalancata e un berretto tondo in testa
BB_1938_title_recto: Head of youth almost in profile to right with mouth wide open and wearing round cap
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: San Vincenzo Ferrer in piedi, in una aureola di nubi, che guarda verso destra e accenna a sinistra
BB_1961_title_verso: Cervo
BB_1938_title_recto: Vincent Ferre standing in an aureole on clouds looking to right and pointing to left
BB_1938_title_verso: Stag
BB_1938_text_recto: Ascribed to Fra Angelico, but close to my 545.C, and if not by Benozzo himself by an Umbrian follower, most likely Bonfigli.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Busto di uomo anziano, glabro, con turbante
BB_1938_title_recto: Bust of smooth-faced middle-aged man wearing turban
BB_1938_text_recto: Umbrian follower of Benozzo who may have had his start under a pupil of Gentile da Fabriano
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane San Giovanni Evangelista a mezza figura in profilo verso sinistra, con le mani giunte in atto di dolore
BB_1961_title_verso: Vergine dell'Umiltà, col Bambino nudo incorniciato da una piega del mantello di Lei, che si stende dalla spalla destra fino al grembo
BB_1938_title_recto: Half-length youthful Evangelist in profile to left with hands clasped in grief
BB_1938_title_verso: Virgin seated on ground, with naked Child framed in by fold of her mantle, stretching from her right shoulder to her lap
BB_1938_text_recto: The youthful John, intended for a Crucifixion, is Umbrian, as the hands tend to prove. The parallel semicircular folds on the forehead make it probable that the author was Caporali. The Madonna is closer to Benozzo but Umbrian nevertheless and possibly by Caporali.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Costruzione della torre di Babele
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: ambedue le copie sono oggi preziosi documenti, anteriori ai guasti ed ai restauri che l'affresco subì, ancor prima di perire nell'incendio del 1944.
BB_1938_title_recto: Building of the Tower of Babel
BB_1938_text_recto: On pp. 22 and 23, Fascicule 179 (1919) of Les Arts, André Pératé publishes the reproduction of a large drawing after the Camposanto fresco representing the Building of the Tower of Babel. It is a sketch that deserves attention, which unhappily I cannot give, as I have not seen the original. Another copy of the same fresco exists in Rome in the collection of Ludwig Pollak. Count Umberto Gnoli has been good enough to send me a photograph of it. It shows slight differences from the Manzi one, is executed in ink, bistre, and wash on paper fixed on canvas, and measures 51 by 14.5. Both are interesting for what they tell about the fresco when it was less ruined and less restored.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane San Giovanni Evangelista
BB_1938_title_recto: Youthful Evangelist
BB_1938_text_recto: Study for a Crucifixion. Close follower of young Benozzo. Another copy of same original by Benozzo occurs on folio 7.B of Koenigs sketch-book (my 588.B).
BB_1903_text_recto: It is hard to decide whether this was done by a follower of the aged Fra Angelico, or of the youthful Benozzo.
Cataloguer's Comments: In BB 1961 and BB 1938 number "164.A" is omitted

BB_1961_title_recto: Sant'Ambrogio in atto di predicare da un pulpito di legno ad un gruppo di donne sedute per terra e uomini in piedi o seduti sopra una panca, fra i quali spicca Sant'Agostino in fondo, di mano del Gozzoli, si legge: "come santo Aughustino stava alla predica di santo Ambrosio"
BB_1938_title_recto: Ambrose preaching from wooden pulpit to woman squatting on the floor and men standing, or sitting on bench. Conspicuous among the last is Augustine. At the bottom in Benozzo's own hand: "come santo Aughustino stava alla predica di santo Anbrosio"
BB_1938_text_recto: Charming, almost lyrical sketch for the fresco in S. Agostino at S. Gimignano. In the finished work this episode had to be combined into one composition with another representing Augustine disputing and necessitated a rearrangement of the figures. The painting is so damaged that it is not fair to campare its quality with that of the well-preserved drawing-companion, by the way, to my 529.C in the Loeser Collection. I owe my first acquaintance with the Darmstadt drawing to Dr. Georg Gronau.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: San Michele a figura intera, con l'elsa di una spada nella mano destra ed un globo nella sinistra in alto un putto che cammina ignudo
BB_1961_title_verso: Leone e giovane nudo con mantello buttato sull'avambraccio
BB_1938_title_recto: Full-length figure of St. Michael holding hilt of sword in right hand, and globe in left. Above him a nude "putto" walking
BB_1938_title_verso: Lion and nude youth with mantle on his wrist
BB_1938_text_recto: The nude "putto" occurs on folio 19 of the Koenigs sketch-book (my 558.B), most of the drawings in which are copies after Benozzo
Cataloguer's Comments: Inventory number missing in BB 1961, BB 1938, and BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Vestizione di Santa Rosa da Viterbo
BB_1961_text_recto: [1958: Studio per gli affreschi nel convento di Santa Rosa a Viterbo, con Storie della Santa, dipinte da Benozzo nel 1453 e distrutti nel 1632]. Le snelle colonne del portico, sotto il quale Santa Rosa viene accolta, hanno capitelli quasi identici a quelli che appaiono nell'affresco di Montefalco, ove San Francesco supera la prova del fuoco; e questa, dei capitelli, è forse la più decisiva "singola prova" che uno studioso possa offrire, non solo per la comune paternità, ma anche per l'identità del periodo. [1958: Oggi che Pouncey ha dimostrato come il disegno si riferisca ai distrutti affreschi di Viterbo del 1453, mi fa piacere di constatare la bontà della mia "singola prova": gli affreschi del Gozzoli nella Chiesa di San Francesco a Montefalco sono infatti del 1452]. Un'altra caratteristica di Benozzo, sulla quale ho già richiamato l'attenzione, è la piega verticale nella manica del frate che riceve la Santa. Ma le prove a sostegno della attribuzione a Benozzo di questo foglio, si potrebbero accumulare "ad nauseam".
BB_1938_title_recto: Monks under porch receiving girl saint. She is attended by her woman friend
Cataloguer's Comments: Inventory number missing in BB 1961, BB 1938, and BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Interno di una Chiesa del primo Rinascimento col soffitto piatto, ma con una finestra gotica nel fondo a sinistra nove figure discutono intorno a una specie di lungo tavolo in prospettiva
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio di capitello a tre schizzi di cavalieri, di cui uno al galoppo
BB_1961_text_recto: Studio per la "Espulsione di Gioacchino dal Tempio" che Benozzo affrescò nella Cappella della Visistazione, annessa al Conservatorio di Santa Chiara, presso Castelfiorentino, poco dopo il 1484 (vedi anche BB n. 543). Nell'affresco il numero delle figure è maggiore e parte dell'architettura sulla destra è omessa;
BB_1961_text_verso: Questo è l'unico esemplare a me noto di un disegno a carboncino di Benozzo
BB_1938_title_recto: Choir of church with flat roof, and early Renaissance forms but Gothic window at end. To left, against arches of low structure behind which rise sumptuous buildings, appear nine figures seemingly discussing. At their feet an oblong geometrical object in perspective
BB_1938_title_verso: Capital of column in ink, horseman with steed galloping and two sketches of further horsemen
BB_1938_text_recto: Originally in black chalk. The first gone over with ink possibly by Alunno di Benozzo. Note that this is apparently the only trace of black chalk found in Benozzo's drawings. The obverse was a study for the fresco representing the Expulsion of Joachim from the Temple in the chapel for which my 543 was another study. The architecture in the drawing is almost identical with that in the painting except that there is more of it on our right than in the painting. The figures correspond only in the bystanders on our left. This sketch thus represents an early stage in the search for the final composition, and that perhaps accounts not only for a certain scratchiness in the figures but a wobbliness in the perspective which naturally was corrected in the fresco.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Quattro teste di Angeli, due di fronte e due di profilo
BB_1938_title_recto: Four heads of angels, two full-face, and two in profile
BB_1938_text_recto: Now correctly attributed to Niccolò da Foligno

BB_1961_title_recto: Giovinetto nudo, con tre piume infilate nel berretto a cercine, e una lunga canna nella mano destra
BB_1961_title_verso: Giovane nudo che tiene un'asta nella mano destra e appoggia la sinistra sul fianco
BB_1938_title_recto: Naked youth wearing hat with three plumes holding long cane in right fist, his left hand extended
BB_1938_title_verso: Naked youth leaning on staff in right hand, while his left arm is akimbo
BB_1938_text_recto: I owe my acquaintance with this sketch to the photo which Dr. Van Marle procured for me. From Benozzo's earliest years and companion to my 545.B. The three plumes are a Medici device and may indicate that the sketch was for a painting ordered by the family.
Cataloguer's Comments: Inventory number missing in BB 1961 and BB 1938. Drawing missing in BB 1903.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Madonna seduta, visibile sino alle caviglie, che regge il Bambino sul ginocchio sinistro
BB_1961_title_verso: Busto di ragazzino
BB_1938_title_recto: Madonna seated visible nearly down to feet, holding Child on her left knee
BB_1938_title_verso: Bust of little boy.
BB_1938_text_recto: As close as possible to Fra Angelico but I no longer (1935) hesitate to give it to Benozzo himself. In the Koenigs sketch-book (my 558.B) there is a copy of this Madonna as she looked before this leaf was mutilated. Her draperies spread over her feet, which rest on a platform. the character seems singularly Benozzesque, as might be expected of one who had learned to draw under Benozzo and not like Benozzo himself under Fra Angelico
BB_1938_text_verso: It seems to me now (1935) done with an almost unexpected freshness, directness, and veracity. Somewhat later perhaps than the Madonna.
BB_1903_text_recto: On the back of this drawing there is a charming head of a little boy. It is enigmatically pretty, dainty, and well preserved; but it lacks power, and seems like a very clever imitation of Benozzo's later phase.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: L'Arcangelo Gabriele, inginocchiato, quasi in profilo a destra, con la mano destra protesa e la sinistra, che tiene un ramo d'olivo, aderente al ginocchio
BB_1961_title_verso: Nerboruto nudo maschile che avanza verso sinistra, con un berretto in testa e le mani atteggiate come per reggere una clava
BB_1938_title_recto: Gabriel, kneeling almost in profile to right, with right hand held out from elbow, and left, with olive branch in it, kept close to knee
BB_1938_title_verso: Powerful male walking along facing to left. He wears a cap and holds his hands as if with both he were carrying a club
BB_1938_text_recto: In attitude and silhouette this figure is identical with the Angel of the Annunciation in the "predella" of the Lateran picture painted in 1450. Nevertheless, the more robust type, and the better understanding of the draperies, bespeak a considerably later date for the drawing. If we examine the Gabriel in the fresco of the Camposanto at Pisa, painted by Benozzo towards the end of his career, we shall see that there also he has not changed in outline, but grown still more robust, even heavy. The inference is that Benozzo had small power of reacting against, or advancing upon, his first well-learned lessons. He had learned to draw certain silhouettes, and was, at need, ever ready to use them like so many punches. What change was inevitable had to take place within the fixed outlines, because to alter these required serious command over the figure in action, and that apparently cost him too much trouble
BB_1938_text_verso: He may have been studied for a Hercules. Scarcely autograph.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Giovinetto slanciato, seduto per terra, con la gamba destra piegata sotto di sé, e con le mani appoggiate al suolo tre studi di panneggi
BB_1961_title_verso: Schizzi di mano posteriore
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of slender youthful figure seated on ground which he touches with both hands. His right leg is curled under him. The attitude suggests a shepherd roused by message of angel in a Nativity. Also three studies for drapery
BB_1938_text_recto: Seems by Benozzo in a Pesellinesque moment. The sketches on verso are by later hand
BB_1903_text_recto: This interesting drawing is hard to place. The seated figure seems to suggest Pesellino more than any other Florentine, and for this reason the author may be assumed to have been within that master's circle, which did not, of course, prevent our man from imitating Pollaiuolo as well.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Studio elaborato per una composizione rettangolare raffigurante Totila all'assedio di Perugia
BB_1938_title_recto: Elaborate study for rectangular composition representing Totila's camp close to S. Ercolano, with the houses and towers of Perugia rising above it
BB_1938_text_recto: The lower right quarter of the drawing is in a poor state and leaves it doubtful if it was originally filled with figures. If there were any they represented the finding of S. Ercolano's body. This study, though catalogued as by Bonfigli, is clearly by Benozzo in his first Umbrian period.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di bambina vista di fronte, semplice e severa
BB_1938_title_recto: Head of a little girl seen full face, simple and severe
BB_1938_text_recto: This would seem to have been done from life by Benozzo at S. Gimignano, or soon afterwards at Pisa.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Donna seduta, intenta a guardare ciò che tiene con le mani nel suo grembo: forse sta cucendo
BB_1938_title_recto: Matron seated looking down at something held between her two hands on her lap. She seems to be sewing
BB_1938_text_recto: This might be a study for a woman in Benozzo's Camposanto frescoes, but she does not occur in any of them still preserved. And yet this sketch may have been done in connection with them and certainly was done at the same time. Some of the woman there recall Cossa. This one recalls that master, and Piero della Francesca and even Cézanne. It is not a resemblance confined to type only. The lighting, the volumes, the space relation, are singularly suggestive of the two artists last named.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: San Girolamo in abito cardinalizio, seguito da un accolito
BB_1938_title_recto: Cardinal followed by acolyte
BB_1938_text_recto: Inscribed in an oldish hand "Giulio da Forlì", and therefore attributed to this otherwise unknown painter. How came this ascription of a genuine drawing by benozzo to an unheard-of name like this? I have no suggestion to offer, yet it may not be without interest to note that in 1447 a Pietro Iachomo da Furli was, along with Benozzo, assisting Fra Angelico in St. Peter's.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Testa e spalle di fanciullo
BB_1938_title_recto: Head and shoulders of child
BB_1938_text_recto: This was catalogued in the first edition as being by Pier Francesco Fiorentino, which would now mean Alunno di Benozzo. But it seems too spirited for that draughtsman at his best, and despite interrupted contours the attribution to benozzo himself is the more acceptable. The type and expression recall children in the Riccardi Chapel, and in the Camposanto frescoes

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Studio di architettura con paesaggio. In primo piano è un pavimento marmoreo quadrettato a lastre rosse, azzurre e seppia. La parte destra del pavimento è coperta da un loggiato a tre arcate che sostiene un palazzo. A sinistra due palazzi in prospettiva. Di là da essi, l'aperta campagna che sale verso un alto orizzonte collinoso
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of architecture and landscape. In foreground a pavement tesselated with squares of pink, blue, buff and white marble. To right, standing upon this pavements, an arcade of three arches supporting a palace. To left two palaces seen in profile. Beyond them the country, stretching upward to a hilly horizon
BB_1938_text_recto: The buildings are pinkish brown, the openings in bistre, the landscape brown and grey, the sky white and grey. There is nothing in this design which as draughtsmanship is peculiary Benozzo's but the colouring is his, so that the attribution to him is probably correct. If his, then from his last years. In 1931 this seems to me to be one of Benozzo's most convincing as well as most interesting drawings

BB_1961_title_recto: "Sinopie" apparse sotto gli affreschi di Benozzo in seguito all'incendio del 1944
BB_1961_text_recto: Schizzate col pennello sull'intonaco umido, guidavano il frescante indicandogli le linee principali della composizione. In complesso, sono artisticamente superiori agli affreschi ora perduti. Questi risalivano agli anni 1468-84 e descrivevano le seguenti Storie del Vecchio e Nuovo Testamento: Maledizione di Cam. Torre di Babele. Adorazione dei Magi. Annunciazione. Ebbrezza di Noè. Abramo e Lot in Egitto. Vittoria di Abramo. Espulsione di Agar e adoratori di Belo. Distruzione di Sodoma. Sacrificio di Isacco. Nozze di Rebecca. Nascita di Esaù e di Giacobbe. Nozze di Giacobbe e Rachele e Sogno di Giacobbe. Incoronazione della Vergine. Incontro di Giacobbe ed Esaù e Ratto di Dina.Innocenza di Giuseppe. Giuseppe riconosciuto dai fratelli. Infanzia e primi prodigi di Mosè. Passaggi del Mar Rosso. Le tavole della Legge. Il Serpente di bronzo. David e golia e Caduta di Gerico. La Regina di Saba. La distruzione dei figli di Cora. Morte di Aronne.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1938 and BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di giovane uomo con berretto e testa di ragazzino, vista da tergo
BB_1961_title_verso: San Luigi di Francia con un rosario, sotto una cupoletta gotica
BB_1938_title_recto: Head of youth wearing cap, and back of head of small boy
BB_1938_title_verso: St. Louis of France with rosary
BB_1938_text_recto: Study for the fresco in the choir of S. Francesco at Montefalco. This fragment of drawings done for or in connection with the frescoes at Montefalco is intrinsically delightful. The head is as vivacious and well drawn as any Benozzo ever did, and the pen-sketch of the saint offers a valuable piece of evidence toward the solution of the question whether certain drawings are by him or his master Fra Angelico.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Donna genuflessa
BB_1961_title_verso: Cavallo con sella, ma senza briglie, che cammina verso destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Kneeling female figure
BB_1938_title_verso: Saddled but not bridled horse walking to right
BB_1938_text_recto: Studio drawings from Benozzo's early Umbrian years.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Salomone e la Regina di Saba
BB_1938_title_recto: Copy of the Camposanto fresco representing Solomon and the Queen of Sheba
BB_1938_text_recto: Very interesting as the original is in bad condition. According to Bellini Pietri's catalogue this copy was in the collection of the Canonico Zucchetti, left to the Opera del Duomo in 1796, and it is not unlikely that it was the Canonico himself who ordered the copy to be done sometime in the second half of the 18th century.
Cataloguer's Comments: Inventory number missing in BB 1961 and BB 1938. Drawing missing in BB 1903.
Cataloguer's Question: See: if the location is S. Matteo or Opera del Duomo di Pisa

BB_1961_title_recto: Cardinale che tiene la mano di un Vescovo genuflesso
BB_1961_title_verso: Testa di Vescovo ancor giovane, disegnata sopra un giovane nudo addormentato
BB_1938_title_recto: cardinal holding kneeling bishop by hand
BB_1938_title_verso: Head of youngish bishop drawn over youthful nude asleep
BB_1938_text_recto: Probably leaf from Koenigs sketch-book (my 558.B) studio copy, and not as I used to think by Benozzo himself
BB_1903_text_recto: Similar in character, of the same date, and perhaps intended, like n. 537, for one of the Montefalco frescoes.

BB_1961_title_recto: Frammento di un busto di giovane uomo, con berretto tondo e lo sguardo volto a sinistra, del quale è visibile la sola spalla destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Fragment of study for portrait of youth seen down to below his right, and his only visible, shoulder, looking to left wearing round cap
BB_1938_text_recto: Carlo Loeser who first drew attention to this head ("Rassegna d'arte", 1903, p. 179) ascribed it to Benozzo himself. It is too flat and too stiff for that artist, and is morelikely by an Umbrian follower, Bartolomeo Caporali for instance.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Mucca che volge la testa a sinistra, mentre il vitellino poppa
BB_1938_title_recto: Cow turning head sharply to left while calf is sucking
BB_1938_text_recto: I owe my acquaintance with this sketch to Mr J. Byam Shaw, who ascribes it to Benozzo, basing his attribution on the similarity amounting almost to identity with the cow in the Riccardi Palace fresco at Florence. The contours seem too stiff and effort to a fellow-pupil or follower. Necdless to add that a cow suckling a calf must have been a stock subject for young artists.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Composizione raffigurante la "Storia dei figli di Cora"
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch for composition representing story of the children of Korah
BB_1938_text_recto: Faithful although later, probably 17th century, copy of the fresco in the Camposanto at Pisa for which Benozzo was paid in 1481. The painting has disappeared but this sketch gives us a fair idea of the arrangement and quality of the composition. One wishes more ruined and lost paintings were as well recorded.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: giovane nudo, con un giunco nella mano destra e, dietro a lui, un leone
BB_1961_title_verso: Testa di serafino incorniciata da otto ali
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude young man standing with reed in right hand behind him a lion
BB_1938_title_verso: Cherub's head seen against halo with eight wings decoratively arranged
BB_1938_text_recto: The face of the cherub, the features, the hair are clearly Benozzo's and to no other master can we attribute the nude young man. We find him again clothed in that loveliest work of Benozzo's youth, the Rape of Helen in the National Gallery (n. 591). This should also be compared with Benozzo's St. Sebastian at Montefalco, or better still with another St. Sebastian at S. Gimignano.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: These two drawings are ascribed to Angelico, but I am confident that they are Benozzo's. This young man is too naturalistic for Angelico

BB_1961_title_recto: San Francesco, volto a destra, con le mani alzate in atto di sorpresa
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Francis turning to right with hands held out in surprise
BB_1938_text_recto: By the young Benozzo or possibly Bonfigli.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Frate seduto su una panca, che alza le mani sbigottito alla vista di una serpe
BB_1938_title_recto: Friar sits on bench and throws up hands at sight of snake curling toward him
BB_1938_text_recto: Early studio. May have formed part of Koenigs sketch-book (my 558.B).
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Cristo consegna le chiavi a San Pietro San Francesco in estasi Vergine a figura intera per una Crocifissione
BB_1938_title_recto: Christ giving keys to Peter. Francis in ecstasy. Full-length Virgin for a Crucifixion
BB_1938_text_recto: May be a leaf out of the Koenigs sketch-book (my 558.B).
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Tre teste maschili, dall'antico
BB_1938_title_recto: Three male heads after antique
BB_1938_text_recto: Early studio. May have formed part of Koenigs sketch-book (my 558.B).
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Aquila romana, ghirlanda di foglie di quercia e nastri
BB_1961_title_verso: Testa mezzo sbiadita di giovane leggermente volto verso destra e, in basso, San Francesco inginocchiato per ricevere le Stimmate.
BB_1938_title_recto: Roman eagle, garland of oak leaves, and ribbons copied from relief in vestibule of SS. Apostoli, Rome
BB_1938_title_verso: Half-effaced head of youth turned slightly to right and below Francis kneeling to receive the stigmata
BB_1938_text_recto: Studio work, like those of the Koenigs sketch-book (my 558.B).
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Monaco e monaca con un libro
BB_1961_title_verso: Testa di cherubino alato
BB_1938_title_recto: Monk and nun holding book
BB_1938_title_verso: Cherub's head with wings
BB_1938_text_recto: By a follower of Benozzo perhaps one of those who did some of the drawings in the Koenigs sketch-book (my 558.B).
BB_1903_text_recto: This sheet, ascribed to Angelico, is clearly by a follower of Benozzo.

BB_1961_title_recto: Vari studi per le figure del Battista, di San Paolo, di San Nicola, di Sante ecc.
BB_1961_title_verso: Il giglio di Firenze e una Madonna con due Santi ai lati
BB_1938_title_recto: Various studies for figures of the Baptist, Paul, Nicholas, female saints, etc.
BB_1938_title_verso: The Florentine lily and two studies for a Madonna with a saint to each side
BB_1938_text_recto: It is hard to understand what made me, when I first saw this sheet of drawings some five and thirty years ago, ascribe it to Cosimo Rosselli. It seems to have all the peculiarities of type, technique, purpose, and quality that characterize Benozzo in his middle years. The sketches on the obverse would seem to have been made for an altar-piece with standing and kneeling figures. Footnote: See my 161.A for one of Benozzo's earliest drawings, a St. Matthew, also at Cambridge.

BB_1961_title_recto: Vecchio Santo ampiamente paludato
BB_1938_title_recto: Heavily draped saint kneeling in profile to right with hands clasped in prayer
BB_1938_text_recto: From Benozzo's ripest years
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Due Angeli inginocchiati e due stanti, per gli affreschi della Cappella Riccardi a Firenze, studi per due mani
BB_1961_title_verso: Vergine eretta in un tabernacolo portato da Angeli: studio per un trasporto della Santa Casa di Loreto, soggetto trattato non raramente a Urbino
BB_1938_title_recto: Virgin erect in Gothic tabernacle carried by angels. Study for a Transfer of the Holy House of Loreto
BB_1938_title_verso: Two kneeling and two standing angels for frescoes in Riccardi Chapel, also studies for two hands
BB_1938_text_recto: A subject not infrequently treated in Urbino
BB_1938_text_verso: Interesting different calligraphy and technique, but probably done about same time. The Madonna is later, if anything, than the angels.
Cataloguer's Comments: Inventory number missing in BB 1961 and BB 1938. Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: La Madonna appare a Santa Rosa di Viterbo seduta sul proprio letto e circondata da amici
BB_1938_title_recto: Madonna appearing to girl saint, who sits up in her bed. She is attended by male and female friends

BB_1961_title_recto: Deposizione, col Calvario in secondo piano ed un paesaggio collinoso nello sfondo: il Salvatore è sostenuto, quasi in posizione eretta, al centro, mentre i Discepoli sono schierati ai lati e le donne si prostrano a baciargli le mani ed i piedi
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch for Deposition taking place in foreground with Calvary in middle distance and landscape beyond. The Saviour is held almost erect between two groups of disciples, while the Magdalen kisses His feet
BB_1938_text_recto: Pictorial and spirited, from end of Benozzo's middle period, when the artist painted the splendid Deposition now in the Horne Collection, Florence. It is not impossible that despite so many important differences the drawing was a first thought for that picture. On the other hand, the half circle at the bottom seems to contain the head and shoulders of a figure conceivably for a Dead Christ. This may mean that the sketch was for a fresco to go over another or over a stained glass window.
Cataloguer's Comments: Inventory number missing in BB 1961 and BB 1938. Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Tondo contenente un San Francesco che regge una croce nella mano destra e accenna con la sinistra
BB_1961_title_verso: Studi architettonici, due per una mensola ed uno per una voluta architettonici, due per una mensola ed uno per una voluta
BB_1938_title_recto: Roundel containing figure of St. Francis holding cross in right hand, and pointing with his left
BB_1938_title_verso: Two drawings for a console and one for a volute
BB_1938_text_recto: Ascribed to Angelico, but clearly not his. The type, the pointing hand, the folds, all speak for Benozzo. It probably was intended for a St. Francis, to be painted on the frame of an altar-piece, or along with other roundels under some fresco.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: It is not quite impossible, however, that its real author was Benozzo's Umbrian pupil, Niccolo Alunno.
Cataloguer's Comments: Inventory number missing in BB 1961, BB 1938, and BB 1903. BB 1903  handwritten by pencil with revisions added in BB 1938

BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane ammantato, ma a capo scoperto, che addita davanti a sé mentre avanza verso sinistra lo segue un giovane in calzoni attillati, giustacuore e turbante, con una spada al fianco e la mano sinistra protesa come a reggere qualcosa
BB_1938_title_recto: Bare-headed young man, in cloak, pointing with right hand as he walks. Following him a turbaned youth, in jerkin and hose, with sword dangling by his side, and left hand held out
BB_1938_text_recto: He doubtless served for a young king carrying a monstrance in his hand in an Adoration of the Magi

BB_1961_title_recto: Presentazione della Vergine al Tempio
BB_1938_title_recto: Design for Presentation of the Virgin in the Temple
BB_1938_text_recto: This is ascribed to Neri di Bicci, but is a most intimately characteristic work of Benozzo's middle years. What could be more his than the types, the architecture, and the arrangement? To make comparisons with other drawings alone, note the likeness between the Virgin and the young female saint in the small design at Dresden, and the resemblance between the figures on either side of the High Priest and one in the other small design at the British Museum. Like those, this Presentation was probably a sketch intended for the employer's eye, but is freer and bolder, although at the same time much less delicate. This "model" was made for the Chapel of the Visitation now attached to the Conservatorio di S. Chhiara outside Castelfiorentino on the road to Castelnuovo, dating from about 1484, when Benozzo frescoed the Cappella della Tosse at some distance farther on the same road. The lower part of the fresco has disappeared, but it is clear from what remains that the sketch is superior to the painting. For the latter the composition had to be narrowed and made more vertical

BB_1961_title_recto: Madonna seduta con un Angelo per parte a destra e a sinistra, su scala maggiore, delle altre figure, un Santo adorante, un giovane seduto visto da tergo, che dipinge
BB_1961_title_verso: Figura monacale seduta, col fazzoletto in testa; tre giovani pastori, uno genuflesso in adorazione, un altro che suona la cornamusa, un terzo che balla
BB_1938_title_recto: Madonna seated with angel on each side. To left on larger scale than the other figures a saint adoring. To right a youth seated, seen from behind, painting
BB_1938_title_verso: Seated figure in monastic robes wearing kerchief. Three youthful shepherds, one kneeling in worship, another playing bagpipes, the third dancing
BB_1938_text_verso: These obviously for an Adoration of Shepherds. Front and back close to Alunno di Benozzo

BB_1961_title_recto: Donna paludata, vista da tergo
BB_1938_title_recto: Draped female figure, seen from behind
BB_1938_text_recto: From Benozzo's early middle years, and of his best quality, resembling a figure in my 540, as well as the woman with the child in the Miracle of Greccio at Montefalco
Cataloguer's Comments: Inventory number missing in BB 1961 and BB 1938. Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Busto di giovinetto, volto di tre quarti verso destra, con i capelli ricciuti e lo sguardo franco e diretto
BB_1961_title_verso: Quattro Santi
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: Vedi anche BB 163 verso
BB_1938_title_recto: Head of youth, smooth faced and curly haired, turned little to right with frank, direct look
BB_1938_title_verso: Four saints
BB_1938_text_recto: The execution is not quite on a level with the excellence of the conception, but the whole is not unworthy of Benozzo
BB_1938_text_verso: Not unlike those on the verso of my 176, by a feeble follower of Fra Angelico. Benozzo thus would seem to have drawn his head on the back of some sketches by a fellow pupil. It is probable therefore that this head dates from his early years, before he had left Angelico's workshop.

BB_1961_title_recto: Quattro nudi in pose diverse
BB_1938_title_recto: Four nudes in various attitudes

BB_1961_title_recto: Sant'Agostino seduto per terra sotto un albero, sofferente di mal di denti: a lui si rivolge un uomo seguito da due donne oranti (una in piedi e l'altra genuflessa) dietro di loro, quasi indecifrabile, il rapido schizzo di una quarta figura a sinistra un muro di città e nello sfondo un corso d'acqua e colline
BB_1938_title_recto: St. Augustine sitting under tree, suffering from toothache. A man addresses him, and behind him appears a woman kneeling, and between them a woman standing. To right a figure sketched so hastily as to be scarcely decipherable. In the background are town-wall and a running stream
BB_1938_text_recto: This drawing, as is sufficiently proved by an inscription, was intended for the frescoes at S. Gimignano depicting the story of St. Augustine but owing doubtless to the triviality of the episode, was slightly changed to represent St. Augustine moved by a voice from heaven, while reading St. Paul, in the presence of his friend Alipius. As the fresco comes between the window and the wall, the oblong composition of the drawing had to be narrowed. In quality it is not quite on a level with one or two of Benozzo's earlier drawings. The line, for instance, is not so delicate. The modelling, however, is excellent.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: Very small

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo di donna vista di spalle, simile al torso di una statua antica
BB_1961_text_recto: Mongan nella pubblicazione summentovata propone l'attribuzione a Benozzo: non vedo di chi altro potrebbe essere. Malgrado la scarsa scioltezza delle linee di contorno, esso ci fa sentire la pienezza di modellato degli scultori classici.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1938 and BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Figura volante verso destra e studi per le sue mani
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch for figure flying to right, and separately of each hand
BB_1938_text_recto: This charming sheet may be by Benozzo in his Umbrian phase, but more likely by his gifted Perugian pupil Bartolomeo Caporali. Another interesting version of the same subject is in the Loeser Collection (Fogg Museum, Loeser Bequest, n. 380), which may be by Albertinelli or Sogliani.
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Busto di donna in profilo verso destra con lunghe trecce girate intorno al capo verso:
BB_1961_text_recto: Le ottime fotografie procuratemi dal Museo di Cleveland confermano la mia ipotesi che questi piacevoli schizzi sono opera di uno degli autori del taccuino Koenigs (BB n. 559.G-1). Essi sono vicinissimi a Benozzo stesso.
BB_1938_title_recto: Female bust in profile to right with plaits wound round head
BB_1938_title_verso: Male head in profile to left, floating angel and two smaller heads in profile to right
BB_1938_text_recto: Attractive and probably by one of the authors of the Koenigs sketch-book (my 558.B) but the reproduction of the recto permits no conclusion regarding authorship or even authenticity, and the original I have not succeeded in seeing, as it passed from hand to hand too rapidly. For the same reason I could not procure a photograph of the verso
Cataloguer's Comments: Drawing missing in BB 1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studi per un piede sinistro, un braccio ed una spalla sinistra, ed il busto d'un uomo che guarda in giù
BB_1938_title_recto: Studies for a left foot, a left arm and shoulder and the bust of a man looking down
BB_1938_text_recto: By a vulgar imitator, perhaps a forger.
Cataloguer's Comments: Former in Paris, Emile Wauters Collection, n. 2

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudi virili in pose che ricordano i Prigioni per la Tomba di Papa Giulio II Lettera autografa di Michelangelo nella quale sono menzionati quattro blocchi di marmo per i Prigioni
BB_1938_title_recto: Various pen-sketches for nudes in attitudes reminding one of the slaves for the Tomb of Julius
BB_1938_title_verso: Autograph letter by Michelangelo which Frey (Text, pp. 119-120) interprets as being directed to a devoted apprentice in Rome or Carrara (possibly Silvio Falconi) and in which four blocks for the slaves are mentioned
BB_1938_text_recto: The date might be either 1514 or 1516. The sketches on the recto Frey rightly considers to be copies after originals by Michelangelo but I cannot accept the attribution to Silvio Falconi. They seem later.
Cataloguer's Comments: Former in Paris, Emile Wauters Collection, n. 119

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo femminile in profilo a destra e, su scala maggiore, busto di donna volta a sinistra, con fazzoletto in capo
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude female figure in profile to right and in larger proportions head and shoulders of kerchiefed woman turned to left
BB_1938_text_recto: Certainly not Michelangelo's and scarcely Italian.

BB_1961_title_recto: Copia di un disegno originale perduto per la fascia inferiore della Tomba di Giulio II, nella sua versione definitiva: con la differenza, rispetto alla Tomba, che sotto alle erme esterne mancano le volute arrovesciate
BB_1938_title_recto: Copy after sketch for lower part of Monument of Julius II as carried out, with the difference, however, that the outer hermae do not rest on volutes but on pilasters narrowing down to their bases

BB_1961_title_recto: Disegno architettonico, presumibilmente per la Tomba di Papa Giulio II secondo il terzo contratto, del 1516 verso Studi di gambe
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: "1957: Il Tolnay, come già lo Schmarsow, lo considera uno studio autografo. Sebbene sia quasi impossibile trarre conclusioni di sorta da un disegno così completamente rovinato, non vedo per quali ragioni questo non debba essere anch'esso, come il n. 1623 bis, una copia da Michelangelo.]
BB_1938_title_recto: Two sheets drawn on front and back in exact imitation of one another: on front we see a design presumably for the Tomb of Julius
BB_1938_title_verso: And on the back, studies of limbs
BB_1938_text_recto: A discussion of these sheets will be found in the Text, but see also my 1697A, 1735, 1736, 1747.
Cataloguer's Comments: Former Beckerath Collection

BB_1961_title_recto: Esatta copia del foglio precedente, meglio leggibile, perché meno guarda, e, come quella, proveniente dalla Raccolta Beckerath
BB_1961_text_recto: [1938: La migliore conservazione di questo foglio permette di avanzare l'ipotesi che l'autore del disegno sia quel San Gallo al quale si deve il disegno per la Tomba di Papa Clemente VII custodito agli Uffizi (n. 183 Architettura).]
BB_1938_title_recto: Two sheets drawn on front and back in exact imitation of one another: on front we see a design presumably for the Tomb of Julius
BB_1938_title_verso: And on the back, studies of limbs
BB_1938_text_recto: A discussion of these sheets will be found in the Text, but see also my 1697A, 1735, 1736, 1747.
Cataloguer's Comments: Two sheets catalogued  with the same item in BB_1903 and BB_1938.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo visto da tergo, volto leggermente a sinistra, ma con la testa in profilo a destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude seen from back, turned slightly to left but with head in profile to right
BB_1938_text_recto: The stringiness of the lines, and the formation of limbs, as well as the general character, and the fact that whatever shading there is goes from left to right, leave little doubt that this poor sketch is Raffaele da Montelupo's. The few words on the verso, said to be in Michelangelo's own hand, do not establish his authorship here any more than in the sketches at Oxford, where we find his writing and Montelupo's drawing.

BB_1961_title_recto: Naso e bocca di un volto giovanile, un vecchio visto di fronte ed uno visto in profilo a sinistra un piede in un calzare theriomorfico ed un orecchio di una testa ricciuta
BB_1938_title_recto: Nose and mouth of youngish face, one eye full face and another in profile left, a foot in profile left with theriomorphic buskin and ear of a curly head
BB_1938_text_recto: By Andrea di Michelangelo in his last, most highly finished phase.

BB_1961_title_recto: Madonna seduta sotto il fusto della croce, col Cristo Morto appoggiato contro il Suo grembo e sorretto in posizione seduta, per le braccia, da due Angeli. Copia dalla Pietà disegnata da Michelangelo per Vittoria Colonna, in cui resta invisibile la sommità della croce
BB_1938_title_recto: Copy by close follower, possibly Marcello Venusti, of the Pietà designed for Vittoria Colonna, with the difference that the shaft only of the cross is visible
BB_1938_text_recto: In quality this is the best record of the lost design, reproducing admirably the flesh touching flesh, as of the arms and hands, the way the armpits of the dead body rest on His mother's knees and how His torso nestles between them. All this better than in the Vatican relief or in the engravings of Bonasone and Béatrizet. The first of these engravings, by the way, is dated 1546 and the second 1547. it is not likely that Michelangelo's design was made much earlier. It would have been reproduced earlier.

BB_1961_title_recto: Maschera mezzo umana e mezzo bestiale e bizzarro fauno rannicchiato con la testa fra le stanghe di un brucia-profumi, ch'egli sostiene con le mani e sul quale soffia per ravvivarne la fiamma (sia la maschera, sia il fauno, in profilo a sinistra e disegnati con cura) nell'angolo superiore sinistro, una donna dal petto grosso che alza le braccia come le Eliadi nella Caduta di Fetonte o i Risorti nel Giudizio Universale più in basso, nudo seduto in profilo a sinistra come in atto di martellare con la destra nell'angolo inferiore destro, una figura rannicchiata con la testa fra le corna di una lira, e un occhio sinistro (tutti schizzi a semplice contorno)
BB_1938_title_recto: Two sketches highly finished and several others in little more than outline. Of the first the more important is a profile to left, half human, half bestial, of the kind that we have on the helmet and armour of the Malcolm warrior (my 1688).
