The other is of a crouching faun in profile left with his head between the arms of an incense burner shaped like a child's sledge. He is supporting it with his hands and blowing to revive the flame. Of the sketches in outline one is a deep-bosomed woman stretching up her arms like the Heliades in Michelangelo's studies for the fall of Phaeton or the Resurrected in the Last Judgement. Below we see a crouching figure full face with his head between the horns of a lyre, a nude seated in profile left apparently  in the attitude of someone hammering away with his right hand, and a left aye as in my 1555 verso
BB_1938_text_recto: There is no reason why these sketches should not be ascribed to "Andrea di Michelangelo", unless it be that the crayon used is somewhat softer. We must, however, recall that all Michelangelo's drawings after 1530 are done with softer chalks than prior ones. The little chains hanging down from the helmet of the monster and from the faun's headdress make one think of goldsmith's work and indeed the sketches may have been for a metalworker - no unusual practice in those days.
Cataloguer's Comments: Loeser bequest

BB_1961_title_recto: Profilo elegante e spiritoso di un giovane volto a sinistra nell'angolo inferiore destro, parte di un volto satiresco visto di fronte
BB_1938_title_recto: Elegant and spirited profile to left of young man. Below to right part of a face, possibly a satyr's, seen frontally
BB_1938_text_recto: By "Andrea di Michelangelo" at his best.

BB_1961_title_recto: Variante dell'Allegoria della Prudenza di Battista Franco agli Uffizi, BB n. 1637, soltanto che qui ella ha due profili, l'uno di fronte all'altro
BB_1961_title_verso: Due fanciulli per la medesima composizione del recto
BB_1938_title_recto: Version of same Prudence that we have in my 1637, only that here she has alternative profiles one in front of the other
BB_1938_title_verso: The two children from the same composition
BB_1938_text_recto: Interesting as being possibly not dependent on my 1637, but a direct transcript, as indeed my 1637 itself, of a design by Michelangelo.
BB_1903_text_recto: Copy on front and back  of a famous allegorical composition in the Uffizi (n. 1637) ascribed to Michelangelo, but almost certainly by Battista Franco

BB_1961_title_recto: Progetto per la decorazione di un soffitto (a penna), e sopra di esso un torso maschile, un avambraccio ed una mano sinistra
BB_1961_title_verso: Un braccio destro, una mano destra (a carboncino), uno studio di panneggio, sopra una spalla sinistra, due nicchie ed un piccolo schizzo di un giovane seduto che legge in un librone tenuto aperto da un putto, ispirato forse dalla Sibilla Delfica (a penna)
BB_1938_title_recto: Studies for male torso and for left arm and hand in black chalk and ink. Plan for the decoration of a ceiling
BB_1938_title_verso: Studies for a right arm and shoulder and a right hand in black chalk and in ink for a cast of drapery over a left shoulder, two scrawls of niches and a small sketch inspired, perhaps, by the Delphic Sibyl
BB_1938_text_recto: None of these sketches is by Michelangelo, but least of all the pen-study for the coffering of the Ceiling. The volutes decorating the oblong are at least a decade later than 1508, when Michelangelo planned out the Ceiling for the first time. The seated nude and the putto  are soft and round in the manner of certain Florentines who in Rome were as much influenced by Raphael as by Michelangelo. I am not acquainted with the original, but in to the reproductions this sheet rouses suspicion.

BB_1961_title_recto: Foglio con vari studi: nudo maschile visto da tergo, busto e torso di un nudo giovanile, due gambe in profilo, una gamba vista di fronte e una serie di teste con elmi fantastici
BB_1938_title_recto: Sheet with various studies: male nude seen from back, bust and torso of youthful nude, two legs in profile, a leg seen frontally and a series of heads wearing fantastic helmets
BB_1938_text_recto: Probably copies by Battista Franco after early design of Michelangelo for the Bathers. The helmeted heads after my 1597 verso, the nude seen from back, the frontal left leg and the helmet at its foot after 1597 recto.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Mezza figura di giovane donna in profilo a sinistra, con un elmo a cornetti sul colmo della testa e un abito che le lascia ignudi i seni dietro a lei è accennata una testa di vecchio e davanti a lei è accennato il busto di un fanciullo che fa per abbracciarla
BB_1961_title_verso: Due teste dello stesso tipo di vecchio sul recto, in profilo a sinistra, con una sporgente barba ricciuta e l'orecchio formato esattamente come quello della Filatrice in BB n. 1680; uno studio anatomico di testa in profilo a sinistra e del suo teschio, di testicoli e riccioli
BB_1938_title_recto: Half-length profile of youngish woman. On the back of her head is a curling helmet, and she wears a dress which leaves the breasts bare. Also a looser sketch of an elderly man's head, and another of a child's bust
BB_1938_title_verso: Two heads of same oldish man in profile to left, with curling protruding beard, and ear shaped exactly like that of the British Museum spinner (my 1680), an anatomical study of head in profile to left, of skull for same, of testicles and of straggling looks of hair
BB_1938_text_recto: For reasons given in the Text I believe the sketches on this leaf to be by "Andrea di Michelangelo".

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Tre teste di donne in profilo iscritto in basso, di mano vicina a Michelangelo, ma certamente non sua, "Gherardo io non ho potuto oggi"
BB_1961_title_verso: Due profili femminili schizzati alla svelta, ed una mezza figura, lavorata più accuratamente, di una leggiadra giovinetta a testa china, con un turbante rialzato a sbuffi sulla fronte
BB_1938_title_recto: Three profile heads of women. At bottom, in a hand close to Michelangelo's, but certainly not his, are the words: "Gherardo io non ho potuto oggi"
BB_1938_title_verso: Two female profiles sketched rapidly, and one half-length figure, more carefully worked, of a charming youngish woman with head slightly bent, wearing a sort of turban puffed out over either temple
BB_1938_text_recto: Even if his, they do not, of course, determinate the authorship of the drawings, although they would go to support my theory that they were done in Michelangelo's studio. It seems to have been the wont of both master and assistants to use the first handy bit of paper that had clear space upon it
BB_1938_text_verso: The original sketch by Michelangelo, after which I assume this was copied, must have been a figure in appearance and style between the one on the back of the British Museum drawing for a sibyl-like young woman (my 1482) and the beautiful red-chalk head (my 1552) and, like these, must have been of date just preceding the Sixtine Ceiling. This is also, as I have tried in the Text to demonstrate, is by "Andrea di Michelangelo."

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Testa femminile
BB_1938_title_recto: Female head
BB_1938_text_recto: Poor copy of my 1522.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Busto rifinito di giovane donna vista di fronte, e testa virile schizzata rapidamente, alle sue spalle
BB_1938_title_recto: Bust of youngish woman seen full face, and rougher sketch of man's head
BB_1938_text_recto: By "Andrea di Michelangelo."

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per una tomba parietale: due sarcofagi con coperchi concavi contenenti due figure distese sono appoggiati a una parete con al centro un tabernacolo con una statua di una Madonna in piedi e ai lati due grandi bassorilievi l'intera struttura ha un coronamento di candelabri e di putti che lottano, non con pesanti ghirlande, come nella Tomba Marsuppini di Desiderio da Settignano, ma con drappi
BB_1961_title_verso: Studi dettagliati dei rilievi per la Tomba sul recto
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for tomb. Two sarcophagi with concave covers stand against a wall the middle rectangular niche whereof is filled with a Madonna, while to right and left are bas reliefs. The whole structure is crowned with candelabra and putti struggling as Desiderio's Tomb of Marsuppini, but with the draperies of a curtain instead of heavy garlands
BB_1938_title_verso: Detail studies of reliefs for above
BB_1938_text_recto: No longer ascribed to Michelangelo, but correctly to Aristotile da San Gallo. Formerly, however, it figured largely in literature. Nothing can be less Michelangelesque that the putti, and as for the reliefs, not only are they not in Michelangelo's spirit but it is hard to imagine what they had to do with the Medici dukes.
Cataloguer's Comments: Handwritten "E" in Inventory number.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Supposto studio per la Tomba di Papa Giulio II
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio di mani. Deboli copie dalle statue dei Prigioni ora al Louvre
BB_1938_title_recto: Supposed study for the Tomb of Julius
BB_1938_title_verso: Hands feebly copied from the Slaves now in the Louvre

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Ratto di Ganimede
BB_1961_title_verso: Torso maschile, [1938: che nel tocco fa pensare a un seguace di Andrea del Sarto]
BB_1938_title_recto: Rape of Ganymede
BB_1938_title_verso: Male torso which in the touch betrays the following of Andrea del Sarto
BB_1938_text_recto: Certainly not by Michelangelo yet the design may have much of him for both the proportions of the figure and the eagle remind us of the Cavalieri and kindred drawings (my 1614). May be the copy of an earlier idea as Thode, Kr. U., No. 216, suggests for this drawing.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: On the other hand nothing could be less Michelangelesque than the action of the nude.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Composizione rettangolare con molte figure rappresentanti la Resurrezione di Lazzaro
BB_1938_title_recto: A rectangular composition with many nude figures representing the Resurrection of Lazarus
BB_1938_text_recto: The drawing before us certainly is not Michelangelo's, and seems to have been done by Alessandro Allori, but the conception is by no means contemptible, and may have in it something of the master's. One is reminded of his Pauline frescoes, and of a sheet at the British Museum (my 1508) containing on both sides various sketches as of a Madonna, a female nude, and figures for a scene in Dante's Purgatory. Could we be sure that in essentials the composition goes back to Michelangelo, and assuming at the same time that the central part at least of Sebastiano's masterpiece representing the same subject is also essentially Michelangelo's, it would enable us to measure the distance travelled by the great master towards a more athletic, more melodramatic, even more brutal attitude towards persons and events.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Allegoria della Prudenza
BB_1938_title_recto: Prudence
BB_1938_text_recto: Study for an allegorical composition by Battista Franco

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Supposti studi per gli Ignudi sulla volta della Cappella Sistina sotto ad essi, a leggero contorno e su scala molto maggiore, un nudo inginocchiato sopra una gamba in atto di alzarsi sull'altra in direzione opposta, una figura confitta su una croce
BB_1938_title_recto: Supposed studies for decorative nudes on the Ceiling and under them in faint outline a nude on much larger scale kneeling on one leg and trying to get up with the other
BB_1938_text_recto: In opposite direction a figure on a cross which suffices to prove that this could not have been done in 1510 (as would be the case if it were an original by Michelangelo), but as late at least as the Pauline Chapel, and in my opinion even later, perhaps by Passerotti. One should compare this with n. 6145F, a drawing ascribed to Passerotti in this collection.
BB_1903_text_recto: One should compare this with n. 6145, a drawing ascribed to Passerotti in this collection.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Schizzi del Giudizio Universale. Catalogati come studi preparatori di Michelangelo per il suo affresco, sono, in realtà, derivazioni da esso ad opera di B. Passerotti, come pienamente dimostrano le gambe e le ombreggiature
BB_1938_title_recto: Catalogued as sketches by Michelangelo for the Last Judgement, bust really by Passerotti, as the legs and the hatching fully prove
BB_1938_text_recto: As for the group of figures, they are either a faithful copy of some discarded sketch by Michelangelo for part of the Ceiling fresco of the Flood, or a free version after the fresco. The large mask is copied from a face in the same composition, to be seen on the left of a woman who carries all her belongings on a reversed stool poised on her head. A kindred drawing exists in Casa Buonarroti (my 1661).

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Fanciulli che giuocano, e due nudi virili, l'uno seduto a meditare, l'altro che riposa semidisteso
BB_1961_title_verso: Due nudi simili a quelli sul recto
BB_1938_title_recto: Children playing at hot cockles, and two nudes, one seated, and the other reclining
BB_1938_title_verso: Two similar nudes
BB_1938_text_recto: By Raffaele da Montelupo

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Quattro studi di gambe
BB_1938_title_recto: Studies of four legs
BB_1938_text_recto: By Raffaele da Montelupo

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Tre studi di un'aquila
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio di un'aquila e di un braccio destro
BB_1938_title_recto: Three studies of an eagle
BB_1938_title_verso: Study of an eagle and right arm
BB_1938_text_recto: By Raffaele da Montelupo

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Cartonetto di un'Annunciazione. È uno studio rifinito, ma senza vita, eseguito sulla base di un disegno di Michelangelo e sotto i suoi auspici, che servì a Marcello Venusti per la sua pala in San Giovanni in Laterano
BB_1938_title_recto: Elaborate but lifeless study for Marcello Venusti's Annunciation at the Lateran done after a sketch and under the auspices of Michelangelo
BB_1938_text_recto: The differences between the design before us and Venusti's finished work are slight, and confined to the desk, which in the sketch is open and has upon it a statue of Moses breaking the Tablets of the Law. The flaccid, limp, cottony quality of the drawing does not permit of its being by Michelangelo, and I see no reason why it should not be by Venusti.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Cartonetto di un'Orazione nell'Orto
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: Per questa composizione dalla quale furono tratte diverse pitture, come il quadretto del Venusti nella Galleria Doria Pamphili a Roma, ci restano fortunatamente alcuni schizzi di Michelangelo stesso.
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of same quality and character as the last for Christ in the Garden , after which various paintings exist
BB_1938_text_recto: Happily some of Michelangelo's own jottings for this composition still remain (my 1572A) and will doubtless aid in convincing us that this helpless piece of draughtsmanship is not by the great master. It should be assigned to Marcello Venusti.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Varie copie da schizzi noti ed ignoti di Michelangelo
BB_1961_title_verso: Parte inferiore di nudo snello con le gambe molto divaricate
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: [1956: Oggi inclino a credere che tutti gli schizzi su questo foglio siano di Michelangelo stesso.]
BB_1938_title_recto: Various copies after known or unknown sketches by Michelangelo
BB_1938_title_verso: Lower part of slender nude with legs wide apart
BB_1938_text_recto: The statuesque figure in profile to right is copied from the sketch for the Matthew on the Malcolm sheet (my 1521). The slight sketches for Madonnas may be copies of studies for the Bruges marble, or of a drawing like the Madonna at Vienna (my 1603). The nude in the lower left-hand corner, leaning against a kind of reading-desk, occurs with slight changes in the background of the Doni tondo as well as in the fresco of the Flood - without the reading-desk. As for the large nude in black chalk, he is copied from a nude for the Bathers on the back of a sheet at the British Museum (my 1479), the recto of which contains among other things, a sketch for the Bruges Madonna. In short, these drawings are copies of various figures done by Michelangelo in his earlier years. Their author was doubtless a close and able follower. The black chalk nude (now, 1934) seems more likely by Michelangelo himself. The interest of the five slight sketches for a woman and child lies in the fact that it is by no means easy to decide whether the originals were meant for the Bruges Madonna, on the one hand, or for the Medici Madonna, on the other, as we might be tempted to assume with regard to the central sketch between the two large figures. Again, we might think of figures in the lunettes of the Sixtine Chapel. It is a warning not to be too positive about the exact purpose of any drawing, as the number of types and attitudes of even such a genius as Michelangelo is strictly limited.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: Who their real author was I cannot tell, doubtless a pupil.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: I cinque Bagnanti più a destra, nella "Battaglia di Cascina", copiati da Daniele da Volterra
BB_1938_title_recto: Five of the figures on the right in the Bathers, copied by Daniele da Volterra

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Studio di mani giunte in preghiera. Del Passerotti
BB_1938_title_recto: Hands in prayer, by Passerotti

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Studio di una mano. Del Passerotti
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of a hand, by Passerotti

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Una Pietà, un grosso putto e un nudo in corsa. Del Passerotti
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for a Pietà, a large putto, and a running nude, by Passerotti

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Schizzo per le Tombe Medicee
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch for Medici Tombs
BB_1938_text_recto: Quite likely by Aristotile da San Gallo. See also my 1697A, 1734A, 1735, 1736 and 1747A

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Studio di alcune figure nel cosiddetto schizzo per la Tomba di Papa Giulio II, BB n. 1632, e quattro righi in frettoloso corsivo, difficilmente di Aristotile da San Gallo e non necessariamente della stessa mano che fece il disegno
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for some of the figures in the so-called sketch for the Tomb of Julius. Four lines of hastily cursive writing scarcely Aristotile's and not necessarily by hand that did the drawing.
BB_1938_text_recto: In the first number of the Miscellanea d'Arte (1903, p. 13), Signor Nerino Ferri, to whim I had the pleasure of pointing out the connection of this drawing mentioned in the note on p. 198 of Vol. I of my first edition - Signor Ferri, supported by the authority of Baron Henri de Geymüller, publishes them all as by Aristotile da San Gallo. Now the affinity of these sketches to Aristotile did not escape my attention when I wrote three years ago the first paragraph of p. 198 of my first edition but I am startled to find them ascribed to him in person. I know him: he is a more dainty, more precise draughtsman but my acquaintance with Aristotile is slight, while Geymüller has re-discovered him, and is a better judge of what may be ascribed to him. If Geymüller were right, my few pages on these sketches would need slight revision, and these sketches would become a trifle more interesting. But although Aristotile certainly could have known more about the Tomb than a later person, he clearly was fond of playing fanciful and even fantastic variations upon the great master's themes, so that even as his they would gain little as documents. Still, these Florence studies and sketches must be somewhat nearer, and the Berlin ones much nearer still, to Aristotile than I used to think. See also my 1735 and 1747. The lost drawing above referred to has the San Gallesque shadings and yet is by the same hand that did my 1649 and 1632, the design for the Tomb.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Profeta che appoggia il libro sulla testa di un putto
BB_1961_title_verso: Variante del Profeta sul recto con due putti
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for prophet supporting his book on a putto's head
BB_1938_title_verso: Different study for same prophet with two putti
BB_1938_text_recto: Both probably Passerotti.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Studio di un Profeta. Probabilmente del Passerotti
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of prophet probably by Passerotti
BB_1938_text_recto: See my 1649

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Donna seduta che abbraccia un bambino mentre un altro bambino si arrampica sulle sue spalle. Copia con varianti della figura di Jechonias in una lunetta della Cappella Sistina. Probabilmente del Passerotti
BB_1938_title_recto: Copy probably by Passerotti after one of the groups in the lunettes of the Sixtine Chapel

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Studio ispirato forse dal famoso torso del Vaticano
BB_1938_title_recto: Study inspired perhaps by the famous Vatican torso
BB_1938_text_recto: By Daniele da Volterra, or possibly Allori. Cf. My 1723.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Disegni architettonici (a sanguigna) per una nicchia fra due colonne e per un colonnato (a penna), profilo d'un fauno e minuscolo nudo in profilo a destra, che regge un piatto con ambo le mani
BB_1961_title_verso: Tre profili a sanguigna, uno a carboncino e la pianta di un edificio centrale, a penna
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketches in red chalk for a niche between two columns and for a colonnade. In pen, profile of a faun and tiny figure in profile to right carrying a dish with both hands
BB_1938_title_verso: Three profiles in red chalk, one in black chalk, and the ground plan for a central building in ink
BB_1938_text_recto: According to Jacobsen and Ferri (pls. XIX and XX, and text, p. 34) the architectural sketches on the recto might be connected with the Papal Chapel of Castel Sant'Angelo and with the courtyard of the Palazzo Farnese. The head of the faun and the nude are fairly close to Michelangelo but the profiles on the verso are no better than Mini's and perhaps his.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Torso virile e un medaglione con la storia del Serpente di Bronzo
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio per un braccio
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for a male torso and, in a roundel, sketch for the Brazen Serpent
BB_1938_title_verso: Study for an arm
BB_1938_text_recto: The sketch for the Brazen Serpent seems almost too dainty in touch and too elaborate in composition for Michelangelo himself, and the torso which, by the way, might do for a slave in the Tomb of Julius, and the arm are  not necessarily by the master. The author may have been a mannerist of the first generation, working not earlier than 1530, for the composition of the roundel seems to betray acquaintance with Michelangelo's studies of about that date, for a Resurrection.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Ecorché di un braccio destro proteso con la mano volta in su in cima le parole spagnuole Dos Reales
BB_1961_title_verso: Dieci o più righi di scrittura assai sciolta; sopra ad essi, il profilo d'una gamba sinistra tracciato a penna, e sopra ancora, a sanguigna, una figura tozza che si volta verso destra con la mano su (una spada?); a carboncino, altro écorché di una gamba sinistra, un nudo in corsa verso sinistra e sotto agli ultimi due, pure  a carboncino, schizzo rapido di un torso e di cose
BB_1938_title_recto: Écorché of right arm held out with hand turned up. On top the Spanish words Dos Reales
BB_1938_title_verso: Ten or more lines of writing in loose hand. Over it profile of left leg done with the pen, and over it again a stumpy figure in red chalk turning to right with hand on what may be a sword. In black chalk écorché of left leg, a nude running to left, and under the last two, also in black chalk, rapid sketch of torso and thighs
BB_1938_text_recto: By unknown follower of Michelangelo's form c. 1530-40, whom it would be worth while to identify.
Cataloguer's Comments: Before inventory number we find: Santarelli

BB_1961_title_recto: Busto di Cleopatra. Secondo me, di "Andrea di Michelangelo"
BB_1938_title_recto: Bust of Cleopatra, by "Andrea di Michelangelo"
BB_1938_text_recto: Note: The only Cleopatra mentioned as having been drawing by Michelangelo is the one which Vasari tells us in the "Life of Properzia de' Rossi", was given by Tommaso Cavalieri to Duke Cosimo. This Cleopatra, which in every probability was in the style of the other designs for Cavalieri may have been the model for the present sketch.
BB_1903_text_recto: Note: It may be objected that as it is known that Michelangelo drew a Cleopatra this may be the one. But the only Cleopatra mentioned is the one of which Vasari tells us in the “Life of Properzia de' Rossi” that it was given by Tommaso Cavalieri do Duke Cosimo. This Cleopatra, then, was in every probability drawn in the style of the other designs for Cavalieri, and not, like the one before us, in a style of twenty years earlier.

BB_1961_title_recto: Profilo di vecchia che guarda in basso
BB_1938_title_recto: Profile left of old woman looking down
BB_1938_text_recto: By "Andrea di Michelangelo."

BB_1961_title_recto: Copia, a penna, di uno studio per la "Battaglia di Cascina", BB n. 1559 verso e, a carboncino, di BB n. 1547 verso
BB_1938_title_recto: Copy in ink of my 1559 verso, and in black chalk of my 1547 verso

BB_1961_title_recto: Busto di un giovane che legge un libro aperto nelle sue mani, studio di un braccio con l'indice puntato e di una mano
BB_1938_title_recto: Bust of youth reading book, which he holds with both hands, and study of an arm with pointing hand and of a hand
BB_1938_text_recto: This is a copy after an original study (unknown to me) for one of the readers by the bedside of Ahasuerus, in the Fall of Haman in the Sixtine Chapel. The arm may have been identical in quality with the Haarlem studies for the same great undertaking.

BB_1961_title_recto: Progetto di fortificazioni
BB_1961_title_verso: Nell0angolo inferiore sinistro, due righi di scritto di Michelangelo che finiscono con la data 25 Luglio 1528; dal lato opposto, a contorni, un nudo con le braccia alzate e la mano così di scorcio che si stenta a riconoscerne i contorni; sotto, un braccio destro piegato verso l'alto; a destra, due braccia incrociate sul petto, come su BB n. 1684 e un profilo volto a sinistra (a penna), ancor più debole (a carboncino).
BB_1938_title_recto: Plan for fortifications
BB_1938_title_verso: To left below, two lines of Michelangelo's writing ending with the date July 25, 1528. Opposite, on outline, a nude with arms stretched up and the hand so foreshortened that one can scarcely interpret its outlines. Below, a right arm bent up and to right two arms joined over breast as in my 1684. Even feebler, to right of sheet a small profile to left
BB_1938_text_recto: These must have been done in the studio while Michelangelo was working on the Last Judgement.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo seduto a capo chino, in profilo a destra, con una curiosa acconciatura del capo
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude with curious headdress seated and looking down in profile to right
BB_1938_text_recto: By a later imitator.

BB_1961_title_recto: Cinque studi di cavalli
BB_1938_title_recto: Studies of horses
BB_1938_text_recto: Copies probably by Montelupo after originals (unknown to me), which, like those at Oxford, must have been for the Bathers.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studi di due nudi nel "Giudizio Universale": quello che cerca di tirarne su un altro, e quello nella barca di Caronte, che si porta la mano alla testa
BB_1938_title_recto: Studies for two nudes in Last Judgement, one in attitude of helping to pull up another, the second for the figure holding his hand to his head in Charon's boat

BB_1961_title_recto: Da prima vennero eseguiti su questo foglio alla nostra sinistra un nudo maschile visto quasi frontalmente e, a sinistra in alto, una maschera di uomo anziano volto in basso a destra al disotto, a sinistra in alto, una gamba destra e a destra, una gamba piegata al ginocchio e tracce indistinte di altre membra e forse di torsi più tardi furono disegnati, in direzione perpendicolare agli schizzi suddetti, un numero di piccoli nudi distesi, accoccolati, seduti e rialzantisi, mentre uno s'inginocchia supplice dinanzi ad un altro, che si volta indietro (questo ricorda la composizione di Genga a Lille dove pure un nudo s'inginocchia dinanzi ad un altro, in mezzo a un gruppo di figure) infine, la pianta di un bastione con la parola "terra", ripetuta, di mano di Michelangelo. Le figure grandi a carboncino, le piccole a sanguigna, e il bastione a penna
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo virile in profilo a sinistra, incrociato obliquamente da una gamba, aggiunta poi; inoltre, vari progetti per bastioni con indicazioni di mano di Michelangelo. Le figure a carboncino, i progetti in inchiostro rosso e nero
BB_1938_title_recto: First there came on this sheet to our left a male nude seen almost frontally, and to left at top the mask of a middle-aged man looking down to right. Below to left a right leg and to right a leg bent at knee and vague traces of other limbs and perhaps torsos. Later at right angles to above, a number of nudes of smaller size, sprawling, squatting, sitting and getting up, while one kneels in supplication before another who turns away (this recalls Genga's composition at Lille, where also a nude kneels before another, in the midst of a number of figures). Finally, plan of a bastion with the word terra in Michelangelo's hand repeat. Large figures in black chalk, the small in red chalk, and the bastion with pen
BB_1938_title_verso: Male nude in profile left and crossing it obliquely from torso to hip a leg, added afterwards. And last, a number of plans for bastions with indications in Michelangelo's hand. Figures in black chalk, the plans in red and black ink
BB_1938_text_recto: The bastions are by Michelangelo for the fortifications of S. Miniato. The hasty small figures on verso are probably Mini's and the over-finished large nudes, on both sides may be by the same hand.

BB_1961_title_recto: Quattro nudi femminili da una statua antica e in direzione opposta, testa con gli occhi bassi. La statua antica sembra la stessa che servì di modello a Michelangelo giovane in BB n. 1397. La testa è copiata dall'affresco del "Diluvio" sulla volta della Cappella Sistina e l'abbiamo già trovata in una copia agli Uffizi, BB n. 1639
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio per un'anca sinistra, una gamba sinistra e per una testa femminile
BB_1938_title_recto: Several studies after female statue, such as occurs in Michelangelo's early Chantilly sheet, and the head out of the fresco of the Deluge that we have found already in a drawing in the Uffizi (y 1639)
BB_1938_title_verso: Study for a left hip and leg and for a female head
BB_1938_text_recto: The latter and our sheet are obviously by the same hand - probably Passerotti's.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di uomo anziano che guarda in fuori, vista quasi di fronte
BB_1938_title_recto: Head of middle-aged man almost full face, looking out
BB_1938_text_recto: This portrait-like head does not seem in the spirit of Michelangelo but more like "Andrea di Michelangelo", for whom, however, it is too good.

BB_1961_title_recto: Sul recto è uno schizzo autografo di Michelangelo con la pianta del "terreno che io o comperato dal capitolo di Santa Maria del Fiore" (Luglio 1518)
BB_1961_title_verso: Testa di giovane girata di tre quarti verso sinistra
BB_1938_title_verso: Head of young man seen three quarters to left
BB_1938_text_recto: Very likely, as Frey suggests, by author of heads on both sides of my 1444 and 2480 verso.

BB_1961_title_recto: Rozzo schizzo di uno degli Ignudi sulla volta della Cappella Sistina e in basso un altro Ignudo a semplice contorno
BB_1938_title_recto: Rough sketch for one of the nudes on the Ceiling and below in merest outline for another
BB_1938_text_recto: O do not feel competent to decide whether this kind of scrawl could have been done by Michelangelo. The figure in outline suggests the Turin studies that I am tempted to give to Silvio Falconi, my 1746B verso.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo di lunghezza sproporzionata in posa non dissimile a quella del cosiddetto Apollo di Michelangelo al Bargello
BB_1961_title_verso: Giovane nudo, più grosso e più carnoso di quello sul recto, con lo sguardo abbassato verso sinistra, ritagliato al di sopra degli occhi e sul lato destro
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude of disproportionate length, in attitude not unlike Michelangelo's so-called Apollo in the Bargello
BB_1938_title_verso: Youthful nude of larger proportions and more fleshy, looking down slightly to left. Cut off above the eyes and on right side
BB_1938_text_recto: As draughtsmanship it is inferior. I venture to suggest that the author of both sketches may have been Mini.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 except the word "inferior", here "wretched".

BB_1961_title_recto: Figura in atteggiamento tragico, appoggiata con ambedue i gomiti ad un parapetto
BB_1961_title_verso: Copia da uno dei primi schizzi di Michelangelo ispirati da Masaccio
BB_1938_title_recto: Figure in tragic attitude leaning with both elbows on a parapet
BB_1938_title_verso: Copy after one of Michelangelo's early sketches inspired by Masaccio
BB_1938_text_recto: Much in this recalls Sebastiano del Piombo, but it is too slovenly for even him. May it also be by Mini?

BB_1961_title_recto: Gamba destra e gamba sinistra
BB_1938_title_recto: Right leg and left leg from the two nudes above the Isaiah
BB_1938_text_recto: Delicate copies by contemporary after the fresco in the Ceiling.

BB_1961_title_recto: Variante più elaborata di BB. n. 1709 per il tabernacolo centrale di una Tomba Medicea con la figura del Duca seduto
BB_1938_title_recto: More elaborated variant of central niche as in my 1709 with sketch of same figure
BB_1938_text_recto: Perhaps by same hand.

BB_1961_title_recto: Al centro donna nuda slanciata con la mano sinistra alzata e, su scala molto minore, un Ercole ed Anteo a sinistra, un nudo che cammina verso sinistra, reggendo un piatto a lunghezza di braccio a destra una donna ignuda, che si rigira su un giaciglio allungando la mano sinistra su un dormiente (senza dubbio Psiche che osserva Cupido mentre dorme) alcune linee verticali e orizzontali riquadrano la donna nuda al centro, rendendo l'intenzione della figura enigmatica e affascinante
BB_1961_title_verso: Busto di satiro e figuretta con bambino in braccio
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch of tall female figure with right hand held up and, on a much smaller scale, of a Hercules and Antaeus. To left a nude walking to left and carrying a dish at arm's length. To right a nude female turning on couch with left hand extended over sleeping figure represents, no doubt, Psyche looking at Cupid while he is asleep. Vertical lines cross the sheet in a curious way and two horizontal ones and some diagonal ones cross the body of the principal figure in what we might take for the outline of a sheet, making the intention of the figure fascinatingly enigmatic.
BB_1938_text_recto: The Psyche and Cupid was used in the pavement of the Laurenziana, Florence. Very poor but genuine work of Michelangelo's following. The tall figure resembles Montelupo's at Oxford (my 1713 verso). The group is taken from another sheet in the same collection (my 1712 verso), which I attribute now to "Andrea di Michelangelo."

BB_1961_title_recto: Due nudi
BB_1938_title_recto: Two nudes
BB_1938_text_recto: Not improbably by Antonio Mini

BB_1961_title_recto: Variante scarabocchiata del Cristo nel "Giudizio Universale"
BB_1961_title_verso: Altra variante sullo stesso tema ma volta a destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Scrawled variation upon the Christ in the Last Judgement
BB_1938_title_verso: Another variation on same theme but facing right
BB_1938_text_recto: Same quality and hand as my 1667

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo che arretra sorpreso
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude starting back surprised
BB_1938_text_recto: Perhaps by Mini.

BB_1961_title_recto: Vari studi di braccia e di mani. Questi studi si ricollegano all'Adamo nella "Cacciata dal Paradiso" sulla volta della Cappella Sistina
BB_1938_title_recto: Various studies for action of arms and hands of Adam in the Expulsion of the Sixtine Ceiling
BB_1938_text_recto: This looks too tight and hard for Michelangelo and may conceivably be a meticulous copy by Bugiardini after a lost or to me unknown original. See my 1409B.

BB_1961_title_recto: Variante scarabocchiata del Cristo nel "Giudizio Universale"
BB_1938_title_recto: Scrawled variation upon the Christ in the Last Judgement
BB_1938_text_recto: Considered by many critics as first thought for that figure. I find it hard to admit that this and my 1665A are the master's.
BB_1903_text_recto: I can scarcely admit that this is the master's.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudi schizzati in varie direzioni e due profili
BB_1938_title_recto: Nudes at various angels to one another, and two profiles
BB_1938_text_recto: Here also there is a suggestion of Montelupo, but the drawing may be Mini's.

BB_1961_title_recto: Piccoli nudi seduti in atteggiamenti diversi, che ricordano il Profeta Giona e gli Ignudi sulla volta della Cappella Sistina in alto, un nudo simile, su scala maggiore e parte di un cornicione
BB_1938_title_recto: Small nudes in various attitudes recalling the Jonah and the decorative figures on the Ceiling, a larger nude of same kind and part of a cornice
BB_1938_text_recto: Too feeble for Michelangelo but faithful copies of originals.

BB_1961_title_recto: Tre teste di fauni ed altre teste e profili grotteschi
BB_1961_title_verso: Testa di donna, quasi di fronte, con pettinatura fantastica, testa di fanciullo paffuto, e schizzi di un orecchio, di un occhio e di una gamba sinistra
BB_1938_title_recto: Head of woman, nearly full-face, in fancy headdress, the head of a puffy-cheeked boy and sketches of an ear, an eye, and a leg
BB_1938_title_verso: Three heads of fauns and other grotesque heads and profiles published by A. E. Popp in Belvedere, VIII (1925), pp 17-18 as by Antonio Mini.
BB_1938_text_recto: The leg is a copy of one by Michelangelo on a sheet in the Louvre (my 1588). These various sketches seem to be by "Andrea di Michelangelo".
Cataloguer's Comments: In BB_1961 "recto" and "verso" are underlined and inverted

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo esile e grazioso addormentato con la testa fra le braccia al suo fianco un ragazzo in tunica che guarda in basso sopra di loro, alcune linee di scritto strappate a destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Graceful slender nude asleep reclining with his head resting between his arms. To his side a boy in tunic looking down. Above them lines of writing torn away to right
BB_1938_text_recto: Excellent but not Michelangelo's, for whom it is too precise and hard in touch and too slender in proportions. Nor is the handwriting Michelangelo's. Inspired, no doubt, by Michelangelo's design for the Dream of Human Life. See my 1749B.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio della parte superiore di Aman crocifisso (sulla volta della Sistina) e delle sua mani e del suo orecchio, e della mano destra di Assuero
BB_1961_title_verso: Scarabocchi per la parte inferiore di una figura, occupante tutta la lunghezza del foglio; in direzione opposta, un torso voltato a destra, una figura, forse femminile, seduta sul terreno verso sinistra
BB_1938_title_recto: Study after upper part of Haman in the Ceiling, for both his hands, his ear, and the right hand of Ahasuerus
BB_1938_title_verso: Scrawls for lower part of figure occupying whole length of sheet, and in opposite direction for a torso turning to right, also a figure, perhaps female, seated on the ground to left
BB_1938_text_recto: Ascribed to Michelangelo but not of his quality. These are faithful copies after the finished painting, made by some clever and painstaking pupil who was thoroughly acquainted with the master's draughtsmanship. The separate sketch for the ear tells its own tale. The copyist, in his eagerness to get it right, departs from Michelangelo's form, and makes the lobe too fleshy.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio elaborato di un torso visto da tergo con un braccio sinistro in posizione singolarmente simile a quella del Giorno nelle Tombe Medicee, e due studi separati del braccio
BB_1961_title_verso: Rapido scarabocchio di un torso e un braccio
BB_1938_title_recto: Elaborate study of the back of a torso and left arm, in position singularly like the Day of the Medici Tombs. Also two repetitions of the arm
BB_1938_title_verso: Rapid scrawl of torso and arm
BB_1938_text_recto: It seems much safer, on the whole, not to accept these studies as Michelangelo's own. Neither the quality nor the manner is precisely his, although very close. Perhaps they are copies after the Day. See next.

BB_1961_title_recto: Parte di un torso in profilo a destra col suo braccio destro ripetizione più leggera, sia del torso sia del braccio
BB_1938_title_recto: Part of torso in profile to right with right arm. Slighter repetition of the same, and of the arm
BB_1938_text_recto: This seems to be by the same hand as the last sheet, and, on the other hand, is so like a leaf in the British Museum (my 1683) that one can scarcely avoid concluding that all are by the same draughtsman in slightly different phases.Now the British Museum leaflet contains on both sides copies after figures in the lower part of the Last Judgement.

BB_1961_title_recto: Schizzo di una figura destinata al "Giudizio Universale"
BB_1961_title_verso: Parte alta di un mutilo Compianto sul Cristo Morto, che include la testa del Cristo in grembo alla Madre. La parte bassa della composizione è visibile su BB n. 1674 verso. Per il commento, vedi ivi
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch for a figure in the Last Judgement
BB_1938_title_verso: See my 1674
BB_1938_text_recto: A figure in this precise attitude does not occur, and to certain minds this would be proof that the sketch was made by Michelangelo. And they may be right. But at the British Museum, at Windsor, at Oxford, and at Lille, there are similar sketches, most of them as dissimilar to anything found in the finished work, yet clearly not by Michelangelo. This Haarlem study is certainly of better quality than those, but scarcely good enough to be the master's. It was done perhaps by some follower who need have been no cleverer than Cungi, either after some slight indication by Michelangelo, or varied with a deliberate fraudulent intention.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per il braccio sinistro proteso in fuori del nudo virile genuflesso su BB n. 1673 recto nell'angolo superiore destro, impastato sopra, un altro studio di spalla e braccio sinistro in profilo
BB_1961_title_verso: Testa e mano alzata di una Pia Donna piangente
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added:  Della stessa mano del foglio precedente.
BB_1938_title_recto: Study apparently for the left arm in the last leaflet, and pasted on, sketch of a left shoulder and arm. By the hand that did the last
BB_1938_text_recto: The verso of this sheet and of my 1673 have been published by Knapp in the text to Frey's Anhang as sketches for a Pietà by Michelangelo, and Panofsky reproduces them in Rep., f. K. W., 1927, p. 42. The touch is too wooly to be Michelangelo's own and a vision at once too crude and too soft. The head of the Saviour is not brutal in Michelangelo's way and the other heads are too gentle for the late date and kind of draughtsmanship. How late may be inferred form the fact that the figure on the extreme right is the imitation of angel on my 1534 verso, which could have been done no earlier than 1550.
BB_1903_text_recto: Probably by the hand that did 15A.

BB_1961_title_recto: Cristo in croce e torso in profilo
BB_1961_title_verso: Il Cristo del recto copiato guardando la pagina in trasparenza, uno o due piccoli schizzi a carboncino e studi di modanature architettoniche a sanguigna
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: L'originale più vicino a questo Cristo, nella posa, è BB n. 1621.
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for figure of Christ on the Cross, in attitude nearest to the one at Windsor. Also a torso in profile
BB_1938_title_verso: The same figure raced through, and one or two small sketches in black chalk, and studies of architectural moulding in red chalk
BB_1938_text_recto: Surely too stringy and fumbling for Michelangelo.

BB_1961_title_recto: Demone che avanza con un Dannato caricato sulle spalle studio di spalla e braccio destro in profilo. Brillante copia contemporanea del Bandinelli dal "Giudizio Universale".
BB_1938_title_recto: Brilliant contemporary drawing by Bandinelli after demon in the Last Judgement who carries by the legs a figure thrown over his shoulders. Also a right shoulder and arm in profile
BB_1938_text_recto: The wriggling lines, the shading, the stroke are certainly Bandinelli's. One should compare the demon's right foot with that of a man in a group on the right in Bandinelli's Ecce Homo at the Uffizi. Cf. The same figure copied by Cungi(my 1745).

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo che vola verso di noi (indubbiamente uno degli Angeli che respingono i Dannati nel "Giudizio Universale"), tre studi di braccia
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: [1956: Il Morelli può aver avuto ragione; ma se autografi, non sono certo del Michelangelo migliore.]
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for nude in attitude of floating toward us, doubtless for one of angels in Last Judgement driving back the wicked. Also three studies of arms
BB_1938_text_recto: Both these are by the hand we recognize in a number of other sketches for the same work, and, like some of these, seem to have been enlarged after light jottings by Michelangelo himself. Morelli ascribed this sheet to Michelangelo.

BB_1961_title_recto: Partenza di Adone per la caccia
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo che afferra un cavallo per la briglia
BB_1938_title_recto: Adonis starting for the chase
BB_1938_title_verso: Nude seizing horse by bridle
BB_1938_text_recto: Said to be a free version of an ancient fresco found in the Baths of Titus. This leaf is certainly by Baccio Bandinelli, here at his very best.

BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane donna seduta in profilo a sinistra, con gli occhi fissi sulla rocca da filare che tiene nella mano destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Young woman in profile to left, seated, with her eye fixed on distaff which she holds in right hand
BB_1938_text_recto: The motive is excellent, and doubtless Michelangelo's, but the execution is by the hand that we know in the interesting sheet at Oxford (my 1555 verso) whereon we find one or two sketches by the master himself and the others by the so-called "Andrea di Michelangelo".
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: I know nothing further of this Andrea except that, to judge by the Oxford sheet and this spinner, he must have been under Michelangelo between 1500 and 1508.

BB_1961_title_recto: Strage degli Innocenti
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio di spalle nerborute, studi più leggeri di una spalla sinistra, di una spalla destra e di un braccio sinistro piegato
BB_1961_text_recto: Copia di un allievo di Michelangelo da un affresco del Quattrocento;
BB_1961_text_verso: Troppo timido per Michelangelo.
BB_1938_title_recto: Muscular back and left shoulder, slighter study for a left shoulder and arm, a left arm bent and another study for a back neck and right shoulder

BB_1961_title_recto: Variazione rapsodica sull'Ignudo seduto a destra sopra il Profeta Gioele nella volta della Cappella Sistina
BB_1938_title_recto: Rhapsodical variation on the decorative nudes above Joel to right in the Sixtine Ceiling
BB_1938_text_recto: (Michelangelo, to my knowledge, scarcely ever used wash.) This is a most characteristic sketch by Bandinelli, with all his dash and emptiness. I should not have taken the trouble to include it here but for the fact that Morelli (Kunstchr.) accepted it as Michelangelo's.

BB_1961_title_recto: Variazioni sul Profeta Giona
BB_1938_title_recto: Variation on Jonah
BB_1938_text_recto: Crude and lifeless. The head and hand betray a follower of Andrea del Sarto. This also was accepted by Morelli (Kunstchr.) as Michelangelo's.

BB_1961_title_recto: Copia contemporanea di uno stretto seguace di Michelangelo del risorto che si solleva da terra puntando le mani dietro la schiena, nell'angolo inferiore sinistro del "Giudizio Universale"
BB_1961_title_verso: Copia della stessa mano del recto del risorto visto da tergo che siede all'estremità sinistra, in basso del medesimo affresco, e copia delle mani dell'uomo che sta in piedi dietro di lui
BB_1938_title_recto: Contemporary copy, by close follower of Michelangelo, after the figure in lowest left-hand group of the Last Judgement, who is raising himself from behind on his hands
BB_1938_title_verso: Copy by the same hand of the seated figure seen over the shoulder in the lowest left-hand bit of the same fresco, and of the hands of the man standing over this one
BB_1938_text_recto: The head of this man in the fresco is perhaps Michelangelo's own and the only extant painted portrait of himself by his own hand. No other attempt at identifying him in his own paintings deserves as much attention. Even of this I mow (1934) entertain serious doubts. It is, however, interesting in this connection that Marcello Venusti in his copy of the Last Judgement made at the end of 1548, now at Naples has introduced to our left of the copy of this head another portrait head, a younger one, perhaps his own. Venusti when he made this was probably in his 37th year and of course he would have done all he could to make himself look like worshipped artist. Hard and stiff, these sketches do not seem by Michelangelo, but I am not so sure of that as I was in the first edition.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: All the others supposed to be he, are not he. Perhaps the absurdest attempt ever made in  that direction is the recent one to identify the Jeremiah with Michelangelo's own head. That these sketches are copies needs no demonstration. They are hard and stiff, although good enough for any one not the master himself. The same hand appears in the following sketch.

BB_1961_title_recto: Schizzo a contorno di un torso nudo virile prono e con le braccia aperte come scendesse in volo, studio separato del suo braccio destro, studio di mani, scorcio di nudo a mezzo busto con le braccia incrociate sul petto
BB_1961_title_verso: Altre figure volteggianti, come sul recto, anch'esse per il "Giudizio Universale"
BB_1938_title_recto: Floating figure with arms held out, another foreshortened, with arms folded, arms, hands, and rapid outline sketch of a torso
BB_1938_title_verso: Various other floating figures for same composition
BB_1938_text_recto: I am able to identify none of these in the Last Judgement. They may therefore be either copies of original sketches not used, or enlargements of slight indications by the master. To this last supposition some weight is given by the fact that while, as I have said, I can find nothing like these figures in the fresco, in the Malcolm sketch for this work one or two figures not unlike these floating ones are to be discerned. The central figure on the recto repeated twice on the verso corresponds in a general way with one of the angels carrying the column as Frey (Text, pp. 128-129) and Steinmann (II, p. 605) have already noted.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: The same copyist, by the way, did at least one more drawing now extant. It is at Oxford (n. 1721) after the figure in the lowest left-hand corner of the Last Judgment who looks back to the left as he is about to get up.
Cataloguer's Comments: The Malcolm sketch mentioned in BB_1938 Text is BB n. 1536 (as we read in BB_1961 text).

BB_1961_title_recto: Spalla e braccio sinistro piegato, visti quasi da tergo
BB_1938_title_recto: Left shoulder and arm seen from right
BB_1938_text_recto: This sketch which I used to give to Bandinelli but which now (1935) seems more like "Andrea di Michelangelo" must have passed for Michelangelo's no later than 1600. A copy of it occurs on a sheet at Munich, dating from that time.

BB_1961_title_recto: Torso di un'antica statua di Venere, vista di fronte
BB_1938_title_recto: Two studies of an antique torso of Venus
BB_1938_text_recto: Possibly by B. Ammannati
Cataloguer's Comments: 1686 and 1686.A are joined together in BB_1938

BB_1961_title_recto: Torso di un'antica statua di Venere, vista da tergo
BB_1938_title_recto: Two studies of an antique torso of Venus
BB_1938_text_recto: Possibly by B. Ammannati
Cataloguer's Comments: In BB_1903 1686.A is handwritten next to 1686

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio di un braccio e del suo scheletro
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of arm, and of its skeleton
BB_1938_text_recto: A most characteristic drawing by Bandinelli

BB_1961_title_recto: Busto idealizzato, in profilo a destra, di un guerriero in armatura assai adorna. [1938: La maschera e il gruppo di Ercole e Caco sbalzati sulla corazza sono reminiscenti del Verrocchio e di Leonardo.]
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: Nell'incisione di A. Tempesta del 1613 viene chiamato "Conte di Canossa", mentre il profilo femminile suo compagno in BB n. 1689, è tradizionalmente detto "Marchesa di Pescara".
BB_1938_title_recto: Ideal bust of warrior in armour on which are embossed a mask in full relief and group of Hercules and Cacus in low relief, reminiscent of Verrocchio and Leonardo
BB_1938_text_recto: By "Andrea di Michelangelo".
BB_1903_text_recto: Copy after a sketch by Michelangelo in the style of his Oxford single heads and other designs slightly antedating the Ceiling. The execution seems to me by Andrea di Michelangelo.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa idealizzata di giovane donna in profilo a sinistra, con un'elaborata acconciatura coronata da un gioiello a forma di Cherubino
BB_1961_title_verso: Quattro profili di teste, assai impacciati, profilo più lavorato di un satiro a bocca spalancata, una figuretta accovacciata e due studi di un giovinetto con un berretto piumato, l'uno del busto e l'altro della sola testa
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added:  È la cosiddetta "Marchesa di Pescara", anch'essa incisa dal Tempesta compagna di BB n. 1688 e della medesima mano.
BB_1938_title_recto: Profile of youngish woman to left, her hair dressed elaborately, with a jewel carved into the shape of a cherub's head
BB_1938_title_verso: Four rough profiles, one more highly finished of satyr with mouth wide open, a crouching figure and two studies, one a bust and the other the head only, of a youth wearing a cap with a plume in it
BB_1938_text_recto: Of same character and by same hand as my 1688
BB_1938_text_verso: These sketches also are by the hand that we found in the British Museum study for a young woman spinning (my 1680) and in the sketches on the verso of my 1555, drawn by "Andrea di Michelangelo".

BB_1961_title_recto: Replica più debole del profilo femminile idealizzato noto come Vittoria Colonna, Marchesa di Pescara
Studio di nudo virile nella posa di Aman crocifisso sulla volta della Cappella Sistina, con due studi separati per la gamba piegata sinistra ed uno per il piede destro
BB_1961_title_verso: Schizzi più improvvisati per la parte superiore della figura sul recto
BB_1938_title_recto: Study after the Haman in the Sixtine Ceiling, with two sketches of the bent left leg, and one of the right foot
BB_1938_title_verso: Less elaborated sketches for upper part of the same figure, one in right, the other in black chalk
BB_1938_text_recto: I judge these sketches to be copies by some close follower of Michelangelo after the fresco and not after drawings. There is nothing in them that might not be Michelangelo except the quality. The Michelangelo I have studied for so many years could not have done the arms and ribs of the nude on the verso. At Windsor there is a copy of the recto which like the one at Haarlem (my 1670) looks as if it was made by a draughtsman who had formed his style while copying the Michelangelo of the Cavalieri and Last Judgement periods.

BB_1961_title_recto: Cristo in croce, pianto da due mezze figure di Angeli librati su nubi, sotto le braccia della Croce
BB_1961_text_recto: Mi rendo conto che la maggior parte dei miei più giovani colleghi ritengono questo foglio l'originale della versione di Oxford, BB n. 1724 A, ma io non riesco a vederci un disegno autografo.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio della figura che rappresenta la Sensualità, seduta in profilo all'estrema destra, poco sopra Minosse, nel "Giudizio Universale"
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for figure trying to soar upward on extreme right in lower right-hand corner of the Last Judgement
BB_1938_text_recto: This is too stringy and dull to be Michelangelo's own work, but it betrays an intimate acquaintance with his manner of drawing at this period.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di uomo barbuto. Studio per una testa nel "Giudizio Universale", ma non del San Bartolomeo come è detto nel Catalogo Malcolm
BB_1961_title_verso: Palinsesto di studi, a semplici contorno, di gambe e di nudi. Sono varie figure imitate da leggeri schizzi di Michelangelo, mai usati e poi perduti, per i morti risvegliantisi, ma tuttora storditi, nel "Giudizio Universale".
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for head in the Last Judgement, not of St. Bartholomew as stated in the Malcolm Catalogue
BB_1938_title_verso: Number of scrawls, studies of legs and outlines of various figures doubtless imitated from slight sketches by Michelangelo, never used and since lost, for the awaking but still dazed dead
BB_1938_text_recto: I no longer feel as sure as I did thirty-five years ago that the big head and the scrawls on the verso are not Michelangelo's own.
BB_1903_text_recto: Last Judgment passing as Michelangelo's, they would seem to be enlargements of his slight notes by pupils or followers. I need scarcely say that if he himself had gone so far with a head as the author of this one has, he would not then have discarded it.

BB_1961_title_recto: Schizzo a soli contorni della "Battaglia di Cascina" corrispondente, nell'insieme, alla grisaille Holkham, ma con l'aggiunta, a sinistra, di tamburini, suonatori di piffero e cavalieri
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch in outlines corresponding, on the whole, with the Holkham grisaille, after the Bathers, with the addition on the left of a groups of drummers, fifers and horsemen
Cataloguer's Comments: In BB_1938 in UK, Cheltenham, Fitzroy Fenwick private collection

BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane donna con lunghe trecce in profilo a sinistra
BB_1938_title_recto: Youthful profile to left with long tresses
BB_1938_text_recto: By "Andrea di Michelangelo."
Cataloguer's Comments: Not present in BB_1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Composizione di dodici figure rappresentanti probabilmente Cristo davanti a Pilato in alto, perpendicolarmente a queste figure, una gamba sinistra delineata a semplice contorno
BB_1961_title_verso: vedi BB n. 1543A.
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: [1957: mentre adesso li ritengo di "Andrea di Michelangelo". Ma, per questo Cristo davanti a Pilato, il Tolnay ripete l'attribuzione di Sir Witt al Bandinelli.]
BB_1938_title_recto: Composition consisting of 12 figures representing probably the Saviour being conducted as prisoner before Pilate. Above and at right angles to these figures, outlines of left leg
BB_1938_title_verso: see my 1543A
BB_1938_text_recto: The story is well told, too well for Michelangelo, who does not set out to be a narrator. Very skilful but rather superficial draughtsmanship  with calligraphic tendencies. The stroke and touch and mannerism of notation point to "Andrea di Michelangelo".Tolnay rightly recognizes the same hand as in my 1704 and 1705, which, following Wickhoff, I used to give to Passerotti.
Cataloguer's Comments: Formerly in Sir Robert Witt collection.

BB_1961_title_recto: Allegoria nota come "La Vanità dei desideri umani"
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: [1957: Il Goldscheider e il Popham lo giudicano uno schizzo autografo del maestro. A me sembra inerte e senza vita come un Marcello Venusti: se fosse veramente di Michelangelo, esso dimostrerebbe che il sommo disegnatore era decaduto al livello dei propri imitatori.]
BB_1938_title_recto: Highly finished study for the allegorical design passing under the title of Dream of Human Life
BB_1938_text_recto: Known in various painted versions, e.g. one in the Uffizi perhaps by Allori and another in the National Gallery. Painstaking and exact copy of a design by Michelangelo made while he was doing the drawings for Cavalieri. It would almost seem as if the uppermost left group of my 1571 were done from one of the couples here.
Cataloguer's Comments: Formerly in Weimar Grand Ducal collection

BB_1961_title_recto: Uomo barbuto seduto avvolto in un manto con la mano sinistra tesa, e nudo virile che si allontana a gran passi portando qualcosa sulla spalla sinistra (entrambi in profilo a destra)
BB_1961_title_verso: Testa attribuita a Raffaele da Montelupo
BB_1938_title_recto: Seated male figure, draped in cloak, with hand extended, and a nude walking away carrying something on his left shoulder
BB_1938_text_recto: The types, ankle, and left-handed shading make it clear that not Michelangelo, to whom this drawing is attributed, but Montelupo was the author.
Cataloguer's Comments: In BB_1961 the location Staatliche Graphische Sammlung  is cancelled and the inventory number, the word recto and all about the verso are handwritten.

BB_1961_title_recto: Schizzo per le Tombe Medicee
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch for Medici Tombs
BB_1938_text_recto: Replica of my 1648A and almost certainly by Aristotile da San Gallo. Geymüller (VIII, fig. 20) placed it very near to Aristotile. Its affinity with, if not derivation from, Louvre n. 686 (my 1729) is clearer even that in the copies. At the same time it helps to bring the Bekerath design for the Tomb of Julius (my 1623) nearer to Aristotile da San Gallo.
Cataloguer's Comments: Not present in BB_1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per un Cristo Deposto: nello sfondo, ai piedi della croce, l'Addolorata con le braccia aperte, e all'ombra delle Sue braccia, quattro uomini intenti a sostenere il corpo esanime del Salvatore: la Vergine è vagamente schizzata a contorni e tutte le figure sono nude
BB_1961_title_verso: Vari disegni architettonici e tre nudi
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Pietà. In background against the cross in vague outline the Virgin with arms spread out. Under the shadow of her arms four men struggling with the lifeless body of the Saviour. All figures are nude
BB_1938_title_verso: Various architectural plans and three nudes
BB_1938_text_recto: As design the Pietà forms a beautiful group of exquisitely compact mass, and splendid action. The execution is, however, not possibly Michelangelo's own, but by some appreciative vigour of even the faltering touches of the same master. The date is certainly toward 1550 (Note: Cf. The Pietà engraved by Julius Bonasone and dated 1546), so that this design may be an offspring of an early idea by Michelangelo for the unfinished Pietà now at Florence.

BB_1961_title_recto: Cartonetto di un'Annunciazione.
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938 Title, in Italian and added comparison with BB nn. 1644 and 1645
BB_1938_title_recto: Highly elaborated study for Annunciation, doubtless for the one painted on Michelangelo's design for the Pace by Marcello Venusti. Certainly not by Michelangelo himself, and most probably by Venusti

BB_1961_title_recto: Tre studi da una Vergine ignuda
BB_1961_title_verso: Giovane ignudo. Della stessa mano del recto e qui ancora più ovviamente Bolognese
BB_1938_title_recto: Three studies after a nude Venus
BB_1938_title_verso: Nude youth, by same hand, here even more obviously Bolognese
BB_1938_text_recto: Certainly not Michelangelo's and judging by the wiry lines, and the strong preference for zigzag hatching, probably Passerotti's
BB_1938_text_verso: After originals by Michelangelo, like the nudes on my 1661. The figure n extreme right is copied from one on my 1397.

BB_1961_title_recto: Quattro studi di mani e vari nudi virili seduti
BB_1961_title_verso: Tre studi di mani e parte alta di un nudo virile, visto da tergo, su scala minore
BB_1938_title_recto: Sheet of studies of hands and of back of male figure
BB_1938_title_verso: Four more hands and several seated nudes
BB_1938_text_recto: This sheet of fetching brilliant studies deserves no small attention, being of the kind which generally passes unquestioned as Michelangelo's. His it clearly is not, but it took the enviable knowledge of the later Italian draughtsmen which Prof. Wickhoff alone possessed to unearth its real author in the clever Bolognese, Bartolomeo Passerotti.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di ragazzo in profilo, un destriero (che sembra copiato da un originale in bronzo) davanti a una panoplia e, a sinistra, un auriga con due cavalli recalcitranti
BB_1961_title_verso: Un grande nudo virile con la testa leggermente piegata a sinistra (a sanguigna), varie modanature architettoniche e una figuretta femminile vestita (a penna)
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch for horse after bronze original, of two others plunging away from their driver, of a trophy, and of profile of youth
BB_1938_title_verso: Various architectural mouldings and large figure of a nude with head bent slightly left
BB_1938_text_recto: The author of this sheet, so obviously not Michelangelo's, has done a number of other drawings, and I suspect that he was Raffaello da Montelupo. My suspicions find confirmation in the fact that the few words in cursive script on the front are almost certainly in Montelupo's hand. Looking at the specimen reproduced in Pini's Scrittura di artisti italiani, we find the last is there identical with the one here, the same way of forming the letter p, and the same v-shaped r. This peculiarity returns even in the more formal hand in the words "Vico mio caro", etc., on our sheet. It is curious that the more finished plunging horse occurs with but slight change in two versions of the Conversion of St. Paul, both ascribed to Pordenone and both by Bonifazio, one in the Uffizi and the other now (1900) in the market but formerly in the Nardi Collection at Mira Dolo. Both pictures in other respects as well the influence of Michelangelo. I should add that it is not improbable that this motive of the charioteer and his mad horses is a hasty copy after a sketch by Michelangelo for a Phaeton, of earlier date than any of the three that we still possess form the master's own hand.

BB_1961_title_recto: Donna seduta con la faccia mezzo velata, simile alle Sibille nella volta della Cappella Sistina
BB_1938_title_recto: Draped seated female in manner of sibyls of the Sixtine Ceiling
BB_1938_text_recto: This is a forgery so brilliant and of so ancient a date that until the other day it had never aroused the slightest suspicion. Something theatrical in the face, the mouth awry, the sweeping lines, the vigorous bravura stroke, may have made this or that student uneasy but I venture to say that, without having another artist to whom to ascribe it, scarcely any one would have dared to take this sketch away from Michelangelo. We owe it to a connoisseur who understands how difficult, nay how impossible, it is to know the great masters perfectly without an intimate acquaintance with all the small fry who surround them or succeed them - we owe it to Prof. Wickhoff that we now can tell the author of such a clever performance. It was the Bolognese Passerotti, famous already in Michelangelo's lifetime as a brilliant penman. There can scarcely be a doubt but that Passerotti made this and similar drawings with the intention of passing them off as Michelangelo's. Here he may have had the Delphic Sibyl in mind, and such of the master's genuine sketches for the Sixtine Ceiling as the one now in t he British Museum for the Isaiah (my 1486). The above paragraph remains to commemorate the first serious attempt made to distinguish between the different imitators of Michelangelo's drawing. In the decades that have passed since writing it, we who have been standing on the shoulders of our predecessors have learnt to look further and see clearer. In most respects the problems confronting us seem more insoluble than ever, but in some few we can perhaps reach more satisfactory, if only temporary, conclusions. Thus I have been led to wonder whether this drawing is not rather by "Andrea di Michelangelo".

BB_1961_title_recto: Vecchia avvolta in un ampio mantello, che discute, appoggiandosi a un bordone, con un ragazzo in piedi al suo fianco
BB_1938_title_recto: Standing figure of old woman, draped in voluminous cloak, a crook or staff in her hand, a boy standing beside her
BB_1938_text_recto: This magnificent drawing is certainly by the same hand as the last, Passerotti's, and made, doubtless, with the same laudable object - to be passed off as a genuine study by the master, presumably for a sibyl in the Sixtine Ceiling. Whether for the mere love of excelling in forgery - a passion of certain minds - or at the orders of some such dealer as the Pomponio who got Calvart (note:  Malvasia, Felsina Pittrice, Bologna, 1841, Vol. I, p. 197) to make copies with slight changes after the Last Judgement to be sold as original sketches, must remain an open question. But although even more brilliant than the seated sibyl, this "sempiternous crone" is more easily recognized as not Michelangelo's, for the simple reason that Passerotti has here overreached himself. Obviously meant for a sibyl, and not for one of the so-called "ancestors of Christ," this hag puts us at once on our guard, for she is not at all in the spirit and intention of the figures executed - for I do not hesitate to assume that the intention and spirit of these figures underwent no change in Michelangelo's mind. Moreover, this creature has obviously been pieced together out of two perfectly distinct figures in the Ceiling. The pose and the majestic sweep of the draperies are taken from the Eternal in the Creation of Eve, while the staff and the hand upon it are copied from the so-called Boaz. As for the boy, he is not even Michelangelesque. Here also it is evident that Passerotti had before him early drawings by the master, supplied, perhaps, by the dealer who ordered such a forgery for the draperies, the early copies chiefly after Masaccio and kindred original studies, and for the rest, such a sketch as my 1545 - nay, I venture to believe that very one. Be it noted how carefully in the left hand Passerotti has copied the left hand of the speaker there, and in the foot the foot of the same figure. Her profile even may have been suggested by the listener's on that sheet. Passerotti's hand betrays itself throughout, where he does not painfully imitate Michelangelo's cross-hatching. For this attribution also all praise to Professor Wickhoff. A poor copy of this is to be found at Lille. I let the above paragraph stand for the same reason that I retain the text of the first edition for my 1704, but like the drawing there discussed this one now seems by "Andrea di Michelangelo." The design before us, whether in this or other versions, must have been known to Bacchiacca, who used it in a birth plate formerly in the collection of the late Mr. F. A. White, and now in the S. H. Kress Collection, New York.

BB_1961_title_recto: Dodici teste copiate da originali abbastanza giovanili di Michelangelo: quella centrale all'estrema sinistra deriva infatti dallo stesso originale che ispirò la testa sul verso dello studio per l'Adamo, BB n. 1519 la maschera di vecchio, subito sotto, è copiata da BB n. 1399
BB_1938_title_recto: Twelve heads copies possibly by Heemskerck after earlyish drawings by the master. Thus the middle one on the extreme left was done after the same original that inspired the head on the verso of the study for the Adam formerly belonging to Mrs. F. Locker-Lampson and now in the British Museum (my 1519A)
BB_1938_text_recto: The mask just below of an elderly man is after the head in my 1399A.

BB_1961_title_recto: Profilo di vecchia ammantata che cammina verso sinistra
BB_1961_title_verso: Schizzo di fanciullo
BB_1938_title_recto: Draped figure of old woman walking in profile to left
BB_1938_title_verso: Sketch of child
BB_1938_text_recto: Clearly by Battista Franco, and so catalogued by Robinson
BB_1938_text_verso: A version of the sketch on the recto in black chalk is to be found at Chatsworth.
Cataloguer's Comments: In BB_1961 we find an handwritten comment over Battista Franco: By Rosso.

BB_1961_title_recto: Crocifissione
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Crucifixion
BB_1938_text_recto: A copy almost certainly of an original (unknown to me) by Sebastiano del Piombo and possibly done by Daniele da Volterra. It is too neat and careful to be by Sebastiano himself.

BB_1961_title_recto: Replica della parte sopra ai sarcofagi nel progetto per le Tombe Medicee al Louvre (BB n. 1735)
BB_1938_title_recto: Replica of part above sarcophagi in Louvre sketch (my 1735) for the Medici Tombs

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per la sistemazione architettonica di una delle Tombe Medicee (a carboncino) perpendicolarmente ad esso, due busti virili (a sanguigna) iscritto nell'angolo superiore sinistro (a penna)
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo femminile in piedi
BB_1938_title_recto: Two slight sketches in red chalk of male busts, and study in black chalk for architectural arrangement of one of Medici Tombs
BB_1938_title_verso: Study in red chalk of standing undraped female figure
BB_1938_text_recto: The busts recall my 1497 verso. While of relatively fine quality, and approaching Michelangelo closely, the leaflet for the tomb is perhaps not his. In kind it is like the Louvre sketch, my 1729 verso, but it is by a different hand one closer to Michelangelo's again whose I do not know, unless indeed, for a reason that will appear presently, it be by Stefano di Tommaso, Michealngelo's foreman at the time. The date of the drawing is given at the top of the leaflet in an inscription, probably in Michelangelo's hand one closer to Michelangelo's again whose I do not know, unless indeed, for a reason that will appear presently, it be by Stefano di Tommaso, Michelangelo's foreman at the time. The date of the drawing is given at the top of the leaflet in an inscription, probably in Michelangelo's hand, which by Robinson is transliterated thus: "A' dì 16 di giugno porto monagniola ventuno soldi al fornaio e chomincio  taglie... nel 1524." Of course the sketches may be of a later date than this, but it is not likely. Their object may be explained by a passage in a letter of Fattucci's to Michelangelo, dated January 30, 1524, of the following tenor: "The pope told me with his own lips that he is anxious to hear of all that you are doing, and would like drawings but not to waste your own time, he begs you will have them made by Stefano, or whom you please." Stefano may thus be the actual author of this sketch, which, at all events, has the interest of showing how far at this date the master had advanced, his own studies being undated. The arrangement is much as it is now three niches, with a duke in the middle one, and below, only one sarcophagus. The duke here is evidently Giuliano. Under the same museum number (42) is catalogued a sketch of an amorino, too soft and pretty, it seems to me, to be by Michelangelo nor does it quite seem by Sebastiano del Piombo, although much closer to him.

BB_1961_title_recto: testa di vecchio e vari studi di nudi virili, fra cui una copia del Crepuscolo in San Lorenzo a Firenze (a penna), e un profilo di testa ideale (a carboncino) non dissimile dalle altre teste michelangiolesche con acconciature fantastiche
BB_1961_title_verso: Uno scheletro e vari studi di gambe, due delle quali a carboncino
BB_1938_title_recto: Sheet with studies, some of them after the figures in the Medici Chapel at S. Lorenzo. In black chalk profile of young woman in fanciful headdress, not unlike other Michelangelesque fancy heads.
BB_1938_title_verso: Skeleton and studies of legs, two of them in black chalk
BB_1938_text_recto: All these sketches are Montelupo's.

BB_1961_title_recto: Quattro studi anatomici di una gamba destra
BB_1961_title_verso: Atletico braccio destro alzato, écorché di una gamba destra (a carboncino) e un groviglio di nudi virili (a penna)
BB_1938_title_recto: Four anatomical studies of a right leg
BB_1938_title_verso: Anatomical study in black chalk of a right leg in opposite direction of athletic right arm held up high, and in bistre a number of prostrate figures
BB_1938_text_recto: The prostrate figures are certainly by Montelupo, as a careful comparison with the other drawings that I ascribe to him will establish. Besides, in all the black chalk studies the shading goes from left to right as is natural for a left-handed draughtsman. The anatomical studies we can safely assume are by the same hand and except that they are in chalk are all but identical with those on my 1642. The prostrate figures may be copied from a sketch for the Brazen Serpent by Michelangelo.

BB_1961_title_recto: Due studi per un gruppo di Ercole e Anteo studio anatomico di una gamba sinistra (come su BB n. 1669), la stessa gamba a semplice contorno, due caricature di una vecchia e d'un vecchio, una civetta copiata da quelle nelle Tombe Medicee, e studi di natura ottica
BB_1961_title_verso: Schizzi di ogni genere apparentemente disegnati senza altro scopo che di ammazzare il tempo; i più degni di nota sono un cavaliere, due profili, la testa di un Mercurio, un teschio, un'anfora, ecc.; tutta la metà sinistra del foglio su successivamente (circa 1531-1533) ricoperta di versi di mano di Michelangelo
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketches of all sorts, drawn apparently with no other object than to kill time. The most noticeable are a horseman, two profiles, the head of a Mercury, etc. The whole left-hand side was written over subsequently with verses in Michelangelo's own hand
BB_1938_title_verso: Two studies of a group for Hercules and Antaeus. Variations upon the themes treated by Michelangelo in drawings at Haarlem and in the British Museum.
