Also the anatomical study of a leg as in my 1669, and the same in outline only, two caricatures of an old woman and an old man, an owl copied from the one in the Medici Tombs, and certain studies of an optical nature
BB_1938_text_recto: Neither the handling nor the quality of these sketches is Michelangelo's own, while the presence of his verses, written after the sheet was drawn upon, makes it certain that they were made in his studio. I used to ascribe this sheet to Montelupo but it is obviously by "Andrea di Michelangelo". The wrestlers were drawn over other studies, but not necessarily at another sitting and far from necessarily by Michelangelo himself.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 until square bracket, then: By whom? I do not hesitate to answer by Montelupo. The horse is of the exact type that we see here on n. 1701 recto; the heads are by the hand which drew the black chalk profile the we find on 1710 recto; the leg in outline between the two groups of Hercules and Antaeus ha the over-slim ankles, and huge ankle-bones that attract attention in the nude on 1701 verso, and in other drawings which like those I have just mentioned are, as I believe, by Montelupo, This sheet, then, would, in my opinion, have been drawing up while Montelupo was working with Michelangelo upon the Medici Tombs. That the date does not make against this hypothesis, we learn from Prof. Frey, who in his commentary on the verses suggests 1532-1533 as the most probable time for their composition.

BB_1961_title_recto: Pianta di Michelangelo per un tabernacolo da reliquia
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo virile di lunghezza smisurata che alza la gamba destra come per salire e ha il braccio sinistro in due posizioni diverse, di cui una verso l'alto, quasi a indicare il cielo
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added:  L'identificazione di questo disegno architettonico col "Tabernacolo" o piccola Cappella commesso a Michelangelo da Papa Clemente VII per le reliquie raccolte da Lorenzo il Magnifico e custodite in San Lorenzo, e la sua datazione - 1532 - si devono al Robinson (appendice, p. 335).
BB_1938_title_recto: Ground plan by Michelangelo of a small relic chamber at S. Lorenzo. See Robinson's catalogue, p. 335, where it also appears that the date is 1532
BB_1938_title_verso: Male figure of disproportionate length with right leg bent at knee and left hand held up
BB_1938_text_recto: This sketch, as comparison with, for instance, my 1701 verso will prove, is by Montelupo, and the date 1532 fits in with the time that he was working for Michelangelo. Tolnay suggests (Münch. Jahrb., 1928, p. 445) that the verso  may be the original sketch for a Resurrection with the contours gone over later, wherefore it makes a poor impression in the reproduction. I cannot see Michelangelo's hand in it and it would not be at all improbable that Montelupo made a variant in his own long-drawn-out type of nude after one of the Cavalieri compositions which the master was working upon at that time.

BB_1961_title_recto: Due uomini occupati a sezionare un cadavere
BB_1938_title_recto: Two men engaged in dissecting a corpse
BB_1938_text_recto: This ghastly sketch, so characteristic of the melodramatic "Tenebristi", is surely, as Prof. Wickhoff was the first to see (Albertina Cat., I, I, p. IV), by Bartolommeo Manfredi.

BB_1961_title_recto: Busto di vecchio, due profili grotteschi, anatomia di una gamba sinistra e quattro figurette
BB_1961_title_verso: Altri due studi di una gamba destra e di un occhio
BB_1938_title_recto: Various sketches as, for instance, of a leg, the bust of an elderly man, various caricatures, etc.
BB_1938_title_verso: Two other studies of a right leg, and one of an eye
BB_1938_text_recto: Certainly not Michelangelo's, and I believe by Montelupo. The few words of writing, in a peculiar cursive, are in the latter's hand.

BB_1961_title_recto: Libera interpretazione della famosa "Baccanaria" di Putti disegnata da Michelangelo nel 1533 per Tommaso Cavalieri, ed ora a Windsor, BB n. 1618
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo virile col braccio destro in due diverse posizioni (abbandonato lungo il fianco e alzato sul capo) che addita con la mano sinistra; perpendicolarmente ad esso, tre studi per le sue gambe
BB_1938_title_recto: Free copy after Michelangelo's famous design for Bacchanal of Children, made in 1533 for Tommaso Cavalieri, and now at Windsor (my 1618)
BB_1938_title_verso: Nude male figure, with right arm held up over head and left pointing. Also studies for legs of same figure - all by same hand as recto
BB_1938_text_recto: That this is a copy and not an original sketch admits of no doubt. It is equally certain that it is by Montelupo. As the original was done in 1533, and presumably sent soon after it was finished, we are safe in assigning this copy to the same date. At this time Montelupo was working with Michelangelo. This copy should be compared with a somewhat similar subject in the Uffizi (my 1640) also ascribed to Michelangelo.

BB_1961_title_recto: Vari studi per caminetti, e la parte superiore di una donna nuda con un velo sulla testa
BB_1938_title_recto: various study for chimney-pieces, and the upper part of a nude female figure
BB_1938_text_recto: This is, again, by the hand which I take to be Montelupo's. Here, however, the attribution to him is almost a certainty. The head has all the characteristics of the drawings in the Uffizi which are there ascribed to him. In this case, the studies of chimney-pieces may have been for those in the Castle St. Angelo, of which Vasari makes special mention.

BB_1961_title_recto: Il gigante Sansone sdraiato, e, arrampicata sul suo dorso, la piccola Dalila che, avendogli tagliati i capelli, pur continuando ad accarezzarlo, si volta a chiamare i Filistei che aspettano nascosti
BB_1938_title_recto: Giant Samson reclining and, in much smaller proportions, Delilah. The moment chosen is when, having cut his hair, she, while still dallying with him, turns around, no doubt to call the Philistines lying in wait
BB_1938_text_recto: One should look at the same subject in the Poldi Pezzoli Museum at Milan, there ascribed to Carpaccio, but really by Francesco Morone, to grasp the difference between the idyllic and heroic, the romantic and the classic spirits. This design is the work of some follower, done perhaps under Michelangelo's eye, and almost certainly in his studio, after some slight sketch by himself like the pen-sketch at the British Museum (my 1504), which may represent a different moment of the same subject and dates doubtless from the same time - 1530 probably. Possibly a third moment is reflected in Allori's drawing in the Uffizi (6655F, Fototeca 12951) representing  Venus embraced by Cupid. Who was the executant of this Oxford design I cannot tell. If Mini's, as is my 1722, this more serious effort to imitate the master must date from the very end of his apprenticeship with Michelangelo, as my 1722 was from the beginning.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 except Michele da Verona instead of Francesco Morone and added: Who was the executant of this Oxford design I cannot tell, but I suspect he was Montelupo.

BB_1961_title_recto: Ritratto di una dama
BB_1938_title_recto: Head of lady
BB_1938_text_recto: Certainly by Bandinelli and portrait of his wife, Jacopa Doni. Other portraits of her by Bandinelli in the Louvre and in the Gathorn-Hardy Collection.

BB_1961_title_recto: Giove che abbraccia Ganimede
BB_1961_title_verso: Torso virile visto da tergo, varie grottesche, ed altri schizzi
BB_1938_title_recto: Jupiter embracing Ganymede
BB_1938_title_verso: Nude seen from behind, various masks, etc.
BB_1938_text_recto: Even Robinson questioned the authenticity of this drawing, not because it is in quality inferior to the others by the same hand which he accepted, but because in the Jupiter the Raphaelesque flavour is too strong to escape attention, and, as Robinson rightly declared, the Raphaelesque excludes Michelangelo. In truth, this sheet is by the hand which has done many of the drawings ascribed to Michelangelo at Oxford. It is hand which I believe to be Montelupo's.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile semidisteso che allontana lo sguardo dallo spettatore verso il fondo e, su scala assai minore, nudo virile in atto di tirare l'arco
BB_1961_title_verso: Altro studio dell'arciere sul recto e un pilastro
BB_1938_title_recto: Of the drawings on this mount we were have to consider n. 5 only. It is of a recumbent male figure looking away to the left, and of a smaller nude shooting. Our reproduction shows only this sketch
BB_1938_title_verso: Again the archer and a pilaster
BB_1938_text_recto: This drawing is inscribed in an old, although later, hand with the name of Antonio Mini, and its character and quality would rather confirm than contradict this attribution. It would seem done after some slight sketch for one of the recumbent figures in the Medici Chapel, possibly for one of the River Gods or inspired by it. Represents a relatively early phase of Mini's career.

BB_1961_title_recto: Tentativo di ricostruzione del celebre torso nel Museo Vaticano
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for an attempted restoration of the Belvedere torso
BB_1938_text_recto: Robinson was inclined to deny the connection, but Heemskerck's sketches after this famous marble should remove any doubt. The author of this one would seem to be Montelupo. A smoother black chalk version of the same sketch, perhaps by Daniele da Volterra, is in the Uffizi, where it used to be ascribed to Michelangelo himself (my 1653).

BB_1961_title_recto: Vedi BB n. 1670
BB_1961_title_verso: Due studi per un braccio sinistro
BB_1938_title_verso: Two studies for left arm. See my 1570 for recto by Michelangelo himself
BB_1938_text_recto: Scarcely by Michelangelo.
BB_1903_text_recto: They are scarcely by Michelangelo, and I do not know who may have been their author. Some close follower, no doubt.

BB_1961_title_recto: Copia del Crocifisso disegnato per Vittoria Colonna
BB_1938_title_recto: Copy of Crucifix made in 1545 for Vittoria Colonna

BB_1961_title_recto: Fauno ebbro ed un altro nudo su scala minore
BB_1961_title_verso: Studi di membra
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude drunken faun and another nude on smaller scale
BB_1938_title_verso: Studies of limbs
BB_1938_text_recto: Excellent copies after originals of about 1530. The quality seems too good for Mini, to whom I used to attribute them. It is conceivable, however, that Mini or somebody else in the studio began this drawing and that the torso and thighs of the larger figure were finished by Michelangelo himself.
BB_1903_text_recto: A careful comparison of this drawing with n. 1722 leads me to believe that they are by the same hand - probably Mini's. Strikingly alike in both is she soft shading with parallel strokes.

BB_1961_title_recto: Composizione di cinque figure: una donna in piedi che tiene un fanciullo per mano e insegna a camminare, con una cinghia, a un altro bambino, fra un anziano uomo ignudo e un'altra figura mezzo cancellata
BB_1938_title_recto: Composition, a woman, two children, a nude man, and another half effaced figure
BB_1938_text_recto: Mr. Daniel Thompson wrote to me as follows in a letter dated April 26, 1934: "It seems to be executed in brownish colour following an external slight drawing in ink upon a rugged pale green ground. The ground is laid thinly on a panel probably with a wooden blade or "slice". The result is a grained, drawn, pitted , irregular surface like a badly plastered wall. It is more painting than drawing certainly but I doubt whether it was ever meant to be completed." I am indebted to Mr Kenneth Clark for the photo and to Mr. Jan Robertson for information. It is tempting to give this sketch to Michelangelo himself in a phase between the Cavalieri compositions and the Last Judgement. Some students might find it easy to dismiss it as by Marcello Venusti. It probably is not by the great master himself and we should, of course, feel safer in thinking so if we could recognize it as done in the exact style of one or another of his few apprentices and innumerable followers. I am not able to do so. The resemblance to the large cartoon in the British Museum (my 1537) is obvious. The question is whether it is derived from it or precedes it. If a derivation, it is odd that the forms are much more elegant, as in the Cavalieri designs, earlier certainly than the British Museum cartoon. If done before the British Museum cartoon we must grant that it is either Michelangelo's own, which is unlikely, or a fairly accurate transcript of a drawing by him. In any case, this sketch demands attention. And what about the subject? Robinson thinks it represents the return from Egypt. Who ten is the child that the woman holds onto by the sash thrown around its chest, and who is the nude middle-aged man who helps it to take its first steps? If this indeed is a sacred subject then perhaps it developes the theme of Raphael's Madonna del Passeggio (Bridgewater House) the woman would be Our Lady, the child Our Lord and the little boy the Baptist. And Joseph may be the dim figure above the last. Who then is the nude? But for the possible Joseph one might be tempted to fancy that the subject was not sacred but Medea with her two children and the pedagogue.
Cataloguer's Comments: The former inventory number 278 is hand corrected with A66C.

BB_1961_title_recto: Grandi studi di mani
BB_1938_title_recto: Sheet covered with large studies of hands
BB_1938_text_recto: Certainly by Passerotti

BB_1961_title_recto: Profilo a sinistra di giovane donna, con naso affilato, labbra tumide, ed un'acconciatura molto elaborata
BB_1938_title_recto: Profile to left of young woman, with sharp nose, thick lips, and highly elaborate coiffure
BB_1938_text_recto: Ascribed to Michelangelo, but, like most of these fanciful heads, by "Andrea di Michelangelo".

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di satiro in profilo a sinistra, disegnata a penna sopra una testa di donna a sanguigna
BB_1961_title_verso: Un volto intontito dagli occhi fissi (a carboncino), studi geometrici di occhi e di viso, un cane che si morde la coda, schizzo da statua antica, ed un numero di parole di scrittura di Antonio Mini (a penna)
BB_1938_title_recto: Head of satyr in profile to left drawn with the pen over a head of a woman in red chalk
BB_1938_title_verso: In black chalk a stupid face, and in ink a geometric one, eyes of another, a dog biting his tail, sketch after an antique statue, and a number of words in the handwriting of Antonio Mini
BB_1938_text_recto: This brilliant sketch, made famous by Mariette, is well calculated to try the student's patience and judgement. It is of splendid quality, in technique scarcely to be distinguished from Michelangelo's real work, and attributed to the great master on the strength of Mariette's authority. Nevertheless, Morelli was almost right in declaring it a forgery. I would but add that it is a forgery, or, to be more exact, an imitation of ancient date, made by some amazingly clever imitator of Michelangelo, most probably during the latter's lifetime. Who he was, I must leave for others to determine. It is clear that he had made a most careful study of the master's early style, and that he had in mind such heads as those, whether in ink or red chalk, which are now chiefly at Oxford my 1520, for instance. It may not be superfluous to point out that a hand certainly not Michelangelo's is most clearly revealed in the hard outline of the nose, in the sweeping strokes of the pen, and in the cross-hatching on the side of the nose. Further study makes it seem likely that the head of the satyr is by "Andrea di Michelangelo". The female profile in red chalk, over which this head was drawn, must have been like the lower left-hand one on a sheet in the Uffizi (my 1627) by Andrea di Michelangelo.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added, instead of [Further study...]: This shading, and something in the shape of the ear, suggest Bandinelli. And, in the end after the sheet in the Uffizi: and done in his most straggling, palsied way, as we find it in his Oxford sketches, and on the back of the “Cleopatra” at the Uffizi. That this head may serve as a sign and a warning I reproduce it.
Cataloguer's Comments: Handwritten In BB_1938: "Verso: a stupid face, in black chalk, fantastic animals and a face in ink".

BB_1961_title_recto: Uomo ritto sulla gamba destra con la gamba sinistra piegata al ginocchio
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio per una tomba parietale con un tabernacolo più largo al centro, ove Vergine col Bambino fra le ginocchia, a sinistra, una figura maschile drappeggiata in piedi, in basso, due figure giacenti su sarcofagi piatti e, a destra, una figura terminale di putto in profilo a destra, somigliante al putto che piscia degli Uffizi, BB n. 1398 A, e che appare anche nella "Baccanaria" di Putti a Windsor, BB n. 1618
BB_1938_title_recto: Man standing on right leg, the left bent back at knee verso Study for monument. In the broader central niche sits the Virgin with the Child between her knees. On the left, an erect draped male figure. Below, on flat sarcophagi, two reclining figures. Also on the right, a terminal figure of a putto in profile to right, resembling the one at the Uffizi (my 1938A) that occurs in the Windsor Children's Bacchanal (my 1618)
BB_1938_text_recto: This leaf with its faint sketches is not Michelangelo's, whose qualities it entirely misses. The nude is copied from the drawing on the back of the Windsor Tityus, with the omission of the right arm. As that design was made in 1533, it gives us the earliest possible date of the leaf before us. The putto on the verso is copied form another design made by the master at about this time, namely, the Children's Bacchanal. It should be observed that it was this study or another like it rather than any sketch by Michelangelo, or the finished works themselves, which gave rise to such designs as those in the Louvre (my 1735, 1736, 1743A), Vienna (my 1697A) which, until the other day, passed for the master's own. Their number makes one ask whether they were not done to be sold. I used to give this sheet to Montelupo. It now seems likely that it is by Aristotile da San Gallo.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: ...designs which, until the other day, passed as the master's own, and which to my amazement and amusement I still find discussed solemnly as somehow containing mystically stored up the divine intentions of great Buonarroti.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile in profilo a sinistra, con la gamba destra posata su un gradino, le braccia alzate e girate così da mettere in mostra le spalle e un accenno di panneggio ricadente dal braccio destro
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo virile nell'esatta posa del nudo sul recto, ma visto di fronte, con la testa in profilo a destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of nude standing on left leg, his right resting on a pedestal, and the corresponding arm held out, seen in profile to left from the arm falls shadow drapery
BB_1938_title_verso: Similar study, with head in profile to right, although he stands much more to left
BB_1938_text_recto: A comparison of these two sketches with those that remain for the Bathers, particularly with the one there for the soldier who is having his armour buckled for him, leaves little doubt that the originals of which they are the copies are of the same date. Only the verso, however, could have been for the Bathers, while the recto was, in every probability, for one of the slaves in the great work undertaken directly thereafter, the Tomb of Julius. Who the copyist may have been is a question, perhaps Bandinelli. The original of the verso must have been a slightly modified variant of my 1594.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added, about the Slaves of the the Tomb of Julius: Hence, hard and tight copies as they are, they remain precious as witnesses to what some of these figures were intended to be. Who the copyist may have been is a question that need no long detain us. Almost certainly it was Bandinelli.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile in piedi, che poggia sulla sola gamba sinistra, incrociandola con l'altra gamba piegata al ginocchio
BB_1961_title_verso: Uomo a metà drappeggiato, in posa simile al nudo nel recto; vari studi per panneggi e versi di una mano che certamente non è di Michelangelo
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for nude, standing on left leg with right bent at knee crossing it
BB_1938_title_verso: Half-draped figure in similar attitude, and various studies for drapery. Also a number of verses in a hand certainly not Michelangelo's
BB_1938_text_recto: Only three of the score or so of lines are published in Frey's Dichtungen (CLVI, 2), but they are three too many. A careful comparison with a letter reproduced in Carlo Pini's Scrittura di artisti italiani, vol. II, establishes beyond reasonable doubt that the writing is Antonio Mini's. The drawings are his also, of course, and, as the nude already suggests Michelangelo's Tityus, we may safely assume that these sketches belong to the end of Mini's stay with the master.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile stante sulla gamba sinistra, con la destra che la incrocia alla caviglia, il quale alza ambo le braccia toccandosi la nuca e affaccia il viso sopra alla spalla sinistra
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: [1957: Potrebbe anche essere un originale ripassato da mano più tarda.]
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude youth standing on left leg, right leg crossing it at ankle, arms lifted and bent at elbow, head showing over left shoulder
BB_1938_text_recto: Copy of identical nature and by same hand as my 1730, after study for one of slaves in the Tomb of Julius.

BB_1961_title_recto: Vecchia alta ignuda che si trascina avanti, in profilo a sinistra, appoggiandosi con la destra a un bastone e tenendo nella sinistra una viola
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo femminile di mezz'età con la testa appena girata verso destra, con una sciarpa sotto i seni, le gambe piegate al ginocchio e solo il braccio e la mano destra visibili, essendo stato tagliato il resto alla nostra destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Tall nude old woman trudging along in profile left with right hand on staff and in left a viol
BB_1938_title_verso: Middle aged female nude with head slightly to right, with a sash under her breasts and right arm and hand only visible, the rest being cut off to right, the legs bent at knee
BB_1938_text_recto: The old woman reminds us of a drawing by Rosso (my 2450A) and must be by an artist close to that master. The younger female, despite a certain softness may be by the same hand.

BB_1961_title_recto: Copia della Madonna di Michelangelo in San Lorenzo a Firenze vista da sinistra
BB_1961_title_verso: Copia della medesima Madonna più affrettata e vista da destra; inoltre un fauno che arretra, una testa canina, due maschere e due mani
BB_1938_title_recto: Study after Michelangelo's Madonna in the New Sacristy at S. Lorenzo, taken from left
BB_1938_title_verso: Hastier sketch of same, seen closely from right. Also a faun starting back, a dog's head, two masks, and two hands
BB_1938_text_recto: These famous sketches, also put in vogue by Mariette, are not Michelangelo's, nor, as Morelli believed, Bandinelli's. They are by Montelupo, See further under my 1701.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: The same hand appears in a number of drawings ascribed to the master – drawings which recall those ascribed to Battista Franco as well as such as are attributed to Montelupo. I more than suspect that they are by the latter, and will, for the sake of convenience, seeing what a number there are by the same hand, assume that they are his.

BB_1961_title_recto: Progetto di una tomba parietale: un sarcofago con un coperchio convesso a due volute poggia su un piedistallo e sostiene sula voluta sinistra una figura distesa simile al Crepuscolo nella Tomba Medicea del Duca Lorenzo a destra e a sinistra del piedistallo si allungano due nudi che rappresentano il Tevere e l'Arno sulla parete sopra il sarcofago, il tabernacolo centrale contiene la figura seduta di un duca, mentre nel tabernacolo a sinistra si vede una figura plorante, in piedi, probabilmente intesa per la Terra: il cornicione di coronamento mostra due figure rannicchiate di dolenti, forse lo scarabocchio a carboncino nell'angolo superiore destro è per una di queste vicino ad esso, poche lettere in corsivo, a penna
BB_1938_title_recto: Sarcophagus crowned by two volutes stands on a pedestal. On the volute left a recumbent nude like the Twilight in the finished work. Below to right and left of pedestal nudes representing Arno and Tiber. Behind and above sarcophagus a niche with seated figure for one of the princes, and to left a lamenting figure probably meant for Earth. Above the cornice two cowering mourners
BB_1938_text_recto: Copy or echo of an idea of Michelangelo's for the Medici Tombs. On the right scrawl in black chalk, perhaps for a mourner and a few letters in ink in a cursive hand. By Aristotile da San Gallo or some one close to him.

BB_1961_title_recto: Progetto di tomba parietale
BB_1938_title_recto: Project of a tomb
BB_1938_text_recto: Thanks to Baron de Geymüller I was able to add in my first edition that this design as well as its replica, my 1747A, are variants of a drawing at Munich since published in the Renaissance Architectur, VIII, fig. 20 (see my 1648A, 1697A).
BB_1903_text_recto: A fanciful variation possibly by Andrea Boscoli on the Medici Tombs.

BB_1961_title_recto: Progetto di tomba parietale. Affine al precedente, e della stessa mano
BB_1938_title_recto: Kindred to last, and by same hand
BB_1938_text_recto: Note the passion for the obvious as revealed in the addition of a moon to Night, of flames to Day, etc. This design is an elaborated and overloaded copy of a sketch probably by Aristotile da San Gallo at Vienna (see my 1747).

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile in piedi, ammantato fuorché sul torace, con la testa girata in profilo verso la nostra sinistra e la gamba sinistra posata su un gradino
BB_1938_title_recto: Study or half-draped male figure standing on right leg, his left raised and resting on a pedestal, the head in profile to left
BB_1938_text_recto: This, which may be by Bandinelli - there is in the reserve of the Uffizi (n. 505) a drawing of his singularly like it - is a copy of a study by Michelangelo, in all probability for his St. Matthew.

BB_1961_title_recto: Schizzo a contorno per una fontana con elaborate istruzioni sul modo d'ingrandirlo per farne un cartone: il bacino è un mezzo esagono, diviso in tre scompartimenti: in alto è lo stemma dei Medici, fiancheggiato da sirene che reggono anfore a destra e a sinistra su basi allineate col dietro della fontana, sono figure giacenti con orci, derivate dai Fiumi di Michelangelo per le Tombe Medicee e rappresentanti il Tevere e l'Arno sopra alla fontana è schizzata (a carboncino) una figura col braccio alzato
BB_1938_title_recto: Outline sketch for fountain, with elaborate directions how it is to be enlarged into a cartoon. The basin is half a hexagon, divided into three compartments. The top is crowned with the Medici arms, flanked by mermaids holding water-jars, representing Tiber and Arno. These are adaptations of Michelangelo' Rivers for the Medici Tombs
BB_1938_text_recto: The author of this sketch is unknown to me.  A person thoroughly acquainted with the documents of the middle of the Cinquecento in the Florentine archives might easily identify the hand, which is very legible, but not free from striking peculiarities.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo che attacca con una lancia
BB_1961_title_verso: Figura che avanza verso destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude attacking with lance - Raphaelesque copy after figure with lance in background of the Bathers
BB_1938_title_verso: Figure moving from left to right - a poor scribble

BB_1961_title_recto: Una mano sinistra aperta, e parte di un'altra mano che disegna
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of left hand spread out, and part of another hand drawing
BB_1938_text_recto: Another of Mariette's famous possessions. Ottley already saw that it certainly was not Michelangelo's, and ascribed it to Carracci. Wickhoff (Albertina Catalogue, I, I, Introduction) discovered the real author in B. Passerotti.

BB_1961_title_recto: Sei teste di animali grotteschi
BB_1961_title_verso: Tre teste simili
BB_1938_title_recto: Six heads of grotesque beasts
BB_1938_title_verso: Three similar heads
BB_1938_text_recto: The shading is done almost altogether with pothooks. This is a trick of Passerotti's, to whom, for other reasons as well, I would attribute this sheet. It was of course an attempt to draw in the spirit of Michelangelo.

BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane donna, seduta sui propri calcagni, in profilo a destra, con lo sguardo fisso sul cerchio che ella tiene nella mano destra, mentre con la sinistra regge dei chiodi
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo visto da tergo con la testa in profilo, il braccio destro alzato e il sinistro pronto a scagliare una lancia, iscritto "Alessandro" di mano di Michelangelo
BB_1938_title_recto: Young woman in profile to right sitting on her heels, looking intently at disk held in right hand while her left holds some nails
BB_1938_title_verso: Nude seen from back with head in profile, right arm held up and the left about to throw a spear
BB_1938_text_recto: I used to give it to Passerotti but it now (1935) seems like the exact copy by a Cinquecento engraver of a study by Michelangelo for the woman in the National Gallery Entombment who sits on her haunches with her hands in pose of holding crown of thorns and nails
BB_1938_text_verso: This may have been a drawing from Michelangelo's studio which Passerotti or whoever was the author of the crouching female nude picked up. Doubtless it was done for the background of the Bathers but discarded and replaced by the one in a similar attitude only that he bears down with a pole instead of throwing a spear upwards. See my 1604 verso and my 1739.
BB_1903_text_recto: Almost certainly by Passerotti; but I cannot decide whether it is a copy after a sketch by Michelangelo dating from the time of the Sixtine Ceiling, or merely a brilliant Nachempfindung - a constructive imitation, done perhaps with the purpose of fraud
Cataloguer's Comments: Handwritten in BB_1938: "c.f. The Woman holding the crown of thorns in the National Gallery Entombment" and " In black chalk. Written on in a very Michelangelesque hand in the word Alessa(n)dro. This may have been a genuine michelangelesque drawing which Passerotti picked up".

BB_1961_title_recto: Parte inferiore di un nudo virile
BB_1938_title_recto: Lower part of male nude, an anatomical study elaborated by one of the Carracci
BB_1938_text_recto: I recommend this sketch, than which the Bolognese never did better, to the prophets of revival of taste in Bolognese painting. Such a revival may indeed come, but it will not be of good taste. How dry and laboured and dull is this compared, I will not say with Michelangelo as in my 1597 but with any good second-rate draughtsman  of the "golden" and preceding age" True, one must have the mind's eye to see the difference.

BB_1961_title_recto: Copia di un perduto studio di Michelangelo per uno dei Prigioni e, perpendicolarmente ad essa, varie piccole figure di Prigioni
BB_1961_title_verso: Vari schizzi collegati con la Tomba di Papa Giulio II: parte di una cornice e, in basso, una "Vittoria" fra Prigioni incatenati a pilastri, disegnati sopra contorni di un braccio sinistro e due gambe piegate ai ginocchi; più a destra, un tozzo nudo acefalo che sembra andare a destra, ma guardandosi indietro, e un nudo che si contorce
BB_1938_title_recto: Copy of study for one of slaves, as well as, in reversed direction and vertically to chest, various small figures for slaves
BB_1938_title_verso: Various sketches connected with Tomb of Julius: part of cornice and below it Victory between slaves chained to pilasters drawn over outlines of a left arm, and two legs bent at knees. Further to right in same direction, a stumpy fat headless nude walking to right and as if looking back, and a squirming nude
BB_1938_text_recto: The large figure is a poorer version of the original copied in my 1746. The Victory and the slaves are variants of my 1672 or of the original (if an original ever existed) which it copied. Front and back are probably by Aristotile da San Gallo.

BB_1961_title_recto: Seppellimento di Cristo
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian (only the first sentence)
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Entombment. Heroic nudes march in front with blazing torches in their hands, and, arriving at mouth of cave, stop and turn round to where four or five others are bearing the Dead Christ on their shoulders and in their arms. They are followed by still others who march in mournful silence, with heads downcast, and their arms crossed over their breasts
BB_1938_text_recto: The execution of this sketch is probably Daniele da Volterra's, but to no other than Michelangelo can belong the invention of this truly sublime design. I know no other treatment of this subject worthy to be compared with this one for impressiveness and majesty. Would that Sebastiano had had it to paint at the time he was doing the matchless Pietà at Viterbo!

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile che corre trasportandone un altro sulle spalle
BB_1938_title_recto: Man running while carrying another thrown over his left shoulder
BB_1938_text_recto: Supposed study for the demon carrying one of the damned in the Last Judgement, just above Charon's back. This group may have been suggested by the following lines in Dante's Inferno, XXI: "L'omero suo, ch'era acuto e superbo, / Carcava un peccator con ambo l'anche, / Ed ei tenea d' piè ghermito il nerbo." This remarkable sketch is one, and perhaps the best, of a series of drawings, most of which may be seen in the Uffizi. There is good reason for believing that the real author was not Michelangelo, but Leonardo Cungi, of Borgo S. Sepolcro cf. My 1677.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per un'Epifania
BB_1961_text_recto: Pubblicato da Tietzte, Critica d'arte, 1949-50, pp. 378-379, fig.  331. Egli lo mette in rapporto con il Cristo davanti a Pilato su BB n. 1096 A ed ha perfettamente ragione, perché il segno e i manierismi sono identici e dimostrano che si tratta della stessa mano.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile in profilo a destra con la mano destra legata dietro al dorso, il piede sinistro ritratto e il braccio sinistro sollevato, assai simile, nella posa, ad uno dei Prigioni di Michelangelo ora al Louvre, ma non tanto da riferirsi ad esso
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio per la gamba del nudo sul recto e tre piccoli gruppi interpretati dal Venturi (ibid., pp. 197, 227) come studi per Giacobbe che lotta con l'Angelo
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for slave standing nearly to right, with left foot and left arm raised, his right hand tied  behind back. Close to but scarcely a study for one of Michelangelo's slaves now in the Louvre
BB_1938_title_verso: Leg of the figure on the recto repeated and three small groups interpreted by Venturi (ibid. pp. 197,227) as being for Jacob wrestling with the angel
BB_1938_text_recto: The execution obviously is not by Michelangelo, but being a faithful contemporary copy of a drawing for so important a work as the Tomb of Julius, this sketch is precious enough. It would seem to be by the same hand as that we find in the copy in the Malcolm Collection after the Haman (my 1690). The date of the original may have been 1512 or 1523. See my 1743A.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile visto da tergo col braccio destro sollevato sopra la testa nell'angolo inferiore destro, iscritto da mano molto più tarda: "A. Boscoli"
BB_1961_title_verso: A giudicare dalla fotografia, si direbbe un nudo virile che imita o copia quello su BB n. 1559 verso
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: [1957: Oggi mi sembra che possa essere un originale, anche se un po' trascurato di fattura.]
BB_1938_title_recto: Slender male nude seen from back with right arm raised over head. In right lower corner and in much later hand "A. Boscoli"
BB_1938_title_verso: The photo seems to show on the verso a copy or imitation of my 1559 verso
BB_1938_text_recto: The nude is too slender for Michelangelo and the hatching, although so close to his, betrays the careful imitator. Probably by a contemporary after an original for the Bathers.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile che sorge ondeggiando come in un sogno dalla tomba aperta, con drappeggio dietro le spalle, l'asta di uno stendardo nella mano destra, la sinistra tesa verso l'alto
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude floating up as in a dream from his open tomb, with a drapery tossed behind him, the staff of a banner in his right hand, his left stretched up
BB_1938_text_recto: School copy of study for the Resurrection made probably before the composition in the British Museum (my 1507).
Cataloguer's Comments: Former Haarlem, Koenings Collection, n. 20.

BB_1961_title_recto: Profilo a sinistra di un giovane che indossa un adorno cimiero piumato a destra, un altro profilo, meno rifinito, nella medesima direzione
BB_1938_title_recto: Profile to left of youth wearing elaborate plumed helmet. To right another less finished profile in same direction
BB_1938_text_recto: Copy or imitation perhaps by Bandinelli after studies by Michelangelo like my 1597 and my 1598B.
Cataloguer's Comments: Former Haarlem, Koenings Collection, n. 185

BB_1961_title_recto: Cavallo montato da due cavalieri ignudi, quello posteriore genuflesso e avvinto al dorso dell'altro parallelamente, una ripetizione a semplici contorni, dei due cavalieri e, in direzione opposta, profilo a sinistra e petto di un giovane
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio di un braccio teso in avanti
BB_1938_title_recto: Horse with two nude riders, the hinder one in kneeling position clings to back of other. Parallel with the group, outline of the two figures and in opposite direction profile to left and breast of youth
BB_1938_title_verso: Study for arm stretched out
BB_1938_text_recto: I cannot make out authorship, purpose or date of these sketches. They may be as late as 1535. On the other hand, they may be fifteen or even twenty years earlier.
Cataloguer's Comments: Former Haarlem, Koenings Collection, n. 513

BB_1961_title_recto: Madonna col Bambino a destra, a solo contorno, un profilo femminile, una coscia in profilo a sinistra e in basso un nudo anziano che guarda in alto portandosi le mani agli orecchi
BB_1938_title_recto: Madonna and Child. The head imitated from my 1608. A female profile in outline only, rump and hip in profile to left and below it an elderly nude looking up with his hands to his ears
BB_1938_text_recto: Not, as I guessed in the first edition, by Mini but more probably by "Andrea di Michelangelo", and one of the latest works of this draughtsman. The handling and quality are what we should expect to have been reached by the author of the other drawings here ascribed to him. The elderly man may be reminiscent of Michelangelo's Phaeton studies and anticipates those for the last Judgement. It is likely, therefore, that when this sketch was done, Mini had already left for France.
BB_1903_text_recto: This sketch is perhaps by Antonio Mini. In quality and touch it is like the drawing at Oxford inscribed in an old hand with his name.
Cataloguer's Comments: Former Oppenheimer Collection, n. 244.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa della Sibilla Cumana
BB_1961_title_verso: Due figure drappeggiate sedute: quella a sinistra nella posa simile alla donna nella lunetta di "Manasses ed Amon", l'altra forse per una variante della medesima
BB_1938_title_recto: Head of Cumaean Sibyl
BB_1938_title_verso: Two draped seated figures. The one to left in attitude like the woman in the Manasse and Amon lunette, the other perhaps for variant of same
BB_1938_text_recto: Probably not after original drawings but variants after the fresco of the sibyl and the seated woman in the fresco just below her done by a fairly capable draughtsman. Most likely Silvio Falconi.

BB_1961_title_recto: Progetto per la Tomba del Duca Lorenzo, iscritto in alto, apparentemente dallo stesso disegnatore, "Sepoltura del Duca Lorenzo di mano di Michelangelo"
BB_1961_title_verso: Una fontana, una donna imitata dall'arte antica, due iscrizioni, una delle quali dice: "Jacopo dela Sovino in Casalgrato Viti" e sotto la donna "nelorto d'Agostino Chigi"
BB_1938_title_recto: Design for Tomb of Duke Lorenzo. Inscribed apparently by same hand, "Sepoltura del Duca Lorenzo di mano di Michelangiolo."
BB_1938_title_verso: Study for fountain and for a woman from the antique. Also two inscriptions, one saying: Jacopo dela Sovino in Casalgrato Viti." And under the woman: "Nelorto d'Agostino Chigi," These words tell an interesting tale
BB_1938_text_recto: This is close to, if not actually by, Aristotile da San Gallo. The affinity between it and the Beckerath design (my 1623) for the Tomb of Julius is striking, yet despite the inscription on top of the sheet I do not hesitate to say that, as a record of a design by Michelangelo, it should not be taken too seriously. That artist would scarcely have condescended to crown a structure with hermae shouldering shells and swinging garlands. It is, in fact, as much of variant upon Michelangelo as Aristotile's other design in the Uffizi for one of these tombs (my 1631, with which this should be compared), and was suggested apparently by some such passing thought of the master's as is represented by my 1497 (see also my 1736). Returning to the writing, which seems Aristotile's if it is not a deliberate forgery, which is unlikely, it could have been intended only to give an idea of what Michelangelo's tomb of Duke Lorenzo was to look like, as in my 1631, he gives a similar idea of the tombs with two sarcophagi each
BB_1938_text_verso: The drawing was evidently copied from a sketch made by Jacopo Sansovino for a fountain to be done for a fountain to be done for the Altoviti House, one known as of the grafitti.
Cataloguer's Comments: Not present in BB_1903.

BB_1961_title_recto: Progetto di tomba parietale con due sarcofagi per le Tombe Medicee
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch for Medici Tombs
BB_1938_text_recto: Repetition with slight variations of my 1697A. See also my 1648A, 1735. The Madonna, for instance, is much younger here.
BB_1903_text_recto: Repetition with slight variations of N. 1735. See that number, under "Addition and Corrections."
Cataloguer's Comments: Despite of the star, the drawing is present in BB_1903. Handwritten comment: Study for a fountain and another of a woman, form the ? Pen and ink. Inventory number handwritten in BB_1961: 112

BB_1961_title_recto: Schizzo a memoria dal cartone della "Battaglia di Cascina" in alto, a sinistra, parte di un arco con bassorilievi figuranti un Battesimo di Cristo e un San Giorgio che uccide il drago
BB_1938_title_recto: Memory sketch after cartoon of Bathers behind the figures part of an arch with reliefs of Baptism and St. George.
BB_1938_text_recto: Certainly not by Michelangelo. The handwriting is definitely not Michelangelo's.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: By whom I cannot tell: possibly a forgery.
Cataloguer's Comments: Inventory number handwritten 122

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile seduto verso destra e studi di braccia e di mani
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo a mani giunte e quattro studi di mani giunte
BB_1938_title_recto: Seated male nude turned to right and studies for arms and hands
BB_1938_title_verso: Study for nude with folded hands and four more studies of folded hands
Cataloguer's Comments: Inventory number handwritten 120

BB_1961_title_recto: Fauno danzante che suona il tamburino
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for dancing faun playing on tambourine
BB_1938_text_recto: This is a copy of my 1581, made by some follower of Michelangelo's, who imitated his style of about 1535-1545. Quite likely it is by the hand which made a number of the drawings supposed to be for the Last Judgement.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile acefalo in posa simile a quello su BB n. 1590 a sinistra, ripetizione più leggera del medesimo nudo e, a destra, scheletro del bacino nell'angolo inferiore sinistro, un fanciullo seduto a bocca aperta, con la mano sinistra alzata
BB_1938_title_recto: Headless male nude similar in attitude to my 1590. Slighter repetition of same nude to left, and to right skeleton of pelvis. Below to left a child seated with left hand held up and open mouth
BB_1938_text_recto: Copies after originals by Michelangelo

BB_1961_title_recto: Demone che si appoggia sul ginocchio sinistro, tendendo la gamba destra in fuori
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of demon resting on knee, the right leg stretched out
BB_1938_text_recto: This figure is obviously connected with the demon who, pulling hard at a rope, is seen conspicuously in the lowest right-hand corner of the Last Judgement. The differences may be due to its being an enlargement of a variant original sketch by Michelangelo himself.

BB_1961_title_recto: Figura incappucciata a capo chino, seduta in profilo a sinistra (a penna) due studi di figura rilassata e la testa di una terza, tutti presumibilmente per un Cristo Morto (a sanguigna)
BB_1961_title_verso: Piccolo nudo accovacciato (a penna) e perpendicolarmente ad esso parte inferiore del mantello di una figura stante (a sanguigna)
BB_1938_title_recto: In ink, cowled figure seated in profile to left looking down. In red chalk two studies of relaxed figure and head of third, all presumably for a dead Christ
BB_1938_title_verso: In ink, a small crouching nude and vertically to it in red chalk skirts of mantle for standing figure
BB_1938_text_recto: The cowled figure is by the hand that did my 1696A, 1704, 1705, possibly "Andrea di Michelangelo". The chalk-sketches as well may easily be by him, particularly the one on the verso.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa nota come "Anima dannata"
BB_1961_title_verso: Atletico torso virile in posizione semisdraiata verso destra
BB_1961_text_recto: [1955: Recentemente mi è stata segnalata ancora un'altra versione della stessa testa: originariamente nella famosa Raccolta di Sir Thomas Lawrence, fu acquistata tra il 1860 ed il '70 da C.C. Perkins di Boston (Mass.), l'autore di Tuscan Sculptors, ed è tuttora in possesso dei suoi eredi a San Francisco. Mi sembra una copia del Bronzino dall'originale di Michelangelo.];
BB_1961_text_verso: [1959: Copia dal modello di Michelangelo per un Dio Fluviale destinato alle Tombe Medicee ed esposto all'Accademia Fiorentina nel 1589. Cfr. BB  n. 1489.]
BB_1938_title_recto: Head of a lost soul roaring with rage or pain. The few straggling hairs erect, shadowy draperies fluttering out like sails from his shoulders
BB_1938_title_verso: Study for the kneeling demon on shore who pulls a rope (in the Last Judgement).
BB_1938_text_recto: There is a gruesome reality here that makes one smile at the harmless Horgon-like head, invented apparently by Pollajuolo, occurring so frequently in Tuscany and Umbria in the last decade of the fifteenth and early in the sixteenth century. Both the idea and the manner belong to the period of the Last Judgement, but the exact likeness of this demon occurs nowhere in that work. The nearest approach to it is the head next to Minos. In the Uffizi there is a copy of this head, more highly finished, completed, turned the other way, and shorn of all its terror. A comparison of the two is instructive (my 1628).

BB_1961_title_recto: Gruppo di nudi. Studio per il gruppo degli Eletti a sinistra della Vergine nel "Giudizio Universale" e vari profili di cornici
BB_1961_text_recto: [1957: La figura a destra ricorda i disegni della Caduta di Fetonte]
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for group of elect to left of Virgin in the Last Judgement. Also several profiles of cornices

BB_1961_title_recto: Cristo Giudice in un cerchio di Eletti
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: È una prima idea poi ripassata dallo stesso Michelangelo per il "Giudizio Universale".
BB_1938_title_recto: Early study for Christ and groups to His right and left in the Last Judgement.
BB_1938_text_recto: Gentler in types, the foremost nude right, in attitude of contemplation, is almost Raphaelesque

BB_1961_title_recto: Busto della Vergine in profilo a sinistra Bambino seduto sopra cuscino che si gira verso la Madre con le braccine tese ed uno sguardo pieno di pathos quasi botticelliano sopra al Bambino, testa maschile vista di fronte, nobile profilo virile e tre putti
BB_1938_title_recto: Sheet of studies. On the right a bust of the Virgin in profile, and the Child on a cushion tossing Himself towards her, with arms held out and a look of almost Botticellian pathos. Over His left arm appears a male head, full face. The upper left-hand corner is taken up with three putti, in whom one feels reminiscences of earlier masters - of Desiderio, perhaps, and Verrocchio. In the space between them and the Christ Child we see the upper part of a noble masculine profile, of a type recalling both the St. Matthew and the Creator of Adam in the Sixtine Ceiling.
BB_1938_text_recto: It is not easy to determine the exact date of this wonderful sheet. The  Madonna's profile recurs with slight change in a drawing at the Louvre (my 1588 verso) of the Sixtine Ceiling period and is close to one of the female helping carry the dead Saviour in the National Gallery Entombment. Her dress suggests the Doni Madonna, painted certainly just before the Ceiling. The other profile, as we have seen, recalls the Matthew as well as the God the Father in the Creation of Adam. The technique yields no clue, although it points decidedly to the year preceding the Ceiling. My own impression is that this design must be contemporary with the two marble tondi, and thus date from just before 1508.

BB_1961_title_recto: Cristo quasi in profilo a destra che stende il braccio destro in senso opposto con aria di comando, mentre sostiene il lembo della sua veste sul braccio sinistro del braccio e della mano sinistra, aperta ed eloquente, vi sono altri due studi separati a semplice contorno
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo virile con la testa in profilo a destra, il braccio destro che punta in direzione opposta e la mano sinistra sul petto; dietro a lui, su scala minore, abbozzo di un altro nudo; davanti, due studi di una mano sinistra con l'indice leggermente piegato
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for draped figure of Christ drawing back His left foot, with His face nearly in profile to right, His right arm stretched out vehemently and in attitude of command, left hand held close to side, but open and eloquent, with a fold of His garment cast over the wrist. Also a separated study for this hand, and another of the same hand and arm, but in different position
BB_1938_title_verso: Nude starting forward on his left foot, with right arm stretched out, and left hand over the chest, another smaller and more sketchy nude, and two studies of a left hand with the forefinger slightly bent
BB_1938_text_recto: Vasari (VI, p. 277) tells us that on a cartoon of Michelangelo's, Pontormo painted a Noli me tangere destined for Alfonso Davalos, and that this was so successful that he had to paint a replica thereof for Alessandro Vitelli. From a letter addressed about the end of October, 1531, by Figiovanni, we learn that Pontormo was then painting this picture in Michelangelo's workshop  (Frey, Briefe..., p. 310). The cartoon must have been finished in the autumn of the same year. Neither of this nor of the two paintings is any trace known to me. But it seems probable that in the draped Christ that we are now examining we have one of the original studies for this work. The stern haughtiness and almost brutal aloofness of the conception well suits the time when the master was girding himself for the Last Judgement. The style of drawing does nor preclude this precise period, although it might point to a somewhat later date. The type of face and the fact that the figure is draped leave no doubt that the sketch is of a Christ. Being of a Christ, and of about this time, I cannot conceive what other purpose it could have served than that of a study for the Noli me tangere. The hand at arm's length sketched on the same side of the sheet would point to an attitude not less stern, but more argumentative. The nude and the hands on the back of the same sheet are probably a slightly earlier sketch for the same idea, but feebler, and as proved by the event, less satisfactory to the artist himself. If, as we have good ground for assuming, these studies were for the Noli me tangere, then that work is no longer wholly lost to us. I do not believe that in the finished cartoon the Christ underwent further change of action or conception. It remains to ask how the Magdalene came into the composition. To the right of course, bust just how? Perhaps a shadow of an answer may flit by us if we turn to Bronzino's exaggeratedly Michelangelesque painting of this subject at the Louvre.
Cataloguer's Comments: Handwritten comment in BB_1961 for inventory number, previously n. 23
Cataloguer's Question: Have I to add this in column N (I think no)? [1938: C. Gamba ha pubblicato in Bollettino d'Arte, 1909, p. 148, una derivazione dal medesimo cartone di Michelangelo, eseguita nel 1536 o 1537 e da lui attribuita a Battista Franco] [1960: Il Tolnay, M., III, p. 110, figg. 290 e 291, ritiene che il quadro pubblicato dal Gamba (fig. 650) sia di bottega del Pontormo e che Battista Franco appartenga invece l'altra versione di Casa Buonarroti, con una roccia al posto del paesaggio con muraglia. Una terza derivazione dal cartone, anch'essa con la muraglia, in raccolta privata milanese, è stata pubblicata nel Catalogo della Mostra del Pontormo, Firenze 1956, n. 69, tav. LXII, coma una delle due copie del Pontormo]

BB_1961_title_recto: Cinque studi: un nudo virile in profilo a destra con il manto cadente dalla spalla sinistra una dama paludata in profilo a sinistra un nudo femminile in profilo a sinistra uno studio di panni sopra una spalla
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo virile con un manto che gli copre soltanto le spalle e le gambe, seduto in contrapposto, quasi frontalmente, con la testa in profilo ed il braccio sinistro teso orizzontalmente verso destra; in basso, su scala minore, una figura accoccolata con un manto gettato sulle gambe e uno studio di panneggi.
BB_1938_title_recto: Sheet of studies. Nude in profile to right with cloak hanging from left shoulder - a copy from the antique of the faun or satyr type. Nude female, seen behind, with cloak hanging from left shoulder - also a copy from the antique. Draped lady in profile to left - a copy, judging by the folds of drapery, after Masaccio. Nude female in profile to left - a copy after an antique of a type approaching the Medici Venus. Cast of antique drapery over a left shoulder
BB_1938_title_verso: Draped male figure seated in contrapposto almost frontally with in sharp profile and left arm extended horizontally to right. Below in smaller proportion a crouching draped figure, and to right a study of drapery
BB_1938_text_recto: One would naturally be inclined to assume that this drawing was made by the youthful Michelangelo after the antiques and cartoons in the Medici gardens. But the exquisite cross-hatching has more freedom than in the very earliest sketches, and one may conclude that the date of this sheet could scarcely be earlier than 1495. The Ghirlandajesque way of sketching the head of the draped lady should be noted: first a line for the contour of the face, and then nibs for the features. If memory do not betray me, there is a striking likeness between the female nude seen from behind and one of the goddesses in Ruben's Judgement of Paris. I need scarcely add this is perhaps the most important of Michelangelo's earliest drawings.
BB_1938_text_verso: These two small sketches seem genuine, the large figure, on the contrary, so weak as to suggest the possibility that it is a copy. The original may have been for the Bathers. Tolnay rightly connects the crouching figure with the Bargello tondo, and the study of drapery with the Bruges Madonna

BB_1961_title_recto: Parte di spalle e braccio destro.
BB_1938_title_recto: Bit of right shoulder and arm
BB_1938_text_recto: First draft of a sonnet beginning with the line: "ne debbo a cor tanto dispiace addio".

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile seduto verso sinistra con le braccia alzate, la testa e le mani appena accennate nell'angolo superiore sinistro, in direzione opposta, testa avvolta in un turbante
BB_1961_title_verso: Vari studi per il piede sinistro del giovane sul recto, un tallone ed un malleolo per un piede sinistro che cammina, testa e spalle di un uomo che guarda in alto a destra, testa (tagliata in alto) e torace di un uomo che si sforza di sollevare un pesante oggetto alla nostra destra.
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for nude over Daniel and in opposite direction turbaned head, perhaps a first idea for one of the sybils, the Delphica, for instance, who in the fresco finished by being much younger
BB_1938_title_verso: Various studies for left foot of same figure, heel and ankle of a left foot walking, head and shoulders and upper part of arms of a man turning to right and pulling hard to lift some heavy object
BB_1938_text_recto: The sheet has been cut down as the lower part of the turbaned face on recto and the upper part of the man pulling on verso are missing. I cannot find the head or the nude on verso in the Ceiling and yet one feels that if not made in connection with this, they at least date from the same period. The nude alone suggests the one on our left in the Sacrifice of Noah, while it corresponds well enough with the man helping to carry the Dead Christ in Michelangelo's National Gallery Pietà to authorize the conclusion that it may have been sketched for that work. And should that turn out to be true it would not only go toward proving that the great failure in the National Gallery is Michelangelo's but dating it. The style and quality of this sheet bring it close to the study for the Libyan Sibyl in the Metropolitan Museum (my 1544B) and to the head in the Uffizi (my 1399A) as well as to a head on a sheet in the Casa Buonarroti (my 1416 verso), where the ear is identical with the one of the man pulling on the verso of our sheet. The date of the last two has been much discussed of late but is established beyond dispute by their close relation to our sheet and its companion in the Metropolitan Museum, both of which as we have seen were done for, or contemporary with, the Sixtine Ceiling.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Testa scapigliata di un'anima dannata che urla di rabbia o di dolore, incorniciata da panni svolazzanti come vele investite dal vento
BB_1961_text_recto: Iscritta in alto "GHERARDUS: DE PERINIS" e in basso a destra: "MICHELAÑ. BONARROTI FACIEBAT". [1957: Le innocue teste da Gorgone, che risalgono, a quanto pare,ad un'invenzione del Pollajuolo, e ricorrono così spesso in Toscana e nell'Umbria nell'ultima decade del Quattrocento o nei primi anni del Cinquecento, fanno sorridere a paragone di questo realismo raccapricciante. Sia il concetto sia lo stile collegano questo disegno al periodo del "Giudizio Universale", ma è un demone che non si riscontra esattamente nell'affresco. La somiglianza più stretta è con la testa accanto a Minosse. È istruttivo confrontare questo disegno con una copia di esso a Windsor, che io solevo considerare come l'originale.
BB_1938_title_recto: Head known as the demon or lost soul
BB_1938_text_recto: Feeble and elaborated copy of the original at Windsor (my 1619)

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Schizzo per i nudi virili in primo piano nel cartone della "Battaglia di Cascina"
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo in atto di alzare il braccio sinistro e la stessa figura vista fino ai ginocchi ma con le braccia al completo, su scala minore, nell'angolo superiore destro; sul nudo più grande ne è stato vagamente disegnato un altro.
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch for foreground figures on the cartoon for the Bathers
BB_1938_title_verso: Nude with left arm held up, another even more sketchy one drawn over. In the upper right corner a nude kneeling lightly on one knee as if about to rise and pointing upward as he does so.
BB_1938_text_recto: Done so freely and therefore with such anticipation of the master's draughtsmanship of forty years later that in my first edition I catalogued it as a copy by Allori. Happily this error counted for little in the effort I made to arrive at an idea of how this famous design was composed. In opposite direction in lower left corner scrawls for two or three nudes struggling up the bank, and towards the middle a group hard to interpret. I cannot take it for either a Madonna and Child or for a Leda and the Swan, as some students have supposed. Could it represent two nudes also for the cartoon of the Bathers, one of whom is preparing to pull a shirt over his head?
BB_1938_text_verso: The first for one of the groups in the Bathers where two nudes hold up a third as in my 1479 and 1598, and the other for one of the foreground figures, the fourth from left. On the edge in a beautiful hand the words: "di Michelagnolo" written perhaps by the first possessor, who may have been a friend or even follower of the artist.
BB_1903_text_recto: Rough, but important, sketch, probably by Alessandro Allori, after the cartoon for the Bathers.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Due piccole figure che camminano furtivamente
BB_1938_title_recto: Two small figures stealthily walking
BB_1938_text_recto: Perhaps for the Expulsion of the Money Changers, and certainly of that late period.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Bambino nudo fuorché per una fascia che gli cinge la vita, in profilo a sinistra e, davanti a lui, un altro bambino nudo inginocchiato in basso, un nudo grottesco che ne porta un altro sul dorso tutti in profilo e disegnati a semplici contorni
BB_1961_title_verso: Cinque putti danzanti, quello più a sinistra a carboncino, gli altri a penna con ombre acquarellate
BB_1938_title_recto: Child making water and to left from it a nude kneeling. Underneath, a grotesque nude carrying another pick-a-back. All these in profile and done with bare outlines.
BB_1938_title_verso: Five putti dancing, the left-most in black chalk the others in ink and wash
BB_1938_text_recto: Two lines and a half in Michelangelo's hand, and lower down another line in a later hand. Frey, 54. The principal motive corresponds with one in the Children's Bacchanal at Windsor (my 1618). Frey is right in pointing out that the one here is not copied, as I used to think, from the great design at Windsor but that it is an antique subject that Michelangelo could have done much earlier. From the style one would be disposed to date it no later than 1510
BB_1938_text_verso: Truly Etruscan in spirit but in no relation to Michelangelo.
BB_1903_text_recto: A copy, I know not by whom, from a group in the Children's Bacchanal at Windsor (No. 1618).

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile visto di fronte, con la testa in profilo a sinistra, un manto buttato sulla sua spalla sinistra e tenuto al fianco dalla mano destra ed un'asta nella mano sinistra protesa in basso, un altro studio per la mano destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Full-length figure of a man covered with antique mantle leaving right shoulder bare. He looks to left, and at arm's length holds a staff or sword with left hand, while his right holds up his draperies. Another study for same right hand
BB_1938_text_recto: This noble figure, even more antique than Donatellesque, certainly belongs to Michelangelo's earlier years. The date at which, for morphological reasons, it must be placed, agrees so well with the time when Michelangelo was commissioned to carve the Twelve Apostles for S. Maria del Fiore, that we can safely assume that this was a sketch for one of them. Which, precisely, may not so readily be determined. As the artist never began another than the Matthew, it was perhaps for that grand work. If so, the conception underwent radical changes, although a likeness remained. Be this as it may, of the quality of the drawing there can be no question. Among the master's sketches in red chalk it would be difficult to name its superior. One of the suavest works of Renaissance sculpture, a St. Peter, probably by Montorsoli, in front of the church at S. Pietro a Sieve, seems to have been inspired by this design even more than by the unfinished marble Matthew. It's instructive to compare with this sheet Uffizi No. 17370F, a faithful copy of it by Gabbiani.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Busto di uomo che guarda in basso a destra, piuttosto pensosamente pianta di una fortezza, due punte di alabarde, parole e frasi
BB_1961_title_verso: Cavaliere visto da tergo in atto di fuggire
BB_1938_title_recto: Head in red chalk of man looking somewhat pensively down to right, resting on shoulders rapidly sketched in black chalk. The remainder of the page is taken up with the plan of a fortification, and two sketches of heads of halberds, all in ink. Various words and phrases
BB_1938_title_verso: Horseman seen from back dashing away
BB_1938_text_recto: It now (1934) seems not improbable that the red chalk head so incisive and so Leonardesque is of the Sixtine Ceiling period, like my 1545A, 1598A and 1599A while the rest may be considerably later. Artists as that time would use up any empty space on paper (then so much more expensive than now) no matter what they had put there years or even decades earlier. A drawing like this head had no value for Michelangelo, he was not a collector of his own sketches on the contrary, he burnt sackfuls of them. A confirmation for the early dating of the head may be the fact that it is copied on the sheet of hands (my 1706) at Oxford, all after earlyish originals
BB_1938_text_verso: The date of this sheet is perhaps about 1530.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Due nudi virili seduti, che reggono libroni aperti. Studi per le figure che sostenevano i Libri di Genealogia nelle lunette che Michelangelo distrusse quando dipinse il "Giudizio Universale" sopra l'altar maggiore della Cappella Sistina
BB_1938_title_recto: Two studies for figures holding up the Books of Genealogy in the lunette which Michelangelo destroyed when he painted the Last Judgement over the high altar in the Sistine Chapel

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Rapidi schizzi per alcune delle figure che cercano scampo nella barca, nell'affresco del "Diluvio", sulla vola della Cappella Sistina
BB_1938_title_recto: Rapid sketches for some of the figures trying to save themselves in a boat in the Sixtine fresco representing the Flood

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Vigoroso profilo a destra di vecchio barbuto e studi di ginocchi
BB_1961_title_verso: Studi di gambe
BB_1938_title_recto: In black chalk profile to right of marked and vigorous head of old man
BB_1938_title_verso: Studies of legs for the decorative nudes in monochrome on the Sixtine Ceiling
BB_1938_text_recto: The features certainly recall Pope Julius, and this sketch may be a memory-portrait, but with much of the quality of the great grotesques as we find it n the Lille sheet. It could not have been done earlier than the beginning of 1511 as Julius was beardless till then.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Studio incompleto, dal modello, di un nudo virile acefalo, semisdraiato verso sinistra ed altri due studi per la gamba sinistra in posizione variata. Il primo studio è tracciato a semplici contorni, ma l'attacco del braccio e la coscia sono minutamente chiaroscurati, producendo un effetto di écorché
BB_1961_title_verso: Due studi per la gamba della figura sul recto. Studi per la statua della Notte nella Sagrestia Nuova di San Lorenzo
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for the Night (New Sacristy of S. Lorenzo), the hip and shoulders fairly finished, but as if after the ecorché the rest in mere outline. Two sketches of hip and torso of same figure, but in slightly different position
BB_1938_title_verso: Two sketches for leg of same figure

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile seduto a gambe divaricate, con la testa girata a sinistra e le braccia aperte: splendido studio del torso e della coscia sinistra, il resto appena indicato
BB_1961_title_verso: Studi di gambe e di piedi
BB_1938_title_recto: Splendid study of torso and legs, with head and arms slightly indicated
BB_1938_title_verso: Three studies for legs
BB_1938_text_recto: The figure seems seated, looking to left, but pointing to right
BB_1938_text_verso: Certainly of the date of the Ceiling. Steinmann (II, p. 594) connects these studies with the nude to the left over Isaiah. The early technique and a comparison with the legs on the verso prove that he is right, and not Jakobsen and Ferri, who interpret them as preparatory to the Christ in the Last Judgement. No doubt there is a certain identity of action for even Michelangelo has a small repertory of movements, and similarities of pose and gesture occur between figures in every part of his long activity. As a matter of fact, the nude on the recto is reserved from the nude as it appears in the fresco with differences only in the action of the arms. This is confirmed by the drawings on the verso in which the legs are already as in the fresco and the foot seen the opposite direction like the left foot of the same. The recto would thus have been done before Michelangelo had decided whether the figure was to look to right or to left. In my 1598B verso we have a sketch for the figure as it was finally painted. Interesting is the statement made by Jakobsen and Ferri (see Text, p. 16) that paper with the same watermark (a siren with a forked tail) has been used by Michelangelo for a letter dated March 8, 1510, and for the next drawing mentioned in this Catalogue (my 1399E), most certainly connected with the Ceiling. We may therefore assume that the sheet we are dealing with is of about the same date. The corresponding fresco would naturally be no earlier.
BB_1903_text_recto: Splendid study of Torso and Legs, with the heads and arms slightly indicated. The figure seems seated, looking to left, but pointing to right
BB_1903_text_verso: Three legs. Exact object unknown, but drawn perhaps in connection with the Ceiling, and certainly of that date.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: A sanguigna: torso e gambe di un nudo disteso, (per l'Eterno nella "Creazione dell'Uomo") a punta d'argento: gambe accavallate (forse per uno degli Angeli nel medesimo affresco, o forse per il nudo decorativo seduto sopra il Profeta Daniele e subito sotto all'Eterno nella "Creazione dell'Uomo") a penna: mezza lunetta che sorregge una scalinata, con un nudo in piedi sul gradino più basso, che accenna ad una figura giacente in cima alla scala
BB_1961_title_verso: A punta d'argento: uno studio di nudo col braccio piegato al di sopra della testa, per l'Ignudo seduto a destra sopra il Profeta Isaia; e studio a carboncino  per il nudo sopra al Profeta Gioele
BB_1938_title_recto: Sheet of studies. In red chalk, torso and legs of reclining nude, for the Eternal in Creation of Adam. In silver point crossed knees perhaps for one of angels in same fresco, or possibly for the decorative nude to right above Daniel and just under the Eternal in same composition. In pen, rapid sketch of a lunette the inner arch of which supports a staircase, upon which stands a nude pointing to a reclining figure on top
BB_1938_title_verso: in silver point, study for nude who holds his arm bent over his head to right over the Isaiah and study in black chalk for the nude to left above Joel.
BB_1938_text_recto: The vicinity of these several sketches on the same sheet is a matter of some importance. It goes to prove how Michelangelo was working on neighbouring compositions a bit here and a bit there as mood or occasion impelled. If we were sure that the pen-sketch was done at the same time we should know that while still working at the central narrative frescoes of the Ceiling he already was thinking of the lunettes with the ancestors of Christ, for the sketch could have served no other purpose.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Nell'angolo inferiore a destra, figura muliebre seduta, volta a sinistra che guarda in alto nell'angolo superiore a sinistra, rapido schizzo di un nudo che corre col braccio alzato
BB_1938_title_recto: Over statuesque draped  female, seated in profile to left, with two heads sketched in, the more accented one looking up. Rapid small sketch of nude running with lifted arm
BB_1938_text_recto: The spirit of this is far from convincingly Michelangelo's, but if his nevertheless, it may have served for one of the Ancestors of Christ in the lunettes of the Ceiling. Jakobsen and Ferri suggest that the seated figure may have served for the Virgin in an Annunciation and the nude for the angel flying down from the left. It now (1934) looks to me as if this nude was embracing and kissing another but so faintly indicated that one hesitates to believe one's eyes.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Rapido abbozzo, piuttosto informe, di un nudo maschile, seduto scomodamente sopra un blocco, in atto di guardare il libro che regge con la mano sinistra sul suo grembo, mentre alza la mano destra come per colpire
BB_1938_title_recto: Rapid jotting of rather shapeless male nude, seated uneasily on a block with his left hand on a book in his lap, at which he looks vehemently, while his right hand is lifted as if to strike
BB_1938_text_recto: The action suggests the Moses of S. Pietro in Vincoli, and the Ezekiel on the Ceiling, but sketched perhaps for one of the Ancestors of Christ. Jakobsen and Ferri (Text, p. 22 and fig. 10) point to the resemblance in action and we may add in shape as well, to one of the Slaves for the Tomb of Julius now in the Florence Academy.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Torso virile con gambe appena indicate, studio per un piede sinistro e contorno di un piede girato a destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Male torso with legs faintly indicated, study for a left foot and outline of foot turned to right
BB_1938_text_recto: Probably, as Frey concludes, the torso was for a Slave in the earliest projects for the Tomb of Julius. Not necessarily autograph. Perhaps by same hand as my 1654A.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Deboli contorni architettonici ed una piccola figura che, secondo Jacobsen & Ferri ricorda BB n. 1571, fig. 631
BB_1938_title_recto: Faint architectural outlines and a tiny figure, according to Jakobsen and Ferri (Text, p. 36) reminiscent of my 1571

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per un torso maschile e braccio destro ripiegato
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio per un braccio sinistro
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for male torso and bent right arm
BB_1938_title_verso: study for a left arm
BB_1938_text_recto: Jakobsen and Ferri (plates XXII and XXIII) consider the arm of the recto to be a study for the arm of Moses, the one on the verso for the arm of David. The style would suit the date of these masterpieces.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Schizzo affrettato della parte inferiore di una figura femminile nuda volta verso destra in atteggiamento che ricorda la Vergine nel "Giudizio Universale"
BB_1938_title_recto: Hasty sketch of torso and hips turning to right, in attitude recalling the Virgin in the Last Judgement

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Rapido schizzo di nudo virile giacente
BB_1961_text_recto: Primo pensiero per il Tizio divorato dall'avvoltoio a Windsor (BB n. 1615).
BB_1938_title_recto: Slight jotting for the Tityus (Windsor)

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Rapidi schizzi di quattro o cinque figure in violento movimento, studio per una Leda abbracciata da un cigno, e un altro nudo giovanile, forse ancora per una Leda
BB_1938_title_recto: Rapid sketches for four or five figures in violent action and study for a Leda in the embrace of the Swan, and another youthful nude, perhaps for a Leda again
BB_1938_text_recto: The nudes in violent action were done for the Bathers and correspond to figures on the large sketch here (my 1397C), for which figures they may have been a preparation. The voluptuous Leda must be of the same date and therefore the earliest of Michelangelo's ideas for that subject that has come down to us. How rapturous, how Correggiesque, how different from the hard sensuality of the famous version of later years preserved for us in Rosso's copy now in the National Gallery.
Cataloguer's Comments: Donazione Santarelli

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Cristo Giudice e, a destra, un gruppo di nudi genuflessi
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch for upper part of Last Judgement, including Christ and figures to our right
BB_1938_text_recto: The figures do not correspond in general arrangement and action so well with the saints that we now see in the fresco as they do with the nudes above them struggling with the columns. It is clear then that this sketch, along with the one for the entire composition in the Casa Buonarroti, was drawn before Michelangelo had yet made up his mind to destroy his own two lunettes belonging to the Ceiling, and use their space for the upper part of the Last Judgement. When he finally did this determination he pushed up into the lunettes the figures originally intended - as we see from the Santarelli sketch - to be on Christ's left, taking away from them their symbols, as the gridiron of Lawrence and the cross of Philip. As is obvious from the implications of the above paragraph, I must have taken this sketch for an autograph by Michelangelo as I certainly do now (1934). It slipped into the school category by one of those errors for which there is no accounting.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di donna rovesciata all'indietro, e quasi in profilo a sinistra
BB_1938_title_recto: Head of a woman looking up almost in profile to left
BB_1938_text_recto: Most probably a study for the Madonna in the Doni tondo of the Tribuna (p. 195). Tolnay says that this head was meant for the Jonah (see Rep. f. K. W., 1927, p. 192, note, and fig. 24). I should not exclude the possibility, but in spirit it seems different, in treatment sculptural, which is far from being the case with the Jonah, and in handling more severe and therefore earlier. I venture to believe that it was sketched at the time that the artist was doing more sculpture than painting, which would suit the Madonna Doni better than the Jonah. When Michelangelo painted that gigantic figure he had perhaps not touched a chisel for three years. The resemblance goes to show how limited was the number of types and attitudes even of a Michelangelo, the greatest of Italian inventors of types and attitudes
