BB_1961_title_recto: Testa china di giovane donna, in profilo a sinistra, con i capelli stretti in un cencio il naso e l'occhio ripetuti in basso su scala un po' maggiore, da una mano inferiore (p. 286)
BB_1938_title_recto: Head of youth in profile to left bending down beside it, study for eye and nose of similar but older face in same position (p. 196)
BB_1938_text_recto: Of the Sixtine Ceiling period but not to be identified with any existing head there. Except for arrangement of hair and shape of cranium very close to profile of Libyan Sibyl. Steinmann (II, pp. 602 and 653), followed by Venturi, believes it may have been intended for the sleeping woman in the Ozias group (Venturi, Michelangelo, 136) not impossible providing one allows for change of sex, character and expression.
BB_1903_text_recto: The finished face may possibly have served as a study for the Woman in profile to right in the lower left part of the National Gallery Deposition.

BB_1961_title_recto: Leggero schizzo per una figura che preme col braccio destro sopra qualcosa che tiene con la sinistra
BB_1938_title_recto: Slight sketch in red chalk for figure bearing down with right arm on something he is holding with his left
BB_1938_text_recto: Frey (pl. 155B, Text, p. 75) suggests that it might have been for a Samson slaying the Philistines or for Christ and the Money Changers. He may be right, but the contours and stroke seem earlier

BB_1961_title_recto: Gamba destra e gamba sinistra di una figura semisdraiata con i ginocchi rialzati
BB_1938_title_recto: Right and left leg of a reclining figure bent at knee
BB_1938_text_recto: Same technique and quality and possibly for same purpose as my 1409A.

BB_1961_title_recto: Tre nudi barcollanti
BB_1938_title_recto: Three nudes in staggering attitudes

BB_1961_title_recto: Tre nudi in atteggiamenti composti
BB_1938_title_recto: Three nudes in attitudes similar to last, and for same purpose
BB_1938_text_recto: These two sketches, like my 1414 and 1415 here and my 1573 at Oxford, are for some composition akin to the Christ chasing the Money Changers out of the Temple, or the Conversion of St. Paul, and are interesting as being among Michelangelo's very last pen-sketches. Further study of this group convinces me that the forms despite a certain sprawling looseness in touch are much earlier  and may be connected with the fresco of the Brazen Serpent on the Sixtine Ceiling.

BB_1961_title_recto: Due studi di nudi, l'uno più rifinito dell'altro, per l'Eletto che ne tira su altri due, con l'aiuto di un rosario, nella parte inferiore sinistra del "Giudizio Universale" doppia scalea divisa da una nicchia rettangolare uno studio per una tomba, tre schizzi di sarcofagi e due di nicchie per la medesima tomba
BB_1961_title_verso: Altro studio per la figura sul recto e rapido schizzo forse per il nudo che gli volteggia vicino a sinistra, nell'affresco. Altri studi per una tomba e le sue volute, e per una scalea
BB_1938_title_recto: Two nudes, one more finished than the other, for one of the blessed who in the lower left of the Last Judgement is seen pulling up two others with the help of a rosary, as in my 1572. A double staircase divided by a rectangular niche, one part going to right along a wall and the other to left. Study for a tomb, three of Sarcophagi and two of niches for same
BB_1938_title_verso: A nude for same figure as on the recto and another more sketchy perhaps for the floating nude next seen on our left in the fresco. Further sketches for a tomb and its volutes and for a staircase
BB_1938_text_recto: Steinmann in Monatsh. f. K. W., 1908 (pp. 963-974) gave the first satisfactory account of this drawing. The staircase is for the monument to Cecchino Bracci (d. Jan., 1544) still to be seen at the Aracoeli, and reproduced in Steinmann's M. um Spiegel seiner Zeit. Note the discrepancies between the sketches and the finished work. The nudes for the Last Judgement were of course done earlier
BB_1903_text_recto: Copies by a pupil after studies for a monument, a staircase, and the upper figure in N. 1572

BB_1961_title_recto: Copiaccia di una dichiarazione, datata maggio 22, 1501
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo visto da tergo in atto di camminare verso destra, due gambe ed una mano destra, tutti disegnati sopra una lettera senza data, scritta da Buonarroto, fratello di Michelangelo

BB_1961_title_recto: Una gamba destra, due nudi ed il profilo di un volto convenzionale
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch of a right leg, of two nudes, one of them probably for a slave in the Tomb of Julius, and profile of a conventionalized face.
BB_1938_text_recto: Slight and early.

BB_1961_title_recto: Metà superiore di un nudo giovanile col volto girato verso destra in basso, linee di scrittura
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch of upper part of youthful nude with face turned away to right. Below it several lines of writing

BB_1961_title_recto: Rapido schizzo per un nudo che si risveglia dalla morte. Indubbiamente intesa per la parte inferiore del "Giudizio Universale", la figura non appare, tuttavia, nell'affresco
BB_1938_title_recto: Rapid sketch for nude figure awaking from death, doubtless intended for lower part of the Last Judgement, although not to be found there

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo che volge il capo bruscamente a destra, verso una figura sorpresa e supplichevole, schizzata più sommariamente
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude turning head sharply to right towards more summary figure of a startled supplicating person
BB_1938_text_recto: I failed in the first edition to see that this is a sketch for a Resurrection like my 1580
BB_1903_text_recto: I do not know what purpose this could have served, but drawing must date from Michelangelo's early, if not earliest, years.

BB_1961_title_recto: Vari nudi che avanzano frettolosamente agguantandosi fra loro, due o tre linee di scrittura e rapidi abbozzi di piedi
BB_1938_title_recto: Number of nudes rushing forward seizing hold of one another, two or three lines of writing, and rapid scrawls of feet
BB_1938_text_recto: Perhaps this study is to be connected with the Ceiling fresco of the Fiery Serpents, and is at all events of that date. The writing, as already seen by Prof. Panofsky is almost certainly Mini's. The cublike nudes may be his as well. They are not Michelangelo's. If for the Fiery Serpents they would tend to strengthen Popp's conclusion (see M. K., p. 159) that Michelangelo had the idea of painting that subject in the Medici Chapel.

BB_1961_title_recto: Tre nudi, a penna, e quattro o cinque più deboli, a matita
BB_1938_title_recto: Three nudes, in pen, four or five fainter ones in lapis
BB_1938_text_recto: Dainty, almost too dainty, and perhaps for Bathers in attitudes of surprise and terror.
BB_1903_text_recto: Three Nudes, in pen and ink, four or five fainter ones in black chalk, in attitudes recalling Nos. 1402 and 1403, although these can scarcely be of so late a date

BB_1961_title_recto: Parte inferiore di una figura seduta per terra con i ginocchi rialzati ed il piede destro sotto la coscia sinistra, così da mostrarne la pianta
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for lower part of reclining figure resting on it's buttock with left leg bent high at knee and tucked under thigh with the foot showing sole
BB_1938_text_recto: The universal technique prevented my recognizing this drawing as an autograph. Frey connects it with the Eve in the Temptation of the Sixtine Ceiling and Popp with the Danae. Popp is certainly nearer to the truth. It is, however, far from safe to make sure of the purpose of an attitude like this one occurring so frequently in Michelangelo's works, particularly in the period of the Medici Tombs.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studi o per, o dall'Adamo nella "Cacciata dal Paradiso" sulla volta della Cappella Sistina
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Adam in Expulsion
BB_1938_text_recto: Probably Michelangelo's and certainly by the hand that did my 1409. done for the action only. Slight differences in right hand and left arm were made in fresco. Interesting to compare with my 1664A, which I take to be a copy after a similar original.

BB_1961_title_recto: Parte superiore d'un nudo virile muscoloso che guarda in basso
BB_1961_title_verso: Due nudi virili, l'uno visto di fronte, l'altro in profilo a destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Rough sketch for upper part of muscular male nude looking down
BB_1938_text_recto: Of the period of the Last Judgement and perhaps for it. To be compared with sketches like my 1525 verso.
Cataloguer's Comments: In BB_1938 we find:  "to be compared with sketches like my 1525 verso"; in BB_1961 "Confrontatelo con schizzi come quelli su BB n. 1525 recto"

BB_1961_title_recto: Maschera di uomo anziano che guarda in basso a sinistra
BB_1938_title_recto: Mask of middle-aged man looking down to right
BB_1938_text_recto: Probably done in connection with the ceiling and perhaps for it's early stages, but does not occur there. It is all but a variant reserved of a head on my 1416 verso.

BB_1961_title_recto: Torso e gamba destra col ginocchio alzato, di una figura supina
BB_1938_title_recto: Torso and right leg bent high at knee of figure reclining nearly flat on it's back
BB_1938_text_recto: Same technique and purpose as my 1401B and 1409A. Only here neither the heroic proportions nor attitude lend themselves quite so well to Danae.
Cataloguer's Comments: In BB_1938 we find:  "Only here neither the heroic proportions nor attitude lend themselves quite so well to Danae"; in BB_1961 "né le proporzioni eroiche, né la posa si prestano ad essere interpretate come una Leda"

BB_1961_title_recto: Leggero schizzo di un nudo virile seduto con la gamba sinistra ritratta ed il braccio destro alzato sopra la testa
BB_1938_title_recto: Slight sketch in black chalk for nude seated figure with left leg drawn up and right arm raised above head
BB_1938_text_recto: Might pass for Degas.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile genuflesso visto da tergo, con le mani alzate come per supplicare
BB_1938_title_recto: Kneeling male nude with hands lifted as if in supplication, seen from back
BB_1938_text_recto: Steinmann (II, pp. 606 and 674) considers it a study for one of the figures in the group of the damned in the Last Judgement. I cannot find its exact counterpart in the fresco, bust it may have been done for one of the nudes struggling to rise but beaten back.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa femminile volta in alto, in profilo a sinistra in alto alcune linee di scrittura
BB_1938_title_recto: Profile of female head. Above it some writing
BB_1938_text_recto: Probably for Sixtine Ceiling and perhaps for a Sibyl as Frey (Text, p. 116) suggests.

BB_1961_title_recto: Tre Ninfe danzanti e due Fauni
BB_1938_title_recto: Three rapidly jotted figures of dancing nymph and two fauns
BB_1938_text_recto: To Frey (Text, p. 116), on the contrary, this looks like a sketch for the Transfiguration and the horns that seem to belong to an old faun he transfers to the forehead of Moses. Scarcely later than 1515. It is interesting that the same sketch should lend itself to such very different interpretations.

BB_1961_title_recto: Piccolissimo profilo di un giovane con un cimiero ornato di pelliccia e di penne
BB_1938_title_recto: Tiny profile of youth with helmet of fur and feathers
BB_1938_text_recto: Very early. Compare with other sketches of same type in Oxford and Paris. See my 1560 and 1597 verso.

BB_1961_title_recto: Braccio destro proteso con la mano pendente
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for right arm stretched out with hand dropping from wrist
BB_1938_text_recto: Conceivably for the Adam but in that case reversed.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo eretto in atto di colpirne uno prostrato, e nudo visto da tergo, accoccolato in una posa molto simile a quella della donna che si lava nel semicupio in uno dei pastelli di Degas
BB_1961_title_verso: Linee di scrittura, che sembrano non essere di Michelangelo
BB_1938_title_recto: Crouching nude seen from back in attitude all but like one of Degas' pastels of women tubbing and another erect nude about to strike a prostrate one
BB_1938_title_verso: The writing on the verso does not seem Michelangelo's.
BB_1938_text_recto: Thode assumes that this is for a Hercules and Cacus and may be right, but the attitude of the arm does not exclude that it may have been for a Samson knocking down a Philistine with the jawbone of an ass.

BB_1961_title_recto: Giudizio Universale
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo virile in una posa di violenta torsione del torace e della spalla destra, col braccio destro alzato
BB_1938_title_recto: Earliest known study for entire composition of the Last Judgement (p. 229)
BB_1938_title_verso: Male nude with chest and right shoulder violently twisted round and right arm lifted
BB_1938_text_recto: The outlines of two of the figures on the left strengthened with ink probably by a later hand. Although Michelangelo's conception underwent considerable change in detail before the fresco was ready for painting, its main masses and movement are here fixed once for all. It is clear that when this was drawn the artist as yet had no idea of the groups of angels with the symbols of the Passion that now top the composition, necessitating the destruction of two lunettes which he himself had painted in connection with the Ceiling frescoes
BB_1938_text_verso: See Münch. Jahrb., 1928, pp. 446, 447, where Tolnay considers it a copy after the original sketch in the archivio for the Resurrection. It is not a copy, but a more tentative and feebler variant.

BB_1961_title_recto: Tre nudi virili barcollanti
BB_1938_title_recto: Three nudes in staggering attitudes
BB_1938_text_recto: See my 1403

BB_1961_title_recto: Tre nudi virili barcollanti
BB_1938_title_recto: Three nudes in staggering attitudes
BB_1938_text_recto: See my 1403
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938. These sketches are companions to numbers 1402 and 1403

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile acefalo e senza gambe, seduto con inerte abbandono e braccio destro proteso, col pugno chiuso
BB_1961_title_verso: Grande testa calva; piccolo torso di un nudo; altro nudo visto da tergo che si arrampica sopra un argine, come per una Bagnante; un braccio e tre studi di gambe
BB_1961_text_verso: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: VersLa testa, fuorché per essere in posizione inversa, somiglia molto a quella su BB n. 1399A recto. Probabilmente sono tutti studi per la storia del "Diluvio" sulla volta della Cappella Sistina (1508-12) e in ogni caso di quella data.
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for torso and arm of reclining nude, and of a right arm stretched out with balled fist (p. 234)
BB_1938_title_verso: Large bald head close, except for being turned in the other direction, to the one on the recto of my 1399A and in smaller proportions torso of a nude, another nude seen from the back crawling up a bank as if for the Bathers, three studies of legs and one of an arm, all probably done in connection with the story of the flood and, in any case, of that date
BB_1938_text_recto: Both are drawn in Michelangelo's most powerful early style. The torso served as preparatory study for the much more highly finished design for a Dead Christ in the Louvre (my 1586)
BB_1938_text_verso: In type and in technique similar to my 1544B, the Metropolitan Museum study for the Libyan Sibyl. See also Festschrift für Julius Schlosser, pp. 159-160, where Prof. Panofsky published these sketches as made for the Last Judgement and as being possibly mere copies; but Michelangelo's types of that late period are athletic, morose and tragic as on my 1468, the chiaroscuro is more elaborated, with modelling nevertheless more generalized as if done, so to speak, in porphyry instead of marble. A comparison between the nude on the recto here and the one on the verso of my 1484 would also serve to confirm the dating of both sides as of the Sixtine Chapel period. As for their being copies I for one miss no quality here that I expect of an original.
Cataloguer's Comments: In BB_1938 we find:  "In type and in technique similar to my 1544B"; in BB_1961 "Come tipo e come tecnica essi ricordano gli studi in BB n. 1544D"

BB_1961_title_recto: Sacrificio d'Isacco
BB_1938_title_recto: Design for a Sacrifice of Isaac
BB_1938_text_recto: Steinmann (II. pp. 595 and 625) connects this one of the medallions in the Sixtine Ceiling. Undoubtedly later but not as late as I implied in my Text. Perhaps towards 1535

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile in corsa, visto da tergo. Studio per uno dei bagnanti nella "Battaglia di Cascina"
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of nude seen from back for one of figures that must have occurred in the cartoon for the composition of the Bathers

BB_1961_title_recto: Sarcofago sormontato da un medaglione e presentato davanti ad un'altra struttura divisa in tre parti, la mediana assai più larga delle laterali
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch for sarcophagus standing on platform against a background. On top of the sarcophagus in the broken arch rests a round slab. The structure rising behind and above this is taller and narrower, and consists of three divisions - the middle one about twice the breadth of those at the sides. The whole is topped by a tall cornice (pp. 217, 221, 335)
BB_1938_text_recto: Most probably this is a sketch for the early project of the Medici Tombs, which was to consist of a cube with a sarcophagus on each side. My 1434 may have been done in this connection. It is on the back of a letter dated 1520.

BB_1961_title_recto: Un progetto per la finestra del piano superiore del Ricetto della Libreria di San Lorenzo e schizzo per il timpano di una porta
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio per una mano che indica
BB_1961_text_recto: Probabilmente uno studio per la mano destra di Giuliano de' Medici.

BB_1961_title_recto: Schizzo architettonico per l'interno di una cupola e per l'arco di sostegno. Assai probabilmente per la Sagrestia Nuova di San Lorenzo
BB_1961_title_verso: Scarabocchi architettonici e linee di scrittura
BB_1938_title_recto: Architectural sketch for an interior of a dome and its supporting arch, in every probability for the New Sacristy
BB_1938_title_verso: Architectural scrawls and some writing for which see Frey, Text, p. 84.

BB_1961_title_recto: Profilo angolare di un edificio a tre piani e alcune parole di mano di Michelangelo
BB_1938_title_recto: The profile edge of a building in three stories
BB_1938_text_recto: An architect's studio drawing. The writing looks very early

BB_1961_title_recto: Leggere decorazioni architettoniche, rapido schizzo di un'aquila ad ali spiegate e decorazione rettangolare, tipo arazzo, con foglie di acanto
BB_1961_title_verso: Alcuni versi trascritti da Frey, Dichtungen, LXVII
BB_1938_title_recto: Slight architectural decorations, and rapid sketch of eagle with outspread wings
BB_1938_title_verso: Some verses transcribed in Frey's Dichtungen, LXVII
BB_1938_text_recto: Below, a rectangular piece of tapestrylike decoration of acanthus leaves, certainly not by the master, and the other studies, including the eagle, now seem perhaps by Antonio da San Gallo the Elder

BB_1961_title_recto: Vari schizzi architettonici come per un timpano e una facciata interna consistente di tre aperture separate da mezze colonne, al di sopra un piano più basso, con tre aperture quadrate separate da circoli. Forse per la parete d'ingresso per la Libreria di San Lorenzo
BB_1938_title_recto: Various architectural sketches as of a pediment and the interior of a façade, perhaps for the inside entrance wall of the S. Lorenzo Library. This consists of three openings separated by half columns, and above it a shorter storey with three square openings separated by circles
BB_1903_text_recto: Below is a door placed like the present entrance door to the sacristy. Although greatly resembling the wall in the sacristy, yet the differences are sufficiently important to make it doubtful whether this sketch was intended for that purpose or for some kindred project of the same date

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio architettonico di un riquadro stretto e alto, chiuso fra due lesene e affiancato da due aperture più piccole
BB_1938_title_recto: Architectural study, consisting of a projecting mass containing an opening flanked by two broad pilasters, and in the background two narrow openings
BB_1938_text_recto: I see no reason (1934) for not connecting this with the Medici Tombs and it may be an early idea for the wall in the New Sacristy with the Madonna, Cosmas and Damian.
BB_1903_text_recto: Architectural study, perhaps for an altar, consisting of a projecting mass containing an opening flanked by two broad pilasters, and in the background two narrow openings.

BB_1961_title_recto: Vari scarabocchi architettonici, fra i quali un alto pilastro terminale sormontato da una testa che sostiene un cornicione, e uno schizzo molto semplice per la facciata di San Lorenzo parole e frasi
BB_1961_title_verso: Frasi frammentarie ("ricordo di tempo...")
BB_1938_title_recto: Various architectural scribbles, including a long terminal pilaster crowned with a head upholding a cornice, and a very simple sketch for a façade of S. Lorenzo. Also a number of words and phrases
BB_1938_text_recto: The whole sheet seems to have been a cast-off letter, as is indicated by one line of writing at the top as follows: "Messere Domenicho a questi dì e stato Iachopo Salviati a pietra santa pare."

BB_1961_title_recto: Schizzo per la facciata di San Lorenzo, che mostra, in basso, tre porte e quattro finestre e, in alto, un timpano grande e due piccoli
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch for façade of S. Lorenzo, showing three doors and four windows below, one great and two small pediments above

BB_1961_title_recto: Planimetrie e schizzo per un portale
BB_1938_title_recto: Slight plans and sketch for portal

BB_1961_title_recto: Rapidi schizzi di finestre per il Vestibolo della Libreria di San Lorenzo
BB_1961_title_verso: Cornice architettonica e studio di mano
BB_1938_title_recto: Rough sketches of windows

BB_1961_title_recto: Rapido schizzo per una finestra o un'apertura
BB_1961_title_verso: Disegno simile al recto ma in proporzioni diverse
BB_1938_title_recto: Rough sketch for window or opening
BB_1938_title_verso: Similar drawing of different proportions
BB_1938_text_recto: Both very likely, as Frey (209,210) proposes, for the Ricetto of the Library of S. Lorenzo

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio forse per un altare
BB_1938_title_recto: Study perhaps for an altar

BB_1961_title_recto: Due capitelli ionici
BB_1938_title_recto: Two Ionic capitals

BB_1961_title_recto: Un capitello ionico
BB_1938_title_recto: An Ionic capital

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per una finestra rettangolare con al centro un colonnino
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for a rectangular window, with a mullion in the middle

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio architettonico, forse per un monumento
BB_1961_title_verso: Replica, non ombreggiata, della parte inferiore del recto e linee di scrittura, con la data 1520
BB_1938_title_recto: Architectural study, perhaps for a monument
BB_1938_title_verso: Unshaded repetition of lower part of recto and writing dated 1520 for which see Frey, Text, p. 57.
BB_1938_text_recto: According to Frey (123 and 124) an early idea for the cupola of the New Sacristy of S. Lorenzo but a comparison with the structure behind the sarcophagus in my 1419 leads one to suspect that it may have been done in connection with that scheme for one of the Medici Tombs.

BB_1961_title_recto: Leggeri schizzi architettonici ed uno studio più per un ricettacolo che per un sarcofago, o forse per la testata di un sarcofago posto fra due pilastri bassi e massicci
BB_1938_title_recto: Various slight architectural sketches and study for receptacle rather than a sarcophagus or perhaps the butt end of a sarcophagus placed between two heavy squat pillars

BB_1961_title_recto: Studi architettonici per le tombe Medicee
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian an added: [1960: Lo scopo di questo e ultimo schizzo è chiarito da un confronto col progetto per le Tombe Medicee su BB n. 1497, ove di vede un alto fastigio con i due troni vuoti sopra alle coppie di pilastri, fra altorilievi con trofei, al centro, e con figure accucciate sotto ghirlande, ai lati. Qui i troni sono più bassi e i nudi raggomitolati sono disegnati nel basso riquadro rettangolare, forse destinato a sostituire la panoplia centrale. Una statuetta (alta cm 54) all'Hermitage è stata considerata opera di un allievo per una di queste figure ripiegate di piangenti. Nel coronamento attuale, i troni sono ridotti a un motivo decorativo astratto, la panoplia nel mezzo è abolita, le figure laterali sono abolite, e rimangono soltanto le ghirlande!]
BB_1938_title_recto: Plan and sketches for a monument
BB_1938_text_recto: The one on the left would seem to be a study for the entablature resting above the pilasters of either of the two tombs in the Medici Chapel with the projecting part of the attic crowning the same monument, dating from a moment when perhaps Michelangelo vaguely thought of placing a figure over each of the salients of the attic as in the Sixtine Ceiling above the Prophets and Sibyls. To the right of this a sketch to me undecipherable. It looks as if it were meant for a low rectangular receptacle which was to be occupied by one ore more squatting figures, as for instance in my 1438.

BB_1961_title_recto: Due o tre schizzi per vasi o bacili
BB_1938_title_recto: Two or three sketches for a vases and basins

BB_1961_title_recto: Leggero schizzo per una tomba, che presenta qualche rassomiglianza con uno o due degli studi per le Tombe Medicee al British Museum
BB_1938_title_recto: Slight sketch for a tomb, bearing some resemblance to one or two of the British Museum studies for the Medici tombs

BB_1961_title_recto: Schizzo per una finestra, o della Sagrestia Nuova o della Libreria di San Lorenzo
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch for a window either in the New Sacristy or the Library of S. Lorenzo

BB_1961_title_recto: Leggeri schizzi architettonici, fra i quali uno studio per una Tomba Medicea in San Lorenzo: esso mostra già due figure distese sopra l'alto sarcofago ed una figura eretta nella nicchia soprastante
BB_1961_title_verso: Alcuni versi
BB_1938_title_recto: Various slight architectural sketches, including one for a tomb, unmistakably for S. Lorenzo. The reclining figures are already visible on the top of the high sarcophagus as well as the erect figure in the niche above
BB_1938_title_verso: Some verses transcribed in Fey's Dichtungen, XXIV

BB_1961_title_recto: Schizzi architettonici, porte e finestre
BB_1938_title_recto: Architectural sketches, doors and windows
BB_1938_text_recto: Doubtless connected with S. Lorenzo projects

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per un pezzo di cornice
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for a bit of cornice

BB_1961_title_recto: Rapido schizzo per la facciata di San Lorenzo
BB_1938_title_recto: Rough sketch for façade of S. Lorenzo
BB_1938_text_recto: Slight and simple

BB_1961_title_recto: Studi per un piccolo altare e per la scala della Libreria di San Lorenzo. Gli schizzi a sanguigna (testa maschile in profilo e parte inferiore di un grande nudo virile seduto verso destra) sono di altra mano, ambedue possibilmente del Mini
BB_1961_title_verso: Schizzi per la scalinata e la Libreria di San Lorenzo. Le tre teste a sanguigna e la parte inferiore di un nudo virile visto frontalmente, a carboncino, sono della medesima mano degli schizzi a sanguigna sul recto
BB_1938_title_recto: On a sheet already containing sketches in red chalk, such as a male head in profile and the lower part of a large nude, both possibly by Antonio mini, studies in pen and ink for a small altar, and various sketches for staircase in the Library of S. Lorenzo
BB_1938_title_verso: Three heads in red chalk by the same hand as the nude on the recto and in black lower part of nude. In pen various sketches for the staircase and Library of S. Lorenzo

BB_1961_title_recto: Struttura architettonica con tre aperture in basso, due in alto, statue nelle aperture laterali inferiori
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch for a structure consisting of three openings below, and two above, with statues in the lower side openings
BB_1938_text_recto: In the first edition it was suggested that this might be an idea for the altar of the New Sacristy in S. Lorenzo. That no longer seems possible. Equally improbable is Popp's inference that it may have been intended for the tombs of Leo X and Clement VII to be erected in a tiny room off the old Sacristy in S. Lorenzo. But it looks as if meant to have three or even four sides and as if the central arch was to be hollow. Is it conceivable that this was the first notion that passed through Michelangelo's head on reading Cardinal Giulio's request for the design of a four-sided structure for the New Sacristy consisting of arches? See extract from Buoninsegni's letter of December  28, 1520, in Tolnay, L'Arte, 1934, p. 38.
BB_1903_text_recto: Sketch for an altar consisting of three openings below, and two above, with statues in the lower side openings. Whether originally intended for the New Sacristy or for the Church of S. Lorenzo itself I cannot tell, but for one or the other almost certainly

BB_1961_title_recto: Disegno in profilo di uno dei sedili e leggii nella Libreria di San Lorenzo. Scarabocchi di due mani e due braccia a sanguigna
BB_1938_title_recto: Profile sketch for one of the reading stands and benches in the Library of S. Lorenzo. Also scrawls of two hands and arms in red chalk

BB_1961_title_recto: Leggero schizzo di un capitello ionico composito
BB_1938_title_recto: Slight black chalk sketch of Ionic composite capital
BB_1903_text_recto: Slight black chalk sketch of a Corinthian composite capital

BB_1961_title_recto: Schizzo di un capitello ionico composito più ornato
BB_1938_title_recto: Black chalk sketch of more ornate composite ionic capital

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per un portale ornato
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for ornate doorway
BB_1938_text_recto: Of his later years

BB_1961_title_recto: Leggero schizzo di una finestra
BB_1938_title_recto: Slight black chalk sketch of window

BB_1961_title_recto: Rapido schizzo per un capitello ionico
BB_1938_title_recto: Rapid black chalk sketch for Ionic capital

BB_1961_title_recto: Schizzo per un capitello ionico composito ornato
BB_1938_title_recto: Black chalk sketch for ornate Ionic composite capital

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per la finestra di un palazzo
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for palace window
BB_1938_text_recto: Hatching and shading not convincingly the master's

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per una struttura simile ad un tabernacolo, ed un sarcofago. Forse per un fonte battesimale
BB_1961_title_verso: Annotazione importante di mano di Michelangelo, in merito alla facciata di San Lorenzo, trascritta nell'appendice del Gotti, p. 185, e nelle Lettere del Milanesi, p. 567
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for a tabernacle-like erection, perhaps for font
BB_1938_title_verso: Important memorandum in Michelangelo's hand regarding the façade of S. Lorenzo, transcribed in Gotti's appendix, p. 185, and Milanesi's Lettere, p. 567
BB_1938_text_recto: More likely, as Frey suggests, for the reliquary at S. Lorenzo (see his Text, pp. 39-40).

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per una nicchia incorniciata da colonne ioniche e sormontata da un timpano spezzato al centro
BB_1961_title_verso: per lo scritto sul verso vedi Gotti
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for niche framed in with Ionic columns and broken pediment
BB_1938_title_verso: See Gotti for writing on verso
BB_1938_text_recto: Unusually precise

BB_1961_title_recto: Schizzi per il soffitto della Libreria di San Lorenzo
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketches, as Frey has rightly seen, for the ceiling of the Library of S. Lorenzo

BB_1961_title_recto: Schizzo per la facciata di San Lorenzo
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo mitrato, seduto in profilo a sinistra, sopra un sarcofago sorretto, sotto le braccia, da un altro nudo
BB_1938_title_recto: Pen scrawl representing mitred nude supported on a sarcophagus by another nude holding him under the arms
BB_1938_title_verso: Sketch for a façade of S. Lorenzo
BB_1938_text_recto: Doubtless a sketch for the Tomb of Julius.
BB_1903_text_recto: Sketch for a façade of S. Lorenzo
BB_1903_text_verso: Pen scrawl representing a mitred Nude supported on a sarcophagus by another Nude holding him under the arms. Doubtless a sketch for the Tomb of Julius
Cataloguer's Comments: In BB_1961 "recto" and "verso" are circled and inverted

BB_1961_title_recto: Vari schizzi architettonici, fra i quali un magnifico studio per un arco trionfale o porta di città
BB_1938_title_recto: Various architectural sketches, including a magnificent one for a triumphal arch or town gate
BB_1938_text_recto: Thomas Ashby in Papers of the British School at Rome (II, 1904, pp. 6-8) suggests that this sketch as well as my 1505 and 1506 are either copies by Coner himself, or copied by some one else from Coner's sketchbook, but certainly not by Michelangelo. Frey, on the contrary, defends them as being early works by the great master. As for me I am not sufficiently acquainted with the contingencies of architectural drawing and the other, even on the same sheet, as for instance on my 1505 or 1505 verso, suggests the possibility that they were done under Michelangelo's eyes with his assistance after slighter sketches by himself or for that matter by Coner, if dates permit the latter supposition.

BB_1961_title_recto: Basi di capitello
BB_1961_title_verso: Planimetria della Libreria di San Lorenzo
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for bases of capital

BB_1961_title_recto: Basi di capitello e cinque linee di scrittura
BB_1938_title_recto: Studies for bases of capitals, with five lines in writing

BB_1961_title_recto: Schizzo quasi al naturale di un nudo maschile in età avanzata, visto dalla vita in su, con la testa girata a sinistra e panni sboffanti dietro le sue spalle come ali, che solleva il braccio destro col quale regge un oggetto simile a un corno potorio
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch of almost life-size male nude of advanced years, seen from waist upwards, turned to left, with billowing draperies to right and left and right arm raised holding what might be a drinking horn
BB_1938_text_recto: Proportions and action belong to the period between the Sixtine Chapel and the Last Judgement. The action suggests the Resurrection and the famous drawing of a demon (my 1619). The neck has the length and the head the detachment of the Giuliano in the Medici Chapel and later figures. The neck in his earlier creations is shorter. The torso recalls the Cavalieri drawings. The right arm is unintelligible, the left arm much better. Tolnay reproduces it in Jahrbuck Pr. K. S., 1933, p. 97, and believes this bravura sketch to be the earliest surviving drawing by Michelangelo, dating it toward 1489. This is another instance of what differences of opinion are still possible in judging of Michelangelo's drawings.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per il nudo in profilo a destra che aiuta l'amico ad affibbiarsi l'armatura, nella "Battaglia di Cascina" rapida indicazione del ventre dell'amico spalla e profilo a sinistra di un uomo che guarda lontano, forse per il motivo dei due soldati che ne sorreggono un terzo (cfr. BB nn. 1479, 1481, 1598)
BB_1961_title_verso: Soggetto non facilmente identificabile: nell'interno di una porta giace un morto in posizione scomoda; a sinistra una figura sta mettendo qualcosa sulla testa di un'altra; a destra due astanti
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for the figure in the Bathers helping to buckle up the armour of his friend, a bit of whose abdomen is roughly sketched in. Also the shoulder and profile to left of a man looking away, perhaps for the discarded motive represented by several sketches (see my 1479, 1481, 1598) of two soldiers holding up a third
BB_1938_title_verso: Rapid, large jotting, with softer chalk than used on the front, of a subject not readily determined. In a door lies a dead figure in an uneasy posture. To left, two figures, one of whom places something on the head of the other. To right, two men look on.
BB_1938_text_recto: A clear, grand arrangement, but for what? Possibly for a fresco representing Judith walking off with the head of Holofernes. The fact that the reclining figure still has his head on is scarcely ground for doubting this suggestion, for in a sketch so rapid as this the artist might not have thought of first decapitating him. This is among the most rudimentary of Michelangelo's studies, and its bold, masterly qualities are particularly recommended to those who would believe in the authenticity of the Uffizi and Berlin designs for the Tomb of Julius, on the ground of their being hasty jottings. The nearest parallel to this study is a rough sketch in the British Museum for an almost shapeless reclining figure of no determinable purpose (my 1480). Close to it is also the torso for a Dead Christ on the back of the British Museum pen-notes for the Sixtine decorative nudes (my 1484). Professor Brinckmann maintains that this and following drawings are copies after the corresponding frescoes and uses exquisitely ingenious and highly elaborate but irrelevant arguments to prove his point. In my opinion they are not copies but autographs by Michelangelo. I know of no one contemporary with that master or later who drew in a way so indistinguishable from him. Opinions apart, one thing is that if they are not originals they are perfect copies not after the frescoes, but of autograph sketches by Michelangelo and therefore can count in the study of the artist's mind as if they were originals (see my 1544B). The reproductions of these drawings in the supplement to Frey give no idea of their quality, and argument based upon them are worthless.
Cataloguer's Comments: At the beginning, in the footnote: These drawings have been published in remarkable facsimile by Bruckmann (Munich), with slight notes. Excellent so fas as they go - by Herr F. von Marcuard. For greater convenience of reference I catalogue them here, not as I found them in the portfolios, but in the order they have in the publication.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile che si allontana brandendo un'asta nella destra e reggendo panni nella sinistra la mano destra e la parte interna del ginocchio destro sono ripetuti anche un'altra mando ed un piede. Studio per la "Battaglia di Cascina" (1504-05) e più precisamente per la figura all'estrema destra nel gruppo detto dei Bagnanti
BB_1961_title_verso: Un torso in posa abbandonata, la testa di profilo e il braccio sinistro appena indicato, la gamba destra e il braccio quasi invisibili; tre rapidi schizzi per un ginocchio
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for the nude lancer in the Bathers, who reaches forward with a lance in his right and drapery in his left hand. The right hand and the inside of the right knee are repeated. Also another hand and foot
BB_1938_title_verso: A torso in reclining position, the profile head and the left arm vaguely indicated, the right leg and arm scarcely at all. Also three rougher sketches of a knee
BB_1938_text_recto: Perhaps for a Pietà or Dead Christ, and not unconnected with such other early studies for this subject as the one just mentioned in the British Museum, the one belonging to the Hon. A. E. Gathorne-Hardy, and the two replicas in the Casa Buonarroti, and at the Louvre. See last paragraph of my 1463

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile seduto in profilo a sinistra. Studio per l'ignudo seduto a destra sopra la Sibilla Persica e accanto alla "Creazione del Sole e della Luna"
BB_1961_title_verso: Studi dal vero per i vari particolari del gruppo di Dio Padre sorretto da Spiriti angelici nella "Creazione dell'Uomo" sulla volta della Cappella Sistina
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for the decorative nude in the Ceiling above the Persica, and next to the Creation of the Sun and Moon
BB_1938_title_verso: Studies of detail from the model of the group of God the Father and attendant spirits in the Creation of Adam
BB_1938_text_recto: Compare the quality of this sheet with my 1476. The head less elaborated. As Marcuard observed there is no space on the leaf to draw the arm in connection with the shoulder, for which reason it is sketched separately
BB_1938_text_verso: Each figure of limb is to be identified with the greatest facility, and indeed an inventory of whole has been made by Marcuard Two of the decorative attending figures in black chalk and on smaller scale were drawn earlier than the larger ones in black chalk. See last paragraph of my 1463 and what is said under my 1544B.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio dal vero per la testa del nudo decorativo seduto a destra sopra la Sibilla Persica (vedi BB n. 1465 recto) uno studio per la gamba sinistra, e due per la gamba destra del Padre Eterno nella "Creazione dell'Uomo"
BB_1961_title_verso: Rapidi schizzi per i due putti avvinghiati sotto l'Eterno della "Creazione dell'Uomo"; torso visto da tergo, e un ginocchio il cui scopo non si riesce a indovinare; contorni di "Ignudi" seduti e scarabocchi indecifrabili
BB_1938_title_recto: Study from the model for the head of the nude sketched on the last leaflet, one for the left leg, and two for the right leg of the Creator in the Creation of Adam
BB_1938_title_verso: More rapid sketches for two of the putti clinging one over the other close to the Creator's right side in the same composition. Also the study of a torso seen from the back, and of a knee, the purpose of which cannot be conjectured. In black chalk the outlines of sketches for decorative seated figures and some undecipherable scrawls.
BB_1938_text_recto: Perhaps the point of greatest interest in the two leaflets is the finding, intertwined, as it were, upon them, detailed studies for two separate if neighbouring composition. The verso of my 1465, where we see the legs for the Creator of Adam, and the head for the decorative nude on the other side of the next composition, all done, most probably, at the same sitting and with the same model, implies even more than the other studies on these two leaflets that at this time the complete design for the Separation of Earth from Water, no less than for the Creation of Adam, must already have existed. It follows, therefore, that Michelangelo, in this instance got two, at  least, of the compositions ready for execution before he began to paint either. The idea then occurs to one that this may not have been a solitary instance.

BB_1961_title_recto: Due fogli impastati insieme: in alto, studi per i ginocchi del Duca Giuliano e per la gamba sinistra della Notte in basso, studio per la gamba destra del Giorno
BB_1961_title_verso: Planimetrie e schizzo per una facciata, di carattere indeterminato
BB_1938_title_recto: Two leaves pasted together, containing studies for the knees of Giuliano, the left knee and thigh of Night, and the right thigh and le of Day
BB_1938_title_verso: Plans and sketch for a façade, of indeterminate character
BB_1938_text_recto: Intended probably for the Library of S. Lorenzo, and not necessarily contemporary with the studies on the front, it having been Michelangelo's habit to take up for sketching the first bit of paper that came to hand

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo acefalo seduto, piegato verso sinistra e in basso, su scala maggiore, testa girata di tre quarti verso l'alto. Studio per il San Lorenzo nel "Giudizio Universale"
BB_1961_title_verso: Figura virile, acefala e senza braccia vista da tergo, che sta saldamente a gambe divaricate, inclinando il torso verso destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for St. Lawrence in the Last Judgement, in the exact attitude that he has in the fresco. The quality is altogether admirable, the soft black chalk used with the utmost effectiveness in the contours. Also, on much larger scale, the head of the same figure
BB_1938_title_verso: Torso and legs of male figure seen from behind, standing firm, with legs far apart, the body bending to right
BB_1938_text_recto: In silhouette having a certain likeness, as Prof. Panofsky points out (see Rep. f. K. W., 1927, p. 43 and fig. 12) with a figure in the Crucifixion of Peter, but too different in action and spirit to have been drawn for it, and more likely for the Last Judgement again, perhaps for the figure to left and above the Isaiah. The hatching and modelling in spite of the lapse of time as in my 1479, for the Bathers.
BB_1903_text_verso: Of unknown purpose, but in system of line and general character recalling such a pen-sketch of this date as one for two small nudes in the Uffizi (n. 1398).

BB_1961_title_recto: Due sezioni trasversali per una cupola e la sua lanterna, due schizzi separati per quest'ultima, uno o più nudi sbiaditi impastato sopra, un piccolo schizzo per una porta di città
BB_1961_title_verso: Segmento della pianta di una cupola; vari studi di Profeti o Apostoli, ciascuno nel suo tabernacolo: uno si alza per parlare, un altro siede assorto, come il piccolo "Sant'Agostino" del Botticelli agli Uffizi (n. 1473)
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: La porta può essere Porta Pia, commessa a Michelangelo nel 1561
BB_1938_title_recto: Two cross-sections for cupola and its lantern, with two separate sketches for the latter. One or more nearly effaced nudes. Pasted on, a small sketch for a town gate
BB_1938_title_verso: Segment of a plan for cupola. Four or five several studies for a prophets or apostles, each in his rectangular niche. One gets up to speak. Another is seated like Botticelli's little St. Augustine (Uffizi) lost in contemplation.
BB_1938_text_recto: The cupola must surely be St. Peter's. The gate may be the Porta Pia. The destination of the sketches for prophets is unknown.

BB_1961_title_recto: Profeta che si alza dalla lettura di un libro, studio per la parte superiore di una figura simile e pianta architettonica
BB_1961_title_verso: Vigoroso nudo virile che alza lo sguardo verso destra, mentre allunga le braccia verso ciò che gli porge un fanciullo a sinistra; all'estrema destra vaghi accenni di due figure, che dovrebbero essere Didone sul suo letto e un'ancella
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch for prophet of same kind and date - about 1550 - as the last, but of greater interest. Also the upper part of a similar figure, and an architectural plan
BB_1938_title_verso: Vigorous nude looking up to right, with his left arm reaching across to something that a boy is holding in his arms. Also one or two other scrawls of figures that in connection with what follows result as being Dido on her couch
BB_1938_text_recto: He is very aged and has been reading. He gets up while shutting his book, and glares with deep-set dimmed eyes but awe inspiring look. It is the Ezekiel of the Ceiling, or better still, the marbles Moses, with the difference that here he is done by an old man and there by a youth, here with a more spiritual and there with a more physical conception
BB_1938_text_verso: Professor Wilde has published this as study for a picture by Daniele da Volterra mentioned by Vasari (now in a unnamed Swedish Collection) which represents Mercury bidding Aeneas to depart from the couch of Dido (see Belvedere, 1927, pp. 142-143, figs. 1 and 2). Undoubtedly the drawing served for the picture but it is not by the hand of the painter, as it has all the dynamic ponderousness of the aged Michelangelo, as well as his tricks and mannerisms of notation at that period. Daniele reduced it to something sleek, half elegant, half brutal. Why should he draw so differently from the way he paints? He does not even quite transfer the drawing, but the two principal figures are much more vertical, more "classical" in the bad sense, than Michelangelo ever is. I know no drawing plausibly ascribed to Daniele that offers a justification for this attribution. What we have here is a note made by Michelangelo for one of his parasites, in this case Daniele da Volterra. This, by the way, is a flagrant instance of the attribution of a drawing because it corresponds to shapes in a painting.
BB_1903_text_verso: Same as 1938 and added:  The arrangement suggests the Laocoon.
Cataloguer's Comments: Handwritten comment in BB_1903: "cf. Daniele da Volterra np. Belvedere. 59".

BB_1961_title_recto: Schizzo, in origine assai affrettato, ed ora quasi svanito, forse per una Caduta di Fetonte
BB_1961_title_verso: Rapido contorno di una figura che corre verso destra, probabilmente per lo stesso scopo
BB_1938_title_recto: Al almost effaced and original hasty sketch perhaps for a Fall of Phaeton
BB_1938_title_verso: Rapid linear indication of figure running to right, probably for the same purpose

BB_1961_title_recto: Ercole, in profilo a destra, stringe contro il proprio torace Anteo che, sollevato da terra, punte le gambe e le braccia per divincolarsi dalla stretta
BB_1961_title_verso: Tracce di contorni della medesima composizione, ma ove Anteo è trasformato in femmina, probabilmente eseguiti da una mano posteriore
BB_1938_title_recto: Small sketch for a Hercules and Antaeus. Hercules is seen in profile to right, holding the giant, who struggles with his legs and arms to get away
BB_1938_title_verso: Tracing outlines of same composition probably by a later hand, with Antaeus turned into a female

BB_1961_title_recto: Satiro seduto in profilo a sinistra con la mano sinistra sul fianco e il gomito destro appoggiato al ginocchio e un nudo femminile chinato verso terra in atto di zappare
BB_1961_title_verso: Due piedi in profilo a sinistra, quello in alto a carboncino, quello in basso, su scala maggiore, a penna
BB_1938_title_recto: Satyr seated in profile to left, with left arm akimbo and right elbow resting on knee. Also a nude female bending to ground hoeing
BB_1938_title_verso: Two feet one in black chalk and a larger and inferior one in ink
BB_1938_text_recto: A delightful early sketch, no later than the Bathers, the satyr laid in with black chalk and finished elaborately with the pen, the female in little more than outline with the pen
BB_1938_text_verso: A warning to students who make too much of mere pen-work which here as calligraphy is close to the master. As for the figures on the recto they may be by Michelangelo but I am no longer sure of it. The satyr and small pen-drawings may be by "Andrea di Michelangelo". On the other hand, the proportions of the female are those in Battista Franco's Noli me tangere. This figure was used by the author of the drawing at Chantilly for the fresco representing Ceres at Fontainebleau that Dimier in his book on Primaticcio ascribes to that decorator.

BB_1961_title_recto: Una Santa di aspetto classico e di portamento eretto, si volta a destra con le mani giunte in preghiera, verso un Santo che potrebbe essere San Pietro, mentre dal lato opposto è inginocchiato un giovane orante altre indicazioni più rapide di una figura in atteggiamento simile
BB_1961_title_verso: Due figure ammantate, in profilo a destra, protese a fissare davanti a loro
BB_1938_title_recto: Female, of classical aspect and erect carriage, turns with hands folded in prayer to saint, perhaps Peter beside her kneels a young man in adoration also more rapid indications of figure in similar attitude
BB_1938_title_verso: Draped youth in profile to right, stooping as he walks
BB_1938_text_recto: Suggests some such figure as the Masaccio-Pesellinesque verso of my 1602 behind outlines of older person in same attitude. Looks like copy after an earlier master. The two males on the recto would suggest Masaccio, yet neither the slenderness nor the drapery of the female recalls him but rather Fra Filippo and Pesellino. Recto and verso may reproduce right and left of some oblong composition.
BB_1903_text_recto: Certainly a youthful copy after an earlier master. The two males would suggest Masaccio, but neither the slenderness nor the drapery of the female recalls that master - at least as we know him at present.

BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane nudo, di proporzioni quasi egizie, che avanza barcollando verso destra con la testa buttata all'indietro
BB_1961_title_verso: Scarabocchi per diverse figure, una delle quali femminile in vari atteggiamenti
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude youth, of almost Egyptian proportions, staggering forward with head thrown back
BB_1938_title_verso: Scrawls for several figures, one of them female, in various attitudes
BB_1938_text_recto: Ascribed to Giulio Romano, but near enough to such early drawings by Michelangelo - as, for instance, the Louvre sketch for the bronze David (my 1585) - to demand mention and possibly connected with the cartoon for the bathers
BB_1938_text_verso: Too unintelligible to be attributed to any one. Four lines of script close to Michelangelo's early writing but stiffer. Above them appear the lower ends of letters showing that the leaf has been cut.
BB_1903_text_recto: Ascribed to Giulio Romano, but near enough to such early drawings by Michelangelo - as, for instance, the Louvre sketch for the bronze David (n. 1585) - to merit mention, at least, among the drawings of his followers.

BB_1961_title_recto: Sette teste grottesche
BB_1938_title_recto: Seven grotesque heads
BB_1938_text_recto: This is a drawing of somewhat earlier date, I should judge, but of the same kind as the one in the British Museum. Morelli consistently ascribed this one also to Bacchiacca
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: Some such head as the one on the left – scarcely a grotesque at all – must have inspired Sebastiano when sketching his head of Leo X at Chatsworth; bust considered as mere draughtsmanship, I should not compare even that head with this one – and Bacchiacca was not Sebastiano – far from it.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio di panneggio per una figura in piedi lievemente girata a destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Draped figure, already catalogued as by Granacci under my 984, and the hatching is there described as: "remarkably close to that of the very young Michelangelo"
BB_1938_text_recto: Looking at this hatching again in October, 1911, I concluded that it was Michelangelo's own and I confirmed this conclusion in February, 1929. In 1934, while rereading Vasari's Life of Michelangelo, A came across a passage that I had forgotten (VII, p. 139) which may be paraphrased as follows: "As it happened that one of the young men who were learning with Domenico (Ghirlandajo) had with the pen drawn certain draped female figures after originals by the master, Michelangelo snatched the sheet and with a coarser pen redrew one of these figures with outlines of his own and in the way it should stand if it was to stand properly. It is a wonder to see the difference between the two ways of drawing, and the quality and sense of youth so spirited and sure of himself that he felt he could improve the work of his master. This sheet is now in my possession, treasured as a relic, for it was given me by Granacci to place it in my book of drawings along with others that Michelangelo had given him. In 1550 Giorgio (Vasari) being then in Rome showed it to Michelangelo who recognized it and was glad to see it again and added in all humility that he was a better draughtsman as a boy than he was now as an old man." It would be rash to conclude that the drawing before us is the same that Vasari had in mind in the passage just quoted. For one thing he speaks of a female figure and this one is rather masculine. On the other hand Ghirlandajo's youths (of one of which this is a copy) and particularly when, as in this case, the head is missing, can almost as well pass for one sex as for the other. Add the probability that the drawing was first done by Granacci, who thus would be the young apprentice of the above narrative, that it was he who gave it later to Vasari, the possibility that this is the image described is by no means to be excluded, particularly as Vasari's descriptions seldom sin through precision. Even if this is not the identical sheet, it must be of the same kind and date, and if we admit that the hatching is by Michelangelo on a drawing after Ghirlandajo by an apprentice of the latter it furnishes diagrammatic, indeed almost geometrical, proof that the same Ghirlandajo and no other was the master who taught the youthful Michelangelo how to draw and formed his style as a draughtsman. Needless to say that this pen-hatching may be the earliest trace of Michelangelo's work that has come down to us.
Cataloguer's Comments: See n. 984: the drawing is already catalogued as by Granacci.
Cataloguer's Question: The drawing is by Michelangelo and Granacci

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile seduto su un parapetto, che si gira all'indietro verso destra
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo virile seduto in contrapposto che tira su la gamba destra tenendo il piede nella mano destra; in direzione capovolta, nudo simile su scala minore; quattro studi di gambe
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for a figure in the famous cartoon of the Bathers . Showing us the back of his head, he turns to the right to climb onto the bank, one leg already touching it, the other hanging over
BB_1938_title_verso: Various rough sketches of legs and two male nudes seated, all for the Bathers, the nudes being just possibly a first idea for the man putting on his hose. The legs were perhaps for the group of the two soldiers one of whom is helping the other fasten on his armour
BB_1938_text_recto: In Agostino Veneziano's engraving after part of the cartoon this figure occurs in the exact position he has here. The sketch on the recto has been worked over more than a little, which fact doubtless accounts for much in it that is unsatisfactory but, restorations apart, it could never have had that decision, that freedom, that complete mastery which we should expect to find in a drawing by Michelangelo for his greatest achievement in draughtsmanship. Yet we must swallow our disappointment. Relatively tame and anxious as is the execution of this nude, it would yet be rash to jump to the conclusion that it is not Michelangelo's. The fine close hatching is most characteristic of him, and while it is true that from him we should have expected more, who else working in this style is there from whom we expect so much?
BB_1938_text_verso: The sketches on the back are still less satisfactory. I hesitate to say they are not by Michelangelo although I should prefer to believe they were by a pupil drawn over faint and no longer visible indications by the master.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: The sketches on the back are also of unquestionable authenticity.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio di una gamba sinistra flessa e visibile dal ginocchio in giù e su scala maggiroe, piede sinistro disegnato sopra il ginocchio di quella gamba
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for left leg and for foot pushing against knee of same leg
BB_1938_text_recto: Kind and quality of my 1399C. Apparently for the Day in the Medici Tombs.

BB_1961_title_recto: Gamba destra di una figura seduta in profilo a destra con vaghe indicazioni del torso e sotto la coscia, di mano di Michelangelo, la parola "in fuora"
BB_1961_title_verso: Torso virile che presuppone una posa eretta con ambo le braccia tirate in alto
BB_1938_title_recto: Leg of figure seated in profile to right. Of the figure the torso only is indicated, and that but vaguely. Under the leg is written in fuora
BB_1938_title_verso: Torso of erect figure with shoulder and beginning of arms suggesting the possibility of it's being connected with the Haman
BB_1938_text_recto: This is a leaf of fairly early date.
Cataloguer's Comments: Handwritten in BB_1938: "Under the leg is written in fuora".

BB_1961_title_recto: Torso virile quasi in profilo verso destra e il medesimo torso ripetuto a semplice contorno
BB_1938_title_recto: Torso of figure standing and facing nearly to right, and the same in scrawled outline
BB_1938_text_recto: This may be a study for the soldier in the Bathers who helps his friend to buckle his armour, or indeed for the Adam in the Sixtine fresco of the Temptation of Eve, and, at all events, is of that early period (much more probably the soldier).
Cataloguer's Comments: Handwritten in BB_1938: "much more probably the soldier".

BB_1961_title_recto: Due acrobati ignudi che ne sorreggono un terzo pure ignudo, in piedi sulle loro mani perpendicolarmente ad essi un nudo di proporzioni quasi colossali, seduto con un fanciullo fra le ginocchia. Gli acrobati a carboncino, l'altro gruppo a penna veros: Ripetizione dell'acrobata a destra sul recto due putti, l'uno visto di fronte, l'altro da tergo, identici a quelli su BB n. 1481 verso e, in direzione opposta, uno splendido studio per l'écorché d'una gamba sinistra e sopra, un interessante quartina di un sonetto. L'acrobata a carboncino e il resto  a penna
BB_1938_title_recto: Two nude acrobats holding erect in their hands a third, also nude at one side of the sheet an almost colossal nude with a child between his knees - a study for the Bruges Madonna
BB_1938_title_verso: A repetition of the acrobat on the recto, two putti exactly like those on the back of the drawing to be catalogued next, and in inverse direction a splendid study from the écorché of a left leg, and above it four lines of an interesting sonnet. These reprinted in Frey's Dichtungen, XXII. The acrobats and the nudes on the back are in black chalk, the remainder in ink
BB_1938_text_recto: The sketch of the acrobats represents perhaps an earlier stage of a drawing in the Louvre, than which, however, it is much more spirited and prompt. A kindred motive occurs in the Oxford drawing (my 1564) for the Sixtine fresco of the Brazen Serpent. The proportion of the Madonna have already the heroic athletic character of the Last Judgement period and should serve as a warning against considering only one factor in the problem of dating drawings. But for the Child many students might have been tempted to assign this nude to the fourth rather than the first decade of the 16th century. As for the acrobats it now seems that they represent an earlier idea for the Bathers where two soldiers were to have held up a third who was to find out from which side the enemy was coming. Adolfo Venturi (M., pl. 45 and pl. 32) has before me reached this conclusion. Cf. Also my 1481 and 1598 as for same composition. In that case the study of a left leg which occurs on the recto of this sheet and on my 1598 would be for the right leg of the soldier who is being held up, only that it is reversed.

BB_1961_title_recto: Figura femminile, piuttosto informe, seduta all'indietro, con le braccia in due posizioni, strette al corpo o appoggiate a un parapetto
BB_1938_title_recto: Reclining almost shapeless nude female
BB_1938_text_recto: A blurred scrawl interesting chiefly as notation done perhaps in connection with lunettes of the Ceiling. To be compared with my 1463 verso, and probably of that date.

BB_1961_title_recto: Slanciato nudo virile con i capelli ricciuti ed arruffati che accenna a destra col braccio sinistro alzato, mentre cammina in direzione opposta, scarabocchi e scritti vari, fra cui un verso autografo
BB_1961_title_verso: Otto studi di putti in pose diverse e in vari gradi di rifinitura; due schizzi semicancellati (a carboncino), l'uno forse per la "Madonna di Bruges", l'altro per una figura col braccio destro alzato; le parole, di mano di Michelangelo, "Lessandro manecti" e la scritta due volte ripetuta da altra mano contemporane "chostì di brugis"
BB_1938_title_recto: Slender nude with straggling curly hair turning sharply to right with left arm held out while he walks in opposite direction. The chest and abdomen are elaborately hatched: the legs are barely sketched, the right arm not even indicated. The other arm is thin and long, like the one for the David in the Louvre drawing (my 1585). Also a leg of putto slightly indicated in black chalk, and the first lines of a sonnet written in sprawling chalk
BB_1938_title_verso: Eight separate putti in different attitudes and in various degrees of finish. Near one the the putti are the words in Michelangelo's hand: "Lessandro manecti." The inscription in another but contemporary hand, "chostì di brugis", is repeated twice, once beside a putto in profile to right, and again a close to one who is seen nearly full face.
BB_1938_text_recto: There is nothing in either peculiarly close to the putto in the Bruges Madonna. One of them is close to the infant Baptist in the Royal Academy tondo. It is interesting to note that there is a strong resemblance between these putti and Desiderio's famous marble one at S. Lorenzo. The nude on the recto seems (1934) connected with the group of three figures in my 1479 and 1598, which must have been meant for the Bathers. And as on the verso of my 1479 there are drawings for putti and on the recto a full sketch for the Bruges Madonna, the almost contemporary writing referring to Bruges on this sheet would indicate that the putti here as well, although never used, were drawn while Michelangelo was thinking about the composition of the Bruges Madonna.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: Still Sir Charles Robinson's ingenious suggestion (“Michelangelo and Raffaello”, Oxford, p. 323) that this inscription may be by Antonio Mini deserves a modified consideration. Mini's the hand certainly is not, but some other assistant might have got the information from Michelangelo. It is just possible that these putti were general studies with no view to any one particular work, although closer to the two marble tondi than to anything else, and dating no doubt from a time two or three years preceding the commencement of the Sixtine Ceiling. The two, however, in profile to right, and two others in almost similar position were, if not drawn for the Giovannino in the Royal Academy tondo, at all events used for that figure. One of them has a pouch or bowl hanging from his girdle exactly as in the bas-relief. It should be noted finally that there is a strong resemblance between these putti and Desiderio's famous marble one at S. Lorenzo.
Cataloguer's Comments: Handwritten in BB_1938: "the first lines of a sonnet written in sprawling chalk. Cf. Frey Handzeichnungen n. 91-2".

BB_1961_title_recto: Mezza figura di giovane donna seduta dal tipo altero di Sibilla e sul suo grembo un minuscolo nudo piegato in avanti a destra, che sembra lillipuziano, ma fu ovviamente disegnato prima
BB_1961_title_verso: Mezza figura di giovane donna girata di tre quarti verso sinistra, dalle fattezza e dall'espressione assai più gentili della sua sorella sul recto
BB_1961_text_verso: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: vers[1938: Oggi sono convinto che la data di questo foglio è assai più tarda (ca. 1530) e la sua affinità con le "teste divine" da me raggruppate sotto il nome di "Andrea di Michelangelo" mi rende sospettoso circa l'attribuzione a Michelangelo stesso, soprattutto della più gentile donna sul verso].
BB_1938_title_recto: Haughty sibyl-like young woman, seated and visible down to below the knees. A nude, in much smaller proportions bending forward to right, seems to stand like a Liliputian in her lap, but was doubtless drawn first. Sketched in with red chalk and then freely with the pen
BB_1938_title_verso: Young woman seen to below waist. She turns somewhat to left, has refined features, and a much gentler expression than her sister on the obverse
BB_1938_text_recto: This is perhaps as near an approach to portraiture as we shall ever find Michelangelo making. Very striking is the height of the cranium, a characteristic also of the Madonna in the Pietà at St. Peter's. The features and the look, however, bring this drawing nearer to the time of the Sixtine Ceiling. The stroke points to a date somewhat earlier than these frescoes, and recalls such a drawing as the one at Oxford of soldiers conversing (my 1545). In his exemplary study on the early career of Michelangelo, Wölfflin (Die Jugendwerke des Michelangiolo, Munich, Ackermann, pp. 61 and 63) dates this head 1505. It certainly is no earlier, and perhaps somewhat later
BB_1938_text_verso: I leave this as it was written thirty-five years ago and but for the dating, which is certainly later, it may still stand. What I now feel and think may be read in Appendix XV.

BB_1961_title_recto: Parte di un sistema decorativo che mostra, entro un pennacchio, una figura maschile, su un trono affiancato, alla sommità, da circoli iscritti in riquadri e sormontato d aun grande rombo con le quattro punte infilate in rotelle a destra, due studi di mani e due di braccia
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio di panni sulle ginocchia di una figura seduta e piccolo schizzo di giovane seduto, leggermente drappeggiato
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: Tolnay collega la mano sinistra con la lunetta di "Manasses-Amon" e (come il Thode) la mano destra e i due studi per il braccio destro con l'Ignudo sopra la Sibilla Persica.  Che siano aggiunte posteriori, non è improbabile.
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for scheme of decoration. In a spandrel a throne where sits a male figure. To right and to left are circles framed in squares, and above the throne a diamond tipped with smaller circles. Part of sheet is taken up by two sketches of hands, one of a whole arm, and another of part of an arm
BB_1938_title_verso: Cast of drapery, and a youthful slightly draped figure done perhaps from the model, and probably intended for one on the Ceiling
BB_1938_text_recto: Frey (see Text, p. 26) suggests that the hands and arms may be studies for the left arm of Adam in his Creation. In that case they would have been added later, which is not improbable. Although the intention of this study for decoration for the Sixtine Ceiling, which Michelangelo perhaps actually began, and then gave up as being "too slight and mean." Wölfflin was the first - and for some time the only one - to realize its purpose and importance. I refer the student to his brief but pithy article in the Jahr. Pr. K. S. (XIII, 1892, pp. 178-182), where he makes also a most interesting attempt to reconstruct the chapel as it would have looked if this scheme of decoration had been carried out.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: Symonds, thereby giving a proof of his radical incompetence in matters artistic, so thoroughly misunderstood it as to suppose that it had some connection with the New Sacristy at S. Lorenzo. (…) The Hands and arms, although doubtless also drawn with reference to the Sixtine Ceiling, are not to be discovered there now. The nearest approaches to them will be found in the old man above Pope Pontianus, and in the woman of the triangle over this lunette.
Cataloguer's Question: I added two phrases in column Y and I separate them with (?)

BB_1961_title_recto: Torso virile
BB_1961_title_verso: Tre giovani nudi seduti in pose contorte come tirassero corde; a sinistra, un nudo virile genuflesso che solleva il braccio destro ad arco sopra la sua testa
BB_1938_title_recto: Three separate studies of beautiful nude youths sitting, of whom two are pulling at ribbons at one side a kneeling figure with his bent arm held up
BB_1938_title_verso: Male torso
BB_1938_text_recto: Manifestly studies for the various single figures of nudes in the Sixtine Ceiling, none of these three is to be found there exactly as it appears here. The nearest resemblance is between the uppermost one in the sketch and the youths in the monochrome space above the painted arch over Rehoboam. The kneeling figure should be compared with the Cupid at S. Kensington. It has a pentimento. At firs the nude was kneeling on both his knees, then on the right only. In going over with ink the kneeling on both knees was emphasized. Certainly this sketch is as close to the Cupid as any of the other figures on this sheet are to the Sixtine nudes. Yet I would not vouch for it that Michelangelo, while drawing it, had in mind the Cupid rather than one of the crouching or kneeling nudes in the Ceiling. One fact, at all events, is established by this leaf: that the Cupid belongs to the period and style of the Sixtine nudes
BB_1938_text_verso: The male torso on the back of this leaf is unexpected. It is of a lifeless seated figure, the head, arms and legs slightly indicated - probably for a Dead Christ. If I had encountered this study by itself, it would scarcely have occurred to me question that I belonged to no earlier period than the Last Judgement. There is something of the late bravura in the forms and spirit, and there is also the loose, careless touch of later years. But at the same time it should be observed that in rapid and large chalk sketches Michelangelo differs little from epoch to epoch - too little, at all events, for ready distinction - so that it is probable that this almost Baroque sketch was done at the same time as the exquisite flowers of Quattrocento art on the other side. A careful comparison with the study for Dead Christ in the Casa Buonarroti will change this probability into certainty. The advanced aspect may further be accounted for, in part at least, by the softness of the chalk and the rapidity of the stroke. It is by no means uncommon for an artist thus to anticipate some later phase of his own style. Steinmann (II, p. 594) goes so far as to say that the torso was done for the Slave over the Sibylla Delphica. While not excluding the possibility, there yet is a definite pathos here which, to my feeling, would only suit a Dead Christ. Why shouldn't Michelangelo in a moment of listlessness or fatigue or mere leisure during his work on Ceiling have planned to do a Dead Christ, a subject, be it remembered, that preoccupied him through the whole length of his career? In the Ca' d'Oro there is a Dead Christ upheld by two angels in which the Saviour corresponds so well with this torso that one cannot but suppose that the artist, Pordenone as it happens, must have been acquainted with a picture done after this drawing; for he is not so likely to have known the drawing itself.
Cataloguer's Comments: Recto and verso are inverted in BB_1961 and BB_1938

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio di panni per una figura seduta con le gambe accavallate, in profilo a destra
BB_1961_title_verso: Rapido appunto per il sistema decorativo della volta della Cappella Sistina. Per un nudo decorativo in profilo a destra, altro nudo schizzato vagamente su scala minore e mano simile alla mano sinistra della Sibilla Eritrea
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch for a prophet on the Ceiling, but for an early phase of that work, and not executed
BB_1938_title_verso: Rapid sketch for a decorative nude in profile to right, also for the Ceiling, and smaller and vaguer sketch for another of these nudes. Also a hand recalling the left hand of the Erythraea
BB_1938_text_recto: He sits with his knees crossed in profile to right in an attitude recalling the Erythraean Sibyl. Badly worked over with the pen and bistre wash, this figure at first seems like a pupil's copy. Careful study convinces me, however, that the outlines in black chalk and some of the pen hatching are Michelangelo's.

BB_1961_title_recto: Sopra fitti disegni architettonici (a sanguigna e a penna leggera), grande studio di una figura seduta con le braccia appoggiate a un cubo a sinistra, ma il volto girato in profilo a destra, mentre un putto sta in piedi davanti al cubo
BB_1961_title_verso: Metà destra di una cerimonia ecclesiastica. Opera di un artista fiorentino raffaellesco
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for the Isaiah. He sits slightly reclining, with his right elbow and left hand resting on a pedestal on the left, his face is in profile to right. A nude putto stands beside him. This is one of Michelangelo's most interesting pen-drawings
BB_1938_title_verso: Sketch for an ecclesiastic ceremonial by some Raphaelesque Florentine
BB_1938_text_recto: Steinmann (II, p. 600) was the first to protest against the accepted designation of the figure on the recto as sketch for the Isaiah. His arguments why it should have been intended for a Sibyl are not conclusive, although the arm lightly outlined on the right seems to belong to a female rather than to a male. Perhaps the solution to propose is something like this: the arm just mentioned may have belonged to a figure with a certain attitude and expression that Michelangelo had not yet decided to give to any person in particular. It may even have been of indeterminate sex. The it occurred to him that it best suited his idea of the Prophet Isaiah it underwent further modifications before it was painted.

BB_1961_title_recto: Due studi di un nudo virile appeso a un albero nello studio a sinistra egli si contorce ancora vivo, nell'altro abbandona la testa nella morte
BB_1938_title_recto: First sketch for the Haman in the Sixtine Ceiling
BB_1938_text_recto: Perhaps the most rapid and spirited of all Michelangelo's drawings, surpassing even the earlier sketch (my 1585) for the bronze David, with which, by the way, it should be compared by any one inclined to doubt its authenticity. He might also look at the sheet (my 1481) with the nude youth on the obverse, and the putti on the reverse. An admirable bit of shorthand is the corkscrew scrawl which renders with the same stroke both the roundness and roughness of the tree-trunk. The action of the upper figure anticipates the Bound Captive (now in the Louvre), upon which Michelangelo was working two or three years later, in 1513. It also should be noticed how perfected already in this figure is Michelangelo's favourite attitude as it occurs so frequently later, one leg stretched out and the other bent at the knee as in the Tityus.

BB_1961_title_recto: Torso e cosce di un piccolo nudo virile seduto perpendicolarmente ad esso, informe busto di giovane e, in direzione capovolta, un'anfora linee di scrittura per tutti i versi
BB_1961_title_verso: Trentuno linee di scrittura
BB_1938_title_recto: Torso and legs only of a small nude figure seated vertically to the torso the bust of a youth as if in rough cast and opposite to last an urn. Also, in every direction, writing, most of it scratched out, and the rest of no interest
BB_1938_text_recto: I have no idea of the purpose of these sketches. The nude might conceivably  be connected with the angels in the Creation of Adam, but this is not probable. It is of the exact kind of a nude for a Crucifixion at Christ Church (my 1574).

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo atletico disteso con le braccia ripiegate dietro il dorso, che si contrae nello sforzo di liberarsi, premendo forte la gamba sinistra contro la coscia
BB_1938_title_recto: Athletic nude with arms tied behind struggling to get free, but bent nearly double with the effort, the left leg pressed hard under the thigh
BB_1938_text_recto: This rapid but masterly sketch, which has all the essential qualities of Michelangelo's feeling and touch, must have been meant for the figure of a slave - perhaps for the one we now see in the Victory of the Palazzo Vecchio - intended for the Tomb of Julius. The attitude suggests certain of the decorative nudes in the Sixtine Ceiling. This, among other considerations, leads up to place it between the completion of the frescoes and the commencement of the plans for the façade of S. Lorenzo. But the way of indicating the contours with curving lines which cross one another is singular, and exactly paralleled in only one other drawing, and that of the period of the Last Judgement, namely a leaf in the British Museum (my 1508), with a study among others perhaps for a scene in Dante's Purgatorio. This consideration need, however, not disturb us in assigning the sketch to an earlier date. Michelangelo's technique and stroke change little in the course of lifetime.
