The only "fool-proof" indication of date that I venture to name is that in no drawing earlier than the Cavalieri series does Michelangelo attempt to model with an effect of rubbing.

BB_1961_title_recto: Tre volti satireschi, a sinistra, vago accenno di testa, probabilmente pure di Michelangelo nell'angolo inferiore destro, rapido schizzo per un Ercole e Anteo
BB_1961_title_verso: Due nudi atletici che guardano in su, alzando aste; a sinistra, vago schizzo di una figura in azione simile; in alto i contorni di uno scudo e in basso, in direzione perpendicolare, una testa
BB_1938_title_recto: Three faces of satyrs. Studies doubtless for grotesque heads, such as we now see in the marbles at St. Lorenzo, but dating perhaps a few years earlier, and intended perhaps for the Tomb of Julius. Also a rapid sketch for a Hercules and Antaeus. On the left of the sheet is a vaguer indication of a head, probably also Michelangelo's
BB_1938_title_verso: Two athletic nudes looking up, to our left vague indication of a figure in similar action, and in black chalk other grotesque heads
BB_1938_text_recto: As grotesque, these heads vie with any others, ancient - which inspired them - or modern. The way of mapping out the features should be compared with the stroke in the sketch for the slave, last catalogued. The shading is characteristic. The touch throughout is free and firm. Nevertheless, Morelli would ascribe this sheet to Bacchiacca! (Kunstchr., 1891-92, p. 212)
BB_1938_text_verso: The nudes are among Michelangelo's noblest achievements, both as draughtsmanship and as design. They nearly face one another, starting forward with staves in their hands, each holding up an arm, and looking up as if to ward off an assault threatening them from above. The actual drawing is not infallibly correct, bust is of scarcely surpassable swiftness and vigour.

BB_1961_title_recto: Semplici contorni, buttati giù alla svelta, di due aspetti di una figura inginocchiata nella posa della "Madonna Doni", ma con le braccia nella posizione tenuta dall'Eterno nella "Separazione della luce dalle tenebre" sulla volta della Cappella Sistina. Le teste sono appena accennate le misure in braccia sono annotate in diversi punti
BB_1961_title_verso: Linee di scrittura
BB_1938_title_recto: Mere outlines, rapidly jotted down, of two aspects of a figure kneeling in the attitude of the Doni Madonna, but with the arms in the position held by the Eternal in the separation of Light from Darkness in Sixtine Ceiling. The heads are barely indicated. Measurements in braccia are noted down at various points
BB_1938_text_recto: Meder (Handz., p. 364, fig. 139) and Popp (M.K., p. 146) have noticed that these sketches are not, ad I thought, for two different statues, but for one seen in two different ways, once frontally and once in profile. This scrawl gains value from its obvious intention. Evidently it was one of the many sketches sent to the stonecutters at Carrara or Seravezza to guide them in blocking out the figures quarried at Michelangelo's orders. Of such drawings there is frequent mention in the contracts and correspondence between the artist and the workmen. It would be of high interest to discover which statue was to be fashioned out of the marble to be thus rough hewn. I have looked through the contracts and letters between Michelangelo and the stonecutters in the hope of finding a correspondence between the measurements in the drawing and any of those given there but in this again I have had no success. Popp (M. K., pp. 145-46) fancies that it may have been for the river gods and of later date. My impression is that this sketch should be dated about 1520. Before leaving it, just a word more. Here we have a drawing which was done with as much unconsciousness of aesthetic intention as is the writing itself. Yet its quality as touch, even as expression of function, is of the highest. I would have this brought to the attention of writers who attribute to Michelangelo such idiot-drawings as the one in the Uffizi for the Tomb of Julius, on the ground that in work of this nature there was no aesthetic intention, and that therefore its puerility does not exclude its being from Michelangelo's own hand. Now correct  draughtsmanship may doubtless have much to do with the artist's intention but the quality of touch, the life, the sparkle, the vibration have just as much to do with his intention as the shape of his head or the colour of his eyes. The age of discretion once attained, and dotage not yet reached, the great draughtsman cannot, if he would, draw lifelessly.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: But while the reclining figure might conceivably represent one at S. Lorenzo, the other has no relation to any statue of which I have been able to discover record. (…) A more diligent and intelligent research might however meet with the proper reward.
Cataloguer's Question: I added two phrases in column Y and I separate them with (?)

BB_1961_title_recto: Schizzi per il capitello di una colonna e cornici varie
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch for the capital of a column

BB_1961_title_recto: Matronale nudo femminile seduto lievemente verso sinistra, ma col viso quasi in profilo a destra, in atto di sostenere il Bambino che poppa vigorosamente stando a cavalcioni sul suo ginocchio a destra è abbozzata una testa di San Giuseppe e al di sotto è indicato a semplice contorno un San Giovannino nudo
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude, matronly female seated turning a little to her left, but her face almost in profile to right, with the Child firmly sketched the head of Joseph, and below it in mere outline the infant Baptiste nude
BB_1938_text_recto: This beautiful drawing, which is obviously for a Holy Family, commonly passes as a study for the marble Madonna in the New Sacristy at S. Lorenzo. In a certain sense that opinion is well founded, but I question whether, when Michelangelo was sketching this design, he already had in mind the sculptures of S. Lorenzo. With a view to these he went, as we know, on April 9, 1521, to Carrara, occupying the twenty days or so that he spent there in making sketches and models for this undertaking. A drawing for the Madonna as she actually was to be carved out of marble must have been ready on April 23, for on that day Michelangelo contracted for the necessary marble, and for the blocking out of his group. That drawing could not have been the one now before us. For one thing, it probably was a mere scrawl with measurements, like the one we have just examined in this collection. Then the divergence both in the movement and the action of the Virgin is too great, and the Joseph and infant John are composed pictorially, not sculpturally. In point of style and manner this sketch (the Madonna's hand still has the early form that we know in the Bargello tondo, and meet again in the fine sketch at Oxford for the child beside the Libyan Sibyl (my 1562)) is not far removed from a sheet in the Louvre drawn on both sides (my 1584), which contains on the front nudes carrying a corpse, and on the back a woman and children. Now that sheet is certainly related to the period of the Sixtine Ceiling, if indeed it was not to some extent intended for that work. Our Madonna, it should however be granted, can be placed three or four years later. Again, there are two other studies in which the same motive recurs with slight modifications. One is in the Louvre (my 1589 verso), the other in the Albertina (my 1603). But for many reasons these may not be dated as late as 1521, and should indeed be put back a number of years. The conclusion we must reach is that all these drawings, of which the one we are now examining probably was the latest, were executed without specific destination as studies for the Madonna suckling the Child, and that when Michelangelo came to work upon the sculptures for S. Lorenzo he made the agreeable discovery that these studies had advanced him on the road to the completion of the Madonna for that monument. I note (1934) sufficient likeness between this nude and the nude on my 1598B, which certainly is for the Sixtine Ceiling, to justify us in dating it from the end of that period or soon after.
Cataloguer's Comments: Handwritten comment in BB_1903: " and the Joseph and infant John are composed pictorially, not sculpturally".

BB_1961_title_recto: Piante, elevazioni ed altri studi per le Tombe Medicee nella Sagrestia Nuova di San Lorenzo
BB_1961_title_verso: Profilo a destra di un volto simile a una maschera mortuaria
BB_1938_title_recto: Plans, elevations, and studies for the Medici Tombs in the New Sacristy at S. Lorenzo. The most important features here are the following: on the upper right-hand a sarcophagus with a cover consisting of a circular slab resting on volutes, standing against a wall under a small square opening flanked by two tall niches. Then, on the left but lower down, the front and sides of a monument, each façade of which contains, as sculptural decoration, two nudes in full relief, clinging to a large slab which rests on a sarcophagus
BB_1938_title_verso: Profile to right of a face like a death mask
BB_1938_text_recto: The attitudes of these nudes vividly recall certain decorative figures in the Sixtine Ceiling. Of all the studies for the Medici Tombs with which I happen to be acquainted this is the earliest. It may indeed be earlier than the one - which surely must have been more elaborated, more of a show drawing - dispatched by Michelangelo to Cardinal de' Medici on November 23, 1520. At all events this sheet gives us some notion of how the monument, intended at first to have four sides, and to stand in the middle of the chapel, would have looked
BB_1938_text_verso: Slight but fine. Its purpose is unknown to me. Of course it suggests the Dying Slave (in the Louvre).

BB_1961_title_recto: Studi per le Tombe Medicee: progetto di sistemazione parietale per una doppia tomba, con due sarcofagi, contenenti figure adagiate nei coperchi concavi, di dignità fluviali inserite sotto i sarcofagi, una statua colossale in mezzo ad esso e uno sfondo che mostra incertezze e pentimenti. In alto, in direzione opposta, schizzo per la statua del Crepuscolo, quasi identico al marmo
BB_1961_title_verso: Studi per le Tombe Medicee: costruzione alta e stretta consistente, dal basso in alto, in un sarcofago a coperchio piatto, due nudi in piedi, appoggiati a un grande piedistallo quadrato, che fa da base a una nicchia, fiancheggiata da scomparti minori, con ghirlande; in direzione opposta, leggere indicazioni di un progetto con due sarcofagi, dal coperchio triangolare; perpendicolarmente ai due studi precedenti, un terzo progetto con un sarcofago dal coperchio a lunetta
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for the Medici Tombs. Certainly from Michelangelo's own hand, as the touch, the stroke, and the peculiar "shorthand" clearly prove. Two sarcophagi stand alongside. The cover of each, consisting of two shallow concave curves, supports a reclining figure. Under the sarcophagus on the left lies a river god. Between the sarcophagi on a pedestal a colossal figure stands erect against the wall. To right and left are windows or rather rectangular niches resting on supports. The one to the right is more elaborated. In the niche itself is the indication of a herma, and against its supports lean two nudes in smaller proportions than the other figure. The the wall forming this background was meant to have a certain thickness, and the monument a certain depth, may be inferred from the indication of figures at the sides. At the top of the sheet, but turned round, is a slight but clear sketch for the Twilight nearly as it was afterwards completed
BB_1938_title_verso: Sketch containing a sarcophagus, and above it a large pedestal with two figures leaning against it, and over it a window or rather niche. This, although it may be simply a study for one half of the monument on the other side, seems more probably a sketch for the four-square monument. Also ground-plan of a square with a sarcophagus on one of its sides
BB_1938_text_recto: Not only the plan, but, as well, the sketch going with it on the back, suggests a monument to stand free with four sides. But the more elaborated study on the front must have been made after that idea was given up, for the notion of two sarcophagi side by side was obviously not to be entertained in connection with a monument to stand in the middle of the sacristy. On the other hand, we are not forced to assume that the sketch for the Twilight necessarily implies that this sheet belongs to an advanced period of Michelangelo's labour over this monument. He may well have had the single figures clearly in mind from the very beginning. It was probably not these which gave him trouble, but the architectural and decorative design. Here the arrangement is still far from what finally was adopted. The likeness of the figures to those which probably existed in the scheme for the Tomb of Julius should be noted. It is interesting also to see how Michelangelo first intended to place the river gods.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per le Tombe Medicee, con due sarcofagi affiancati posti davanti a una parete articolata in tre scomparti quadrati inferiori e tre scomparti allungati superiori nell'ordine superiore, il tabernacolo centrale sormontato da una lunetta, contiene una statua seduta e i tabernacoli laterali, sormontati da occhi, contengono figure in piedi nell'ordine inferiore, il riquadro centrale contiene il leggerissimo schizzo della Fama, seduta a braccia spalancate, che tocca le lapidi infestonate nei riquadri laterali in basso si legge, di mano di Michelangelo: "La fama tiene gli epitafi a giacere / Non va né innanzi né indietro, / Perché son morti e e' loro operare è fermo"
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio per le Tombe Medicee, eguale a quello sul recto nelle linee fondamentali, ma meno lavorato e con la differenza che i riquadri inferiori contengono, invece delle lapidi, statue sedute in posizioni alquanto simili a quelle delle attuali statue dei Duchi. Manca la figura della Fama; mancano le figure nei tabernacoli laterali superiori e la statua seduta nel tabernacolo centrale è sostituita da una vaga figura allungata
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for the Medici Tombs. Two sarcophagi on a platform against a high background, consisting of a base in three divisions, and above it a high windowlike opening flanked by a niche on each side. In this opening appears a tall seated figure, and in each niche the indication of a standing one. At the bottom of the sheet is an inscription, not divided into lines, which I copy out of Prof. Frey's invaluable edition of Michelangelo's verse: "La fame tiene gli epitafi a giacere, / Non va né inanzi né indietro, / Perché son morti, e e' loro operare fermo."
BB_1938_title_verso: Two sarcophagi of the simplest possible kind, standing on a high platform against a wall in six divisions, the three below shorter, and forming a kind of base. In the upper middle division a scrawl to indicate the figure. Just above each sarcophagus a seated figure, and, I mistake not, the one at the right is Lorenzo, and the other Giuliano, in something like the attitudes that they now have
BB_1938_text_recto: This sheet, from Michelangelo's own hand, is a further study for the arrangement of the Tombs in pairs along the walls of the Sacristy. The sketch on the back is clearly for the monument of the two dukes. The destination of the other is less certain. I state as a mere possibility that it was for the monument to Lorenzo the Magnificent and his brother Giuliano, in which case the seated figure would represent the Madonna which is now placed over their tombs.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio architettonico per le Tombe Medicee, macchiato e confuso, ma forse il più interessante di tutti gli schizzi superstiti e certamente autografo: è un progetto di tomba parietale con un solo sarcofago su cui si adagiano due figure che ricordano l'Aurora e il Crepuscolo: le loro teste toccano la cornice sulla quale si ergono scomparti dello sfondo, uno quadrato al centro, due rettangolari ai lati, divisi da coppie di colonne o pilastri considerevolmente aggettanti la suddivisione continua nel fastoso coronamento con troni sopra le coppie di colonne, che separano la ricca panoplia al centro degli scomparti laterali, con figure accovacciate sotto ghirlande nel riquadro a sinistra del sarcofago è schizzata la figura seduta del Duca Giuliano, mentre in primo piano, sulla piattaforma in basso, giacciono due divinità fluviali
BB_1961_title_verso: Due urne e contorni di un nudo che si tocca la spalla alzando il braccio destro (a carboncino)e dieci righe di un madrigale (a penna)
BB_1938_title_recto: Study, blurred and blotted, but perhaps the most interesting of all the sketches for the Medici Tombs, and certainly from Michelangelo's own hand. On a pedestal rests a sarcophagus with two figures, recalling the Dawn and Twilight, reclining upon it. The heads of these figures are on a level with the top of the base, the one in the middle being a square, and the others flanking it as windows. Between each two divisions are two columns or pilasters projecting considerably. Above this order are three further divisions, decorated in high relief, the one in the middle with trophies, the one n the left with crouching figures. The top was to have been highly ornate. Below, on the platform, clear of the sarcophagus, lie two river gods. Against the left-hand division of the base we see the seated figure of Duke Giuliano
BB_1938_title_verso: Two urns, and outlines for a nude doubling his right arm up to his chin
BB_1938_text_recto: The resemblance of this sketch to the monument as finally left is so striking that one feels tempted to believe that this is one of the last drawings that Michelangelo made for the Tombs. But there are difficulties in the way of this idea. The greatest of these is the indication, to one side, of Giuliano. Lorenzo is not drawn, but we scarcely can conceive of Giuliano thus subordinately placed to one side, unless Lorenzo was to balance him on the other. Then if this was a monument to both the dukes, how is it that there is but one sarcophagus? There is moreover, no trace in contemporary records of a deliberate intention to break with the plan established toward the end of 1523 of having the sarcophagi in pairs. If it could, however, be assumed that this drawing was later, as one is certainly tempted to assume, then it would clearly witness to Michelangelo's final decision to have the arrangement pretty much what it is now. What alternative to suggest I scarcely know. Surely not that it is a sketch for the four-sided monument as first planned
BB_1938_text_verso: The nude may have had some connection with the Victory of the Palazzo Vecchio. Should that have been the case, then Michelangelo must have been working on this group while the plans for the Tombs were being settled. Also a number of lines of a madrigal published in Frey's Dichtungen, p. 15. A drawing clearly resembling the recto may have been known to the sculptor of the beautiful monument to a Duke of Montmorency (died 1652) at Moulins, translated of course in the severe forms of the most noble 17th century in France.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile, visto da tergo, che s'incammina verso destra
BB_1961_title_verso: Torso e coscia sinistra di un nudo semidisteso
BB_1938_title_recto: Male figure, seen from behind, walking away to right. The outlines have been gone over with a stilus, and the rest is somewhat rubbed
BB_1938_title_verso: Study for torso and left thigh of the Night in the Sacristy of S. Lorenzo
BB_1938_text_recto: This is of the exact quality of my 1548 and 1549. The attitude recalls as well the model for a river god, now in the Academy, discovered since the first publication of this book.

BB_1961_title_recto: Cinque studi per strutture simili ad archi trionfali, forse per un altare monumentale, ma non direi per quello della Sagrestia Nuova di San Lorenzo
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio di panneggio per una figura seduta verso destra e vago accenno di testa in profilo a destra
BB_1961_text_verso: versIl profilo non è certamente di Michelangelo. Il panneggio sembra suo.
BB_1938_title_recto: Several studies for structures like triumphal arches, conceivably, although not probably, for the altar in the New Sacristy of S. Lorenzo
BB_1938_title_verso: Cast of drapery for seated figure and a head in profile to right vaguely indicated
BB_1938_text_recto: Popp (M. K., pp, 169-170) makes the interesting suggestion that the drawings on recto may have served for the Tomb of Leo X in S. Maria Sopra Minerva.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per una porta sormontata da un blasone papale
BB_1961_title_verso: Quattro studi di porte o di finestre, una delle quali con stemma mediceo
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for window or door, with Medici arms
BB_1938_title_verso: Same, with papal blazon
Cataloguer's Comments: Recto and verso are inverted in BB_1961 and BB_1938

BB_1961_title_recto: Disegno per i podio della Tomba di Papa Giulio II, eseguito probabilmente nel 1526. Foglio mutilo a sinistra in basso
BB_1961_title_verso: Schizzi grossolani, di parecchi pezzi separati, per questo podio, con annotazioni verbali e misure
BB_1938_title_recto: Design for podium of Tomb of Julius, made probably in 1526
BB_1938_title_verso: Rough sketches, with verbal annotations and measurements of separate pieces of this podium
BB_1938_text_recto: Under the design is the following in the artist's own hand: Questo schizo e una parte della faccia dina(n)zi della sepultura el quale e tucto / finito di quadro e d intagli la qual parte e alta dalla terra alla prima corni / ce braccia sei e dall u(n) canto all altro di largeza braccia u(n)dici ed e di pezi / sessa(n)ta secte cho(n) que pezi segniati ch(e) u e su el numero. ed e messo i(n) / sieme in una sta(n)za che e in casa i(n) sul cortile nella quale / sta(n)za e dua ruote d u(n) carra ch(e) io feci fare e lasso el resto e / in un altra sta(n)za terrena i(n) casa i(n) roma."
Cataloguer's Comments: In bracket another inventory number: 1947.1.17.1

BB_1961_title_recto: Madonna seduta con la testa volta in profilo che abbraccia il Bambino appoggiato alla sua spalla sinistra in direzione opposta, Madonna seduta che guardo lo spettatore e abbraccia il Bambino appoggiato alla sua spalla destra: iscritto nell'angolo inferiore destro
BB_1961_title_verso: Due registrazioni di pagamenti scritti di mano di Michelangelo
BB_1938_title_recto: Two studies, in reversed order, for the Madonna and Child. In the one she is seen full face, while the Child looks away to the left in the order, almost the whole figure is given, seated, looking in profile to right at the Child
BB_1938_title_verso: Two records of payment written in Michelangelo's hand
BB_1938_text_recto: Both, particularly the one in profile, are curiously Donatellesque. These are simple drawings in pen and ink, done by Michelangelo to serve as models for Antonio Mini. Beside them we see the latter's attempts to copy them in red chalk. As he took service in December, 1523, and the date October 4, 1524, occurs on the back, it cannot be said that in the course of a year he had made great progress. His copies resemble certain primitive types of draughtsmanship - Aztec, let usa say. Michelangelo seems to have found his apprentice dawdling, and under his more wretched copy has written: "Disegnia Antonio /disegnia Antonio disegnia e no(n) p(er)der te(m)po"
Cataloguer's Question: For transcription  of Michelangelo's words I referred to BB_1961

BB_1961_title_recto: Pianta ed elevazione di una struttura a un piano, in forma di mezzo ottagono
BB_1938_title_recto: Plan and elevation of a one-storeyed octagonal structure
BB_1938_text_recto: Fine penmanship.

BB_1961_title_recto: Gigante nudo disteso col volto girato verso una figuretta nuda che gli si avvicina
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian except words between []
BB_1938_title_recto: Outline sketch for a giant reclining, and a smaller figure approaching him, doubtless a study for a Samson and Delilah
BB_1938_text_recto: This rapid jotting dates, to judge by the style, from about 1530. The same subject is treated by a pupil in large red chalk drawing at Oxford (my 1718), but there the arrangement is somewhat different. It has not escaped me that the larger figure corresponds to a surprising degree with the Venus designed in 1531 by Michelangelo, and coloured by Pontormo, now in the Uffizi. It might be said that rather than for a Samson this was a sketch for that Venus. I should answer that in the sketch the figure is male, and, what is more important, that the smaller figure is stealthily approaching the larger, whereas the subject of Pontormo's picture being Venus embraced by Cupid, Michelangelo would not have failed, even in the earliest jotting down of the motive, to indicate this action. As a matter of fact the two motives have much in common. For Michelangelo every subject became a problem in pose and action. Poses and actions are as limited as the letters of the alphabet and like them suffice for all the needs of any one artist even if he is a Michelangelo. In this case the figures lend themselves almost as well to one interpretation as to the other. Cf. My 1718. A design, by the way, independent of the cartoon for the Pontormo painting and representing Venus breaking Cupid's bow may have existed and antedated the cartoon. This design is represented in several slightly differing versions of a picture by Allori. One at Montpellier, one at the Uffizi and another at Hampton Court. It must have been known to Lotto when he did his Rospigliosi Triumph of Chastity no later than 1528.
Cataloguer's Question: See column N "except the word between []"

BB_1961_title_recto: Sezione di una cornice e capitello composito
BB_1961_title_verso: Colonne e trabeazioni
BB_1938_title_recto: Section of a cornice and capitals
BB_1938_title_verso: Columns and entablatures

BB_1961_title_recto: Sezione di una trabeazione
BB_1961_title_verso: Capitelli con variazioni di motivi ornamentali
BB_1938_title_recto: Section of a cornice
BB_1938_title_verso: Bases and capitals

BB_1961_title_recto: Resurrezione di Cristo
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: [1957: Nel suo dipinto al Fogg Museum di Cambridge, Marcello Venusti usò la figura del Cristo in questo disegno o forse copiò un'altra versione di esso, più elaborata, con guardie simili a quelle in BB n. 1612. Per altre copie di questa composizione vedi Wilde.]
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for a composition of Christ's Resurrection
BB_1938_text_recto: The most carefully thought-out and noblest of the designs for this subject. Here Christ floats away as in a dream, like a rising mist, and even the soldiers have less agitated attitudes. The greatest merit of this composition is, perhaps, its spaciousness and the pictorial intention is, for Michelangelo, singularly clear. If Sebastiano had put painted it, we should have had a picture of a solemnity and grandeur rivalling, if not surpassing, his matchless Pietà. The forms and the technique have all the characteristics of the Cavalieri and kindred drawings, and the date is therefore about 1533.

BB_1961_title_recto: Cristo che sorge dalla tomba. Egli scosta il coperchio col piede sinistro e china lo sguardo sui soldati stupiti o ancora addormentati, mentre accenna verso l'alto con la mano destra e regge lo stendardo nella sinistra
BB_1938_title_recto: Christ rising out of the tomb. He pushes the lid aside with His left foot, and looks down to right upon the amazed or still sleeping guards, while He points upward with His right hand, and holds the banner in His left
BB_1938_text_recto: His figure is fairly elaborated, but the others are in outline. The quality is excellent. The Christ, by the way, is but a more highly finished version of the one traced on the back of the Tityus at Windsor (my 1615).

BB_1961_title_recto: In alto, una Madonna col Bambino benedicente disteso nel suo grembo e la testa girata in profilo verso sinistra ove è posato un libro di preghiere che Ella sfoglia con la mano destra in mezzo alla pagina un gruppo di nudi meditabondi accovacciati per terra in basso, un nudo virile, o piuttosto un écorché di un nudo, ritto sopra una sola gamba altri scarabocchi meno interessanti qua e là
BB_1961_title_verso: Atletico nudo femminile, in piedi e simile nudo semidisteso come in un sonno agitato; intorno, cinque teste, una o due delle quali vicine al grottesco
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian except the last phrase: (BB n. 2252A), foglio che porta sull'altra faccia una figura allegorica, riferibile agli affreschi eseguiti a Careggi nel 1538-42.
BB_1938_title_recto: Sheet with various studies. A rapid sketch for a Madonna, in profile, with the Cupid lying in her lap. She turns the pages of a prayer book with her right hand. Below, a group of nudes reclining and brooding
BB_1938_title_verso: Athletic female nude standing, another reclining as if in troubled sleep, and several heads, one or two of them approaching the grotesque. Still lower on the sheet is a nude, or rather an écorché, standing on one leg. There are several less interesting scrawls here and there
BB_1938_text_recto: It is not impossible - for Michelangelo was a lifelong student of Dante, and is said even to have illustrated him - that these refer to the following lines in Purgatorio (canto IV, 103-108): "ed ivi eran persone / Che si stavano all'ombra dietro al sasso, / Com'uom per negligenza a star si pone. / Ed un di lor che mi sembrava lasso, / Sedeva ed abbracciava le ginocchia, / Tenendo il viso giù tra esse basso."
BB_1938_text_verso: This side is, as draughtsmanship, more interesting than the other, although both doubtless were done at the same time. The date should be about 1535, as in the firm outlines in hard chalk there is considerable resemblance to the MALCOLM drawing for the Last Judgement (my 1536). The feeling for form is the same as in that famous fresco, with this striking difference, that here it is colossal but firm and alive, and there colossal but frequently lacking the breath of life. The verso, at all events, of this sheet seems for power and touch, to be among Michelangelo's masterpieces, and perhaps the last wherein his hand retains all its pristine vigour. A drawing of exactly the same type and spirit as the one on the recto, but done a little earlier, must have inspired Pontormo when he sketched the Madonna on the verso of the Hamburg drawing (my 2252A), an allegorical figure made for Castello, the date of which we know to have been between 1528 and 1532.

BB_1961_title_recto: Leggero abbozzo per un nudo virile che si curva alzando le mani come per difendersi dalla minaccia di un colpo che gli giunga dall'alto
BB_1938_title_recto: Slight jotting of a nude

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile che avanza verso sinistra con le bracci alazate
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch of nude with arms thrown up, coming forward to left, no doubt for the Last  Judgement
BB_1938_text_recto: This figure, with slight change, occurs in the upper left-hand corner of the Malcolm sketch, for the great composition
Cataloguer's Question: In BB_1961 we find the number of the compared drawing, 1536 recto, but not in BB_1938

BB_1961_title_recto: Due nudi accovacciati o ruzzolanti con la testa in avanti. Anche questi, studi per il "Giudizio Universale"
BB_1938_title_recto: Two nudes crouching or tumbling head downwards, also for the Judgement

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio di un braccio destro piegato con la palma della mano aperta verso l'alto
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for right arm held up and the shoulder
BB_1938_text_recto: A rough sketch, perhaps for a figure in the Last Judgement, just above Peter's shoulder to right. At all events of that period.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile acefalo, seduto e visibile fino ai ginocchi, che punta l'indice sinistro verso una ferita nel costato e stende la mano destra come in atto di proteggere o di benedire il braccio destro e il ginocchio destro sono ripetuti a sinistra e in basso
BB_1961_title_verso: Torso arrovesciato all'indietro con la testa arretrata fra le braccia tese; in basso, ciò che sembra un pugno chiuso (ma è uno scorcio di testa disegnato in direzione opposta)
BB_1938_title_recto: Rough large study, in little more than outline, of seated male figure, without head or feet. His right hand is held out as if in protection or blessing, his left touches a wound in his side
BB_1938_title_verso: Scrawl for torso of figure in action, with head thrown back between extended arms. Below a balled-up hand
BB_1938_text_recto: The purpose of this uncouth sketch, is not clear. One feels that it must have been made with reference to the Last Judgement. But if for the Christ, as one is tempted to believe, it must have been for a softer conception than in the fresco and corresponding to the Bonnat drawing for the upper part of the composition (my 1395C). I cannot get over the feeling that the man who made this sketch was well acquainted with the famous Vatican torso
BB_1903_text_recto: The purpose of this uncouth sketch is not clear. One feels that if by Michelangelo at all – and that is fairly to be assumed – it must have been made with reference to the Last Judgment. Bust surely not for the Christ, as one is tempted to believe. I cannot get over the feeling that the man who made this sketch was well acquainted with the famous Vatican Torso.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per un gruppo di Marie piangenti, a sinistra, ai piedi della Croce
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for the Holy Women at the foot of the Cross - for the lower left-hand part of a Crucifixion
BB_1938_text_recto: The action is rendered admirably, but in the touch there is a certain hesitation - not so much in the outlines as in the shading. The date should be about 1535. This sketch, be it noted, has no connection with the series of studies for a Crucifixion done for Vittoria Colonna and later.

BB_1961_title_recto: Due studi di un Cristo che caccia i Mercanti dal Tempio
BB_1961_title_verso: In basso, schizzo per la metà destra di una Cacciata dei Mercanti dal tempio, con uno sfondo architettonico; in alto, e in direzione perpendicolare al primo, un abbozzo per la metà sinistra
BB_1938_title_recto: Christ expelling the Money-Changers from the Temple
BB_1938_title_verso: Sketch for the right side of the same, with indication of architectural background, and, separately at other end of sheet, jotting for the left side

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio di un Cristo che caccia i Mercanti dal Tempio
BB_1961_title_verso: Quattro singole figure per lo stesso tema del recto
BB_1938_title_recto: The same
BB_1938_title_verso: Single figures, and one group for the same

BB_1961_title_recto: Cristo caccia i Mercanti dal Tempio
BB_1961_title_verso: Studi di singole figure e di un gruppo per lo stesso tema del recto
BB_1938_title_recto: The same
BB_1938_title_verso: Single figures for the same
BB_1938_text_recto: These sketches of nude figures, loosely handled, and drawn, I should think, about 1545, were used by Marcello Venusti, who polished them up and waxed them down into a small picture, which the curious may admire at he National Gallery.

BB_1961_title_recto: Madonna - è difficile dire se nudo o drappeggiata - in piedi, ma leggermente piegata sui ginocchi, che tiene in collo il Bambino, il quale L'abbraccia con infinita tenerezza
BB_1938_title_recto: Study - it is hard to be sure whether of a nude or draped figure - for a Madonna bending slightly at knees, with the Child most fondly embracing her
BB_1938_text_recto: This figure, as action no less than as draughtsmanship, bears considerable resemblance to the Mary in the Crucifixion (my 1530). being even looser in manner, it may be dated about 1550.

BB_1961_title_recto: Vergine Annunciata che posa il libro a sinistra, sull'inginocchiatoio, volgendo la testa in profilo a destra verso l'Angelo, tagliato fuori dal foglio
BB_1961_title_verso: Schizzi vari, non autografi
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: [1959: Per l'Angelo Annunciante, che completava questa Vergine, vedi BB. n. 1534 verso.]
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for the Virgin in an Annunciation
BB_1938_text_recto: One of the finest recent acquisitions of the British Museum. There scarcely can be a doubt by Marcello Venusti for the Lateran. Only in the action of the torso does it differ from the finished work.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile in atto di sollevarsi da terra e due studi della sua mano destra
BB_1961_title_verso: Testa di ragazzo con berretto che guarda in su a destra
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added:  L'altra [19559: già nella raccolta Walter Gay ed ora al Louvre] è riprodotta ?
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of Adam in the Creation of Adam in the Sixtine Ceiling. The hands are repeated
BB_1938_title_verso: Head of boy in cap, looking to right - after one of the decorative nudes in the Ceiling
BB_1938_text_recto: In my first edition, while speaking of this drawing in highest terms, I did not assign it to Michelangelo himself and said that neither the planes nor the light and shade are such as my eyes are accustomed to discover in the master's genuine drawings. There are few sketches that we attribute to Michelangelo about which I now could say with absolute conviction that they are from the hand of the master and there are many more which in my heart of hearts I am equally disinclined to take away from him. This is the kind of drawing regarding which I find it impossible to decide. If not Michelangelo himself its author was all but as great a draughtsman and being such, and having nothing to do but copy what was before him, why should he fumble for the hands as he did so admirably in the lower left-hand corner? Fumbling on the part of an artist is natural enough when he is trying to think things out but hardly so when he is copying another draughtsman. So as lifelong experience has taught me to accept when in doubt rather than reject, I transfer this sheet from the school of Michelangelo to the body of his autograph drawings. It is not without significance that the two other versions of this study for the Adam, the we know, agree so exactly that each might pass for an accurate version of the other. One is in the Ingres Museum at Montauban and apparently unpublished. The other has been reproduced in the Burlington Magazine for June, 1935 (opp. p. 278), by Maurice Delacre, who claims that it is the original and the Burlington Magazine version a copy, perhaps a forgery. To my eye this version, belonging, by the way, to Mr Walter Gay of Paris, looks in the reproduction harder and more accentuated, and therefore the copy. Be that as it may be, the three versions in such perfect agreement go to prove that even if none of them is an autograph they accurately reproduce an original study by Michelangelo for the Adam.
BB_1938_text_verso: The head on the reverse of the Adam may be a copy of a discarded study by the master for the nude just under the right leg of the Adam, or possibly for the one with the cornucopia above the Adam and Eve in the Expulsion. On the Oxford sheet of heads made toward 1560-70 after drawings then believed Michelangelo's (my 1706) this head occurs but more elaborated, one cannot say whether after the sketch before us or after another, the autograph perhaps.
BB_1903_text_recto: Adam is a very interesting drawing, in many respect so excellent that one is tempted to give it the benefit of the doubt, and let it pass for Michelangelo's. But neither the planes nor the light and shade are such as my eye is accustomed to discover in that master's genuine drawings. It is more probably a copy after the fresco, made perhaps by the hand to which are due the British Museum copy after the Haman (n. 1690), and M. Valton's copy after a Slave (n. 1746). The head on the reverse of the Adam, which is probably by the same hand, is certainly not Michelangelo's.

BB_1961_title_recto: Busto di uomo dall'aspetto di satiro, nudo fuorché per un panno gettato sulla spalla destra, che volge la testa in profilo a sinistra, con occhi sgranati e selvaggi
BB_1938_title_recto: Bust of man with alert, wild look, in profile to left. But for drapery over the right shoulder he is nude
BB_1938_text_recto: A superb example of Michelangelo's style, no less splendid in conception than concise and masterful in execution. Note the modelling of the cheek-bone, the neck, the shoulder. Bronze itself could scarcely give greater firmness. The hatching is characteristic of the years just preceding the cartoon for the Bathers, and the date may be 1502 or 1503.

BB_1961_title_recto: A destra, uomo eretto, in profilo sfuggente verso destra, avvolto in un drappo che gli lascia scoperti un braccio e la spalle, col piede destro appoggiato su un gradino ed il gomito destro su un libro, che la mano sinistra regge sul ginocchio la stessa figura ripetuta a sinistra, ma nuda ed a solo contorno, mentre la prima è tratteggiata in direzione perpendicolare a queste, due figure e, in mezzo ad esse, rapido schizzo per una scaramuccia fra fanti e cavalieri nell'angolo superiore sinistro, alcune linee di scrittura autografa
BB_1961_title_verso: Nell'angolo superiore sinistro, a contorni leggeri, ripetizione del San Matteo sul recto e piccolo nudo virile che ci volge le spalle; nell'angolo superiore destro, indicazioni ancora più leggere di una figura col braccio destro sopra la testa e del busto di un'altra figura; nell'angolo inferiore destro, per l'altro verso, una quartina e mezzo di un sonetto; grottesche ed arabeschi
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: [1938: Come ben vide il Frey, il piccolo nudo che volge le spalle è un appunto per uno dei Bagnanti nella "Battaglia di Cascina", poi elaborato in un altro studio del British Museum, BB n. 1476 recto. (?) Le grottesche e gli arabeschi non sono di Michelangelo, bensì della mano che eseguì un capitello arabescato, una copia di questi studi per il San Matteo ecc. su un foglio agli Uffizi, BB n. 1645 A.]
BB_1938_title_recto: Sheet of studies. On the right a draped figure, but with shoulder and arm bare, stands more than in profile to right, his right foot resting on a pedestal, his right elbow resting on a book, which the left hand supports on the knee. To the left is a figure in almost identical pose, but nude and in outline only, whereas the first is hatched. Across the sheet, between the two figures, runs a sketch for a skirmish of horse and foot - the work of an instant - with non shading, vividly recalling Ghirlandajo's best and most rapid sketches, as for instance the bas-reliefs in the Albertina drawing representing Zacharias in the Temple
BB_1938_title_verso: Grotesques and arabesques not by Michelangelo but by the hand that did the pen-sketches on my 1645A. By Michelangelo himself, in outline only, the Matthew again and, as pointed out by Frey, a note for the figure in the Bathers of which my 1476 is an elaborate version. On opposite edge of sheet even slighter indications of a figure with an arm over its head and shoulders and of another head and shoulders
BB_1938_text_recto: There can be no doubt that the two figures are first thoughts for the St. Matthew, and it is highly probable that the skirmish was for the background of the cartoon for the Bathers. This sheet may therefore safely be assigned to 1504, the figures to the very beginning and the skirmish to the end of the year, for it need not be assumed that the whole was drawn at the same moment. The few written words are not devoid of interest, scribbled down most likely in a moment of listlessness. The show the drift of the artist's mind at the time. They are: "Dio devotamente," and perpendicular to these, "Deus in nomine salvum me fac," and perpendicular to this again, "stanza nell'inferno."
BB_1938_text_verso: The one with the arm over the head suggests the Slave for the Tomb of Julius but more probably was meant for the Bathers. Also six lines of verse for which see Frey, Text, p. 9. The leaf has been cut down at the edge.
Cataloguer's Question: I added two phrases in column N and I separate them with (?)

BB_1961_title_recto: Saggio o Astrologo, in profilo a destra, con in mano una sfera ed in testa un cappello da pellegrino
BB_1961_title_verso: Testa in profilo a sinistra e studio di mano
BB_1938_title_recto: Draped figure of a sage. In profile to right holding out a sphere. He wears a pilgrim's hat
BB_1938_title_verso: Head in profile left, and below it a hand
BB_1938_text_recto: Michelangelo's chief interest here is the drapery, which, as in several other studies, he derived from Giotto and Masaccio, if indeed he did not actually copy them from those masters. In the face there is a curious suggestion of Michelangelo's own cast of features, but of himself as an elderly man. The technique of the drawing rigidly compels us to date it about 1500, and thus not even a professional iconographer will feel obliged to prove that this sage was actually intended by Michelangelo for a presentment of himself. In the good old times it passed for this
BB_1938_text_verso: Perhaps in the whole range of Italian art there will not be found e head approaching nearer to the Greek type. It has the aloofness and pathos of the works we are accustomed to connect with the name of Scopas. But whether all this is convincingly Michelangelesque is another question, and the execution does not help us to a decision. On the whole, I think the probabilities are greatly in favour of its being by Michelangelo, in which case it would have been drawn later than the figure on the other side, and we should have to agree with Mr. Colvin (Guide, p. 30) that the head as well as the hand were done as studies for the Adam in the Sixtine Ceiling. It is, at all events, rash to take away from Michelangelo work of this order, in conception matchless, in execution if really inferior then inferior to his own best only, without being as the same time able to assign it with certainty to some other artist. Some day I may be ashamed of having had any doubts on this matter, meanwhile let me be frank and add that there is here a non so che, which makes me think of Sebastiano del Piombo's Lazarus. May it not be a copy by the latter, corrected by Michelangelo - for that these pen-strokes are Michelangelo's I cannot doubt?

BB_1961_title_recto: Cristo risorto con uno stendardo appena accennato nella mano destra sollevata e con la mano sinistra aperta verso terra
BB_1961_title_verso: Animale grottesco, figura nuda che avanza reggendo un piatto, e debole contorno, sempre a carboncino, di un grande torso nudo buttato all'indietro
BB_1938_title_recto: Resurrected Christ. He soars over the sepulchre with a banner (scarcely perceptible) in His hand
BB_1938_title_verso: Grotesque animal, and a nude walking forward holding out a dish, and faint chalk outline of large nude torso stretched backwards
BB_1938_text_recto: If the study of the recto was intended for the same work as we were the other sketches for a Resurrection, then this one, later certainly than the rest, would indicate a change and even an enfeebling of the idea. The proportions, the attitudes, the execution, witness clearly to the date of this drawing. It belongs to the period of the Last Judgement. As a matter of fact, the attitude and action are almost of the Christ in that fresco but reversed. We shall not be staying far if we assign it to about 1536, scarcely earlier.
Cataloguer's Comments: Handwritten comment in BB_1903: " and faint chalk outline of large nude torso stretched backwards".
Number omitted in first edition

BB_1961_title_recto: rapido schizzo di un nudo inginocchiato e piegato in avanti (come per bere ad un ruscello) col braccio sinistro disegnato in due posizioni (col peso sulla mano o col peso sul gomito)
BB_1961_title_verso: Studi di cornici per un camino con sopra scritto "8 iuli e 7 baiochi", a carboncino e, a sinistra, otto righi di scrittura a penna, autografi anch'essi
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of a mantelpiece, written on it, "8 ruli e 7 baiocchi". Black chalk and 8 lines of writing in pen
BB_1938_title_verso: Rapid sketch of nude squatting in profile right perhaps as Frey suggests (see Text, p. 77) for a figure in lower left of Last Judgement
Cataloguer's Comments: Handwritten comment in BB_1903: " Verso: Study of a mantlepiece, written on it, "8 ruli e 7 baiochi". Black chalk and 8 lines of writing in pen". Recto and verso are inverted in BB_1961 and BB_1938.

BB_1961_title_recto: A destra, due nudi avvinghiati in lotta a sinistra, nudo semiriverso, visto da tergo
BB_1961_title_verso: Frammento di lettera con la firma di Michelangelo e la data 18 ottobre 1524. Vedi la trascrizione in Frey, Testo p. 135
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketches for the upper part of a reclining figure, and two wrestlers
BB_1938_title_verso: Fragment of a letter with Michelangelo's signature and the date Oct. 18, 1524 - the whole transcribed in the MALCOLM. Cat. and by Frey, Text, p. 135.
BB_1938_text_recto: The above sketches are in outline and done with a trembling hand yet so splendid, so clearly realized is the action of the wrestlers, that one scarcely notices the faltering lines. These wrestlers must have been intended for a Hercules and Antaeus. As we have seen, the small study in red chalk at the British Museum (my 1490) for the same subject is from about the same time. According to a record quoted by Gaye (Carteggio, II, p. 464), Michelangelo was expected to carve out of the block ultimately allotted to Bandinelli, a Hercules and Antaeus.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studi architettonici per la Libreria di San Lorenzo
BB_1961_title_verso: Testa di giovane in profilo a sinistra, che guarda in basso, a semplice contorno. Per quanto nobile e bella, nel suo stato di conservazione attuale, questa testa pare di dubbia autenticità
BB_1938_title_recto: Architectural studies for the Library of S. Lorenzo
BB_1938_title_verso: Outlines of a head in profile to left looking down, noble and fine, yet, in its present state at least, of dubious authenticity

BB_1961_title_recto: Studi per una struttura parietale, per basi di colonne e per altri elementi architettonici che parrebbero destinati al Ricetto della Libreria di San Lorenzo (circa 1524)
BB_1961_title_verso: Studi per una struttura parietale, disegnati da Michelangelo sopra due teste a carboncino, l'una in profilo e l'altra di fronte, non sue e forse del suo allievo Antonio Mini
BB_1938_title_recto: Sheet of studies in pen and ink for bases of columns and another architectural features said to be for the vestibule of the Library of S. Lorenzo
BB_1938_title_verso: Those on the back were drawn over two heads in black chalk, one in profile and the other full face, not by Michelangelo, and possibly by his pupil Antonio Mini

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per una Crocifissione: Cristo è inchiodato su una croce che in cima ha la forma di un "A" arrovesciato sulla cui punta viene a trovarsi, la testa del Salvatore, mentre la Vergine e San Giovanni si curvano verso la croce
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: (vedi BB n. 1690A, n. 1724A, n. 1621 recto, n. 1622, n. 1574, n. 1583, n. 1530, n. 1582, n. 1595 recto, n. 1547 verso) (?) La poetessa morì nel 1547. Ma lo stile di questa serie è generalmente più tardo.
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Crucifixion. Christ is nailed to the cross, the top of which is shaped like an inverted triangle. The Saviour's head rests at its apex. To right and left stand John and the Virgin.
BB_1938_text_recto: These two figures show interesting pentimenti. The torso on the cross is a most exquisite bit of modelling. This is one of a series of studies for a Crucifixion which occupied Michelangelo toward the end of his acquaintance with Vittoria Colonna (see my 1547).
Cataloguer's Question: I added two phrases in column N and I separate them with (?)

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per una Crocifissione, con Giovanni e Maria che si stringono alla croce, Lui che alza lo sguardo verso la testa pendente del Cristo, Lei che preme la guancia al Suo fianco
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: BB n. 1518, che è databile per evidenza intrinseca intorno al 1550.
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Crucifixion. Christ nailed to the cross, with His head drooping to left. Mary leans up against His side, and John, standing close, looks up.
BB_1938_text_recto: This belongs to the same series as the last, although not for the same composition. In date it may be somewhat later, but nearly as well of the same time. The Virgin resembles the one in my 1518

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo visto da tergo
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude seen from behind
BB_1938_text_recto: Slight and latish

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile eretto che porta qualcosa sotto il braccio destro
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude carrying something under right arm
BB_1938_text_recto: Slight, and from the period of the Last Judgement

BB_1961_title_recto: Profilo a destra di un animale dal corpo canino e dalla testa serpentina. Esso ricorda vagamente quei bronzetti d'arte scitica, che ultimamente sono diventati così di moda
BB_1938_title_recto: On same mount, sketch of animal not unlike one of those Scythian bronze plaques which since the first publication of this have become so very popular

BB_1961_title_recto: Vergine Annunciata che appoggia il braccio destro ad una tavola, sopra la quale si libra l'Angelo, che vola vicino fino a toccarla
BB_1961_title_verso: Al centro leggero schizzo di una figura che si libra curvandosi in avanti verso sinistra e di cui solo le gambe sono rifinite; a destra, un letto con pesanti cortine; nell'angolo inferiore sinistro, disegnato in parte sopra alla figura centrale, un Angelo Annunziante, volto a sinistra
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Annunciation. The Virgin leans with her right arm on a table, over which the angel comes flying, close enough to touch her
BB_1938_title_verso: A reclining figure of a Dead Christ on the lap of His Mother, only the legs finished. Of somewhat earlier date, and drawn partly over it the Announcing Angel
BB_1938_text_recto: This certainly served for some such picture as the Annunciation we now see in the Corsini Gallery in Rome, executed by Marcello Venusti. Michelangelo could scarcely have drawn in this style before 1550, nor many years afterwards.
Cataloguer's Comments: Handwritten comment in BB_1903, near "A reclining figure of": " a dead Christ on the lap of his mother, only the legs finished of".

BB_1961_title_recto: La Caduta di Fetone
BB_1938_title_recto: Fall of Paheton
BB_1938_text_recto: A less elaborated and much more delightful version than the over-finished one at Windsor. Drawn for Tommaso Cavalieri in 1533. At the bottom is a note from Michelangelo to Tommaso as follows: " Co. Tommaso se questo schizzo non vi piace ditelo a Urbino che io abbi tempo d'averne fatto un altro domani dissera, vi promessi, o se vi piace e vogliate che io lo finisca." I doubt that Cavalieri had the audacity to tell his friends that the design did not please him, and it scarcely will be assumed that the Windsor version was done in the twenty-four hours. But this Malcolm sketch is surely the earlier, and as it was executed in Rome, its date much precedes Michelangelo's departure thence, in June, 1533. When the more finished version was finally received on September 5, Cavalieri speaks of it as something long promised (see Frey's Dichtungen, p. 522).

BB_1961_title_recto: Studi per il "Giudizio Universale"
BB_1961_title_verso: A destra sette piccole figure singole, per il "Giudizio Universale"; a sinistra, su scala maggiore, due studi di una testa quasi in profilo verso destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Studies for Last Judgement
BB_1938_title_verso: Various small single figure for the same, and on a large scale two heads almost in profile to right
BB_1938_text_recto: At first the sheet had on it at the top a superb sketch of a torso and arms in Michelangelo's grandest manner, and, lower down, a seated nude. Just what purpose they were meant to serve I cannot tell, unless indeed they were the lower one for the Christ, and the upper one for angels hurling down the damned. Then Michelangelo added a sketch for the groups that comprise St. Sebastian and the figures below of repelling angels. The great difference between the sketch and the corresponding parts of the fresco shows that we are in the first stages of the work. The date therefore is 1535, and this is important, for it enables us to place many other drawings in more accurate chronological order.

BB_1961_title_recto: Cartone per una Sacra Famiglia e Santi detto "Epifania". Leggermente seduta la Vergine ascolta il discorso eloquente di un giovane Santo, probabilmente San Giovanni Evangelista, che con la mano destra impone a San Giuseppe il silenzio, come se temesse la sua interruzione il Bambino Gesù gioca seduto sopra un cuscino fra le gambe materne e San Giovannino lo guarda, come se anelasse di partecipare al suo giuoco in alto si scorgono vagamente le teste di altri Santi
BB_1938_title_recto: Cartoon for Holy Family. The Madonna, lightly seated, listens to the eloquent discourse of a young saint, probably the Evangelist, while with her left hand she puts off Joseph, as if fearing his interruption. Between her feet the Child plays on a cushion, and the infant John looks at Him, as if eager to join Him. The heads of several other saints appear vaguely at the top
BB_1938_text_recto: It requires much patient study, and some faith, to discern in this sadly ruined and restored cartoon the hand of Michelangelo, but it is discernible, and unmistakable, especially in the relatively untouched Evangelist, and in the Children In type and spirit the connection with the frescoes of the Cappella Paolina is obvious, and I think the completion of these works, 1550, the latest date that may reasonably be assigned to the cartoon. As is well known, a painting executed from it exists in the Casa Buonarroti. It is not at all improbable that this cartoon is the one thus referred to in the inventory made on Michelangelo's death of the contents of his house: "Un altro cartone grando dove sono designate et schizzate tre figure grande et dui putti". My 1725A should be studied in this connection.

BB_1961_title_recto: A sinistra, un madrigale a destra un leggero schizzo di un nudo seduto su un trono e voltato verso destra col braccio proteso, come a suonare un corno
BB_1961_title_verso: Testa d'uomo quasi in profilo a destra (di autenticità discutibile), e studio per l'anatomia di una gamba nella posizione della gamba sinistra del Giorno della Tomba Medicea
BB_1938_title_recto: A madrigal published in Frey's Dichtungen, n. 402. To the right a slight sketch of a nude seated facing to right, with his arm held out
BB_1938_title_verso: Head of man nearly in profile to right of questionable authenticity, and study for the anatomy of a leg in the position of the left leg of the Day in the Medici Tombs
BB_1903_text_recto: These sketches are certainly of the same date as those for the Medici Tombs.

BB_1961_title_recto: Pianta ed alzato di una struttura architettonica tripartita, mediante colonne in una nicchia centrale e in tabernacoli laterali sormontati da riquadri, il tutto poggiante su tre scalini e coronato da una cupola
BB_1961_title_verso: Frammento di una pianta architettonica
BB_1938_title_recto: Below in brown ink elevation of building and sketch of small structure consisting of three openings led up to by three steps
BB_1938_title_verso: Diagram in black chalk
BB_1938_text_recto: Over the central opening a lunette, over the side ones square panels, over them a cornice and above it a dome like my 1566 (Oxford) and like Popp, pl. 69B (Casa Buonarroti) in connection with works at S. Lorenzo. To left above in Michelangelo's writing "Sessantuno / l auena ce(n)to I A l orzo 37" (in S. Lorenzo?)
Cataloguer's Comments: In BB_1938 in UK, Cheltenham, Fitzroy Fenwick private collection
Cataloguer's Question: I wrote in Y column "Fitzroy Fenwick private collection" because it wasn't a museum collection

BB_1961_title_recto: Disegno per una saliera
BB_1961_text_recto: È certamente autografo e viene riferito alla saliera d'argento eseguita nel 1537 su modello di Michelangelo per il Duca di Urbino (vedi Vasari, VII, p. 363).

BB_1961_title_recto: Due piccoli nudi in atto di volare verso l'alto, intesi probabilmente per il "Giudizio Universale"
BB_1938_title_recto: Two small nudes floating upward, probably intended for the Last Judgement
Cataloguer's Comments: Sold at Christies May, 1902, n. 212

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per il Cristo della Chiesa Santa Maria sopra Minerva a Roma, tratteggiato minutamente ed elaboratamente dal petto in giù, il resto a contorni in direzione opposta, leggero schizzo a sanguigna di una gamba e di un piede
BB_1961_title_verso: Schizzo di nudo per il medesimo Cristo e varie membra
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for the Christ in the Minerva. From the breast down elaborately and minutely hatched the rest is outline. Also a slight sketch of leg and foot in red chalk only
BB_1938_title_verso: Sketch of nude for same Christ, and various limbs
BB_1938_text_recto: The contract for this work was made on June 14, 1514, and the drawing must be of about the same date. Excellent is Dr. Frey's suggestion that this may represent the first version of the statue, which version, because of flaw in the marble, Michelangelo threw aside.
Cataloguer's Comments: Former Oppenheimer Collection; in BB_1903 Mr. J. P. Heseltine

BB_1961_title_recto: vedi BB n. 1696A
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo virile, come sospeso per le braccia, con la testa che pende verso destra; in alto, un distico e una quartina e fra essi, in direzione perpendicolare, torso virile seduto
BB_1938_title_recto: Verso of sheet. (See my 1696A for recto) Various sketches in red chalk for a leg, two torsos, a head in profile (not by Michelangelo), and with the pen a geometrized profile, a nude in suspended attitude, and to one side of the sheet two lines of a sonnet and below it to right four other lines, while between and vertical to both appear a torso and legs of a figure seated to right
BB_1938_text_recto: The seated nude may have served for a decorative figure on the Sixtine Ceiling and the one that seems suspended may possibly have had something to do with the Haman there or possibly, as Tolnay suggests, with a slave on the Tomb of Julius, although it seems as a whole too scattered for sculpture and the legs are not flexed as they are in all the figures for the monument.
Cataloguer's Comments: Former Sir Robert Witt
Cataloguer's Question: This is the only verso of the sheet, the recto is 1696A. Is it correct how I insert them?

BB_1961_title_recto: Vecchio in profilo a destra, che protende il braccio destro (a penna) e due studi di avambracci (a sanguigna)
BB_1938_title_recto: Copy of Peter in Masaccio's Tribute Money
BB_1938_text_recto: A very early work, exactly contemporary with the Louvre drawing (my 1587) after the two figures on the extreme left in Giotto's Assumption of the Evangelist, and of its precise technique and quality. Also arms in red chalk probably by Michelangelo despite appearances to the contrary.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: An arm in red chalk is by a later and feebler hand

BB_1961_title_recto: Tre soldati visti da tergo
BB_1938_title_recto: Fragment of cartoon for the group in lower left corner of the Cappella Paolina fresco representing the Crucifixion of Peter
BB_1938_text_recto: According to Steinmann this is a fragment of Michelangelo's original cartoon, done on the same kind of paper that the master used for the cartoon of the Battle and altogether of better quality and less retouched than the cartoon at the British Museum (my 1537). To my eyes there is a disturbing sleekness about these figures. It may be accounted for by their having been worked over by another hand, perhaps Daniele da Volterra's. Of the uppermost figure left there is a version possibly by Allori in the Collection of Professor F. J. Mather, Washington Crossing, Pa.

BB_1961_title_recto: Piccolo nudo virile piegato in avanti e accennante verso la sua sinistra
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of nude
BB_1938_text_recto: In exact attitude of those in Oxford (my 1569, 1 and 3), which Robinson describes as of a figure going downstairs. The nearest approach is the nude in the upper corner right of the Conversion of Paul. It is at all events a late drawing but hardly as late as1550.
Cataloguer's Question: I can't read a handwritten comment in BB_1961 on the location: Los Angeles, Bernard Hammel Coll. ?

BB_1961_title_recto: Torso virile con una piccola testa inclinata a destra, appena indicata in basso, studi separati di una spalla destra abbassata e di una spalla sinistra rialzata
BB_1961_title_verso: Scarabocchi che sembrano degli écorchés di una gamba destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for torso with head just indicated bent to right Below separate sketches of lowered right and raised left shoulder.
BB_1938_title_verso: Scribbles looking like écorché of right leg
BB_1938_text_recto: An interesting drawing of early date. To be compared with similar studies in the British Museum, at Casa Buonarroti, and in the Louvre (my 1416 and 1484 verso). Probably it also was intended for a Dead Christ.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studi per una Sibilla Libica
BB_1961_title_verso: Altri due studi per la Sibilla Libica e scarabocchio di una figura scimmiesca seduta
BB_1961_text_recto: La figura scimmiesca può aver servito per una delle figure degli Antenati di Cristo nelle lunette sulla volta della Cappella Sistina.
BB_1938_title_recto: Studies on front and back for the Libyan Sibyl
BB_1938_text_recto: A copy of recto, minus the large head, exists in the Uffizi under N. 2318F. In the thirty years that I have known this drawing it has never occurred to me to question that it was an autograph. Nor to my knowledge has anybody else doubted it. But were I to apply to it the kind of criticism that has been made of the Haarlem drawings for the Ceiling how should we justify our confidence? The first sketch on the recto would seem to have been the young Goethelike profile below on our left. Taken by itself its authenticity would scarcely pass unchallenged. Even more seriously should we hesitate over the rapid sketch of torso, head and left arm drawn over and above it. While the arm and the hand are almost of the shape and action that we find in the finished fresco of the Libica, the torso and head are stiffly erect with nothing of the inclination and movement of the finished figure. But what could have been its purpose seeing that the mask which was drawn first has already the exact tilt of the same sibyl? And the less said about the drawing of the hand the less sceptical we shall be. After this the artist sketched in the seated nude with head and arms and swing of the body almost as in the completed work, only that the legs are missing. Instead we have under the hip a sketch of the left foot. Then he repeats the toes twice, in the empty space to the right. Finally, in the empty triangle to left he tries to improve on the left hand and succeeds. On the verso in swift supple contours the back, belly and legs of the same figure and right thigh and knee, and on top a huddled apelike figure in small dimensions. Returning to the recto, we may ask why, if an autograph, there is no logical sequence to the order in which these various studies were sketched and we may wonder at the absurdity of placing a foot under a thigh and the improbability that a supreme draughtsman would need to repeat the toes thrice, and we may quarrel with the breadth of the ear, with the inferiority of the hands (particularly of the more elaborate separate one If compared with the right hand for the same sibyl on the famous Oxford sheet, my 1562), with the overdone shading and with the overmonotonous hatching. It could be argued that the author of these studies was one of those contemporary copyists or rather forgers who picking up a sheet of Michelangelo's with an empty side, took advantage of it to fill it with brilliant imitations that would sell as originals. But when I hold this leaf at certain distance from the eye I get a feeling that it is all by Michelangelo because it has his tactile values, his line, his touch. And against this feeling no argument of the kind brought to bear can prevail. Quality is the ultimate test and feeling is the only judge of quality, a poor vacillating one, and at times an unjust judge, but the best there is.

BB_1961_title_recto: Quattro rapidi schizzi per un piccolo nudo che si curva a colpire un gigante prostrato
BB_1938_title_recto: Four rapid sketches in black chalk for a small nude bending over and beating a prostrate giant
BB_1938_text_recto: These sketches cannot, like my 1571 represent Samson slaying a Philistine, for in that case the Hebrew and not his adversary was the giant. They would seem rather to have been done at the request of Daniele da Volterra for his Louvre picture representing David slaying Goliath.

BB_1961_title_recto: Gruppo di tre soldati in piedi, impegnati in una conversazione animata
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: [1938: Franco si servì probabilmente di quella copia per due figure nel suo dipinto del 1587, ora a Pitti, raffigurante la "Battaglia di Montemurlo", che è un centone di prestiti dal maestro. Uno studio ulteriore di questo disegno meritatamente famoso mi ha indotto a chiedermi se non sia anch'esso opera di "Andrea di Michelangelo". S'intende che conclusioni definitive per ciò che riguarda disegni attribuiti a Michelangelo e ai suoi apprendisti sono quasi sempre fuori posto.]
BB_1938_title_recto: Three soldiers standing engaged in animated conversation
BB_1938_text_recto: This is one of the most brilliant, and, in some respects, one of the most troublesome of Michelangelo's drawings. I should be ashamed to confess how many scores of hours I have devoted to its study. I will first state some of the objections that may be made against its authenticity. The figures do not stand firmly nor are they constructed so well as they might be. The torso of the speaker seems almost disjointed from his hips, and the build of the listener's shoulder is not intelligible. Singular also are the straight lines for the same figure's side, and his chest, which is literally rectangular. Then the almost total absence of cross-hatching rouses suspicion. Moreover, the clear spaces meant for the lights, as on the arm and chest of the speaker, are drily and somewhat mechanically mapped out. There is also a certain carelessness, a touch almost of bravura, in the shading of certain parts, as, for instance, the legs. Against this indictment there is much to be said in defence. The sketch is obviously rapid, whence its unusual freedom, and also carelessness. Classical canons of pose, and perfect intelligibility of structure are not to be expected in a hasty drawing even by Michelangelo. In general appearance it is like the superb sketch in the British Museum of sibylline young woman (my 1482). The touch, the penmanship, so to speak, is almost certainly his, and his are the many mannerisms. The pointing hand, for instance, is his most intimately, and we find it in the Bargello Madonna (the tondo) and the Oxford drawing (my 1562) for the boy accompanying the Libyan Sibyl. The clawlike index of the listener's hand is almost as good as a signature, and for a parallel I refer to the British Museum sketch for the Isaiah (my 1486). The right leg and foot are also peculiar to Michelangelo, as we see in my 1590 verso. The profile of the same figure closely resembles one in the Albertina sketch after an original by Masaccio. The correction of the speaker's chin is made exactly as in the Louvre sketch for the bronze David. Finally, let me say that this design has magnificent dramatic qualities, and the certain things in it can be the handiwork of the highest artist only, as, for instance, the arm of the figure behind the speaker. Let me add also that no case can be made out against it because of anything unusual in the "technique". In Michelangelo's unquestionable drawings I have found nearly every possible kind of stroke and shading. Besides, the technique of my 1546, which is of indubitable authenticity, has nearly the same system of hatching. It may be further objected that the vehemence of the listener is unexplained, that the action is unnecessarily expressive, if these in a sketch, obviously episodical, be faults, they are faults we shall find again and again in the Sixtine Ceiling. It is indeed to the period when that work was in hand that I would assign this drawing. It is too free to be earlier, and there are obvious reasons for one of the medallions which the decorative nudes hold suspended between them, for some such one as that between Noah's Sacrifice and the Erythraean Sybil, representing, perhaps, Caesar's address to his army at Rimini. A copy of this drawing ascribed to Battista Franco was famous in the eighteenth century, and is reproduced in Roger's Century of Prints, I, opp. p. 71. To judge by the reproduction, this copy certainly was by Franco, and if by Franco then a strong proof from without that the original was by Michelangelo. Note It may be the one used in this artist's Battle of Montemurlo, now at the Pitti, painted in 1597 and so full of borrowings from the great master. To clench the argument, on the back of the drawing are several words in Michelangelo's own hand, written at the time when the sketch was drawn. Much further study of this deservedly famous drawing leads me to suggestions rather than conclusions that will be found in Appendix XV. I may add that in the study of the drawings attributed to Michelangelo and his apprentices conclusions are nearly always out of place.
Cataloguer's Comments: Note: For more complete descriptions I still refer the student to Sir Chas. Robinson's catalogue. Despite its frequent errors of attribution, it remains one of the best works on any one great collection of drawings, and considering when it was written - at the darkest moment before the dawn of systematic and accurate criticism - its excellence can never be too much admired.
Cataloguer's Question: In BB_1939 Text we find a mention of Appendix XV (but I don't have it). I also added a note in BB_1938 text.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa in profilo che porta il berretto frigio di tipo toscano
BB_1961_title_verso: Un soldato dalle gambe nude e col braccio destro sul fianco e una figura ammantata e incappucciata che piega la testa sul petto e cammina come in sogno
BB_1938_title_recto: Two figures, one of a soldier barelegged with right arm akimbo the other heavily draped and cowled, with his head bent over his breast, walking as in a dream
BB_1938_title_verso: Head in profile wearing the Tuscan fashion of Phrygian cap
BB_1938_text_recto: In kind like my 1545, and probably of the same date.
BB_1903_text_recto: In kind exactly like n. 1545, and certainly of the same date.
Cataloguer's Comments: Recto and verso are inverted in BB_1961 and BB_1938

BB_1961_title_recto: Tre studi anatomici: un torace col braccio sinistro piegato in su (un po' come nel David di marmo), una coscia e un ginocchio. Iscritto "di undici di agosto"
BB_1961_title_verso: Vari studi anatomici, due dei quali probabilmente per un Cristo crocifisso
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of chest with left arm bent upward, somewhat as in the David. Also a thigh and knee
BB_1938_title_verso: Several anatomic studies, two of them probably for a Crucified Christ
BB_1938_text_recto: It may be doubted whether any of these can be brought into connection with the David. The torso with the flexed arm resembles in action the nude in the Louvre (my 1589). On the recto the words "di undici di agosto".
BB_1903_text_recto: It is more than probable that this series of rather feeble sketches is the master's, but I scarcely think that any of them can be brought into connection with the David. The torso with the flexed arm resembles in action the nude in Louvre (n. 1589). The words di undici d'agosto are as close to Michelangelo's handwriting as the sketches are to his drawing. Both, however, are characterised by an unusual timidity.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile acefalo, semidisteso, col braccio destro infilato fra le gambe
BB_1961_title_verso: Studi per una spalla, un braccio piegato e una mano. Non di Michelangelo
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for a reclining figure
BB_1938_title_verso: Several studies of shoulder, flexed arm and hand not by Michelangelo
BB_1938_text_recto: Clearly for the Night in the Sacristy of S. Lorenzo, similar in pose, quality, and style to the one next to be described. It is noteworthy how halting are the outlines in most of these chalk drawings, as if the instrument were not quite under the master's control. His  way of handling it would suggest that he forgot that he was not holding a pen in his hand
BB_1938_text_verso: My present feeling (1934= is that these may be by Michelangelo himself although feeble enough.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile semidisteso, acefalo, senza braccia e con la sola gamba destra visibile fino al ginocchio
BB_1938_title_recto: Torso and thighs of recumbent male nude
BB_1938_text_recto: This is a study for the Day in the New Sacristy at S. Lorenzo and but for the parts missing it differs slightly from the statue as we now see it. Which has the thigh titled up a little more and the leg bent a little less.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio di una gamba destra, con la coscia modellata a perfezione in senso opposto, studio che illustra l'azione di un braccio destro alzato
BB_1961_title_verso: Leggero schizzo di un torso
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of a right leg, the thigh beautifully modelled. In inverse direction study to illustrate action of lifted right arm
BB_1938_title_verso: Slight sketch of a torso
BB_1938_text_recto: This is contemporary with the Sixtine Ceiling. The torso and arm have the touch of one or two drawings for the work here at Oxford. Indeed it is possible that the leg is a study for the man supporting an expiring youth in the Deluge, and the torso for the figure clinging to the tree in the same composition.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa virile in profilo a destra
BB_1961_title_verso: Uomo che trasporta un porco
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of man's head in profile to right
BB_1938_title_verso: Man carrying a hog
BB_1938_text_recto: He has a vehement, almost fierce, look, exaggerated by the protruding lip and projecting nose. The columnar neck is magnificent. It is a masterpiece of design, exquisitely precise in the rendering of the surfaces, yet with a splendid largeness of handling. The type recalls the three soldiers (my 1545) and the profile  head also at Oxford (my 1546 verso), which we already have catalogued, and more than one head - the Josiah for instance - in the Ceiling. The treatment of the hair is also paralleled there, particularly in the figures dating presumably from the earlier part of that enterprise. We may place it toward 1509. It seems to me now (1935) that the head on the recto of this sheet is late, as late as the Medici Tombs and thrown off by Michelangelo while he was thinking over the head of Duke Giuliano. The length of neck, the dramatic look, the plastic stroke and the somewhat emphatic lighting suit the later date better. If it could be regarded as a study for the man riding on the shoulders of two others for the Brazen Serpent /my 1564) it would countenance Dr. Popp's contention that this design was made not for the Sixtine Ceiling but for the Medici Chapel (M. K., pp. 159-160).
