BB_1938_text_verso: The action of the torso thrown back is superb.

BB_1961_title_recto: Busto di giovane donna vista di spalle ma con la testa in profilo a destra. Ella porta gli orecchini ed un copricapo con falde rialzate sulla fronte come un diadema
BB_1938_title_recto: Bust of youngish woman, the shoulder turned away, but the head in profile to right
BB_1938_text_recto: She wears earrings and a turbanlike hat with turned-up brim. She has the beauty, the refinement, and the charm of the earlier decorative figures in the Ceiling. The workmanship differs slightly form my 1551. I used to think we might date it 1508 but I now (1935) believe it may be ten or more years later. Robinson, n. 53, is an excellent copy of this head probably done by Salviati. In the Uffizi there is another of no interest, except that it passes for an original.

BB_1961_title_recto: Busto in profilo a sinistra di un vecchio barbuto che urla
BB_1938_title_recto: Bust profile to left of bearded oldish man shouting
BB_1938_text_recto: I used to date the profile as contemporary with the Ceiling, but it may be as late as the Medici Tombs. With the hand cf. My 1584 verso.
BB_1903_text_recto: The character of the face and the treatment of the hair permit us to consider it as contemporary with the beginning of the Ceiling. In quality it is not inferior to the last two.

BB_1961_title_recto: Due studi montati sul medesimo foglio in alto, schizzo leggero di un nudo seduto in basso, testa d'uomo in profilo a sinistra
BB_1938_title_recto: Two studies mounted on same sheet, the upper one a slight sketch of seated nude, the lower one a man's head in profile to left
BB_1938_text_recto: The nude is a rapid note, probably from the model, for a Dead Christ, and would seem to belong to the epoch of the Sixtine Ceiling. The Head is an amusing caricature, nearly contemporary with my 1551, 1552 and 1553.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio di un drago raggomitolato su se stesso, con la coda ritratta fra le gambe e sotto l'ala il lungo collo annodato e la testa dalle fauci spalancate posa sul terreno due profili e qualche altro schizzo indecifrabile
BB_1961_title_verso: Sulla destra, tre profili di un giovane (rassomigliante a molti altri profili della stessa mano al British Museum, agli Uffizi e altrove) e a sinistra studi di occhi e di capelli, chiaramente intesi per insegnare il disegno a un allievo, al quale Michelangelo rivolge le parole scritte nell'angolo inferiore desro: "Andrea, abbi patientia / a me me  consolatione assai"
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of a dragon huddled together, its tail curled between its legs and under its wing, its long neck in a knot, and the head with its yawning maw on the ground. Also the profile of a man in red chalk. Below it, in inverse direction, the profile of a youth, two profiles in outlines and some other undecipherable strokes all in red chalk and by a pupil's hand
BB_1938_title_verso: On the right, three heads, in profile, of a young man, resembling many other profiles by the same hand in the British Museum, the Uffizi, and elsewhere, and to the left, sketches for eyes and locks of hair. These sketches served as a drawing lesson to a pupil whom Michelangelo addresses thus: "Andrea, abbi patientia / a me me consolatione assai."
BB_1938_text_recto: One of Michelangelo's greatest and most artistic creations. As pen-work we find here the highest and last stage of the earlier manner, while Michelangelo was still using the pens as an instrument for elaborated drawing. This sketch should be compared with my 1545, which it even surpasses. In date it should be somewhat later, but not much, and a year or two before the Ceiling. A good copy of this is in the Louvre, n. 693
BB_1938_text_verso: By this Andrea are the various scrawls on this side, as well as the head of a youth and other profiles on the front. As the dragon is drawn over this head, we may infer that the lesson sketches came some that earlier. "Andrea" must have been a pupil of Michelangelo's at this date - 1507 or thereabouts. Nothing further is, I believe, heard of him. Other such drawing lessons are known. One is of about the same date, and, in every probability, by the same pupil, my 1689. Another is the one in the British Museum for Antonio Mini (my 1502). If we should be obliged to recognize that this drawing was done towards 1530 it would be a warning to pay almost no attention to technique, stroke and touch in dating the drawings of the master, for it may be doubted whether on grounds of style alone it would occur to any one to date it later than the beginning of the Sixtine Ceiling. A for this Andrea being a myth (apart from the question of designation which I prefer to make, when possible, with a Christian name) he is as much an artistic personality as scores upon scores of masters of this and masters of that reconstructed by German art history. And he might as well, for all I care, be called the master of the dragon sheet profiles. (See also Appendix XV.) Note the arabesque that renders the eye and eyebrow of the profile almost touching the dragon's snout is nearly the one used by Sebastiano in drawing the face of the tall nude on the back of his Viterbo altar-piece - quite natural that pupils of the same master should learn the same nation. Finally, it should be noted that this dragon was probably done in connection with the candelabra of the Medici Chapel.
Cataloguer's Question: In BB_1939 Text we find a mention of Appendix XV (but I don't have it).

BB_1961_title_recto: Cavaliere che irrompe su un gruppo di nudi abbattendone alcuni, mentre altri l'attaccano con lance
BB_1938_title_recto: Horseman opposed by lancers, attempting to gallop over a group of prostrate and struggling nudes
BB_1938_text_recto: This sketch, no less vigorous and bold in touch than in action, has, since Ottley, been connected with the Bathers, for the background of which it may indeed have been intended. (Note: It is, however, not impossible that it is a study for one of the medallions in the Sixtine Ceiling, the one for instance beside the Creation of Eve.) It is in Michelangelo's swiftest style, a few of the figures in vague outline, but the rest shaded with sabre strokes of the pen. The action, by the way, of the figure on the right is singularly like that of the so-called Apollo in the Bargello, and this resemblance is one of the many reasons for questioning whether that work can be identical with the one executed so late as 1532 for Baccio Valori.

BB_1961_title_recto: Torso virile visto da tergo e cavaliere che carica al galoppo
BB_1938_title_recto: Back of a torso a horseman charging at full gallop
BB_1938_text_recto: Highly spirited sketch, probably for the background of the Bathers and how much like the "Tartar Rider" dear to Sung painters!. The horse and the other scrawls in black chalk do not seem to be Michelangelo's, and are at all events of no importance.

BB_1961_title_recto: In alto, cavallo acefalo in profilo a destra, in basso due studi delle parti posteriori di un cavallo, e rapido schizzo di una zuffa di fanti e cavalieri
BB_1961_title_verso: Rime riprodotte in Dis. Lawrence e pubblicate varie volte, ma meglio di tutti dal Frey, Dichtungen, II, III, IV, V, VI.
BB_1938_title_recto: Horse in profile to right below, two studies of the hind quarters of a horse, and between them a rapid sketch of horse and foot fighting
BB_1938_title_verso: Verses, reprinted more that once, but best in Frey's Dichtungen, II, III, IV, V, VI
BB_1938_text_recto: Similar in spirit to my 1556. Michelangelo paid as little attention to the horse as he did to everything else in the visible universe that was not the human figure. In his existing works the noble beast occurs but seldom, and then drawn in a conventional and perfunctory fashion. These sketches, however, must have been done direct from nature, and with a result most surprising for I question whether in the whole range of Italian art, not excepting even Leonardo, we shall find another horse so like the real animal, and so close to the horse as contemporary art since Géricault has presented him. Evidently Michelangelo, when he chose, could observe, and render, as no other of his contemporaries. There scarcely can be a doubt that all these sketches were intended for the background of the Bathers.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio del torso e della gamba sinistra, visti da tergo, per il nudo che regge la staffa sul recto
BB_1961_title_verso: Un nudo che monta a cavallo e un altro che gli regge la staffa
BB_1938_title_recto: One nude mounting a horse, and another holding the stirrup
BB_1938_title_verso: Study probably for the torso of the latter figure
BB_1938_text_recto: The group is hasty and rough, but spirited. The torso is one of Michelangelo's best pensketches. Both are certainly of the kind and quality of my 1559, and like that, intended for the background of the Bathers. A copy of the torso is to be found in Casa Buonarroti, see my 1656.
Cataloguer's Comments: In BB_1961 "recto" and "verso" are inverted with handwritten comment.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile seduto in profilo a sinistra con le braccia e le gambe terminanti in code di pesce e in testa il petaso alato di Mercurio perpendicolarmente ad esso, due teste barbute (di cui una calva) e un'altra testa imberbe
BB_1961_title_verso: Quattro studi dal vero: il dietro di un torso; una spalla sinistra col braccio alzato, visti da tergo; un braccio sinistro alzato, visto dal basso, col torace in profilo; un femore destro
BB_1938_title_recto: Various studies from nature. The back of a torso a left shoulder and outstretched arm from behind the thigh of a right leg
BB_1938_title_verso: Torso of seated man wearing winged Mercury cap, his arms and legs terminating in scrolls. Two bearded heads of men, one of them bald, and yet another head
BB_1938_text_recto: It is barely possible that the studies of the outstretched and uplifted arm are for the figure in the Bathers holding up his arm while a friend is buckling on his armour. The technique and quality - which is of the best - are, at all events, of the date of that great composition, 1505 or so.
Cataloguer's Comments: In BB_1961 "recto" and "verso" are inverted with handwritten comment.

BB_1961_title_recto: Vergine seduta in grembo a Sant'Anna
BB_1961_title_verso: Giovane nudo virile visto da tergo fino all'attacco delle gambe; perpendicolarmente ad esso quattro teste più o meno elaborate e il busto di un giovinetto seduto in profilo a sinistra
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of a group of the Virgin seated in the lap of St. Anne
BB_1938_title_verso: Torso with head and arms of youth seen from behind. Several heads more or less elaborated. Heads and torso of seated youth in profile to left
BB_1938_text_recto: St. Anne sits almost in profile to left, and the Virgin turning towards her sits on her right knee. The Child is supported on the Virgin's right hip. The Child already suggests the Infant in the various studies which may be connected with the Madonna for the New Sacristy at S. Lorenzo
BB_1938_text_verso: He is the model or the type which Granacci, Franciabigio, Bacchiacca, and even Andrea and Pontormo used, or rather imitated. The verso is of the precise date of my 1560. Not only is the touch the same, but one of the heads, that of the bald old man, occurs in both. But it may be questioned whether the recto be as late. The extreme length and gracility of the figures, the oval of the Virgin's face, and the sort of sash he wears diagonally from the shoulder to the waist all recall the early Roman Pietà. And there can be no doubt that the motive is Leonardo's. It is not necessary to suppose that Michelangelo already seen Leonardo's cartoon; but on hearing it talked about it may have occurred to him to jot down his own idea of how this motive should he treated. If all this is true, we may assign this sketch to the earlier months of 1501.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio dal vero di un ragazzo che regge un rotolo sotto il braccio sinistro ed accenna con la mano destra, per il genietto accanto alla Sibilla Libica nella volta della Cappella Sistina un po' più in basso, uno studio per la mano destra della Sibilla Libica e, su scala molto minore, sei rapidi schizzi a semplice contorno di Prigioni, tre dei quali legati a colonne, ed uno che lotta per liberarsi dalle catene, assai simile alla statua del Louvre nell'angolo superiore sinistro, studio di cornice
BB_1961_title_verso: Due studi accurati per una gamba sinistra ripiegata, ed un altro per una coscia e ginocchio. [1938: Come ha proposto il Frey, sono studi per un Prigione.]
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: [1959: Lo studio per una cornice può essere riferito anch'esso alla Tomba di Papa Giulio II.]
BB_1938_title_recto: Study from nature for the boy holding a scroll under his left arm, and pointing with his right hand to the Libyan Sibyl - in the Sixtine Ceiling, of course. A little below and on the same scale, study for the sibyl's right hand. On much smaller scale, rapid outline sketches of six slaves, three of them tied to columns, and one of them differing but little from the Louvre slave struggling to get free. Also the study for a cornice
BB_1938_title_verso: "Two careful studies of a bent leg, and another of a thigh and knee" as Frey suggests, for one of the slaves
BB_1938_text_recto: this sheet is not only one of the most beautiful that Michelangelo has left us, but, for many reasons, one one of the most interesting as well, one the clean paper came first the two studies for the group of the sibyl. That a working drawing already existed, we infer from the fact that only so much of the boy is sketched as actually appears in the fresco but the hand goes to prove that the cartoon was not yet begun, for in the finished work it is changed enough to indicate some alteration in the action of the sibyl. It would seem that at this point Michelangelo, suspending work on the Ceiling, rebounded instinctively to the great task of his life, the Tomb of Julius, jotting down six sketches for a captive slave, among them conspicuous the one now in the Louvre, on which he is known to have been working in 1513. That the part of the Ceiling in which the Libyan Sibyl occurs belongs to the end of that enterprise has been established beyond question by the acute, genuinely admirable criticism of Dr. Wölfflin (Rep. f. K. W., 1890, pp. 264 et seq.). Even in the finished frescoes signs are not wanting that, feeling the approach of the end of this undertaking, Michelangelo's mind was wandering off toward the Monument. At alla events, it is just above this sibyl that we find in one of the two exquisite nudes that motive of the hand touching the back of the head which gives such pathos to one of the slaves in the Louvre. I am thus led to wonder whether the drawing before us does not bear witness to a suspension of work on the Ceiling at the moment that the Libyan Sibyl was to be painted. Such an interruption occurred, as we know, in the autumn of 1510, when the Ceiling was not yet quite finished. If my conjecture be right, it was with this sibyl that Michelangelo began again in the spring or summer of 1511. In the intervening months he must have spent some of such time as he had to spare from dunning and mere worry, on the Tomb of Julius. But we have not yet extracted from this sheet all that it has to teach us. Three of the slaves are tied to columns, and these three sketches throw a flood of light on what, to me at least, has been one of the darkest spots in that dark subject - the architecture and general arrangement of the Tomb of Julius as originally planned by Michelangelo. All contemporary accounts speak of the slaves as standing against pilasters crowned with hermae. The vision called up at the mere mention of this is baroque enough but far worse is the presentation we find in the two or three wretched drawings (Florence and Berlin) which were still widely accepted as Michelangelo's own when this book appeared for the first time. In these feeble scrawls the hermae are elaborate, full-bosomed busts, whose chins just touch the tops of the slaves' heads. And now look at the columns in the Oxford drawing. In the first place, they are higher than the slaves, so that the hermae are well out of the way. And then - and this is important - the hermae are much smaller than the diameter of the columns, mere fair-sized knobs carved into decorative heads, perhaps even grotesques. But even thus, great difficulties remain. These knob-heads are a possible ornament on columns standing free. To introduce them on pilasters is an ingenuity of bad taste, of which I should be willing to accuse Michelangelo only on convincing proof. True the Ceiling itself has instances enough of triviality and vulgarity in architectural arrangement, but nothing approaching this. I am led therefore to suggest the query whether Michelangelo actually would have put even these knobs on the pilasters of his finished work, whether he would not rather have left them out. In that case the tradition about the hermae might have been kept alive by the existence of drawing like this, and as well of course by their presence in the blighted, stunted, finished work, where however the slaves were deliberately omitted, the purpose of the cornice is unknown to me.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio di una figura seduta in profilo a sinistra per il Josaphat in una lunetta della Cappella Sistina
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for the figure seated in profile to left for the Jehroam in a lunette of the Sixtine Chapel
BB_1938_text_recto: In the fresco perhaps not entirely by Michelangelo himself, the figure has lost much of its dignity and refinement, and the action has undergone the very slight change from reading to actual writing. The date of the drawing may be early in 1512. I can not get over the feeling that it is curiously like Andrea del Sarto in touch. A black chalk drawing of same figure reproduced in Ottley looks more like a copy after the fresco.

BB_1961_title_recto: Due studi, l'uno sotto l'altro, per folle di nudi che raffigurano, in alto, il flagello dei serpenti di fuoco e, in basso, la guarigione dei colpiti che guardano il serpente di bronzo
BB_1961_title_verso: Torso virile, con studio anatomico del collo
BB_1938_title_recto: Studies, one under the other, for the entire composition in the Ceiling representing the plague of fiery serpents and the cure of the stricken by gazing on the brazen serpent
BB_1938_text_recto: For an excellently worded appreciation of this sheet I must refer to Robinson's catalogue. Suffice it to say that it is an unsurpassed masterpiece of draughtsmanship. But for the small scale, I doubt whether even the Bathers could have presented finer action than we have here. It is almost an epitome of Michelangelo, for, while we are, on the one hand, reminded of the juvenile Centaurs and Lapiths we are, on the other hand, shot forward as far as the Last Judgement. Of parts of this late work there are suggestions here, not only in the grouping and action of the plague, but in the very touch of the more loosely drawn figures. Indeed, had I but these figures alone, I should scarcely have suspected their having been done at so early a date. As is well known, Michelangelo made no use whatever of this study. Doubtless he did not feel it to be suitable to the space at command, we are all the richer for these two versions and while the fresco is not to be compared for action with the sketch, it has greatly improved upon it in one respect. Instead of the mad struggle to catch sight of the brazen serpent, we have, in the painting, the deeply touching motive of the gazing figures, motionless, awestruck, saved. It is of course a great improvement also to have the two groups really forming one whole, with the plague still raging among some, while the others are already convalescent but then it is by no means to be assumed that the position of the two sketches on the sheet necessarily proves that that was the relative order in which Michelangelo ever intended to transfer them to the spandrel. A clever pen-copy of a group in the lower part exists in the Uffizi (n. 606E) and is rightly ascribed to Aristotile da San Gallo. There also is the partial copy of the upper part ascribed to Gabbiani (1737F). In the lower part is conspicuous a group of two nudes upholding a third as in my 1479 and 1598 where, however, the one supported is held by the foot and the knee while here he rides on the shoulders of the two others. The close likeness of the motive cannot surprise us for Michelangelo recurs to the same theme repeatedly in the course of years.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di giovane fauno che ride
BB_1961_title_verso: Un memorandum di mano di Michelangelo e uno studio di panneggio di altra mano
BB_1938_title_recto: Head of young faun
BB_1938_title_verso: Study of drapery not by Michelangelo. A memorandum in Michelangelo's hand
BB_1938_text_recto: Carefully and elaborately modelled in a way which suggests that it may have been done for execution in bronze. Both the red-chalk technique and the quality recall the Windsor Bacchanal (my 1618). For this and other reasons, the treatment of the hair, for instance, this head must be placed alongside of the drawings for Tommaso Cavalieri. The most probable date is about 1534.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studi architettonici per la Sagrestia Nuova e le Tombe Medicee in San Lorenzo: sono piante, alzati e indicazioni sommarie dell'articolazione della parete col progetto di due tombe affiancate, dai coperchi a semplice spioventi
BB_1938_title_recto: Architectural studies for the New Sacristy and its tombs at S. Lorenzo. "They represent both elevations and plans, and show the ground lines of the inner face of the wall of the chapel." Two tombs with plain sloping or roof-shaped lids are here seen placed side by side
BB_1938_text_recto: This, of course, recalls one or two of the sketches in the British Museum for this same task. The one with a large statue in the middle niche, and a smaller one lower down at the side, may possibly have been for the Tomb of Lorenzo the Magnificent, the larger statue representing the Madonna.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio di un drago accovacciato o di una salamandra e di un nudo che avanza barcollando verso sinistra
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of a couchant dragon or salamander and of a nude stumbling forward to left salamander
BB_1938_text_recto: This is probably by Michelangelo and, as Robinson states, of about 1530. May have been done in connection with the Medici Chapel.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo visibile fino alla coscia che cerca di sollevarsi da terra, strisciando verso destra e guardando in direzione opposta, con la testa e le spalle presentate di scorcio in basso, studio ingrandito della sua mano destra
BB_1961_title_verso: Gamba destra col piede nascosto sotto il polpaccio di una gamba sinistra
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for foreshortened nude getting out of tomb and looking back to left below, the right hand separately
BB_1938_title_verso: Right leg with its foot hidden under the calf of a leg
BB_1938_text_recto: For a figure that occurs in the lower left corner of the Last Judgement
BB_1938_text_verso: Probably for the nude helped by a woman in the group of the floating figures to left in the Last Judgement. In the first edition I published this sheet as by the same hand that did a number of drawings at the British Museum, at Lille, Windsor and elsewhere. It now seems in so fas as one can judge of matters where "a hair divides the false from true" more intimate, more supple, more alive, in short, then the drawings just referred to. Good enough to be Michelangelo's own. The verso certainly so.
BB_1903_text_recto: Study after a foreshortened figure getting out of the Tomb and looking back to the left. The original occurs in the lower left-hand corner of the Last Judgment
BB_1903_text_verso: Legs of a Nude foreshortened. These drawings are by the hand which made the various copies either of the Last Judgment itself, or of original sketches for it, which are found in the British Museum, at Lille, Windsor, and elsewhere.

BB_1961_title_recto: Busto di una creatura dal sesso incerta, più probabilmente maschile, che, a bocca spalancata, alza il capo in profilo verso destra, con i capelli stretti in un cencio, il petto e la spalla destra scoperti, il braccio destro visibile fin quasi al gomito, il sinistro molto meno
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: [1957: Philip Pouncey ha richiamato la mia attenzione sul fatto che questa figura appare in uno degli affreschi di Taddeo Zuccari in San Marcello al Corso, a Roma. Vedi Goldsheider, Appendice, nn. 169, 170.]
BB_1938_title_recto: Head of uncertain sex, more likely male. Mouth open, looking up to right, the right arm visible nearly to elbow, the left much less, with a kerchief wrapped tight around the skull, with bare shoulder and chest
BB_1938_text_recto: The attitude suggests a figure resting on the elbow as if to prepare to rise. The type, action, technique and quality of this fragment would tempt one to believe that it was part of Michelangelo's cartoon for the Last Judgement. A head and shoulders close to it does occur in the lower left of the composition but not really like it. If this is by Michelangelo why did he discard it? On the whole, it is harder to reject than to accept it and its present state makes a decision hazardous.

BB_1961_title_recto: Teschio avvolto nel lenzuolo funebre. Dev'essere uno studio per un risorto che esce dalla tomba nella parte inferiore sinistra del "Giudizio Universale"
BB_1938_title_recto: Small study of head of skeleton enveloped in shroud as if rising from tomb in lower left-hand side of the Last Judgement

BB_1961_title_recto: Studi di un braccio e di due gambe piegate
BB_1961_title_verso: vedi BB n. 1724
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of arm and shoulder, and two bent legs
BB_1938_title_verso: See my 1724
BB_1938_text_recto: Of small importance, but may be Michelangelo's. The arm would do him no discredit. If his, then of about 1535. Note: More than a year after writing the above, looking at the figure again, it occurred to me that the arm and possibly the bent legs as well may have been studies for a Resurrected Christ in the attitude that we see Him, for instance, in the Windsor design, where He is seen, a single figure, rising out of the tomb, with both His arms tossed up (my 1616). In 1934 I cannot understand how I could find fault with so admirable a drawing.

BB_1961_title_recto: Sei studi, con leggere varianti, per un Sansone che ammazza un Filisteo (due studi a semplice contorno, due un po' ombreggiati e i due più in basso, condotti a finimento) nell'angolo superiore destro è stato incollato un foglietto quadrato con quattro abbozzi di figure per un Cristo che caccia i Mercanti dal Tempio sotto il foglietto è schizzato il busto di un uomo col braccio alzato a colpire
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio per una gamba sinistra di una figura seduta e dello scritto. Non di Michelangelo
BB_1938_title_recto: Six several studies for Samson slaying a Philistine. Two in outline, two more shaded, and the lower two carefully elaborated. The uppermost one to left resembles a group in my 1748B, copy of a lost design by Michelangelo known as the Vanity of Human Wishes.
BB_1938_title_verso: Study of left leg for seated figure and some writing not by Michelangelo
BB_1938_text_recto: The action is good. The modelling, forms, and technique differ but slightly from the Cavalieri drawings, from the various later studies for the Resurrection, and those for the Last Judgement, especially the one in the Malcolm Collection (my 1536). Robinson suggests that it may have been intended as a design for a medal. It will be remembered that in the passage of the Autobiography where Cellini recounts how he told Duke Cosimo what he thought of Bandinelli' Hercules and Cacus, he says that out of the original block Michelangelo had intended carving a Samson with four figures. But the great artist's various schemes for using that marble came to a head in 1528, and the sketches before us can scarcely be of so early a date. On the other hand, this may possibly be the leaf referred to by Vasari in his life pf Pierino da Vinci (VI, p. 128): "Vinci, having once upon a time seen certain sketches by Michelangelo for a Samson slaying a Philistine with the jawbone of an ass..." On the right of the recto another small square leaf has been pasted. It contains three or four roughly sketched figures for Christ Chasing the Money-Changers from the Temple.

BB_1961_title_recto: Su due fogli incollati insieme, cinque studi per un Cristo deposto
BB_1938_title_recto: Two sheets of studies on the same mount. Sketches for Pietà and for two disciples carrying body of Christ
BB_1938_text_recto: I must refer the student to Robinson's admirable note on this leaflet. He is of course right in seeing in the Pietà a sketch for the Rondanini group, and right in dating the drawing as of about 1542. It should be noted how in the action of the legs this as well as every other Christ for a Pietà that we have from Michelangelo's hand, harks back to the picture in the National Gallery. The slight sketch on the extreme right anticipates the motive of the Florentine Pietà.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nove leggeri schizzi di singole figure giacenti o dormienti a destra un gruppo di tre, ovviamente Apostoli, per un'Orazione nell'Orto
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added the copy's number in the Uffizi: BB n. 1645
BB_1938_title_recto: Various slight studies of single reclining or sleeping figures, and of a group of three, which leave no doubt but that this is a preliminary sketch for the famous cartoon of Christ in the Garden, mentioned by Vasari as belonging to the Duke Cosimo
BB_1938_text_recto: This cartoon is now represented by a copy in the Uffizi, and by a number of paintings, the best of which to my knowledge is in the Balbi Piovera Collection at Genoa. The date of studies before us is about 1545.

BB_1961_title_recto: Due piccole figure nude che si chinano verso terra come per attingere l'acqua da un torrente
BB_1938_title_recto: Two small studies of nude figures, reaching down as if to get water in a stream
BB_1938_text_recto: Date about 1540. This sketch should be connected with the Last Judgement, for one of the blessed pulling up others. See my 1403A.

BB_1961_title_recto: Tre nudi in atteggiamenti violenti, quello nel mezzo sembra percuotere gli altri due
BB_1938_title_recto: Three figures slightly and hastily done
BB_1938_text_recto: In all probability for that late composition, Christ Chasing the Money-Changers from the Temple. Interesting as an example of the master's use of the pen in his last years. How little it has changed in sixty years! A number of other such sketches may be seen in the Casa Buonarroti at Florence (my 1402, 1403, 1414, 1415). All these sketches seem now (1934) much earlier and, as already suggested by Frey, done perhaps in connection with the fresco of the Brazen Serpent on the Ceiling.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per una Crocifissione: Cristo ha la testa infossata nelle spalle, le braccia ed il torso rilasciati nella morte: a destra, la Madre si stringe il capo fra le mani a sinistra, l'Evangelista guarda in alto con un certo risentimento
BB_1961_title_verso: Cristo in Croce
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for a Crucifixion. Christ is nailed to the cross, His head sunk into His shoulders, the arms and torso relaxed in death. To right His mother with her hands to her head to left the Evangelist looking up with a certain resentment
BB_1938_text_recto: The pathos suggests the great Pietà at Florence

BB_1961_title_recto: Annunciazione: la Vergine è una maschia e robusta figura seduta col volto in profilo a destra, mentre l'Arcangelo, creatura più gentile, entra in volo, da quel lato, con la mano destra protesa e la sinistra sul cuore
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian, except the reference to Malcolm collection, here London, British Museum
BB_1938_title_recto: A robust masculine figure seated with the face in profile to right serves for the Virgin. The angel, a more gentle being, floats in from the same direction, his right hand held out, his left to his heart
BB_1938_text_recto: This sketch has all the characteristics of Michelangelo's latest draughtsmanship, and should follow rather then precede the sketch for the same subject in the Malcolm Collection (my 1534). Above the Virgin's head are a few words in writing, not less loose and sprawling than the drawing, bearing pathetic witness to the cry Michelangelo so commonly uttered in his last years that writing was a burden to him. One of these words is "Casteldurante," another is "Pasquino," and although the rest are scarcely intelligible these words may help to fix the exact date of this sketch. Casteldurante was the home of Cornelia, the wife of Michelangelo's beloved servant Urbino. The latter died December 3, 1555, and thereupon his widow retired to her home with her children, Michelangelo's wards. A correspondence ensued, and the carrier of the letters was a muleteer named Pasquino. The earliest date for our drawing is therefore 1556 - and I doubt whether it can be much, although it may be a year or two, later.

BB_1961_title_recto: testa che guarda in basso, un po' verso destra
BB_1961_title_verso: Modanatura ed un capitello con grottesca
BB_1938_title_recto: Head looking down, somewhat to right
BB_1938_title_verso: Moulding, and a capital with a grotesque
BB_1938_text_recto: The loose touch and the whole treatment are very late.

BB_1961_title_recto: Quattro nudi volti a destra e visti di spalle
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian, except references of collection's numbers, here 332, 333, 334 (instead of 80, 81, 82).
BB_1938_title_recto: Four nudes
BB_1938_text_recto: They bear a strong resemblance to some figures in the foreground on the left in the Crucifixion of Peter. But the workmanship is at the least ten years earlier than the date of that fresco. The use of this sketch is thus unknown, unless indeed we assume - what need not be considered improbable - that it was done without reference to the fresco, but found later by Michelangelo among his papers, and thereupon introduced, with considerable changes of course, into the composition. Has affinities with certain nudes on my 1600, the sketch for a Martydrom of St. Catherine, made for Bugiardini. Note: Numbers 80, 81, 82 are architectural studies and genuine. On 81 recto there is , besides, the study of a right arm.

BB_1961_title_recto: Cristo sulla Croce e sparse linee di scrittura. La testa del Cristo è volta in alto come se fosse ancora vivo
BB_1961_title_verso: Scarabocchi indecifrabili, fra i quali un busto
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Christ on the Cross. The head of Christ is turned up as if still alive
BB_1938_title_verso: Undecipherable scrawls, one of a bust
BB_1938_text_recto: The date is scarcely later than 1515. Lines of writing up and down across the page some according to Frey (Text, p. 66) Michelangelo's own and some not.

BB_1961_title_recto: In alto, due donne sedute l'una accanto all'altra per terra, la più anziana di profilo a destra, la più giovane in atto di volgersi verso sinistra con un movimento ed un gesto di grazia squisita, mentre si porta la mano al seno per allattare il bambino che ha in grembo in basso, senza tratteggi chiaroscurali, bensì a semplice contorno, una testa irsuta in profilo e, in direzione perpendicolare, un vigoroso nudo virile lungo il bordo destro, varie linee di scrittura. Come se avesse previsto i dubbi sull'autenticità di questo disegno, Michelangelo ha scritto vicino al gruppo delle due donne, "chi dire mai chella fosse di mie mani"
BB_1961_title_verso: Giovane donna inginocchiata a destra, che tiene sopra un vassoio una testa umana e gira il volto nettamente a sinistra, ove sono schizzati un profilo d'aquila  e una lampada. In alto sei o sette righi di scrittura
BB_1938_title_recto: Two women seated beside each other on the ground, the elder one in profile to right, the younger one looking to left with a movement and gesture of exquisite grace, while holding her hand to her breast as she gives suck to the child in her lap. Another part of the leaf has a vigorous male nude in outline also a head in profile. As if foreseeing Morelli's doubts regarding the authenticity of this drawing, Michelangelo has written by the group of two woman, "chi dire mai chella fosse di mie mani."
BB_1938_title_verso: Young woman kneeling to right, but her head turned sharp to left, holding on a charger a human head. An eagle's head and a lamp
BB_1938_text_verso: At the top are six or seven lines of writing in a more archaic but contemporary hand, from which it appears that this leaf came out of an account book by Donato di Nertino and Buonarroto di Simone, money-changers in Mercato Nuovo. This Buonarroto, is, of course, Michelangelo's brother. If we had more knowledge regarding the business connection between Donato and Buonarroto, we should know the earliest date which this sheet could possibly have; but I have not come across any reference to this affair. We are thus left to judge by the internal evidence. The hatching is no longer Michelangelo's earliest manner, is much less laboured, and altogether more free. The woman with the child already suggests the Madonna in the Medici Tombs; the action and pose of the arm, for instance, are nearly the same. In the Louvre catalogue the two women are described as the Madonna with St. Anne. That is no impossible designation; but they sit on the ground in attitudes which remind one vividly of the groups in the triangles between the sibyls and prophets in the Sixtine Ceiling. The one between Ezekiel and Erythraea is most to the point; the types also are of this period. It seems to me more probable, therefore, that the two women were intended for one of the Sixtine family groups. As for the nude and the figure on the other side, I have a suggestion to make which is most unlikely, yet worth the mere making. It is that the nude is for a David and the figure on the other side, not for a Salome, but for a servant receiving Judith the head of Holofernes. These two subjects, it will be remembered, occupy two neighbouring corners of the Ceiling. If this suggestion should happen to be well founded, then these sketches would have to be regarded as first thoughts, before Michelangelo had settled on the final treatment of these two themes. At all events, I would not place them much later than 1509. The left leg of the nude, for instance, is too much like the study for the anatomy of the leg on the back of the British Museum drawing (my 1479) - containing, among other studies, one for the Bruges Madonna - to have been done many years later than that marble. Frey's contention (Text, p. 18) that this can be no earlier than 1513 is groundless, as we do not know the exact date of Donato di Bertino's and Buonarroto di Simone's coming together. It may have been as early as 1511, which would allow the sketches to have been done in connection with the Sixtine Ceiling.

BB_1961_title_recto: Piccolo schizzo per una Resurrezione
BB_1938_title_recto: Small sketch for Resurrection
BB_1938_text_recto: Corresponds closely to the larger study at Windsor (my 1612). Date about 1530.

BB_1961_title_recto: Fauno danzante che suona un tamburo, mentre un satiretto gli balla accanto
BB_1938_title_recto: Faun dancing, striking a tambourine, while a young satyr dances beside him
BB_1938_text_recto: A characteristic and beautiful drawing of the period following the completion of the Sixtine Ceiling cf. My 1584 verso. The dancing faun at Windsor (my 1749) is a copy made by a brilliant pupil in the manner of his master at about 1535

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per un San Giovanni Evangelista in piedi sotto la croce, con le mani incrociate sul petto
BB_1961_text_recto: Questa figura fa parte della serie di studi per una Crocifissione ispirata da Vittoria Colonna (cfr. BB n. 1529). Essa appare in BB n. 1621 e fu presa a modello dall'autore di un dipinto nella Galleria Doria Pamphili.
BB_1938_title_recto: St. John, for a Crucifixion
BB_1938_text_recto: One of the series of studies for a Crucifixion made about 1544
BB_1903_text_recto: This probably was by Michelangelo, and one of the series of studies for a Crucifixion made soon after 1540

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per una Crocifissione: Cristo pende da una croce di tipo normale formando con le Sue braccia e il braccio trasversale della croce come un triangolo arrovesciato la Vergine e San Giovanni stanno ambedue a capo chino
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: Anche questo fa parte della serie di Crocifissioni ispirate da Vittoria Colonna e segue il Crocifisso eseguito per lei nel 1545. The number's reference, BB n. 1530, is added too.
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for a Crucifixion
BB_1938_text_recto: One of the series done soon after 1545. Here, as in the Crucifixions in the Malcolm Collection, Christ is represented expiring on the cross, the top of which is shaped like an inverted triangle. There is a pentimento in one of the arms. Mary and John stand in tragic attitudes.

BB_1961_title_recto: Due nudi che trasportano un cadavere sulle loro spalle
BB_1961_title_verso: Donna piuttosto giovane, seduta con le braccia appoggiate a destra, a un tavolo, su cui tiene aperto un libro, ma col volto girato a sinistra, come per ascoltare un fanciullo nudo che, in profilo verso destra, sembra voler leggere il libro guardandole sopra alle spalle; un altro fanciullo nudo cerca di attirare l'attenzione della donna, agitandosi in grembo a lei
BB_1938_title_recto: Three men carrying corpse on their shoulders
BB_1938_title_verso: Youngish woman seated somewhat to right but looking to left while her hands hold a book spread open on a desk at a level with her shoulders; one child, nestling up to her, tires to get her attention, while another in profile to right seems to wish to look over her shoulder into the book
BB_1938_text_recto: Executed freely and largely, yet adequately rendering a motive unrivalled as action. The figures are on almost colossal scale, the most colossal being the corpse, whose shoulders are supported on the shoulders of the two men behind, while its legs swing over the shoulders of the foremost figure enclosing his head. The weight of the corpse, the strain on the bearers, the swing of their march, are all conveyed with a complete realization of the force employed
BB_1938_text_verso: This may be a study for a Madonna with the two Holy Children, yet the resemblance in motive, action and pose to the sibyls and prophets on the Sixtine Ceiling is so great that one may be justified in considering it a discarded idea for one of the sibyls with the accompanying genii. The Isaiah, the Libyan and the Erythraean sibyls are the next of kin to this figure, but the original drawing for the Isaiah (my 1486) still more than fresco. Whatever its purpose, its connection with the Ceiling is too close to permit us to date it much later than 1512. The resemblance of the lower child to the faun (my 1581) fixes the date of that drawing also. Steinmann (II, p. 600) connects the recto with the flood and it occurs to me now (1935) that it may be even earlier and intended for a group in the background of the Bathers. As for the verso I now see in it too much resemblance to the Madonna with the two Children on my 1599, the Children being all but identical in both, to assign to it a date much earlier than 1520. It may even be questioned whether this group, like the one in my 1599, is not by "Andrea di Michelangelo."
Cataloguer's Comments: Handwritten comment in BB_1903, next to "the Isaiah, the Libyan ecc.": "[reconsider c.f Sebastiano]"

BB_1961_title_recto: Rapido schizzo per il David di bronzo ordinato dalla Signoria il 12 agosto 1502 per il Maréchal de Gié e, dopo la sua disgrazia, consegnato al tesoriere reale Florimond Robertet. David, giovanissimo, sta eretto in profilo a sinistra, col piede destro sulla testa di Golia a destra si legge: "Davicte cholla fromba e io chol larco". Più sotto: "Michelagniolo" e, ancora più in basso: "Rocte lalta cholonna..." (Petrarca, sonetto 229). Fra il David e queste parole, in direzione capovolta, schizzo per il braccio e la spalla sinistra del David marmoreo, disegnati probabilmente vari mesi prima del resto
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo virile in atto di scavare e studio separato del suo braccio destro; due busti visti da tergo e due studi per una spalla; tre versi iscritti nell'angolo superiore sinistro
BB_1938_title_recto: Rapid sketch for the bronze David ordered by the Signoria on August 12, 1502, for the Maréchal de Gié, and on his disgrace, given to the royal treasurer Florimond Robertet. David nude, very young, stands in profile to left, with right foot on head of Goliath. On the same side, but to right, we read: "Davicte cholla fromba e io chollarco." Just below: "Michelagniolo." Much lower down: "Rocté lalta cholonna..." Between the David and these words, but in reversed direction, is a sketch of a right arm and a shoulder for the marble David, drawn probably a number of months earlier than the rest
BB_1938_title_verso: Nude with the action of person digging  (note: Compare the man digging in the Drunkenness of Noah as well as the one on our extreme left holding onto the sheep in the Sacrifice of Noah, both among the earliest in the Sixtine Ceiling), two busts seen from behind and studies for a shoulder and beginning of arm and one for a right arm. At the top of sheet three lines of verse, published in Frey's Dichtungen, CLXVI
BB_1938_text_recto: This is a leaf the study of which cannot be too highly recommended to those who would seriously acquaint themselves with Michelangelo's quality no less than with his shorthand and draughtsman's tricks, for here we have sketches of unquestionable authenticity . The drawing of David's nose betrays the influence of Ghirlandajo, who also used to make a nib serve for a nose.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per il Cristo morto seduto e appoggiato all'indietro, con la testa ricadente sulla spalla destra e ai lati, due studi separati per il Suo braccio destro
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Dead Christ, reclining with head falling on right shoulder
BB_1938_text_recto: The torso is exquisitely modelled, the legs are slightly indicated. It is a more finished version of a drawing in the Casa Buonarroti (my 1416). Intended doubtless for some Pietà, and dating from a time just preceding the beginning of the Sistine Ceiling. There, in the Deluge, is an expiring nude carried on another's shoulder, which resembles this study closely. The right hand recalls the one in the Oxford drawing (my 1562) for the child in the Libyan Sibyl. The other hand is almost more like Sebastiano del Piombo's exaggeration of Michelangelo's forms than Michelangelo's own but it was the Ceiling and kindred works upon which Sebastiano formed his Roman manner. Also two sketches for the right arm. Obviously used by Sebastiano in his Pietà at Ubeda and published as Sebastiano by Prof. Panofsky in Festschirft für Schlosser, pp. 150-161. Since this was published, I have reconsidered this study again and again. At times it seemed as if it should be given to Sebastiano. In the end my doubts have cleared up and given place to the conviction that it must be Michelangelo's. Not only this modeling but the contours seem beyond Sebastiano's highest reach, particularly when drawing on a scale approaching this one. It may however be later than I used to think it, ten or even fifteen years later than my 1416, which it repeats and elaborates. It may be asked whether it is likely that Michelangelo would go back to a skerch of years before when he wanted to draw a more elaborate version of the same figure. In answer I refer to what I have been obliged to say again and again, namely that even a genius like Michelangelo has a surprisingly limited repertory of types, poses and movements and that they vary surprisingly little from one period to another of his long career, least of all in the years between 1505 and 1535. While I can make no surmise as to what led him to repeat this motive later we must never loose sight of fact that even of a life regarding which we are so abundantly informed as Michelangelo's we know but fragments, although in his case happily the most important ones. Everybody who had access to him asked him for drawings for this and drawings for that. The may have done this Louvre sketch for some such occasion and preserved it as indeed he must have preserved its much earlier model (my 1416). When years later Sebastiano dunned him for a dead Christ that he could use for the Ubeda picture, Michelangelo sent him this one. That this procedure is by no means improbable we may infer from the folowing chance fact that has come down to us. A few years earlier than the beginning of the Ubeda picture Sebastiano on July 15, 1532, returns the drawings of a Christ to Michelangelo because it is "quasi simile a quello de Sancto Pietro Montorio" - almost identical with the one for Saint Peter in Michelangelo. I trust that the student can be left to draw his own conclusions with regard to the attribution as well as the dating of this sheet. There remains just one more consideration. It is that Sebastiano was an accomplished painter and an indifferent draughtsman. If he was able to achieve such a masterpice of drawing he would have done at least as well in the painting. The painted figure, however, is a wooden and stiff as the sketched one is rhythmic and supple. And finally, whatever Sebastiano may have been able to do in 1517, when youngish and utterly abandoned to the tempering glow of Michelangelo's genius, twenty years later, lazy and indifferent, he could not have risen to this quality.

BB_1961_title_recto: Uomo in piedi ed un altro chinato in profilo a destra
BB_1961_title_verso: Spalla e braccio ripiegato
BB_1938_title_recto: One man standing and another bending over
BB_1938_title_verso: Shoulder and flexed arm
BB_1938_text_recto: Copies made by the youthful Michelangelo after the two figures on the left in Giotto's fresco in the Peruzzi Chapel at S. Croce, representing the Evangelist mounting to heaven. Made as early, perhaps, as 1492, hatched closely and precisely as in the kindred drawings at Vienna, Munich, Chantilly and elsewhere.
Cataloguer's Comments: Handwritten comment in BB_1903: "Verso: a shoulder + flexed arm; red chalk"

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per un Mercurio o un Orfeo o un Apollo, e in basso studio più affrettato per un ragazzo nudo con un carico sulla spalla sinistra
BB_1961_title_verso: A carboncino e non autografi, un ricalco del cosiddetto Mercurio sul recto e una ripetizione del profilo; altrimenti, schizzai a penna in ogni direzione, una testa di un uomo barbuto con cappello piumato, un profilo di giovane, un putto che guarda in alto, un nudo virile visto di fronte, dal petto ai ginocchi, una testa di cherubino e, più importante di tutti, uno studio a semplici contorni di un Prigione che si tocca la nuca con la mano; vicino ad esso, le seguenti quattro linee dal terzo sonetto del Petrarca sulla morte di Laura: "L'ardente nodo ond'io fui d'ora in ora / Cantando anni ventuno ardendo preso / Morte disciolse né già  mai tal peso / Provai ne credo...."
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian, except for the  il braccio destro è visibile in due posizioni, piegato attraverso il torace e pendente lungo il fianco.
BB_1961_text_verso: "Ma il profilo di giovane donna ricorda il profilo della Madonna su un foglio pieno di schizzi a penna, a Berlino, BB n. 1396, databile intorno al 1508.
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for a Mercury (or an Orpheus or Apollo)
BB_1938_title_verso: A number of sketches in various directions. A head of a man wearing a plumed cap. A left leg. A male mask in profile recalling the Madonna in the Berlin drawing (my 1396). Lower part of a male figure. A child, a cherub, and - most important of all - a study for the slave (now in the Louvre) with his hand touching the back of his head. A tracing in black chalk of the figure on recto, scarcely by Michelangelo and the following four lines from Petrarch's third sonnet on the death of Laura: "L'ardente nodo ond'io fui d'ora in ora / Cantando anni ventuno ardendo preso / Morte disciolse né già  mai tal peso / Provai ne credo...."
BB_1938_text_recto: He is a beautiful as a god should be, and is nude but for a shadowy drapery falling behind the shoulder, and hanging down from the left arm. The right arm falls along the side, while with the left hand he holds a viol to this shoulder. On his head, a winged cap. Lower down, is a rougher study for a nude in the Sixtine Ceiling, those for instance near the Creation of Eve, or near the Separation of Light from Darkness. He suggests as well the reclining figure beside the Madonna kissing the Child in Michelangelo Bonnat's famous sheet (my 1599). The Mercury is perhaps Michelangelo's most antique inspiration
BB_1938_text_verso: There is a freedom of touch in the hatching on this sheet which we shall not find in Michelangelo's earliest drawings. The presence of the sketch for the slave is not decisive evidence of the exact date, for it might have been jotted down late in 1505, when the Tomb of Julius was begun, or, on the other hand, after the completion of the Sixtine Ceiling, when this monument was taken up again. The presence of the putto, so distinctly in the style of those in the Ceiling, if not actually for one of them - the nearest are the one beside Joel, and another on the pilaster beside Jonah - would point to the later date; and this view would be strengthened by the quality of the draughtsmanship.
Cataloguer's Comments: Handwritten comment in BB_1903 next to "Mercury": " or an Orpheo or a Apollo"; at the end "Verso:  a tracing in black chalk of the figure on recto, scarcely by Michelangelo."

BB_1961_title_recto: Due nudi femminili seduti l'uno accanto all'altro col volto girato a sinistra e il braccio destro proteso: la donna alla nostra destra allatta un bambino seduto a cavalcioni sul suo ginocchio sinistro
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo virile visto frontalmente, che si torce per guardare la mano destra posta sopra la spalla destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Two nude women seated. Both looking to left and with right arm stretched out. The one on the right holds astraddle on her left knee a child sucking at her breast
BB_1938_title_verso: Elaborate study of a nude in a somewhat contorted attitude looking at his doubled-up right arm
BB_1938_text_recto: The technique of this sketch is relatively rare in Michelangelo, consisting of little more than outlines with almost no shading, and that not done by cross-hatching, but with more or less parallel curves. It is, in short, almost the manner of Raphael in his mature years. Its purpose is enigmatical. The woman with the child differs only in the pose of the head and in the absence of clothing from the study at the Albertina suggesting the Madonna of the Sacristy of S. Lorenzo (my 1603). It is of earlier date than the beginning of the Sacristy of S. Lorenzo, and I believe nearer to the completion of the Sixtine Ceiling, but not later than 1514.
BB_1938_text_verso: The action suggests the Victory in the Palazzo Vecchio, and although it could scarcely have been drawn for that figure, it yet helps to fix the date as being between the completion of the Sixtine Ceiling and the beginning of the façade of S. Lorenzo. Unfortunately, this drawing has been retouched, but it retains great power notwithstanding. Its purpose is not clear. The quality of the works is like that of the Mercury. Perhaps it had some connection with the Tomb of Julius. It occurs to me now (1934) that the figures on the recto may have been done in connection with one of the lunettes over the popes on the Sixtine Ceiling and the verso for a figure in the Tomb of Julius as conceived after the death of that pope.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: But why is she touching the other, and who is this other one?
Cataloguer's Comments: Handwritten comment in BB_1903: "[Surely two independents studies]" and "This drawing is now mounted with the old verso as recto"

BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane nudo virile in piedi, visto di fronte, col peso sulla gamba destra e la gamba sinistra un po' arretrata, il braccio destro non raffigurato e il sinistro piegato al gomito, l'intera figura finemente chiaroscurata con tratteggi incrociati e paralleli
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo virile con testa e bracci a arrovesciate all'indietro (studio per l'Aman crocifisso), busto di un vecchio con una barba lunga quanto quella del Mosè e, in direzione capovolta, studio di un a braccio destro; inoltre, parole, forse inizi di poesie, sparse sul foglio
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude youth standing lightly on his right leg, the right arm not given, the left in outline is bent at the elbow. Elaborately shaded with cross-hatching
BB_1938_title_verso: Study for the Haman in the Sixtine Ceiling. In almost the same position that we find him in the fresco, with the difference that the movement instead of going from left to right goes from right to left. Also, but in inverse direction, a right arm, and inverse to this again a very slight sketch of the bust of an old man with a beard as long as the one of Michelangelo's Moses. A few words, seemingly the beginnings of poems, are scattered over the page
BB_1938_text_recto: A slightly varied copy of this figure exists at Windsor (see my 1749A)
BB_1938_text_verso: The date of this leaf is happily determined by the presence of the sketch for the Haman. As this bit of the Ceiling was painted scarcely earlier than 1511, the drawing will be of the same time. And this date is a valuable acquisition, for it furnishes proof that several kindred drawings - my 1588 and 1589, for instance - need not be earlier as, but for this, one might be inclined to hold.
Cataloguer's Comments: Handwritten comment in BB_1961's inventory number: RF

BB_1961_title_recto: San Girolamo ignudo, piegato su ambedue i ginocchi, in profilo a sinistra con un sasso nella mano sinistra ed il braccio destro proteso
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude Jerome kneeling on both knees in profile to left with a stone in his left hand and right arm stretched out
BB_1938_text_recto: It may be questioned whether an unspoiled touch of Michelangelo's hand remains here. The drapery and rocks are certainly not Michelangelo's but added by the hand which scrawled the word or two at the top of the leaf. The rest may, however, have been Michelangelo's originally and of the period of the Bathers.

BB_1961_title_recto: Faunesco nudo virile, in profilo a destra, col braccio destro proteso, che saltella sulla gamba sinistra, mentre solleva in alto la gamba destra, piegandola al ginocchio
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for a faunlike male nude in profile to right, leaping on his left leg, the other held up and bent at the knee, the right arm held out
BB_1938_text_recto: The action and spirit of this nude bear considerable resemblance to the only figure with a bow in the Gods Shooting at a Mark (Windsor, my 1613), and if not a study for that, is at all events of about the same date - perhaps 1530.

BB_1961_title_recto: Donna matura seduta in profilo a sinistra, nuda fuorché per un drappo che le copre i ginocchi, col braccio destro abbandonato lungo il fianco, mentre il sinistro si appoggia a qualcosa
BB_1938_title_recto: Female of ripe years seated, and but for a drapery over her knees, nude. She is in profile to left, her right arm falls to her side, while her left leans against something
BB_1938_text_recto: Probably done in connection with the Sixtine Chapel and may be an early idea for be an early idea for one of the sibyls or possibly for one of the figures in the lunettes. So close to Sebastiano that in the first edition I catalogued it as his also under my 2498.
Cataloguer's Comments: In BB_1903 it's catalogued also as Sebastiano del Piombo's under 2498
Cataloguer's Question: In BB_1903 it's catalogued also as Sebastiano del Piombo's under 2498: I insert it only in comment, is it correct?

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio di due nudi in lotta, forse per un Ercole ed Anteo
BB_1961_title_verso: Linee di scrittura
BB_1938_title_recto: Two nudes wrestling. Study possibly for a Hercules and Antaeus
BB_1938_title_verso: Lines of writing for which see Frey, 35A, and his Text, pp. 21-22
BB_1938_text_recto: The action is of the best, the mannerisms are certainly Michelangelo's. Morelli showed haste in condemning it. To the right, where the sheet must have been cut away, the fore part of a nude in outline, in an attitude recalling the studies for the Matthew. The date is not easy to fix, but most likely not long after the Sixtine Ceiling.

BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane nudo visto frontalmente ma con la testa girata in profilo alla sua destra, con la gamba destra leggermente alzata, il braccio destro sollevato ad arco dietro la testa e il braccio sinistro posto attraverso il petto
BB_1961_title_verso: Lo stesso giovane del recto, ripreso a sanguigna
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude youth with his head in profile to right, standing on left leg, the right slightly lifted the right arm is bent upward at the elbow, and the left drawn across the chest toward it
BB_1938_text_recto: A study from the model. The pen-work is closer to that in the two nude women (my 1589), but, as the touch is much less prompt, it is probably earlier. I am inclined to put it as early as the end of 1504, and it can be nothing less than a first study for that figure in the cartoon for the Bathers whom a companion is helping to fasten his armour. In the Holkham grisaille he is the topmost figure on the right. Be it noted, by the way, that this drawing furnishes at least one good proof for the substantial faithfulness of that copy. My 1730 verso is the copy of a slightly varied original.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 except "My 1730 verso is the copy of a slightly varied original."

BB_1961_title_recto: Donna volta verso destra che guarda in alto
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo virile nello stesso atteggiamento della donna sul recto
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: Cfr. lo studio per San Giovanni Evangelista, BB. n. 1582 e il dipinto della Galleria Doria Pamphili a Roma, nel quale questi disegni furono adoperati.
BB_1938_title_recto: Woman facing to right and looking up
BB_1938_title_verso: Male nude in same attitude
BB_1938_text_recto: Study for a Crucifixion, and late

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile seduto con le gambe incrociate verso destra, ma col volto girato a sinistra, che si tocca la coscia con la mano destra e alza la mano sinistra nel gesto di chi parla
BB_1938_title_recto: Male nude seated somewhat to right but facing to left, legs crossed, the right arm falling at the side, the left hand held out from the elbow
BB_1938_text_recto: This seems to be a study from life done at first rapidly with black chalk, then, while the model was still keeping his pose, gone over and corrected with ink. The style and manner is the same as in my 1588 and 1589, although inferior. This is the sort of sketch which I fancy escaped by accident from Michelangelo's periodic bonfires. It is probable that it was intended for some figure in the lunettes of the Sixtine Chapel. These, executed last of all were begun in August, 1511, and finished in October, 1512. The particular figure for which the sketch may have served is the one over Pope Voius. But the differences are considerable, for besides having a child between his legs, this figure sits a little more sideways, and is older.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo visto da tergo che solleva la mano destra tenendo bassa la sinistra a destra accurato studio di una gamba sinistra dal ginocchio in giù, col piede bene in mostra sotto, una testa di guerriero in profilo a destra che indossa un cimiero fantastico e bizzarro altri due schizzi di cimieri, l'uno sormontato da un'aquila, l'altro con un combattimento a rilievo
BB_1961_title_verso: Sette teste, sei delle quali in profilo, con pettinature fantastiche, senza dubbio destinate anch'esse alla "Battaglia di Cascina"
BB_1938_title_recto: Sheet of studies. Nude seen from behind probably intended like my 1479, 1481, 1598, etc. for the episode in the Bathers of two nudes holding up a third. A leg from above the knee with the foot stretched to the utmost. A head in profile to right wearing a fanciful helmet. Two helmets, one with a combat worked in relief, and the other topped by an eagle
BB_1938_title_verso: Seven heads, six of them in profile, with fantastic headdresses no doubt for the same purpose. (See my 1624C for copy of this leaf.)
BB_1938_text_recto: This fine early drawing, with its careful hatching, may have served for part of the cartoon of the Bathers (see my 1479, 1598, 1625). The warrior's head would point to that, and the eagle helmet differs but slightly from the one in the Holkham grisaille.
Cataloguer's Comments: Handwritten comment in BB_1903: "verso: seven heads, six of them in profile, with fantastic head dresses."

BB_1961_title_recto: Due nudi che ne sollevano un terso
BB_1961_title_verso: Due schizzi di un torso visto da tergo e schizzo di un nudo contorto. Tre piccoli abbozzi di nudi in vari atteggiamenti
BB_1938_title_recto: Two nudes holding up a third
BB_1938_title_verso: Two sketches of back of a torso and sketch of a contorted nude, in a free, rapid Raphaelesque manner, in ink. Three small rough sketches of nudes in various attitudes also for Bathers
BB_1938_text_recto: A more elaborated version of the sketch in the British Museum (my 1479) and like that connected with the cartoon for the Bathers. Although more finished, it does not seem of so good a quality perhaps because the shading has been reinforced by a later hand
BB_1938_text_verso: The Raphaelesque sketch, so much like the Haman in the Ceiling, is perhaps for the middle figure in the group on the recto.
Cataloguer's Comments: Handwritten comment in BB_1903: "Verso: Two studies of a left back of a torso, and a rough sketch of contorted nude, in a free raphaelesque manner, pen and ink. Three rough sketches of nudes, reclining, form behind and lowering down
Cataloguer's Question: I couldn't read the word before down in column Z

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per una Crocifissione
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio prospettico di una volta
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Crucifixion
BB_1938_title_verso: Perspective study of vaulting
BB_1938_text_recto: If by Michelangelo, as is probable, it must be earlier than any other done for or in connection with those made for Vittoria Colonna, e. g. my 1530. Curious is the head tainted with a touch of that poverty of feeling which overcame Michelangelo when he designed the head of the Minerva Christ.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa giovanile che si volta a destra sorridendo e, in basso, dita e pollice di una mano destra lungo l'orlo inferiore del foglio diverse parole in una scrittura per me non intelliggibile, ma apparentemente di mano di Michelangelo
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo virile seduto che si piega verso sinistra e volge la testa a destra nel medesimo atteggiamento della testa sul recto
BB_1938_title_recto: Youthful smiling head looking out to right, and below fingers and thumb of right hand. Along the lower left edge of the sheet several words of writing to me unintelligible, but seemingly in Michelangelo's hand
BB_1938_title_verso: Youthful nude leaning forward towards left and head in same attitude as on recto
BB_1938_text_recto: Steinmann (II, pp. 595 and 693) recognizes the verso as a study for the nude to the left of Isaiah on the Sixtine Ceiling, a reversal of my 1399D, corresponding more closely with the figure in the fresco but feels doubtful about its being an autograph. The head on the recto would be a study for the same figure. The difficulties of accepting these drawings are slight compared with the attempt to reject them. There is a look in the head which is a trifle unexpected and the shape of the ears is not convincingly Michelangelo's. The hand is feeble, but so it is in the fresco. The nude is more satisfactory although hypercriticism might find faults enough. And yet I can discover no solecism here that Michelangelo himself could not have committed. And if not Michelangelo's sketches for this nude shouldering a cornucopia what are they? Not copies after the fresco, for the head on the recto is older, more faunlike and the right arm of the nude is not covered by the cornucopia as it is in the painting. A copyist making variations after the finished figure is scarcely to be thought of unless indeed, what seems unlikely in this case, he was a deliberate forger. We fairly are reduced to the alternative of accepting this sheet either as an autograph or as a copy of an autograph, copy so faithful and of such a quality that an eye like mine can not distinguish it from an original. For which reason it seems wiser to accept it as Michelangelo's autograph. The nude is, by the way, both in modelling and contours close to the study in the British Museum for a Madonna (my 1493) and it has further affinities with my 1399A, 1416 verso, and 1596A.
Cataloguer's Comments: The reference to 1596A in BB 1938 is changed in 1397B-1 recto in BB 1961.

BB_1961_title_recto: Profilo di uomo con elmo sormontato da un drago secondo la tradizione verrocchiesca
BB_1938_title_recto: Profile of man wearing a helmet mounted by a dragon as in the Verrocchiesque tradition
BB_1938_text_recto: Early.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa grande al vero di un uomo barbuto con turbante
BB_1938_title_recto: Life-size head of bearded man wearing turban
BB_1938_text_recto: I see no reason for not accepting this head of Michelangelo as an autograph portrait of himself. It is in a bad state, but where not defaced or retouched the folds and the hatching are as much his as any other early pen-drawings rightly attributed to him. In the Louvre there exists a bust seen above a parapet (Louvre n. 1649) corresponding so exactly to the drawing that it must have been done after it. The painting looks like Dnaiele da Volterra's. The age given on the parapet cannot be trusted. Michelangelo could not have been 47 years old when he drew his own portrait. Perhaps the 4 ias a misunderstanding for 2 and the reading should be 27. That is the utmost age one could give to the face in the drawing, seeing that it is of an Italian of about 1500, when people in general, and Italians in particular, aged earlier than they do now. The style of the draughtsmanship would in no way oppose our dating the sketch 1502. Needless to insist on its interest and importance. Here we have Michelangelo as he saw himself in earlier years, the self-aware genius who a few years later bearded the fierce Pope Julius and some twenty years later still terrorized Clement VII. There is a look in the eye as of one who does not suffer fools gladly. The mask recalls portraits of the school of Pergamon - a school of which the mature Michelangelo often reminds us.

BB_1961_title_recto: Due studi per una Madonna seduta con un San Giovannino (o un San Giuseppe) disegnati in direzioni opposte
BB_1961_title_verso: Donna alta, in piedi, col volto quasi in profilo a sinistra e lo sguardo abbassato verso un bambino seduto a leggere sopra un mantello che ella regge dietro a lui, in alto, con la mano destra; in basso, studio separato del bambino; a sinistra, tre ottave in versi, e tre linee separate, tutte pubblicate nelle Dicthtungen del Frey, XXXVII (pp. 293, 372)
BB_1938_title_recto: Sheet of studies. The Virgin lightly seated to left, with the Child between her knees, snuggling up against her breast to the right the infant John restless with the cross in his left hand. The Virgin is distinguished, even elegant. The Children are peculiarly large
BB_1938_title_verso: Tall woman looking down upon a seated child who is busy reading. Her face is almost in profile, and with her right hand she holds up the drapery on which the child is sitting. Below, another study of the child. Also three octave stanzas of verse, and three spare lines, all of which are published in Frey's Dichtungen, XXXVII
BB_1938_text_recto: As a complete pyramidal group this sketch has few rivals. Whether intended - if with any definite purpose - for painting or sculpture is not clear. To my feeling the arrangement is more adapted to marble or bronze. In opposite direction to this is another study for the Madonna seated, leaning back a little, the better to support the weight of the Child, Who embraces and kisses her. To right, a nude asleep with the right arm thrown over the head - perhaps St. Joseph, and at all events an integral part of the group. The tenderness and pathos of the Madonna and Child are matchless
BB_1938_text_verso: The purpose of this drawing would seem to have been a marble group representing the Madonna looking down on the Christ Child reading. The motive is of course unprecedented. The arrangement would lend itself perfectly to execution in marble, and the platform on which the Child sits is a clear enough indication of the material that was in Michelangelo's mind when he made this sketch. Prof. Frey suggests that the shading in the background is for a niche, and he must be right. The Child is but little changed from the one in the Doni tondo. It seems to me not impossible that the group of the Madonna with the infant John on the recto was drawn two or three years later than the rest of this leaf. Let us look first at the other two sketches. The cross-hatching is still close, although freer than in Michelangelo's earliest work. The child on the verso has too much resemblance to the one in the Doni Madonna - which picture, I take it, was painted just before the beginning of the Sixtine Ceiling - and to the putti on the early shhet at the British Museum (my 1481 verso), to be of a date much later than, say, 1510. In the group of the Madonna kissing the Child, His arm has the precise form that we find repeatedly in the Ceiling, and never much earlier or later. The arm of the sleeping figure thrown over the head is also a common motive in the Ceiling. But in the group with the infant John there is a greater freedom of touch, a looser hatching, which makes me suspect that it is of somewhat later date. This impression is confirmed by the size of the infants, which certainly indicates an advance in Michelangelo's conception of the child's form - an advance accelerated, no doubt, by his having designed for the Ceiling so many putti necessarily on a larger scale than was called for by smaller and more intimate compositions. The Madonna, again, seems to me to descend from and not to precede the younger sibyls in the Sixtine Ceiling. As for the infant John, he should be compared with the putto in the Ceiling who supports Daniel's book, and also with the infant John in the beautiful red chalk drawing for a Madonna in the Louvre (my 1584 verso), which certainly stands close to the work in the Ceiling. The internal evidence would thus go to prove that the earlier sketches on the leaf might be contemporary with the Ceiling, and that the later one cannot have been done long afterwards. But it is obvious that a drawing like this later one must have been known to Raphael, and inspired his Madonna of Francis I, a work finished in 1518. Considering that the relations between Michelangelo and Raphael were not intimate, nor even direct, we must allow some itme for this motive to have reached Raphael, and can date its production scarcely earlier than 1516. then it should be noted that this same sketch is of the kind which had a great influence on Sebastiano del Piombo. One should look at the hand of the Madonna and compare it with, for instance, the Magdalen's in Sebastiano's Raising of Lazarus. Now, as we have seen (cf. section on Sebastiano), Piombo seems to have begun to study Michelangelo in good earnest when the Ceiling was approaching completion and to have form his manner on that and on drawings furnished him by Michelangelo directly afterwards. We may safely conclude, therefore, that these sketches are of no earlier date than 1510 and no later than 1516 - I should think no later than 1514. Certainly no part of it has any connection with the work at S. Lorenzo. The writing on the recto, of no intelligible significance, is by Prof Frey said to be Antonio Mini's. If true, which seems to me improbable, it would prove only that this leaf was still in Michelangelo's possession in 1524 or later - no cause of surprise, considering how many drawings he kept locked up in chests. I let this remain because it proves how difficult, if not impossible, it is to date the drawings of Michelangelo and his apprentices on internal evidence only. My present feeling about the Madonna and infant John on the recto will be found in Appendix XV.
Cataloguer's Question: See reference to Appendix XV in BB-1938 Text.

BB_1961_title_recto: Martirio di Santa Caterina. La scena si svolge sulle gradinate del vestibolo di un palazzo. La vergine martire, che appare in primo piano legata ad un palo fra due ruote esprime estatica rassegnazione, mentre i suoi nudi carnefici vengono scagliati da una forza invisibile contro i mozzi delle ruote e gli astanti terrorizzati, si accalcano in due gruppi compatti a destra e a sinistra. Nello sfondo, un altro gruppo fugge verso destra, mentre da sinistra entrano una principessa e le sue ancelle con gesti di gioia santa
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for a Martyrdom of St. Catherine. The scene takes place on the terraced steps of a palatial vestibule. The virgin martyr, with an expression of ecstatic resignation, appears in the foreground tied to a stake between two wheels. Her nude executioners are hurled over the wheel supports, and the bystanders press, in frightened haste, to right and left. In the background another group crowds to right to get away, while from the left enter a princess and attendants with gestures of holy joy
BB_1938_text_recto: As was first published by Adolfo Venturi (L'Arte, 1899, pp. 259-261), this sketch is the one made by the master for his life-long friend, the self-satisfied, painstaking, amiable simpleton, Bugiardini. A long article might be written and read with no profit wherein Vasari's methods and credibility would be discussed, and the differences between Michelangelo's sovereign genius and the hopeless, irremediable mediocrity of a Bugiardini made brilliantly clear but the intelligent student may have the pleasure of following it out for himself. The materials are this noble, intellectual design - where for once outside of Trecento art, the theme is treated as it should be - Bugiardini's puerile labour, still at St. Maria Novella, and Vasari's delightful pages on that painter in general, and on this work in particular. Here is what Vasari says about this altar-piece: "il quale finalmente diede finita l'opera in modo che non si conosce che Michelagnolo lo guardasse mai" (VI, p. 208). IN short, nobody would have known that Michelangelo had ever had anything to do with it. The precise date of the drawing is not easily fixed. The style and the workmanship recall the sketchier parts of the Cavalieri and kindred designs, as well as some of the studies for the Last Judgement and others of that period. The saint herself, in action, in expression, and even type, recalls the "Vita Contemplativa" in the Tomb of Julius. The reclining figure in the foreground already suggests the Paul in the fresco of the Pauline Chapel.
