Nothing in either style or workmanship would exclude the possibility that Michelangelo made this sketch during his last visit to Florence in the summer of 1533. The architecture may not be altogether without interest in connection with the genesis of the Laurentian Library.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: With that subtlety of pretentiousness which characterises the affrighted ignorance of officials, this masterpiece has been ascribed by the ex-officio Roman connoisseurs to Bugiardini. I shall not pay them the compliment of attempting for their benefit to demonstrate the obvious and even axiomatic. My friend Dr. Frizzoni has besides long ago entered his protest against this solemn nonsense. On the other hand, there can be no doubt that this sketch was made by the master for his life-long friend, the self-satisfied, painstaking, amiable simpleton, Bugiardini.

BB_1961_title_recto: La Caduta di Fetonte
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: [1957: Il gesto di Giove che fulmina ricorda quello di Cristo nel Giudizio Universale.]
BB_1938_title_recto: Fall of Phaeton
BB_1938_text_recto: Another version of the finished Windsor drawing (my 1617), and even earlier than the Malcolm one (my 1535), although later probably than the Haarlem sketch (my 1471). Consult these drawings in Catalogue. In the upper part this version differs from the others in that Phaeton falls between the horses instead of to the side. This instinctive stretching of arms towards the ground recalls the nude Joram falling out of a chariot in the medallion to the left of the Drunkenness of Noah in the Ceiling. Below, Eridanus is no indifferent river god, but stretches his arms upward, and the Heliades are even more convulsed than in the Malcolm sketch. Yet this is much more like the final version than the study for this part only at Haarlem. There Eridanus lies in the posture of the drunken Noah on the Sixtine vault and the Eliades, sexless, suggest Signorelli's "Fulminati" at Orvieto. Eridanus reminds us of Titian's Lawrence in that saint's martyrdom at the Gesuiti, Venice.

BB_1961_title_recto: In primo piano, vecchio ammantato in profilo a sinistra, dietro a lui, a destra, un altro uomo anziano, pure in profilo a sinistra, un uomo più giovane, di cui sono visibili solamente la testa e le spalle
BB_1961_title_verso: Uomo genuflesso a sinistra, ma visto da tergo, con un berretto schiacciato in testa
BB_1938_title_recto: In foreground an elderly man in profile to left in long mantle, elaborately hatched behind him to right another man, also in profile, slightly bending over, wearing large keys at his girdle, and to left another, younger man, whose head and shoulders only are visible
BB_1938_title_verso: Youngish man kneeling to left, but seen from behind, wearing a flat cap
BB_1938_text_recto: These are perhaps the finest of Michelangelo's earliest drawings, and they are obviously copies after older masters. Whose the originals may have been cannot - at least, for the figures on the recto - be open to doubt. These massively dignified people, with their majestic draperies, this profile in the foreground, could not have been a creation of any one but Masaccio, Perhaps one may venture to be more precise, and to suggest that these worthies were taken from the fresco of the Dedication of the Carmine described at length by Vasari. The man with the keys may well be the porter of the monastery whom Vasari mentions. Messer Giorgio, it is true, speaks of him as holding the keys in his hand (Vasari, II, p. 296), but we know he was not wont to sin on the side of over-exactness. The keys are so prominent that they must be considered as a badge of office, and Masaccio is not likely to have painted two porters. As for the kneeling figure, here also the sense for form, the structure, and the draperies are Masaccio's. In the Casa Buonarroti there is on the verso of n. 36F (my 1663 verso) a similar group with the addiction of two other figures. Certainly not by Michelangelo himself but copied (perhaps by Antonio Mini?) from an original by the master done after the same fresco as the recto of the sheet we have just catalogued.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added: I am, however, not aware that the flat cap was worn so early. Yet scarcely any one but Masaccio can be thought of as the author.
Cataloguer's Comments: The old inventory number (S.R. 150) is corrected with handwritten comment

BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane donna seduta, che inclina il capo verso destra ed abbassa lo sguardo sul bambino nudo, a cavalcioni sul suo ginocchio destro, al quale ella porge il seno. Questo è il più bello dei vari studi per una Madonna del Latte, essendo l'azione e l'espressione insuperabili ed il trattamento libero e adatto allo scopo
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo virile senza braccia, di proporzioni signorellesche, visto da tergo, ma col volto girato in profilo a sinistra
BB_1938_title_recto: Youngish woman seated, with her head bent down a little to right, looking at the naked child on her knee sucking at her breast. This is the most beautiful of several studies treating the same motive, the action and expression being unsurpassable and the handling free and to the purpose
BB_1938_title_verso: Nude man without arms, of rather Signorellesque proportions, seen from behind with the face in less than profile to left
BB_1938_text_recto: The date of this leaf is hard to determine. If we had no other guidance than is given us by the figure on the back, we might date it along with the beautiful Chantilly sheet (my 1397), as of 1504, or earlier. Nor does the Madonna give any decisive clue - unless indeed it be her head, which is drawn peculiarly with coarse lines, and altogether in a way which I find paralleled but once, and that in the drawing for the Christ at the Minerva (my 1543) formerly in the Oppenheimer Collection and now belonging to Mr. Brinsley Ford. That sketch dates from early in 1514, and I would place the Albertina leaf no later, at all events. Be it noted that, although the motive of the Madonna closely resembles the one executed for S. Lorenzo, it yet could scarcely have been drawn with a view to that work. Evidently it was an idea that haunted Michelangelo for many years, but which he seems to have realized only in more than mid-career with the group at S. Lorenzo. Morelli condemned this leaf altogether. The nude on the verso seems now (1934) to have been done, like my 1479, 1597, 1598, and 1645A, for the group of two soldiers holding up a third in the background of the Bathers. The Madonna need not have been done at the same date but possibly soon after.
BB_1903_text_verso: Same as 1938 and added:  Is it possible that this was intended for one of the Slaves in the Tomb of Julius; or was it indeed for a back view of the Christ at the Minerva, corresponding to the front view belonging to Mr. Heseltine (n. 1543)?
Cataloguer's Comments: The old inventory number (S.R. 152) is corrected with handwritten comment

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo anziano, grasso, che si protende ansiosamente in avanti e nudo in profilo a destra (per il soldato che aiuta l'amico a fissarsi l'armatura)
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo virile, visto da tergo, in atto di puntare un'asta verso destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Studies (it would seem from the model) for the figure helping friend with his armour, and for the fat man rushing forward
BB_1938_title_verso: Study - more highly modelled than the recto, and perhaps gone over with white - for the nude carrying a lance in the back row of the same composition
BB_1938_text_recto: Both in the famous composition of the Bathers, and dating probably from late in 1504. Morelli's condemnation of these figures was more intelligible, if no more defensible, than many other of his pronouncements about Michelangelo's drawings. That this leaf is the master's admits of no doubt, but it certainly is disappointing - as are nearly all the other remaining studies for the Bathers
BB_1938_text_verso: A drawing like this one may have had considerable influence on Raphael's draughtsmanship.
Cataloguer's Comments: The old inventory number (S.R. 157) is corrected with handwritten comment. In BB_1903 verso a handwritten comment correct with " more highly modelled than the recto, and perhaps gone over with white" the original sentence "of exact kind and quality of those on the recto".

BB_1961_title_recto: Studi di braccia in diverse posizioni, con indicazioni numerate dei muscoli
BB_1938_title_recto: Studies of arm in various positions, with ciphered indication of the muscles
BB_1938_text_recto: This is identical in quality with the last leaf for the Bathers, and must have been done with a view to that work, although its exact purpose is not to be determined. Four of the arms finished in pen, the rest more sketchily in black chalk.
Cataloguer's Comments: The old inventory number (S.R. 167) is corrected with handwritten comment. In BB_1903 a handwritten comment correct with " Four of the arms finished in pen and ink: the rest more sketched in black chalk " the original sentence "Pen and ink, all but the uppermost arm, which is in black chalk".

BB_1961_title_recto: Studi, in vari stadi di rifinitura, da vaghe linee di contorno alla più squisita elaborazione, per un udo femminile che siede, mostrando la schiena ed il seno sinistro, con la testa in profilo a sinistra, incorniciata dalle braccia, che poggiano, come i ginocchi, contro un drappeggio altri schizzi indecifrabili iscritto a penna "Micaelis Angeli manu anno aetatis suae LXXXVII Romae 1560, XXVII Martii" e più stoot a matita "A li 17 di febbraio a hore 23 a uso fiorentino 1563 alla Roma el Anno 1562"
BB_1938_title_recto: Studies in various stages of finish, from vague outline to the highest elaboration, of a nude seated woman leaning with her knees and arms against a drapery. Her head, in profile to left, is framed in by her arms and hands, and she shows her back and her left breast
BB_1938_text_recto: The motive is by itself an invention of genius, for one may scarcely conceive of another so calculated to bring out all the plastic qualities of the human figure. Indeed it is one that with variants has been treated again and again by the draughtsmen of your own time, by Degas in particular, in his many studies of women coming out of the bath. The execution of the most finished study (of the others it is not easy to speak) is indeed exquisite, yet not without a touch of senile mannerism. Nevertheless, this drawing cannot possibly belong to the date vouched for by the inscription. This, in ink, runs as follows: "Micaelis Angeli manu Anno aetatis suae LXXXVII. Romae 1560, XXVII. Martii." Below this some person, certainly not Michelangelo, has added in pencil: "ali 17 di febbraio a hore 23 a uso fiorentino 1563 alla Roma el Anno 1562." What all this nonsense may mean I cannot tell, but I venture to say that no competent person who has made a serious study of Michelangelo's whole career as a draughtsman will place this drawing later than 1540. Indeed, the works it goes with best are the Cavalieri drawings, particularly the Ganymede and the Windsor Phaeton (my 1614, 1617). It even occurs to me that this leaf may possibly have been done in the course of a drawing-lesson given by the elder to the younger friend. This would explain the various stages of finish, and, indeed, the roughest version (on the left) is scarcely Michelangelo's own, and may be the pupil's - whoever he was.
Cataloguer's Comments: The old inventory number (S.R. 169) is corrected with handwritten comment

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile in piedi, visto frontalmente, con la testa in profilo a destra, e il torso leggermente arretrato che stringe il gomito sinistro con la mano destra, pressando il braccio destro dietro la schiena su tutta la figura sono indicate le misure in proporzione ai lati, altri due schizzi leggerissimi
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo virile in piedi, leggermente volto a destra, ma con la testa in completo profilo, che tiene le braccia piegate, l'una sul dorso e l'altra sul torace
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude standing with head in profile to right, his body turned somewhat in same direction, the torso thrown back a little, the right arm extended across the back, with the fingers resting on the left arm. All over the figure are indications of measurement for proportion. Also two very slight other sketches
BB_1938_title_verso: Nude standing turned a little to right, but his face in complete profile, his arms folded
BB_1938_text_recto: The movement and proportions of the nude recall the David, although there is no obvious resemblance between them. The torso and the thighs are carefully and beautifully worked, the head and the legs caressly. An almost contemporary copy of this figure on a larger scale once belonged to Sir Edward Poynter
BB_1938_text_verso: This is a rapid study from the model, which model recalls the drawing in the Louvre (my 1594) for the man having his armour put on (in the Bathers), and cannot be of later date. A patient comparison with the figure on the recto, and with many of the pen-drawings of this period, must remove all question as to this sketch being by Michelangelo himself (note: An exact copy of this figure in the Uffizi (n. 6550F) passed as Pontormo's). The intention of both these nudes is pretty clear. They almost certainly are sketches for the slaves, which seemed to have formed part of even the earliest design for the Tomb of Julius. The one on the verso is almost identical with the uppermost one in the Oxford sheet containing slaves (my 1562).

BB_1961_title_recto: Altera testa giovanile, con un berretto munito di faldette sopra gli orecchi, che abbassa lo sguardo verso destra
BB_1961_title_verso: Volto assai eguale a quello sul recto, eseguito da un artista come il Sogliani
BB_1938_title_recto: Head of youngish person wearing a cap with lappets covering the ears, looking down a little to right haughtily
BB_1938_title_verso: Mask of nearly the same head, done by some such artist as Sogliani
BB_1938_text_recto: The style of this head is of the end of the Ceiling. It must have been  a study for a head in one of the lunettes, among the last bits designed by Michelangelo for the Sixtine Ceiling and recalls the Joseph over Pope Eutychius. Dr. Popp (Belvedere, Forum, VIII, 1925, p. 75) is right in dating the superb head on the recto much later hand it follows, of course, that it could not have been done for the Sixtine Ceiling. It occurs on a Madonna in a sheet formerly in the Oppenheimer Collection which looks like a copy by "Andrea di Michelangelo." See my 1694.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa satiresca a bocca spalancata, con diadema lunato e la barba ed i capelli acconciati con effetto decorativo
BB_1961_title_verso: Parte inferiore di figura rapidamente schizzata nella posa del Sansone ad Oxford
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for grotesque head with hair and beard decoratively arranged
BB_1938_title_verso: Lower part of a figure rapidly sketched in the attitude of the Samson at Oxford (my 1718)
BB_1938_text_recto: This, the most beautiful of Michelangelo's grotesques, belongs almost certainly to the period of the Medici Tombs
BB_1938_text_verso: This one is closer to Michelangelo, but scarcely his own
BB_1903_text_verso: Same as 1938 and added:  and not impossibly like the one at Oxford by Mini

BB_1961_title_recto: Tre Fatiche d'Ercole che si susseguono come in un fregio: da sinistra, Ercole e il Leone Nemeo, Ercole e Anteo, Ercole e l'Idra di Lerna
BB_1938_title_recto: Three feats of Hercules represented as one design . To right and left are Hercules with the Hydra and Hercules with the Lion. Between them is Hercules and Antaeus
BB_1938_text_recto: 1. The Hydra is a dragon of huge bulk with a long tail, and many serpent heads which career over the hero, hiss venomously in his face, or bite his body and limbs, as he leans upon its already supine carcass, toiling to master it. This design has great decorative beauty, the figure of the hero furnishing, as it were, a framework for the pattern formed by the hydra and its many heads, while the contrast between the high finish of the man and the lighter sketching of the monster - contrast surely deliberate - serves the double purpose of bringing the action into clear relief and of accentuating the differences between those elements in the legend which, from a plastic point of view, are more and those which are less real. 2. Hercules holds Antaeus between his arm and his chest, pressing the life out of the giant as he struggles, with his head buried under his own inverted torso, and against the loins of Hercules, his left foot stemmed against the hero's left knee, his left hand pressing against his slayer's right thigh. From Hercules' right shoulder hangs a shadowy drapery. 3. Hercules, nude, with the lion skin swinging behind him, straddles over the lion, and stooping a little to right wrenches the jaws apart. This, again, is most decorative, the lion and the lion's skin forming at once a frame and a background for the most beautiful, most exquisitely finished nude that Michelangelo ever drew. Above this group we read in the artis's hand "Questo è il secondo leone che Ercole ammazzo." This sheet shows us Michelangelo at the very beginning of his later manner, I mean the manner in which we find great dignity, matchless feeling for form, and wonderful finish, tinctured, if not tainted, with a certain relaxation of vigour in mere touch, as well as a certain carelessness in the drawing of extremities. In date it would seem somewhat earlier than the Cavalieri drawings, although it is tempting to fancy that it must have formed one of that series.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per una Resurrezione: Cristo ignudo, fuorché per l'ombra di un lenzuolo che Gli ricade dalle spalle, esce dalla tomba, tocca terra con un piede e già s'innalza, con lo sguardo ed il moto di un essere inconscio, in stato di sonnambulismo. Delle guardie molte dormono ancora, alcune fuggono costernate, altre brancolano, tuttora ignare di quanto sta accadendo
BB_1961_title_verso: Un braccio ed altri leggeri schizzi
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Resurrection. Christ, nude, with a shadowy drapery tossed from His shoulder, bursts out of the tomb, touches the ground with one foot, and already soars up, with the action and look of an unconscious, somnambulant being. Of the guards, some are still asleep, others take flight in consternation, while the rest grope about, not yet aware of what is happening
BB_1938_title_verso: An arm and other slight sketches
BB_1938_text_recto: This is an enlarged and elaborated version of the small sketch in the Louvre (my 1580). Both in the forms and in the treatment it has too many resemblances to the Three Deeds of Hercules to need special indication. They are doubtless of the same date. This also is a "show drawing" - it is indeed a marvel of dramatic force - and may well have been made for Cavalieri, although internal evidence alone would incline me to believe it of slightly earlier date.

BB_1961_title_recto: I Saettatori
BB_1961_title_verso: Memorandum con la data 12 Aprile 1530
BB_1938_title_recto: The gods shooting at a herma with a target affixed to it
BB_1938_title_verso: Memorandum with the date April 12, 1530
BB_1938_text_recto: They whirl up, some touching the ground with the toes of one foot only, one floating, and others sprawling or kneeling, all in attitudes of shooting. Yet but one bow appears in the composition, and that is carried by a Silenus-like creature who is not aiming. The foremost kneeling figure is singularly like one of the Aeginetan marbles at Munich, and should serve as a warning to those who would suppose Michelangelo had acquaintance with the Parthenon sculptures. In foreground lies a sleeping Cupid, in which Professor Lange finds a resemblance to Michelangelo's youthful work. Under the hindmost figure two putti are bowling at lighted faggots to make them flare up
BB_1938_text_verso: This may be the exact date of the drawing on the recto, but it need to be, and here again one is tempted to believe that I must have been made for Cavalieri, in which case it would be two or three years later. The putti are exactly like those in the Bacchanal which we know was done for Cavalieri. No drawing by Michelangelo is more famous, and it deserves most of its renown. The theme itself has the alluring fascination of young and graceful nudes in splendid action, while, but for slight signs of carelessness in the extremities, the modelling is to the last degree exquisite, conveying a sense of a substance firmer than flesh, and yet more plastic than marble, or ivory, or even bronze. The subject, according to respectable German authorities, seems taken from Lucian's Nigrinus. This sketch was engraved by Béatrizet and, as is well known, served a follower of Raphael's for a fresco now in the Villa Borghese.

BB_1961_title_recto: Ganimede rapito in cielo dall'aquila di Giove
BB_1938_title_recto: Rape of Ganimede. Jove's puissant eagle soars calmly upward, bearing the beautiful youth, who lets himself go voluptuously as he nestles between the eagle's wings and claws
BB_1938_text_recto: Quite likely this leaf is only half its original size, which must have been that of the other finished Cavalieri designs. The missing lower part may have had a landscape, a barking dog, etc. as in all the copies after this composition. There is a splendid contrast between action and relaxation, and as a pattern the design is delightful, Ganymede's fluttering mantle completing it to perfection (note: If this were of an earlier date, one would not hesitate to pronounce it a faithful copy, rather than Michelangelo's original. But this Cavalieri series is so constantly characterized by feebleness of touch and smoothness of execution that I do not in this instance regard these defects as militating against its authenticity. So fa as I know, no better version of this drawing exists, although Allori's, in the Uffizi, come close to it). This is perhaps the earliest of the drawings which we know that Michelangelo did for Tommaso Cavalieri. On January 1, 1533 (according to Frey, Dichtungen, p. 513), Cavalieri thanks Michelangelo for two drawings, and it is probable that the Ganymede was one of these. On September 5 (ibid., p. 522), Cavalieri speaks of this drawing as being for some time in his possession. Then it must be with this drawing that we should connect the facetious suggestion of the jovial and frivolous Sebastiano del Piombo in a letter dated July 17, 1533, that the Ganymede with the addition of a halo would do excellently well for a St. John the Evangelist rapt up to heaven, to be painted by Giovanni da Udine in the cupola of the New Sacristy at S. Lorenzo. We may thus date it early in 1533. (See Frey's Text, p. 11). The version there mentioned as in the collection of the late Newton Robinson is by Marcello Venusti.

BB_1961_title_recto: Tizio giace legato ad una roccia, guardando l'avvoltoio che gli dilania il fianco. L'uccello è uguale all'aquila che abbiamo visto nel Ganimede. Molto caratteristici sono la roccia e il tronco d'albero che assume la vaga forma di un'aquila urlante
BB_1961_title_verso: Figura ottenuta, dallo stesso Michelangelo, riprendendo i contorni del Tizio schizzato sul retro, e adattandoli, senza reale modifica di membra, ad un Cristo Risorto che tiene alto lo stendardo; accanto ad esso, appunto di una figura volta in lato, senza dubbio per uno dei soldati
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian from "The date is..."
BB_1938_title_recto: Tityus chained to a rock, on which he lies stretched, looks at the eagle, who is rending open his side. The eagle is the bird that we have seen in the Ganymede. Highly characteristic is the rock, and a sort of stump which takes the vague shape of an eagle screaming
BB_1938_title_verso: The same figure rapidly sketched on the outlines by Michelangelo himself, and arranged without much actual change of limb for a Resurrected Christ holding up the banner. Beside it an equally rapid sketch of a figure looking up intended, no doubt, for one of the soldiers.
BB_1938_text_recto: What could bear stronger witness to Michelangelo's indifference to mere invention, and to his preference for a few fixed attitudes than this change of a supine victim subjected to torure into the victorious Christ. He knew, as the greatest artists always have known, that it is not in inventiveness that the spirit of the highest art resides. The date is scarcely months, if even weeks, later than Ganymede. In the letter of September 5, already cited, Cavalieri speaks of this Tityus also as being since some little time in his possession. It is indeed not improbable that, as Professor Frey suggests, this was the other drawing for which Cavalieri thanked Michelangelo on January 1, 1533. On September 5, as he writes, Ippolito de'Medici saw this design, and made Cavalieri lend it to him to be carved in crystal by Giovanni (delle Corniole).

BB_1961_title_recto: Cristo Risorto
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Resurrected Christ. He is a most beautiful youth, nude, with but a shadowy drapery tossed behind Him. He soars up with His arms spread out, His right foot pressing the tomb as if about to take flight
BB_1938_text_recto: Not free from certain mannerism, it yet is one of the masterpieces not only of Michelangelo's but of all draughtsmanship. In point of date it seems to fit in between the last drawings and the next - 1533, therefore.

BB_1961_title_recto: Caduta di Fetonte. In cima al foglio Zeus in groppa alla sua aquila, scaglia la folgore: al centro la quadriga, i cavalli e Fetonte precipitano a capofitto in basso, si vedono il fiume Eridano indifferente, le tre Eliadi piangenti, Cicno ed un portatore d'acqua in un canneto
BB_1961_title_verso: Busto di donna disegnato da "Andrea di Michelangelo"
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for a Fall of Phaeton. At top of sheet Zeus is seen riding his eagle and hurling the thunderbolt. In the centre are the chariot, the four horses, and Phaeton crashing headlong. Below, Eridanus indifferent, the three Heliades in attitudes of despair, Cycnus and a watercarrier in a reedy meadow verso Female bust by "Andrea di Michelangelo"
BB_1938_text_recto: This is more highly elaborated, and more decoratively arranged version of the sketches in the Malcolm Collection (my 1535), and at Venice (my 1601), but scarcely a more spirited one. Altogether admirable in the Windsor shhet is the gropu of Father Eridanus and the Heliades. In a letter of September 5, 1533 (Frey, Dictungen, p. 522), Cavalieri acknowledges having received this drawing three days before
BB_1938_text_verso: The hair, the folds, the stroke should be compared with my 1630.

BB_1961_title_recto: Baccanale di putti
BB_1938_title_recto: Bacchanal of children
BB_1938_text_recto: In the foreground we see to left a female satyr suckling one child while sheltering under her mantle another asleep, and to the right a man asleep, with putti, pulling a cloak away from behind him. In the centre a number of children are toiling to carry an ass with its feet in the air. Above on the right other children play around a butt, some lapping wine from the butt itself, one drawing it into a dish, and others drinking. On the left we see more children busy around a cauldron, some attending to the fire, others to the pot, and one bringing in a sucking pig. Engraved by Béatrizet, by Aenea Vico in 1546, and again in 1553 by an anonymous engraver giving the address of Antonio Lafrerii. That this strangely charming composition was made for Cavalieri we know from Vasari but even without him we should conclude from internal evidence that it belonged to the series. The children are exactly those we have seen in the Gods Shooting, the sleeping nude is like the Eridanus in the Phaeton, and the treatment is exactly the same as in the other Cavalieri drawings. The date may be 1533, and certainly not later than 1534, for with the Last Judgement Michelangelo's drawing undergoes a further change. A pen-drawing at Oxford (my 1716) is a hasty copy after this composition. The sketch in the Uffizi (my 1398A), for the Tenieresque naughty child in the uppermost group on the right, is taken from the antique and may have been done twenty or more years earlier.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 except last sentence: the sketch in the Uffizi (n. 1641), for the Tenieresque naughty child in the uppermost group on the right, despite its being on a leaf with three lines of Michelangelo's handwriting, seems to me nothing more than a copy, although a clever and spirited one.

BB_1961_title_recto: Schizzi per la parte inferiore del "Giudizio Universale"
BB_1961_title_verso: Studi di nudi e di membra
BB_1938_title_recto: Studies of nudes and of limbs
BB_1938_title_verso: Sketches for the lower part of the Last Judgement
BB_1938_text_recto: These sketches seem to me now (1934) to have been done at a fairly early moment in the gestation of the whole design, when the artist jotted down gropus or single figures for every part of the composition as they occurred to him, without close reference to their ultimate place in the composition.
BB_1903_text_recto: Not of the finest quality, but probably Michelangelo's. The smaller figures on the verso are much better, although even they are inferior to other studies for the same composition
Cataloguer's Comments: In BB_1961 "recto" and "verso" are circled and inverted

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per una Crocifissione: Cristo è inchiodato su di una croce a forma di "Y" con il capo ricadente sulla Sua spalla sinistra, fra la Vergine che si volge a Lui e San Giovanni che incrocia le braccia curvo per il dolore
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio di una gamba
BB_1938_title_recto: Christ on V-shaped cross, with His head falling on His left shoulder below, two figures, one looking up, and the other bent with grief
BB_1938_title_verso: Study of a leg
BB_1938_text_recto: Christ is highly finished, but the other figures are slightly sketched. As in most of the series to which this belongs, there are numerous pentimenti. The series I refer to is of the studies for a Crucifixion made in 1546 for Vittoria Colonna, some however doubtless done later, after her death.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per una Crocifissione: Cristo è inchiodato  su una croce del tipo solito, fra la Vergine tutta raggomitolata, che si stringe il capo con le mani incrociate e San Giovanni che alza il volto e le mani verso di Lui
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Crucifixion. Here Christ is on an ordinary cross. He has been much changed and worked lover. To right St. John looking up, and to left the Virgin with folded arms, her face in her hands
BB_1938_text_recto: Far less interesting and, as it seems to me now (1934), either altogether later or the last of the series done for Vittoria Colonna.
BB_1903_text_recto: For the same series as the last, but far less interesting.

The attribution of the second to Pontormo may count as a partial acknowledgement that both are Naldini's.

BB_1961_title_recto: Epifania
BB_1938_title_recto: Design for Epiphany
BB_1938_text_recto: Ascribed to Andrea. This is a copy after a sketch by the master. Two other copies are known to me, both in the Uffizi. One (n. 634E) may be an exact repetition of Andrea's original. The other (Santarelli 677) is a little more free. That this Louvre version is Naldini's will not be discounted by ant one acquainted with that draughtsman. The hand of the angel is as good as a signature.

BB_1961_title_verso: Debole schizzo di una Madonna in una nicchia con quattro Santi ed in alto lingue fiammeggianti ed Angeli
BB_1938_title_recto: Virgin kneeling in profile to left worshiping the Child, Who lies on the edge of her spreading mantleBackground of clouds and trees
BB_1938_title_verso: Faint sketch of Madonna in niche with four saints and above tongues of flames and angels. More characteristic of Neri than the front
BB_1938_text_recto: Ascribed formerly to Filippino. The type, the heavy build, and the draperies of the Virgin on the recto made the attribution to Filippino absurd. There was more reason in thinking of Fra Filippo, to whose period this sketch belongs but the more I studied it - and I did study it for many years - the stronger grew my conviction that its real author was Neri di Bicci not so much, I should add, the Neri of the tasteless large altar-pieces, as the painter of a number of smaller pictures, chiefly Madonnas, which, in the private collections, where usually they are found, pass under much greater names. In this sketch the most determining detail is the background with cloudlets that Neri seldom omits form his works.

BB_1961_title_recto: Santo Vescovo (probabilmente Sant'Agostino) seduto in atto di scrivere su un rotolo spiegato sulle sue ginocchia
BB_1938_title_recto: Saint, probably Augustine, seated on ground with a scroll on his lap on which he is writing
BB_1938_text_recto: Ascribed by Wickhoff to Alvise Vivarini and in Albertina Cat. III (n. 7) to the following of Lorenzo Monaco. It is so close to Bicci di Lorenzo that it may be by him but to me it looks even more like his son Neri's work done in his studio.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile adagiato, in profilo a destra, ma con lo sguardo verso lo spettatore, che si solleva puntando le mani dietro a sé
BB_1938_title_recto: Male nude seen reclining to right and lifting himself with both hands behind him, but looking straight out

Cataloguer's Comments: Loeser bequest.

BB_1961_title_recto: Ritratto di donna piuttosto giovane, seduta in una savonarola di tre quarti verso sinistra, ma con la testa vista di fronte e la mano destra posata sull'avambraccio sinistro
BB_1938_title_recto: Portrait of youngish woman seated turning slightly to left, but head seen full face. Her left arm rests on her chair. Her right hand touches her left wrist
BB_1938_text_recto: It is ascribed to Andrea, and Morelli (Kunstschrift) attributed it to Puligo. Nevertheless it is distinctly Pontormesque, as the arrangement, the somewhat puffy modelling, and the folds go to prove. I am inclined to believe that it is by Pontormo himself, although the drawing of the hands is far from exemplary. Could be dated between 1525 and 1530.

BB_1961_title_recto: Ritratto di giovane uomo, seduto, con un guanto nella mano destra e la sinistra appoggiata sul ginocchio. L'azione sembra ispirata dal Duca Giuliano di Michelangelo
BB_1938_title_recto: Portrait of youngish man with glove in right hand, and left hand resting on knee. The action seems inspired by Michelangelo's Duke Giuliano
BB_1938_text_recto: The quality is of Pontormo's best. It turns out that this drawing undoubtedly served for the portrait of a man with a lute by Bronzino in the Uffizi (n. 1575). The easy inference is that both were from the same hand. Looked at closely we see that the sketch, although squared for transfer, could not have served for the cartoon of the painting. The differences are too many. The face in the drawing is broader, the nose fleshier and shorter, the whole cast of features more plebeian. In short the painting turns the rather thickset though still young mechanic into a humanist, a collector perhaps, a musician certainly. Then the draperies in the drawing have an ease and the the touch a freedom which are closer to Pontormo than to Bronzino. There I must leave it for I have unfortunately not seen the original again and the reproductions differ widely. If Bronzino, this drawing must be early for if by Pontormo it would be of the S. Felicita period. But it would not surprise me if not in spirit only but in material fact as well this study were by the older and greater master and that owing to some accident the painting was done by Bronzino. Perhaps the sitter wanted to be portrayed as more of a gentleman than Pontormo would make him.
BB_1903_text_recto: The quality is of Pontormo's best.

BB_1961_title_recto: Uomo con una sciarpa avvolta intorno al capo: la testa, la manica e la mano altamente rifinite, il resto appena indicato
BB_1961_text_recto: Attribuito ad Andrea del Sarto, ma più probabilmente una delle prime cose del Pontormo

BB_1961_title_recto: Fanciullo in piedi
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938 and 1938 Title, in Italian
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of child, attributed to Andrea, and for his Dresden Madonna, but really Pontormo's, as the forms, the quality, and stroke prove
BB_1938_text_recto: It is of course from his earlier years when he was nearest to Andrea.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Lunetta con un Compianto sul Cristo morto
BB_1961_title_verso: Frammento di una figura femminile seduta su un muricciolo
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Deposition in lunette. Christ reclines with His head and shoulders in the lap of a disciple, as in Andrea's Pitti Pietà. Another disciple, also nude, kneels behind. To right is seen Mary fainting into the arms of two women. There is good action in this fine composition
BB_1938_title_verso: Female figure seated on wall. Giglioli in Dedalo, VII (1926/27), p. 780, connects it with Poggio, which would make the recto a good deal earlier than I had considered it to be in my first edition. Clapp (Dessins, p. 87) had given it the same date as Poggio without having seen the verso.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane donna nuda, che tiene raccolto sui fianchi un velo con la mano sinistra e si tocca una treccia con la mano destra, mentre un putto vivace fa per allontanarsi da lei verso sinistra
BB_1938_title_recto: Young nude female stooping slightly as she holds, joined over her loins, a slight drapery. With her right hand she touches one of her tresses. Beside her, a lively child about to rush off to the left
BB_1938_text_recto: This charming study is catalogued as a preparatory sketch by Andrea for his Scalzo Charity. But the stroke and modelling are far too feeble for him, and to the knowing eye every bit of this design so clearly betrays the hand of Pontormo that it is surprising that it has never before been ascribed to him. The woman's face has the long oval that we know in his St. Veronica in the Pope's chapel at S. Maria Novella, in the Madonna formerly at S. Michele, in more than one figure in the Annunziata fresco, and elsewhere. The chubby child is Pontormo's typical one. But, better than a signature, are the hands, all three of them being, one more than the other, intimately characteristic of our artist. No doubt when making this design, Pontormo had Andrea's Charity in mind, and indeed the action of the child is taken , although reversed, from one on the right in that composition. It is not improbable, moreover, that our group was drawn while Pontormo was still with Andrea in 1512-1513, and on acquaintance with the latter's original design for the fresco. As for the subject, it must be a Venus getting out of the bath, with Cupid gambolling by her side.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Ritratto a mezza figura di una fanciulla piacente, ma un po' maschile, col braccio sinistro appoggiato ad un tavolo ed il destro appoggiato al sinistro
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: [1957: Questo disegno deve aver fatto una grande impressione a Degas (in parte, immagino, a causa della sua attribuzione a Leonardo) perché lo copiò due volte, in un disegno e in un olio, National Gallery of Canada, Ottawa
BB_1938_title_recto: Portrait bust of pleasant, although somewhat masculine, young woman, with left arm resting on table and right folded across other
BB_1938_text_recto: Owing doubtless to the arrangement of the arms, this splendid design was still catalogued as Leonardo's when my first edition appeared. Morelli (Kunstchronik) ascribed it to  Bacchiacca, and German critics to Franciabigio. But many years ago its real authorship was recognized by Signor Enrico Costa. Indeed, this attribution is so obvious that nothing short of total ignorance of Pontormo as a draughtsman and as a painter could fail to assign this portrait to him at sight. Who but he has just these hands and this ear? And who else has features modelled in exactly this manner? Its date can scarcely be before 1525.
Cataloguer's Comments: In Inventory Number the "F" is circled and we read handwritten "wrong!". In BB_1961 Text "National Gallery of Canada, Ottawa" is handwritten.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Busto di uomo attempato, quasi in profilo a destra

BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo prono, appoggiato ai gomiti
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: [1957: Il dipinto corrispondente a questo disegno è stato ritrovato da R. Oertel nel Museo di Hannover.]
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for St. Jerome kneeling in fervent prayer
BB_1938_title_verso: Nude female lying on her stomach, but with chest resting on her elbows
BB_1938_text_recto: The recto was suggested perhaps by Leonardo's picture now in the Vatican. The style point to about 1535 or later, and as the design is squared for enlarging, a painting corresponding to it probably was executed. As Clapp has pointed out, it comes very near to the figures in the S. Felicita chapel.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi

BB_1938_text_recto: The youth on the recto is of the type appealed to Puligo, particularly in such cases as the knee-length young prelate, until recently in Lord Plymouth's Collection and the bust of another youth in the Abreo Collection of the Seville Museum.
BB_1903_text_recto: He resembles the charming portrait at Lucca, enough to make one wonder almost whether this be not a study for that.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Composizione di sei figure per una delle lunette a Poggio a Caiano
BB_1938_title_recto: Another study for same purpose
BB_1938_text_recto: I have said in the text regarding these two designs that they could not have been made for the lunette which was executed, and they must have been intended for the one opposite, taken in hand after the siege of Florence. To what I have there said in proof of the later date it should be added that the shield under the window in my 1976 has an advanced Cinquecento shape, and the further and more important comment that the style of drawing is late. The most obvious characteristic of Pontormo's middle period is the mannered way of giving accent to his figures by the excessive swelling of their limbs, a characteristic displayed in both these sketches, particularly in my 1977. See, for instance, the extraordinary distortion of the forearm of the female figure in the lower right-hand corner.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi

BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938 and 1938 Title, in Italian
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of winged putti, flying birds, and in a cartouche drawn with pen, six tiny putti flying one after the other. Altogether charming
BB_1938_text_recto: See Clapp (Dessins, p. 102), who has excellent reasons for believing that these were to serve for the Careggi frescoes.
BB_1903_text_recto: Probably not later than 1530. Altogether charming.

BB_1938_title_recto: Study for knee-length portrait of soldier in simple jerkin, with strap for belt and left hand on pommel of sword
BB_1938_text_recto: A remarkably personal yet direct presentment. Vasari speaks of a portrait of a Francesco Guardi in soldier's dress done during the siege of Florence. The person in our sketch has nothing of the professional military swagger, and the style of drawing would bear out the date of the siege. Possibly, then, this is the sketch for that painting.

BB_1961_title_verso: Testa di fanciulla ricciuta
BB_1938_title_recto: Two separate studies for costume and headof elderly woman, the latter, although half effaced, is still full of spirit and individuality
BB_1938_text_recto: Latish. The head of young girl on verso is of poorer quality and may be a copy by Pontormo after a Quattrocento head. See for the sketches on the recto Jenö Lànyi in Mitt. d. K. H. Insti. Florenz, IV, pp. 93-95. He attempts to prove that they were for the portrait of Maria Salviati at the Uffizi (n. 3565). The difficulty is that the head is so much older looking than in the painting and so much older than the woman under forty that Maria was in 1537 when she sat for this picture.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Schizzo sommario, ma grande e splendido di un nudo virile disteso su un panneggio, lungo il fianco sinistro, con la gamba destra ritratta e la testa quasi nascosta dal braccio a sinistra, in direzione perpendicolare al nudo, due teste virili un po' stralunate
BB_1961_title_verso: Altre otto teste più o meno spettrali, due delle quali a penna, ed un piccolo nudo
BB_1938_title_recto: Summary, but large and splendid sketch of nude lying on his face with right leg drawn back on right side. The head is almost hidden by the arm
BB_1938_title_verso: Eight more or less spectral heads, two of them in ink, and a small nude

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane nudo disteso sul fianco destro, che cerca di respingere col piede, urlando, un personaggio che l'afferra per il polso sinistro
BB_1938_title_recto: Sprawling youthful male nude lying on his side and yelling
BB_1938_text_recto: A caricature of Michelangelo's Tityus, but intended perhaps for the S. Lorenzo frescoes, and certainly of that date.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Donna slanciata visibile dalla vita in giù con le gambe nude, la destra appoggiata a una sfera, la sinistra piantata fermamente sul terreno in direzione capovolta, studio separato per il piede destro
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio molto più affrettato per un nudo maschile col braccio sinistro alzato
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of lower part of very slender female, nude below pelvis, with right leg resting on stone, and left firmly planted on ground also study for a foot
BB_1938_title_verso: Much hastier study for male nude with left arm held up
BB_1938_text_recto: Perhaps Pontormo's masterpiece in red chalk. Not only have the limbs a tender grace, and an elegance as of Cellini's most finished bronzes, but a luminousness of a translucent substance - a quality obtained by the exquisite way in which the white of the paper has been used as a material. The contours have great charm although they lack the vivid, vital touch of an Andrea. The date is between 1520 and 1530
BB_1938_text_verso: Clapp (Dessins, p. 118) connects the recto with the St. Michael at Pontormo, and I admit that the action of the legs is like that figure, but the proportions are much nearer to the Galatea in the Barberini picture. It may have served for both as is the case of my 2225A, which seems to have been used for the St. Francis in the S. Michele Visdomini altar-piece and later on for the Pygmalion.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Due giovani nudi virili, quello a destra visto di fronte e appoggiato ad un'asta, l'altro in profilo verso destra, in basso deboli indicazioni di una testa
BB_1961_title_verso: Giovinetto nudo seduto per terra con le braccia teste in avanti come se brancolasse, a carboncino; rapidi schizzi di un profilo e di un nudo femminile visto da tergo, a penna
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938 and 1938 Title, in Italian
BB_1938_title_recto: Two youthful nudes, one leaning on staff, seen full face, and the other beside him in profile
BB_1938_title_verso: Youthful nude seated on ground with arms stretched out as if groping. Almost like the boy in the Annunziata Visitation although somewhat later. In ink rapid sketches of a profile and of a female nude, seen from back
BB_1938_text_recto: These figures are in every way close to Andrea. Perhaps they were intended for an Adoration of the Shepherds. In lower corner, faint indication of head.
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 and added, after "Shepherds": but possibly for Poggio a Cajano.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi

BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo virile visto di fianco e busto di putto che vola verso destra

BB_1938_title_verso: Male torso seen form side

BB_1938_title_recto: Upper part of youthful figure, with arms as if flying, and face as if possessed. Also winged putto flying, and seated figure raising himself on his hands

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Putto a cavalcioni di un tronco d'alloro, con la mano sinistra alzata in atto di trionfo, ed ogni membro teso al massimo
BB_1938_title_recto: Putto straddling trunk of laurel, with left hand held up in triumph, and every limb stretched to utmost
BB_1938_text_recto: Done certainly in connection with the decoration of Poggio a Cajano, but in the one lunette that was painted it does not occur, although the sketch is squared for enlarging.
BB_1903_text_recto: Done certainly in connection with the decoration of Poggio a Cajano, but in the one lunette that was painted it does not occur, although the sketch is squared for enlarging.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi

BB_1938_text_recto: Both this and the preceding sketch may have been, as the more mannered draughtsmanship would seem to imply, for the second lunette which was, I suspect, planned but never painted.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile seduto con la testa gettata all'indietro e lo sguardo a sinistra egli allunga la gamba destra per terra mentre la sinistra è piegata e sollevata e piega il braccio destro sulla testa, serrando il pugno sinistro vicino al collo

BB_1938_title_recto: Study of nude seated with head tossed back in profile to left, with right leg stretched out and left drawn up, right arm bent over head, and left with fist doubled up held close to neck
BB_1938_title_verso: Cast of drapery
BB_1938_text_recto: Fine although angular contours, and excellent shading. Doubtless done in connection with Poggio a Cajano, but does not occur in the fresco

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane nudo virile semisdraiato su un parapetto al quale appoggia il gomito sinistro
BB_1961_title_verso: Schizzo rapido, benché a grandezza naturale, di una testa quasi in profilo a sinistra
BB_1938_title_recto: Study (probably from nude male model) for shepherdess reclining on extreme right lunette at Poggio a Cajano
BB_1938_title_verso: Rapid but large sketch for portrait head nearly in profile to left
BB_1938_text_recto: The only difference is that in the painting the legs are extended on the ground, while here the nude lies on the parapet, with the left leg hanging over it, and the other drawn up. The drawing before us is at all events one of Pontormo's most spirited and most vivid, and of singular brilliancy of touch.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Giovinetto nudo, seduto frontalmente con le gambe ritratte e i piedi incrociati che si fa solecchio con la mano destra in basso altri studi per le sue gambe e, su scala minore, un altro nudo accoccolato nell'angolo superiore destro, in direzione capovolta, piccolo appunto di un nudo virile semidisteso col braccio sinistro alzato sopra la testa
BB_1961_title_verso: Giovinetto che siede per terra appoggiandosi al gomito sinistro; la stessa figura ripetuta in basso su scala minore; a sinistra, grande studio di una gamba destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Rapid but most delightful sketch of youthful nude seated fronting us with legs drawn up and right hand shading face. Certainly for Poggio a Cajano, and perhaps for the figure seated on the ground on the extreme left but turned sideways towards us. A smaller sketch for the same, various limbs, and a mere jotting for the figure seated on the parapet on the extreme left in the fresco
BB_1938_title_verso: Hasty study from draped male model for shepherdess reclining on extreme right in same fresco; my 2159C offers a more elaborated version. On the left we see a leg which in the fresco belongs to the shepherdess seated on the parapet. This part of the composition was thus already fixed when Pontormo drew this figure.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi

BB_1938_title_recto: Study of heroic female nude, reclining on her right elbow, with book in right hand, and with left arm around child, who lies suckling at her breast as she looks down at him
BB_1938_text_recto: This noble composition is but a variant, and I venture to believe a happier variant, upon Michelangelo's cartoon for a Venus embraced by Cupid, which Pontormo coloured in 1531. This study must, however, have been drawn some years later, but it is still free from obvious attempts to imitate Michelangelo's over-finished style of draughtsmanship of this years.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi

BB_1938_title_recto: A nude, and, on smaller scale, one male nude striding along like St. Christopher, and one rather charming female nude lightly seated. Very Michelangelesque. Squared for enlarging. Probably for S. Lorenzo.

BB_1903_text_recto: This fine figure probably was done in connection with Poggio à Cajano, where, however, it does not occur.

BB_1961_title_verso: Quattro nudi virili, uno disteso visto da tergo, uno genuflesso e altri due accoccolati, l'uno quasi frontalmente e l'altro quasi in profilo a destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude seated on ground, with arm resting on bent left knee, and another nude kneeling in profile to left. Of the same quality as the recto of the last, although somewhat later and probably already done in connection with Poggio
BB_1938_title_verso: Reclining figure seen from back, and two others crouching, one seen nearly front and the other sideways. The two latter are almost certainly for the shepherd seated on the ground on the extreme left of the Poggio a Cajano fresco
BB_1903_text_recto: Same as 1938 except Of the same quality as the recto of the last, and the seated figure probably for the same purpose, but the kneeling one may have been for the "Pietà", for which we have the dead Christ.

BB_1938_title_recto: Head

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi

BB_1961_title_verso: Altri due studi a sanguigna per il nudo inginocchiato sul recto e, a carboncino, una grande figura diabolica, un piccolo schizzo per la stessa, e altri per una piccola donna incinta e per una testa
BB_1938_title_recto: Two swift and charming sketches in red chalk for nude figure kneeling in profile to right, probably for the Creation of Eve (see my 2108). In black chalk, one faint and another more elaborate sketch in imitation of one of Michelangelo's reclining figures in the New Sacristy at S. Lorenzo
BB_1938_title_verso: Two further studies for same kneeling figure, and, in black chalk, a large demon shape, and a small female nude. Beginning of last manner

BB_1938_title_recto: Child's head turned slightly to right, in black chalk. Study of bent left leg, and of knee in red chalk
BB_1938_title_verso: Study of drapery for young female head, excellent
BB_1938_text_recto: The child's head was for decorative putto on the left in the S. Michele altar-piece, the leg for the infant Baptist, and the female head probably for the Madonna in the same work.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi

BB_1961_title_verso: Giovane donna nuda a mezza figura
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: [1957: Craig Smith, Art Bullettin, Settembre 1949 (figg. 10 e 11) attribuisce ambedue gli schizzi al Bronzino. Può darsi che egli abbia ragione per ciò che riguarda il
BB_1961_text_verso: o, ma non riesco a scorgere la mano del Bronzino nel recto.]
BB_1938_title_recto: Realistic bust of coarse, middle-aged female, kerchiefed, open-mouthed, with eyes turned up, and candle in right hand
BB_1938_title_verso: Upper part of youngish nude female
BB_1938_text_recto: Middle years.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi

BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938 and 1938 Title, in Italian
BB_1938_title_recto: Christ on the Cross, the top of which is shaped like a triangle, against whose apex rests the Saviour's head. Copied, with slight variations, from the Crucifixion with a cross of similar shape, by Michelangelo at Windsor (my 1621). Late
BB_1938_text_recto: I feel very doubtful about his sheet after seeing the original again. The old attribution to Battista Franco on the verso may hit the truth.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Fanciullo nudo seduto a gambe divaricate verso destra, che accenna con la mano destra mentre si tocca il ginocchio con la mano sinistra
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo deforme visto da tergo
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938 Title, in Italian and added:
BB_1961_text_verso: Benché iscritto "Jacopo Pontormo", dubito che sia suo.
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude child pointing with right hand, his left hand touching knee. Study, but in reversed direction, for infant Baptist in the altar-piece at S. Michele Visdomini

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo maschile semisdraiato
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938 and 1938 Title, in Italian
BB_1938_title_recto: Study from male nude, for reclining shepherdess on right in the Poggio a Cajano fresco
BB_1938_text_recto: Similar to my 2047, but much nearer the action - is in fact, of the exact action - of the painted figure. Both these drawings are deliberate imitations of Michelangelo's style of curvilinear draughtsmanship. Even the accent and the shorthand tricks suggest the greater master in his earlier phases, as, for instance, in the design of a warrior, perhaps for the St. Matthew (my 1399). It is noteworthy, however, that, as is usual with imitators, Pontormo in these drawings, outruns his master's style of the moment and, indeed, in some respects these two studies remind one of nothing so much as of a series of black chalk sketches in London, Windsor, and Lille, for the Last Judgement, done by some clever assistant of Michelangelo's at that date.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per il panneggio intorno alle gambe di un'esile donna che scende uno scalino verso sinistra
BB_1961_title_verso: Rapido schizzo di un paesaggio a sanguigna, nel quale sono disegnati a carboncino due mani e un panneggio
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for drapery below the waist of slender female walking
BB_1938_title_verso: Rapid sketch of middle distance of landscape in red chalk, and drawn over it in black chalk two hands and bit of drapery
BB_1938_text_recto: The study of drapery is almost certainly for the young woman in the Annunziata Visitation, carrying a basket on her head. One of the hands is for the old woman with the staff in her hand. Be it noted, however, that in the fresco the corresponding parts are reversed, which proves that, to begin with, Pontormo intended having these female figures on the right, instead of on the left. The other hand may be the Virgin's or one now draped. Clapp connects them with one of the Panshanger Joseph panels (Life, fig. 30). They may have served for either, both paintings being of nearly the same period.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Giovinetto nudo disteso per terra sul fianco destro, con la gamba destra piegata al ginocchio e la gamba sinistra buttata in avanti così da passargli davanti al naso anche un esile nudo seduto leggermente
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938 and 1938 Title, in Italian
BB_1938_title_recto: Youthful nude lying on right side on ground, with lower leg bent at knee and upper leg folded back so that tip of toe reaches beyond head, also a slender youth lightly seated. Probably for Poggio a Cajano
BB_1938_text_recto: No modern French draughtsman could have chosen a more audacious pose, and, what is more singular still, there is in this sheet very little that might not pass for the work of the best recent Parisian artists.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo di un giovane prono a terra come in atto di bere a una pozza testa velata di giovane donna in profilo a sinistra e studio del suo velo
BB_1961_title_verso: Un cavallo e studi di gambe equine
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude youth reclining on left side. Head of youngish woman in profile to left heavily draped, and a cast of drapery
BB_1938_title_verso: Studies of a horse
BB_1938_text_recto: It is not improbable that all these sketches were done in connection with the Adoration of the Magi now in the Pitti, in which case they represent the first groupings rather than the final intention. The profile would thus be for the Madonna in a more traditional attitude than in the picture, the nude for the kneeling king, and the horses for those in the middle distance.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi

BB_1961_title_verso: Due ginocchi
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for left arm draped above elbow, with hand shutting down on something
BB_1938_title_verso: Legs
BB_1938_text_recto: Clapp (Life, fig. 70) correctly identifies the recto as being for the young man in the foreground at Poggio.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Donna alta e elegante d'ispirazione classica, avvolta in un drappeggio che lascia trasparire il nudo, col braccio destro rialzato sopra al gomito, e il sinistro abbandonato lungo la roccia alla quale ella si appoggia (a carboncino), parzialmente disegnata sopra la parte inferiore di un nudo femminile (a sanguigna)

BB_1938_title_verso: Male nude seen from behind, four busts, and two knees
BB_1938_text_recto: This was perhaps intended for some allegorical figure painted at about the same time that Pontormo was doing the Louvre altar-piece.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Scarno vecchio barbuto, avvolto in ampi paludamenti, in atto di scrivere sopra una tavoletta che regge contro un muro con la mano sinistra nell'angolo inferiore destro, una mano destra e una mano sinistra col pugno stretto, degne di Andrea del Sarto
BB_1961_title_verso: Delizioso studio dal vero di un giovane in abiti da lavoro, con la testa in profilo a destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of bearded, thin, but heavily draped old man leaning against wall, writing on tablet which he holds to wall with left hand. This is for the Evangelist in the early altar-piece at Pontormo. Below studies for both hands-worthy of Andrea - for the St. Michael in same work. Black chalk but the hands in red chalk
BB_1938_title_verso: Delightful study from model of youth in working clothes with head in profile to right

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Torso visto da tergo, in una posa che ricorda gli studi michelangioleschi dal torso vaticano, ma con il braccio sinistro piegato indietro
BB_1938_title_recto: Torso seen from behind, in attitude recalling Michelangelesque studies after the Vatican torso, but with the left arm bent back. Late

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Mezza figura di donna attempata con ampio mantello e fazzoletto, le mani appoggiate alla vita
BB_1938_title_recto: Half-length figure of elderly woman with ample cloak and kerchief, her hands resting over her waist

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo maschile in profilo a destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Male nude in profile to right
BB_1938_text_recto: Middle period weak.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo giovanile piegato a destra come per zappare, con tutto il proprio peso sulla gamba destra e gli occhi fissi sull'asta che tiene con ambo le mani in direzione opposta, un profilo
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio di una gamba destra piegata (a carboncino) e di un braccio sinistro (a sanguigna)
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: [1938: Mi sembrano troppo deboli per essere autografi.]
BB_1938_title_recto: Youthful nude bending over to right, with entire weight on left leg, looking at staff or mace which he holds with both hands. In inverse direction, a profile
BB_1938_text_recto: Early, and admirable, possibly for Poggio a Cajano.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Incantevole nudo virile che si piega con abbandono verso sinistra
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo maschile visto da tergo, ma con la testa in profilo a destra e le mani giunte in preghiera
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938 and 1938 Title, in Italian
BB_1938_title_recto: Charming male nude with drooping figure, and head bent down in profile to left - study for pretty female in right upper part of the Pietà at S. Felicita
BB_1938_title_verso: Male nude seen from behind but with head in profile to right. His hands are folded in prayer
BB_1938_text_recto: This is splendidly relaxed, supple, pliant, and in outline fluent.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di un giovane dagli occhi spiritati, volta di tre quarti verso destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Male head, with wild eyes turned slightly to right, studied from life for foremost figure in the Pietà at S. Felicita

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Testa maschile
BB_1938_title_recto: Male head. Middle period

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di uomo anziano
BB_1961_title_verso: Confuso studio di un nudo virile acefalo, con gli arti in varie posizioni
BB_1938_title_recto: Bust of bald-headed elderly man, study from model
BB_1938_text_recto: Clapp (Life, fig. 72) identifies it with the head of the peasant to the extreme left at Poggio. Certainly one of the most contemporary of old master drawings.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Torso nudo appoggiato sul fianco destro, visto da tergo
BB_1938_title_recto: Female torso resting on hip, seen from behind. Smooth and late

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di vecchio leggermente buttata all'indietro, con espressione di sofferenza
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio curiosamente accademico per un nudo che regge un'asta nella mano sinistra
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian and added: [1957: Fu identificato dal Clapp col Battista dipinto su uno dei pannelli del Carro della Moneta di proprietà della Zecca, del 1514 circa. Avendo finalmente veduto quei pannelli alla Mostra del 1956 non metto più in dubbio l'identificazione pur essendovi un abisso fra il disegnatore e il pittore di queste banali decorazioni per pubbliche cerimonie.]
BB_1938_title_recto: Old man's head tossed back a little to left, with expression of suffering
BB_1938_title_verso: Curiously academic study for nude holding staff in left hand. Clapp (Life, fig. 8) connects it with John Baptist for the Carro della Zecca. Unfortunately I gave never been able to see these fragments of the Carro although they are supposed to exist.
BB_1938_text_recto: This head, which would seem to have been suggested by the Laocoön, occurs several times in Pontormo's early pictures. You may find it thrice at least in the National Gallery Story of Joseph. This particular study (of fine plastic and colour effect, by the way) may have been for Joseph in the S. Michele Visdomini altar-piece.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo piuttosto esile visto da tergo con le braccia alzate come per ascendere al cielo
BB_1938_title_recto: Rather slender nude, with arms held up almost as if floating upwards. Seen from behind. Late and Michelangelesque, but fair

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Due torsi distesi visti da tergo, ed uno cisto di fianco
BB_1938_title_recto: Two reclining torsos seen from behind, and one seen sideways. Late

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Donna nuda seduta verso destra, ma con la faccia volta allo spettatore, che allunga il braccio destro fino a toccare l'orlo di un libro aperto
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938 and 1938 Title, in Italian
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude female reclining, seen sideways from behind, but with face to front, with right hand at arm's length resting on edge of open book - study suggested by one of Michelangelo's reclining figures, and intended, perhaps, for a sibyl
BB_1938_text_recto: Clapp (Life, fig. 132, and Dessins, p. 168) suggests that this and my 2086 may gave been sketches for the frescoes in the Loggia of Castello.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Torso maschile con la testa buttata all'indietro e le mani come legate dietro alla schiena
BB_1938_title_recto: Male torso with head thrown back and hands behind. Late, and probably for some Dead Christ, as my 2066, 2069 or for a Christ at the Column

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo femminile di forme mature, ma maestose, disteso frontalmente su dei cuscini, col braccio destro alzato sopra la testa che è in profilo a sinistra ed il braccio sinistro allungato a toccare un globo, posato su un parapetto
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude female of mature but majestic form reclining on pillows, with right arm raised to head (which is in profile to left), and left arm stretched out with hand resting on globe
BB_1938_text_recto: See my 2084. Clapp (Life, fig. 133) connects it with the frescoes for Castello or Careggi.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Busto d'uomo ancor giovane con la testa buttata un po' all'indietro
BB_1938_title_recto: Portrait bust of youngish man with thrown back a little, study for head on extreme right in the altar-piece at S. Felicita

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo maschile sul punto di inginocchiarsi a destra, con la testa in profilo perduto e il braccio destro teso in avanti studio di spalle testa di persona anziana vista di fronte e profilo a sinistra di persona morta o addormentata
BB_1938_title_recto: Male nude kneeling to right, with hands held out. His head is seen almost from the back. Also head of person dead or asleep turned down to left, and head of elderly female
BB_1938_text_recto: These powerful studies were probably made in connection with the S. Felicita Pietà before it had taken final shape in Pontormo's mind. Thus the nude would be for the kneeling figure in the foreground, the face almost in profile for the Dead Christ, and the other head for one of the holy women.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile a mezza figura visto da tergo, che si appoggia inerte a un parapetto, colla testa nella mano destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Limp male nude, seen from behind leaning with head in right hand on parapet
BB_1938_text_recto: Middle period.

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo seduto a gambe aperte, appoggiato al gomito destro con un bastone nella mano sinistra
BB_1961_text_recto: [1957: Non già, come credevo, uno studio poi scartato per un pastore nella lunetta di Poggio a Caiano, bensì probabilmente riferibile a uno dei Patriarchi già affrescati nella volta della Cappella Capponi a Santa Felicita (1526-28), come suggerisce il Gamba.]
BB_1938_title_recto: Seated nude, with legs apart and drawn up, leaning on right elbow, his left hand resting on staff, doubtless for one of shepherds at Poggio a Cajano, although he does not occur in the fresco

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
BB_1961_title_recto: Torso visto da tergo, in una posa che ricorda gli studi michelangioleschi dal torso vaticano, ma con il braccio sinistro piegato indietro
BB_1938_title_recto: Torso seen from behind. Late

Collection_main: Gabinetto disegni e stampe degli Uffizi
