Another reflection we are led to by the loose handling, which anticipates Michelangelo's later manner, is that, as is exemplified so frequently, the imitator is apt not only to take his start from the point at which he first finds his master, and to travel forward in tho same direction with tho increased velocity of a fresh energy; but also that the imitator, running a necessarily shorter orbit around the same ideal, passes more rapidly through its phases, and thus at times anticipates some of those to which every definite manner or style once taken up, automatically, and inevitably leads.
BB_1903_title_recto: Study for a Crucifixion. The Crosses are very high, impressively towering over the groups below. The middle one, which rises a little above the others, is shaped at the top like an inverted A, as in several of Michelangelo's own so much later studies for the same subject. On the left, a group of horsemen. Below, various attendants on the fainting Virgin, and figures looking up

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per una Pietà in cui la Vergine siede per terra col Figlio in grembo, circondata da altre quattro figure
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo atletico, con le braccia legate dietro la schiena, il volto barbuto chino in avanti e la gamba sinistra piegata al ginocchio
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Pietà
BB_1938_title_verso: Athletic nude with arms bound behind him, his bearded head drooping and Ieft log bent at knee. Perhaps for Flagellation
BB_1938_text_recto: Does not look by the same hand as the recto or indeed by Sebastiano in any other phase known to me, but much more as if by some Michelangelesque follower of a later generation, like AIessandro Allori. Several compositions by Eugene Delacroix remind us of this Pietà by Sebastiano. It would be more interesting still if it could be proved that Delacroix invented the pattern and action for himself because he too was, despite all differences, a master of the nude.
BB_1903_title_recto: Study for a "Pietà"

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per la "Flagellazione" affrescata in San Pietro in Montorio a Roma
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for the Flagellation executed in fresco at San Pietro in Montorio
BB_1938_text_recto: I do not believe that Sebastiano actually began this work until he had finished his paintings at the Pace which seem to have taken up the whole 1521. This study is of scarcely earlier date.
BB_1903_title_recto: Study for the Flagellation executed in fresco at San Pietro in Montorio

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per il Cristo nella "Flagellazione" in San Pietro in Montorio a Roma
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Christ in the Flagellation at San Pietro in Montorio
BB_1938_text_recto: Study for the Christ in the Flagellation at SanPietroin Montorio. I cannot quite accept N. 365, a male head, and its verso, the figure of a woman, as Sebastiano's, although it has found favour with critics of note. To me these drawings would rather seem to be by a Roman imitator of the Venetian.

BB_1961_title_recto: Papa Clemente VII e l'Imperatore Carlo V, seduti a un tavolo, discutono una questione forse relativa al Nuovo Mondo, poiché il Papa accenna col dito a un mappamondo, che uno dei due assistenti a destra gli sta presentando con sollecitudine; anche quattro assistenti a sinistra sembrano prendere un vivo interesse alla discussione, uno consulta un volume in folio, un altro misura una carta geografica con un compasso; alle loro spalle, alcune figure in abiti talari; a destra tre cavalieri con cappelli piumati; al centro, sopra un parapetto, la tiara del Papa e la corona dell'Imperatore ai lati di un ostensorio
BB_1961_text_recto: Sebbene nessun documento parli della presenza di Sebastiano a Bologna al tempo dell'incontro fra il Papa e l'Imperatore nel 1530, non è affatto improbabile che il Papa, durante il lungo periodo di rapporti con Sebastiano, gli abbia ordinato una pittura che celebrasse l'avvenimento: pittura per la quale Sebastiano non arrivò mai a fare più che lo schizzo. È fuori discussione che si tratta di un disegno di Sebastiano e di quella data. Confronta BB n. 2497 D, replica, verosimilmente autografa, al Louvre.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per una Crocifissione: vasta composizione pittorica, con un Cristo su una Croce posta in prospettiva a destra (come in uno degli schizzi per una Deposizione ad Haarlem), a sinistra varie figure che soccorrono la Vergine prostrata e tutt'intorno soldati a cavano e a piedi con lance e bandiere
BB_1961_text_recto: Quantunque attribuita a Michelangelo, questa composizione è sotto ogni aspetto la più veneta che si possa assegnare a Sebastiano. Il suo largo respiro è assai significativo e la fattura è così pittorica da suggerire il Pordenone o il Romanino, piuttosto che un qualsiasi Fiorentino e meno che mai il meno pittorico fra di essi. Inoltre non vi si può trovare alcun accenno ad una chiara linea di contorno, ma soltanto vaghi aggruppamenti di masse. Nuila potrebbe essere più caratteristico di Sebastiano del tocco e del chiaroscuro, deile gambe affusolate e dei cavalli fantastici. Deve essere anteriore a qualunque altro disegno di Sebastiano per questo tema, anche a quello famoso del British Museum, BB n. 2485. Quello, anzi, sembra il risultato di critiche mosse da Michelangelo a un disegno come questo, nel quale la sua influenza non è ancora percettibile. Un confronto tra il presente disegno e queilo di Londra offre una chiara idea di ciò che fosse Sebastiano agli inizi e di ciò che tentò di farne Michelangelo. Uno stadio intermedio della medesima composizione, è rappresentato da una copia ad Oxford, BB n. 1708. 1955: Debbo ringraziare Giuseppe Fiocco per avermi segnalato che questo foglio è uno studio del Pordenone per la Crocifissione nel Duomo di Cremona.
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Crucifixion... A broad pictorial composition, with the cross to one side and Christ seen upon it sideways, as in one of the Haarlem sketches for a Deposition. On the left a group surrounding the prostrate Virgin. All around, soldiers, horse and foot, with lances and flags
BB_1938_text_recto: Although attributed to Michelangelo, this is in every way the most Venetian composition that can be ascribed to Sebastiano Its extension in breadth is significant enough, and the whole treatment is so pictorial as to suggest Pordenone or Romanino rather than any Florentine, and least of all its least pictorial one. Then nowhere can you find an approach to a clear outline, but only broad massing, and vagueness. Nothing could be more characteristic than the touch throughout, or the shading, or the spindle legs, or the fantastic horses. It must be a drawing preceding any others of the kind by Sebastiano, even the famous one in the British Museum. The latter must have arisen after Michelangelo's criticism upon such an one as this, wherein his influence is as yet scarcely perceptible. A comparison of the two gives us a vivid idea of what Sebastiano was to start with and what Michelangelo endeavoured to make of him.                                                                                                    Another drawing, an intermediate stage of the same composition, is represented by a copy at Oxford (my 1708).
BB_1903_title_recto: Study for a Crucifixion

BB_1961_title_recto: Figura femminile, avvolta in leggeri panneggi, seduta di tre quarti verso sinistra, con la testa vòlta a destra
BB_1961_text_recto: Fischel (OLD Master Drawings, Settembre-Marzo, 1939-40,  pp. 31-32) giustamente ricollega questo disegno alla "Madonna del Velo" a Napoli.

BB_1961_title_recto: Copia tratta dalla Madonna ed Angeli nell'Accademia di Venezia, BB n 2501, ivi attribuita a Michelangelo, ma realmente, come vide il Wickhoff, di Sebastiano
BB_1938_title_recto: Copy after the Madonna and Angels in the Venice Academy there ascribed to Michelangelo, but really, as already recognized by Prof. Wickhoff, by Sebastiano
BB_1903_title_recto: Copy after the Madonna and Angels in the Venice Academy there ascribed to Michelangelo, but really, as already recognised by Prof. Wickhoff, by Sebastiano del Piombo

BB_1961_title_recto: Cristo deposto, sorretto da otto figure
BB_1961_text_recto: 1957: Le debolezze di questo disegno anticipano curiosamente le debolezze stilistiche del tardo Michelangelo.
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of eight or nine figures for Deposition or Pieta
BB_1938_text_recto:
I should think about 1515-1518 to be the proper date for this design...The female .figure
must have been known to Rosso Fiorentino before 1521, the date of his Volterra Descent from the Cross, in which there is one reminiscent of her.
BB_1903_title_recto: Study of eight or nine figures for a Deposition or "Pieta."

BB_1961_title_recto: Quattro studi per un Cristo morto steso per terra e tre studi del suo braccio destro
BB_1938_title_recto: Various studies for the Dead Christ in the Viterbo "Pietà"
BB_1938_text_recto: There is here a touch of Florentine dryness almost as of the late Pontormo, Bronzino and even Allori. Conceivably by Giovanni Paolo Rossetti for his Volterra Deposition of 1551.
BB_1903_title_recto: Various studies for the Dead Christ in the Viterbo "Pietà"

BB_1961_title_recto: Donna che fila, uomo che dorme, due bambini che giuocano ed un terzo addormentato nella sua cuila
BB_1961_title_verso: Per questo disegno vedi BB n. 1578 B
BB_1961_title_correction: Per questo disegno vedi BB n. 1578 A
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for a domestic subject, probably a Holy Family
BB_1938_title_verso: For verso see my 1578A
BB_1938_text_recto:
This must be early, perhaps as early as 1512-13...The length of the neck
makes it probable that this sketch was done some few years later, and others features and
traits have enough in common with the few drawings that may be by Pietro Urbano
(my 1444, 1661B verso, 2480 verso...) to make one suspect the same
hand here also...
BB_1903_title_recto: Study for a domestic subject, probably a Holy Family

BB_1961_title_recto: Madonna seduta frontalmente, ma col torso girato in profilo sinistra, che sorregge il Bambino nel suo grembo
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Madonna in profile to Ieft with the sleeping Child between her knees
BB_1938_text_recto: As early perhaps as 1514.
BB_1903_title_recto: Study for a Madonna in profile to left with the sleeping Child between her knees

BB_1961_title_recto: Madonna seduta in profilo a sinistra che regge il Bambino nelle braccia protese e, nello sfondo, un'altra figura appena accennata
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio raffaellesco per una Sacra Famiglia con San Giovannino o meglio per un Riposo durante la Fuga in Egitto
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Madonna in profile to Ieft, holding the Child at arm's length, and in the background another figure
BB_1938_title_verso: Study for Raphaelesque Holy Family with Infant John, or rather for a Rest in the Flight
BB_1938_text_recto: The verso is in the style which recalls drawings of the Pietro Urbane-Mini type.
BB_1903_title_recto: Study for a Madonna in profile to left, holding the Child at arms' length, and in the background another figure
BB_1903_title_verso: Study for a rather Raphaelesque Holy Family

BB_1961_title_recto: Madonna seduta col Bambino addormentato fra le braccia
BB_1938_title_recto: Madonna seated with the Child asleep in her arms
BB_1938_text_recto: This rapid, fumbling sket-ch, ascribed to Michelangelo, is by Sebastiano, and done, like several others, under the inspiration of the figures in the lunettes of the Sixtine Ceiling. The next-of-kin to this are two other drawings for the Madonna in this collection (my 2494 and 2495...). One should note the shading that serves as drapery over the knees. As nearly always in Sebastiano's sketches of this period, the head is very tall. The faltering, almost aimless line, is also characteristic. The length of neck would suggest a later date, after 1520.
BB_1903_title_recto: Madonna seated with the Child asleep in her arms

BB_1961_title_recto: Due uomini accovacciati per terra, che alzano gli occhi sbigottiti
Incontro della Vergine con Sant'Elisabetta, la prima a figura intera, la seconda interrotta alla vita
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for the entire figure of the Virgin and the upper part of Saint Elizabeth
BB_1938_text_recto: This was ascribed by M. Frédéric Reiset, in the Louvre catalogue, to Sebastiano, but stated to be a study for the Louvre Visitation. It is not for that work, but for a later Visitation done for Santa Maria della Pace (note length of Virgin's neck), the fragments of which now belong to the Duke of Northumberland at Alnwick.
BB_1903_title_recto: Study for the entire figure of the Virgin and the upper part of Saint Elizabeth

BB_1961_title_recto: Madonna seduta col Bambino sul ginocchio destro, San Giovannino sotto il braccio sinistro e, dietro, San Giuseppe e Sant'Anna
BB_1961_text_recto: Con antica iscrizione: "Fra Bastian del Piombo"

BB_1961_title_recto: Papa Clemente VII e l'Imperatore Carlo V, seduti ad una tavola, circondati da ecclesiastici e studiosi
BB_1961_text_recto: Il foglio è mutilo a destra, dove appaiono le sole mani dell'astante che regge i mappamondo. È forse una replica autografa di BB n. 2488 A.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per Cristo portacroce
BB_1961_title_verso: Figura del Padre Eterno

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per la Sant'Agata del 1520 a Pitti

Gentildonna appena trentenne, vòlta verso destra, visibile fino ai ginocchi, con un vestito dalle maniche a sbuffi (come la "Sant'Agata" della National Gallery a Londra, n 24) e una sciarpa che ricade in una grande ansa dalla spalla sinistra al braccio destro
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch for portrait of lady scarcely thirty turned somewhat to right although her look is almost frontal. She is seen down to knees, has a kerchief on the back of her head, wears a dress with puffed sleeves like the National Gallery Saint Agatha, and a scarf that falls in a loop from right shoulder to her arm.
BB_1938_text_recto: Exceedingly pictorial modelling of face, in which respect it is remote from Michelangelo and even Pontormo. The only surviving sketch for a portrait. Note how much more "bourgeois" in character than any of the finished works.

BB_1961_title_recto: Madonna seduta col Bambino acefalo, in piedi su un parapetto
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Madonna and Child. She sits a little sideways on a parapet upon which the Child stands
BB_1938_text_recto: The action is intimately Michelangelesque, and the motive magnificent, but the handling is sufficiently independent of Michelangelo to account for the fact that this noble design already bears the name of Sebastiano. Both as motive and as style this study stands between the former Oppenheimet sketch for a Holy Family, and the painting of the same subject at Naples. This picture, by the way, is not, as both Oavalcaselle and Morelli agree, an early, but, on the contrary, a relatively late work, being, despite its Raphaelesque motive, treated in an advanced Michelangelesque fashion, and painted in that cool grey manner which in Sebastiano we discover first in his various portraits of Clement VII. It was done, as a matter of fact, for the Holy Family at Burgos, which corresponds in every way with what has been said about the character and dating of the drawing.
BB_1903_title_recto: Study for Madonna and Child. She sits a little sideways on a parapet upon which the Child stands

BB_1961_title_recto: Sant'Agata a figura intera e studio per una mano, su scala maggiore
BB_1938_title_recto: Saint Agatha carrying her breasts on a tray in right hand and holding up her draperies with left. Also study for a hand
BB_1938_text_recto: Apparently for an altar-piece of which, however, we have no further knowledge. It may have been done toward 1523.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per una Sacra Famiglia: nell'interno di una stanza fra una tenda a destra e una finestra a sinistra, la Madonna regge col braccio sinistro il Bambino nel suo grembo, mentre colla mano destra tiene qualcosa come una ghirlanda al di sopra di una figura vagamente accennata che potrebbe essere San Giuseppe
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Holy Family... Within a room between a drawn curtain and window, the Madonna holds the Child with her left arm on her lap, while with her right hand she holds something like a garland over a vague figure, who may be Joseph
BB_1938_text_recto: In the action of the Madonna there is a close resemblance to the female in Roman costume, turning away with her hands held up, in the Raising of Lazarus. The elegance and daintiness would point to a slightly later date than that work. In spirit it is not unlike the Holy Family at Burgos although somewhat earlier.
BB_1903_title_recto: Study for a Holy Family. Within a room, between a drawn curtain and a window, the Madonna holds the Child with her left arm on her lap, while with her right hand she holds something like a garland over a vague figure, who may be Joseph. In the action of the Madonna I feel a close resemblance to the female in Roman costume, turning away with her hands held up in the Raising of Lazarus.

BB_1961_title_recto: Due figure femminili drappeggiate
BB_1961_title_verso: Studi di piedi, a penna, disegnati in senso inverso sopra una figura femminile in atto di spargere fiori
BB_1961_text_recto: Gli angoli superiori sono stati ritagliati.
BB_1961_text_verso: I primi non mi sembrano convincenti e sono forse di un'altra mano.

BB_1961_title_recto: Cristo deposto da sei figure, in grembo alla Madre svenuta
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio di gambe e di panneggi
BB_1938_title_recto: Study of eight or nine figures for a Pietà
BB_1938_title_verso:
Study of legs, and
drapery
BB_1938_text_recto: To what is said in the text I should now (1934) like to add that nothing can be less sculptural than the figure of the Madonna prostrate in a faint, piercing as it were the group and extending inward into space. Michelangelo, as I conceive him, could not have done a head like the one upon which Christ's head rests, or an old woman like the one clinging to His legs, who, by the way, anticipates Sebastiano's prophets at San Pietro in Montorio and the old woman in the Chigi Birth of the Virgin at Santa Maria del Popolo in Rome.
BB_1938_text_verso: Poor, but in technique closer to Michelangelo than recto...
BB_1903_title_recto: Study of eight or nine figures for a" Pietà"

BB_1961_title_recto: Sul tergo della pittura di Sebastiano rappresentante la "Pietà"
BB_1938_title_recto: A number of sketches in black or red chalk, pell-mell one over the other
BB_1938_text_recto:
I can attempt to ascribe only the most easy to decipher. The largest, taking up the greater part of the space, is the head with the curling, streaming looks of a youthful figure asleep. The high lights done with white. Apparently it was first drawn with small open eyes. Than came a tall nude stretching from top to bottom of panel, sketched after the lay figure with its Ieft arm extended. From above the hip of this nude seems to emerge something that could be taken for a queer leg bent at the knee. But the upper part of this looks more plausibly like a much enlarged eye of the head first mentioned, this time seemingly with the lid closed in sleep; what seems to be the foot. may be the bead possibly of a seated nude at right angles to the tall one. Finally, the other eye was enlarged to match the first one, turning the face into a sleeping one. On our left we see two studies for the seated Virgin in the Pietà. Owing to the unevenness of surface it is very difficult to obtain a satisfactory reproduction of these sketches and scarcely anything appears of the detail so characteristic of Sebastiano as, for instance, the excrescent ankles and the elongated forefingers. It is to be assumed that no one will dispute that these scrawls are by Sebastiano. Michelangelo is of course out of the question if only for the fact that he was at Florence or the Tuscan seaside while this Pietà was being designed and painted. If these sketches were on paper some students would try to convince us that they were by "Andrea di M.", Mini or Silvio Falconi, perhaps even Daniele da Volterra or Venusti. Finding them on the back of a picture finished about 1517, none of these attributions are chronologically possible except to Silvio, and there is no reason to assume that this person was in any way attached
to Sebastiano as an apprentice who might conceivably have been allowed to do these scrawls. But there is no sheet of sketches catalogued here as Sebastiano's which contains more incitations to the student to attribute those on the back of this Pietà to the various authors just mentioned. The sleeping face would not easily escape being taken for Daniele, the heads of the two Madonnas done so geometrically would be given to the omnibus Mini comprising my "Andrea," the historical Mini and perhaps Pietro Urbano. The cipher like a tilted 6 that
does for nose and mouth of the tall nude occurs on the famous drawing of a Dragon
(my 1555,...), the back of which is certainly by "Andrea," while the dragon may be his as well.

BB_1961_title_recto: Cristo morto sorretto dalla Vergine
BB_1938_title_recto: Dead Christ supported by His Mother
BB_1938_text_recto: Of somewhat later date than the last.
BB_1903_title_recto: Dead Christ supported by His Mother

BB_1961_title_recto: Madonna seduta che abbraccia il Bambino e San Giovannino in piedi alle sue spalle
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio della Vergine per una Visitazione
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Madonna holding the Child, with the Infant John by her side
BB_1938_title_verso: Study of the Virgin for a Visitation
BB_1938_text_recto: Although showing great kinship with Michelangelo's figures in the spandrels and lunettes of the ceiling, this design may yet be considerably later, but scarcely later than 1520.  The resemblance of her head to that of the person supporting the Virgin in the Leningrad Pieta makes it likely that it is in fact as early as 1517. It curiously answers to the description given in a letter of no earlier date than 1532, addressed by Sernini to Giovanni Mahona, of one of two subjects that Sebastiano could paint for the latter's master, Don Ferrante Gonzaga. It reads thus: "Una Nostra Donna bella con Figliuolo in braccio et un San Giovanni Battista che faccia seco un poco da moreschina come il pili delle volte si sogliono dipingere" (Campori, Sebastiana del Piombo e Ferrante Gonzaga, p. 5). It is possible that being asked to give an idea what subject he might paint, Sebastiano pulled out this very design.
BB_1938_text_verso: This is so strikingly and manifestly Venetian that I am not a little surprised at its not having long since put students on the track of the real author of the sheet. The draped figure resembles nothing else so much as some of the most Hellenizing bits of the most Hellenizing of the Lombardi in their famous reliefs at Saint Antony of Padua. It is just possible that it is a study for the Louvre Visitation, which would agree with the date one should give to the Madonna. But the style is far too Venetian for such a date (1521), and the fact that the sheet has been cut at the top, decapitating the figure, would point to the conclusion that, done earlier, it accidentally turned up when the artist was looking for blank paper, whereupon he used the other side, and then trimmed the sheet to suit the Madonna and Child. It escaped me when I was writing about this sheet more than thirty years ago that this sketch copies a figure in an Attic funeral stele of the 4th century.
BB_1903_title_recto: Study for a Madonna hold ing the Child, with the infant John by her side
BB_1903_title_verso: Study of the Virgin for a Visitation

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per una Madonna che abbraccia teneramente il Bambino
BB_1961_title_verso: Un madrigale scritto da Michelangelo con inchiostro nero e poi cancellato con inchiostro marrone
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Madonna, tenderly embracing the Child
BB_1938_title_verso: A madrigal in Michelangelo's handwriting written with black ink, and then cancelled with brown
BB_1938_text_recto: Formerly gilt all around the edges. Action and drapery seem close to the woman holding a child in the lunette of Simon, Boas and Obet. Perhaps as early as 1514-1515.
BB_1903_title_recto: Study for Madonna, tenderly embracing the Child
BB_1903_title_verso: A madrigal in Michelangelo's handwriting written with black ink, and then cancelled with brown

BB_1961_title_recto: L'Eterno Padre volteggiante fra le nubi
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for the Eternal floating through the air
BB_1938_text_recto: On March 25, 1532, Sebastiane writes to Michelangelo begging drawings for a "Nativity with God the Father in the midst of Angels" (Milanesi, Sebastiano del Piombo, p. 88). This sketch was more than probably done by Sebastiano on Michelangelo's indication for the Eternal in the altar-piece still to be seen at Santa Maria del Popolo ... but discarded for a more purely Sebastianesque figure. Our sketch is well on the way to Tintoretto in all except technique.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studi per una Sacra Famiglia con Donatore
BB_1961_title_verso: Altro studio del Bambino Gesù, come sul recto, iscritto da tarda mano cinquecentesca "Fra Basto del Piombo"
BB_1961_text_recto: Probabilmente dopo il 1530, e per una Sacra Famiglia come quella ora a Napoli... Il profilo del donatore suggerisce il donatore nella "Sacra Famiglia Borgherini" nella National Gallery di Londra (n. 1450).
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Holy Family with Donor
BB_1938_title_verso: Study of Infant Christ on the recto in silverpoint and white and "Fra Basto del Piombo" in a late 16th century hand
BB_1938_text_recto: Probably after 1530 and for a Holy Family like the one now at Naples... The profile of the donor suggests Clement VII.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per il gruppo di donne nella "Visitazione" dipinta per Santa Maria della Pace a Roma, i cui frammenti appartengono ora al Duca di Northumberland, ad Alnwick Castle
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for the group of women in the Visitation painted for Santa Maria della Pace, the fragments of which now belong to the Duke of Northumberland at Alnwick
BB_1938_text_recto: Important for what it tells us about the finished work but scarcely an autograph.

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per una Flagellazione Originariamente a carboncino : il Cristo, la colonna, la cornice, la piattaforma e parte delle due figure ripassate liberamente a penna; dei carnefici e degli spettatori rimangono soltanto i contorni perforati
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Flagellation originally in black chalk The Christ, the column, the cornice, the platform and part of two figures inked over freely. The executioners and spectators remain as pricked outlines only
BB_1938_text_recto: It seems natural to take this sheet as a study for Sebastiano's fresco at San Pietro in Montorio. Mister Popham rightly remarks that the "penwork is characteristically Venetian," and it could be argued that  hen first asked to paint the fresco Sebastiano freely designed a Flagellation and a Venetian composition was the spontaneous result. In the Christ there is something of the Giorgionesque Sebastiano as at San Bartolommeo in Rialto, and of the young Titian as in Saint Mark Enthroned at the Salute, both in Venice. On the other hand, the earliest possible date for this sketch is 1517 and in every probability  considering how dilatory a worker Sebastiano was, it may be two or three years later. But even in 1517 Sebastiano should give signs of contact with Michelangelo. Here there are none. There are traces of quite another influence, namely Signorelli's. The proportions and the action of the pricked figures are reminiscent of the latter. So perhaps is the outlining by pricking. One is reminded of drawings by Signorelli like my 2509 N-1, 2509 E-1, and 2509 A-3. And the attitude of Christ reminds us not at all of Michelangelo but of Signorelli's figure for the Morra Flagellation, my 2509D-11... But nowhere else in  Sebastiano is there a touch to witness that Sebastiano had ever looked at Signorelli. Turning for a moment to the penwork, I find on comparing it with the Berlin and Lille drawings (my 2475, 2481...) that the notation although so Venetian, yet is not the same as in those. The line tends to be more ductile, more sweeping as suits an engraver, or one destined to become one. Now there was a Venetian roaming about Central Italy in the fourth or fifth decade of the 16th century who was an imitator of Michelangelo, who could easily have known Sebastiano's and Signorelli's Flagellations and whose penwork has a closer resemblance to that in this design that has Sebastiano's. This Venetian was Battista Franco, and I wonder whether he was not the author of the Amsterdam sheet. In the Museum of Rennes there is (cadre 29) a pen-drawing (27 by 18) after the Christ in the Flagellation, in the Museum of Besançon another in black chalk (N. D. 1624). I mention them to forestall their attribution to Sebastiano himself.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di vecchia in profilo verso destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Head of pathetic old woman in profile right
BB_1938_text_recto: No small resemblance to the Anna in the Louvre Visitation. Yet the sentiment is not Sebastiano's, and the penwork more like Battista Franco's. It may be the latter's or by a later imitator.

BB_1961_title_recto: Vecchio barbuto in atteggiamento disperato e due figure con le teste vòlte in profilo, una a destra e l'altra a sinistra
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for old bearded man in attitude of despair and of two other figures with heads turned in profile, one to right and one to Ieft
BB_1938_text_recto: Supposed to be for the background figures in Sebastiano's Raising of Lazarus. Neither their expression nor action suit that subject particularly, and in the handling there is little to compel one to ascribe this sheet to Sebastiano rather than to one of many other followers of Michelangelo, as for instance Vasari or even Tibaldi.

BB_1961_title_recto: Figura maschile inginocchiata e varie altre figure a contorni vaghi
BB_1961_title_verso: Alcune nicchie e finestre
BB_1938_title_recto: Kneeling male figure, and in vague outline several others
BB_1938_title_verso: Windows, scarcely Sebastiano's; perhaps Michelangelo's.
BB_1938_text_recto: The purpose of this sketch would remain obscure, if a copy there of in the British Museum, ascribed to Daniele daVolterra but more likely by a later Florentine, did not make it clear that it was for a Pietà. The kneeling figure was added later and may be for a Nativity rather than, like those in outline, for a Pieta. It no longer seems likely that they are by Sebastiano. One may hazard the guess that they are by a Florentine follower of Michelangelo working in Rome and acquainted with Sebastiano's work. The windows or niches and architectural outlines on the verso are certainly Michelangelo's and most probably of his last Roman period.
BB_1903_title_recto: A kneeling male figure, and in vague outline several others
BB_1903_title_verso: Windows, scarcely Sebastiano's; perhaps Michelangelo's.

BB_1961_title_recto: Sette figure abbastanza elaborate ed altre appena accennate, per un'Ascensione o possibilmente (ma non probabilmente) per una Discesa dello Spirito Santo
BB_1938_title_recto: Seven figures fairly elaborated and several others barely indicated for an Ascension or possibly (but iess likely) a Descent of the Holy Spirit
BB_1938_text_recto: Too agitated and too sentimental for Sebastiano, to whom it is attributed. The forms and the penwork are scarcely his. An excellent but later drawing. Perhaps Venetian.

BB_1961_title_recto: San Luca
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Saint Luke, ascribed to Fra Filippo
BB_1938_text_recto: Fischel, p. 85..., ascribes this sketch to Perugino. He is probably right.
BB_1903_title_recto: Study for Saint Luke, ascribed to Fra Filippo

BB_1961_title_recto: Natività
BB_1938_title_recto: Design for Nativity
BB_1938_text_recto: The attribution to Sebastiano no longer convinces me. The landscape, the boy Baptist, and even the angels might be by him when closely imitating Pesellino. The Madonna and Joseph are Verrocchiesque in a way that suggests the young Perugino. Is it possiblethat this Nativity is a copy of a design by the great artist? Another artist whom a number of features in this Nativity recalls is the Castello Master.
BB_1903_title_recto: Design for a Nativity, ascribed to Ghirlandajo

BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane cavaliere visto da tergo, in atto di allontanarsi verso destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Youthful horseman seen from behind riding inward to right
BB_1938_text_recto: ...ascribed to Raphael, but characteristic of Signorelli in what may be called his Raphaelesque mode. Its nearest parallel is at Orvieto the youthful horseman on the pedestal from which Antichrist is preaching.

BB_1961_title_recto: Volto chino di uomo attempato, in profilo a destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Fragment with face of middle-aged man looking down in profile right
BB_1938_text_recto: After 1500. Perhaps for an Adoration of the Shepherds.

BB_1961_title_recto: Due giovani nudi virili: l'uno con il braccio ed il ginocchio destro poggiati a terra e la mano sinistra portata alla testa, l'altro sdraiato per terra di fronte a lui, con la gamba sinistra ritirata sotto quella destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Two youthful nudes, one supporting himself on right knee and hand with his Ieft to his head, and the other facing him but sprawling on ground with Ieft leg tucked under right
BB_1938_text_recto: Apparently for the Resurrection of the Dead at Orvieto..., where we find figures closely resembling these although not identical with them. In quality this drawing recalls my 2509.E-9..., formerly in the Oppenheimer Collection, and like that suggests Timoteo and even more Raphael.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di uomo vista di fronte
BB_1938_title_recto: Head of man facing front
BB_1938_text_recto: As the spare features and long face have some resemblance to Dante and as he wears leaves on his cap we have here in all probability a study by Signorelli for a portrait of the poet. Perhaps it was for Orvieto where however Dante is represented in profile. It has taken me a long time to get over feeling that this sketch was by Piero di Cosimo. I see now that it is too plastic and too decided for the latter.
BB_1903_title_recto: Head of a Man with bay leaves in his cap, probably Dante

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo visto da tergo, che si piega in avanti, curvando la schiena ed accennando in alto con la mano sinistra
BB_1938_title_recto: Fleshy nude seen from behind dragging himself along with bent back and Ieft hand pointing upwards
BB_1938_text_recto: Ascribed to Timoteo, but same hand as my 2509.D-7, 2509.E-9...and 2509.H-9, and imagined turned round almost identical with the first of these numbers and in treatment with the last. The resemblances in action to the guard in the foreground left of Raphael's Liberation of Peter...can have no bearing on the attribution. It probably was done in connection with the Orvieto frescoes, perhaps for the Resurrection of the Dead.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo seduto per terra da sinistra a destra, ma vòlto verso chi guarda e col braccio sinistro proteso che afferra un'asta Iscritto Timoteo Viti in grafia settecentesca, nell'angolo inferiore sinistro
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude seated on ground from Ieft to right but facing us, and with his Ieft hand at arm's length grasping staff
BB_1938_text_recto: Ascribed to Timoteo, whose name in 18th century hand appears in lower Ieft-hand corner. Close to the other drawings ascribed to Timoteo which we attribute to Signorelli, but the lighting and the stroke seem to betray the hand of a deliberate imitator.

BB_1961_title_recto: Due frammenti di una Flagellazione, sette figure in tutto
BB_1938_title_recto: Two fragments of design for Flagellation-seven figures in all
BB_1938_text_recto: Both spoiled by pricking and in outline only so that it is hard to do justice to these figures. They probably were never more than copies nearly contemporary, of an original drawing by Signorelli himself for the Flagellation of about 1510 at Morra.

BB_1961_title_recto: Uomo ammantato, di mezza età, che si vòlta verso destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Draped middle-aged man turning away to right
BB_1938_text_recto: Close to Signorelli in his last phase and perhaps by Papaoello.

BB_1961_title_recto: Maddalena in piedi, con gli occhi bassi e la testa inclinata verso la spalla sinistra, che regge il vaso degli unguenti nella mano destra e con la mano sinistra raccoglie i lembi del suo pesante mantello
BB_1938_title_recto: Magdalen heavily draped stands with head bent a trifle to our right and looks down, holding vase in her right hand and with Ieft the folds of her mantle
BB_1938_text_recto: Close to the Magdalen of 1504 at Orvieto..., but there are significant differences in spirit, in action, and in draping, the painting suggesting something at once more Peruginesque and more provincial.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di adolescente con i capelli raccolti come in una rete sulla nuca, inclinata verso destra per guardare in basso
BB_1938_title_recto: Head of young woman with hair in net down to shoulders, turning a little to right to look down
BB_1938_text_recto: Companion to last. Turned around it might almost have served for the Sait Eligius at Borge San Sepolcro... but is certainly later.

BB_1961_title_recto: Un diavolo afferra per la nuca un nudo virile che cade sopra un ginocchio urlando e portandosi la mano destra all'orecchio
BB_1938_title_recto: Demon hurls himself on a nude who falls on one knee howling, with his right hand to his ear
BB_1938_text_recto: Copy of study for two figures in foreground Ieft in fresco of the Damned at Orvieto...The original must have been of the elaborate, rather delicate quality of my 2509.H-2...This almost contemporary copy looks fairly exact.

BB_1961_title_recto: Cavaliere lanciato al galoppo verso sinistra, col mantello svolazzante, la testa abbassata in profilo, il braccio destro alzato a colpire, il sinistro nascosto dallo scudo
BB_1938_title_recto: Horseman charging to Ieft bending down in profile with right arm in position of brandishing sword, his Ieft hidden by buckler, a cloak fluttering from his shoulder
BB_1938_text_recto: For a Saint George, but neither for the fresco grisaille at Orvieto nor for the panel in the Vom Rath Collection, Amsterdam. Probable date 1505-1510.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile visto da tergo, ma vòlto di tre quarti verso sinistra, che si solleva in punta dei piedi giungendo le mani sopra la testa, come volesse colpire con un flagello od una frusta; ripetuto, su scala minore, nell'angolo superiore destro; a giudicare dal tocco il monogramma "L S" nell'angolo destro inferiore, deve essere stato aggiunto più tardi
BB_1938_title_recto: Male nude to left with hands joined above head in posture of person about to strike with lash or whip. In upper corner right small sketch for same. The monogram below to right, if we may judge by the stroke, must have been added later
BB_1938_text_recto: For an executioner in a Flagellation, a subject occurring a number of times in Signorelli's extant paintings from the early masterpiece in the Brera to the late composition at Altenburg...This drawing must have been done for the fresco at Morra..., where it appears with little change in action and none in proportion. In the abbreviated version of the same design, the panel in the Franchetti Collection at Venice... this nude is not omitted.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di giovane con capelli ricciuti ricadenti sulle spalle, bocca aperta, occhi alzati in estasi
BB_1938_title_recto: Head of youth with long curls falling down to shoulders, mouth open, and eyes turned up in ecstasy
BB_1938_text_recto: For John the Baptist in Perugia altar-piece of 1484.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile visto da tergo, con la mano sinistra sul fianco e la destra attorno alla coscia sinistra di un corpo nudo, abbandonato come fosse un cadavere, che egli porta sulle spalle
BB_1961_text_recto: Il dipinto più vicino per qualità a questo nudo, è il frammento col "Giovane che si toglie la camicia" già nella raccolta Cook a Richmond, ora in prestito al Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge.
BB_1938_title_recto: Male nude seen from behind with Ieft hand on hip and right around Ieft thigh of limp naked body that he carries slung over his shoulders
BB_1938_text_recto: For the frescoes at Orvieto, where the limp body turned around and the shoulders only of its bearer appear in the lower right hand corner in the composition of the Damned... My 2509.D-6... is a study for a similar one. There is another sketch of the same nature in Berlin. In quality the painting nearest to this nude is the figure taking off his shirt in the fragment of the Baptism now in the Cook Collection, Richmond.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa virile in profilo a sinistra
BB_1961_text_recto: Schizzo o cartone per la testa del terzo Arcangelo da destra, nell'affresco dei "Dannati" ad Orvieto
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch or cartoon of head of archangel extreme right in fresco of the Damned at Orvieto
BB_1938_text_recto: Fragmentary.

BB_1961_title_recto: Un nudo virile, accompagnato da una figura femminile, leggermente vestita, commenta i gesti di "Padre Tempo", il quale getta per terra un satiro con la mano sinistra, mentre addita il cielo con la destra; fra l'uomo e la donna fa capolino una faccia che scintilla di curiosità
BB_1938_title_recto: Male nude accompanied by slightly draped female expatiates on ''Father Time" who pushes a satyr down to the ground with his Ieft hand while pointing upward with his right. Between the male and female peeps a face sparkling with curiosity
BB_1938_text_recto: Framed by Vasari as a Carpaccio. The types, the proportion, the spirit are so Signorellesque that the only excuse for questioning that it is by Signorelli himself is that the touch is rather niggling. Yet it is far too good to be by any of his followers and I venture to believe that it is his autograph, done probably about 1510 and for a series of mythological and allegorical scenes of which we have another example in my 2509.D-6

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile con elmetto, che cammina pettoruto verso destra, col braccio destro teso in avanti ed il sinistro abbandonato lungo il fianco, col pugno serrato a metà
BB_1961_title_verso: Gambe, braccia, mani e teste, a sanguigna. Tre leggeri schizzi dal vero, due in costume del tempo ed il terzo nudo, a carboncino
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude in helmet strutting to right with right arm stretched its full length and left at side with hand half clenched
BB_1938_title_verso: Right legs, arms and hands and bead in red chalk. In black chalk three slight sketches from model, two in costume of time, and third nude
BB_1938_text_recto: From Signorelli's later years, perhaps for some Roman subject.

BB_1961_title_recto: Varie copie di scolari da originali del Signorelli: Una Madonna seduta, in un ampio mantello, che si piega sul Bambino nudo che tiene fra le braccia- derivata da un'opera abbastanza giovanile del maestro Due schizzi per un giovane Battista, uno dei quali con panneggi angolosi come negli affreschi di Loreto (circa 1480) e nella "Circoncisione" della National Gallery di Londra, circa 1491 Una figura a metà drappeggiata volteggiante come uno degli Angeli nella cupola della sacrestia di Loreto
BB_1961_title_verso: Copie di tre nudi in atteggiamento di sorpresa, derivate da originali fatti senza dubbio per Orvieto, e più particolarmente, per il "Finimondo"
BB_1938_title_recto: Various school-boy copies after Signorelli: Madonna seated amply draped bending over the naked Child in her arms-after some fairly early work of tho master. Two sketches for youthful Baptist, one with angular draperies as in the Loreto frescoes and slightly later in National Gallery Circumcision...Whirling half-draped figure suggesting one of the angels in the cupola of the sacristy at Loreto
BB_1938_title_verso: Copies of three nudes in startled attitudes, after originals done no doubt for Orvieto, and more particularly for the End of the World
BB_1938_text_recto: I cannot identify the other sketches on the recto. One however, the profile of a youth wearing a broad starched collar, is obviously of the 17th century and leads to the question whether the whole sheet is not of the same period.

BB_1961_title_recto: Atletico nudo giovanile visto da tergo, con la testa vòlta di tre quarti verso sinistra, braccia e gambe nella posizione di chi sta per lanciare qualcosa
BB_1938_title_recto: Youthful athletic nude seen from behind, head in just less than profile Ieft with arms and legs in position of one about to hurl something
BB_1938_text_recto: I have not seen the original. The pose suggests a figure for a Stoning of Stephen and the technique, the modelling, and the proportions point to the Orvieto frescoes. Perhaps it was intended for a predella to an altar-piece done during those years, and possibly for an episode in the fresco recounting the Misdeeds of Antichrist... The figure that comes closest is the soldier in the End of the World

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile piegato in avanti che accenna verso l'alto con la mano destra ed apre la mano sinistra in atto di supplica
BB_1961_text_recto: Con ogni probabilità uno studio per gli affreschi nel Duomo di Orvieto e specialmente per la "Resurrezione della Carne" benché non sia riscontrabile né in quello né in altro affresco. Cfr. BB n. 2509.E-8.
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude stooping on right foot pointing upward with right hand and with left appealingly open over thigh
BB_1938_text_recto: In every probability for Orvieto and possibly for the Resurrection, but to be discovered neither in that nor in any other fresco.

BB_1961_title_recto: Quattro figure che illustrano l'apertura del 33° canto dell'Inferno di Dante Il poeta e Virgilio, in profilo verso sinistra, chinano lo sguardo su dei nudi virili, l'uno, l'Arcivescovo Ruggieri, accovacciato per terra con le mani legate dietro la schiena, l'altro, il Conte Ugolino, che lo tiene giù per il collo ed accenna al suo cranio aperto
BB_1938_title_recto: Four figures illustrating opening of 33rd canto of Dante's Inferno. 'rhe poet and Virgil look down to Ieft at two nudes, one with his hands tied behind him sitting stretched on the ground, while the other holds the first down by the neck and points to his open skull. The one who is talking is Count Ugolino and the other is the ArchbishopRuggieri
BB_1938_text_recto:
It is usually assumed that the sketch was made for the Dante illustrations at Orvieto. If that is so it would suggest that Signorelli's first idea-or that of his employer-was to take subjects from the entire Divina Commedia and not, as finally decided, from the Purgatory only. On the other hand, it is possible that this design was done without thought of Orvieto, where, by the way, the compositions are circular or oblong and not, as here, vertical, and as the too small head of Virgil suggests, at a later date. The Ugolino episode may perhaps be descried in the fresco representing Hell...but treated quite
differently.

BB_1961_title_recto: Quattro nudi maschili: il primo a sinistra morde la polvere, mentre il secondo gli lega le mani sul dorso, premendolo contro la terra; un terzo avanza da destra, cercando di svincolarsi dal quarto che è intento a legargli le braccia dietro la schiena
BB_1938_title_recto: Four male nudes. To Ieft one tramples over back of another who as he bites the dust, has his arms tied behind him by the first. In foreground a third steps out as if to get away while a fourth binds his arms as well behind him
BB_1938_text_recto: Kind and quality of nudes at Orvieto. If done in connection with the frescoes there, it need not have been, as generally assumed, for the one representing the Damned but rather for the one depicting the misdeeds of Antichrist. There we see men being taken prisoners, although we cannot find the exact counterpart of the drawing. Or again there are scenes in the grisailles illustrating the great poets of antiquity. Above the medallion of Perseus and Andromeda there is a rectangular composition representing three demons attacking as many nudes... The action is close to our sketch but on a lower and less heroic scale of vitality. The same is true of the nudes in the medallions accompanying Lucian...

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di uomo non più giovane, di tre quarti a sinistra, inclinata in avanti
BB_1938_title_recto: Head of youngish man, three-fourths to Ieft, slightly leaning forwards
BB_1938_text_recto: Known only in this poor reproduction, but seems probable, and of kind attributed by some to Timoteo Viti. If authentic, it is of the Orvieto period and perhaps for one of the heads tpere, although I have not succeeded in identifying it.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di uomo glabro, china quasi in profilo a destra, col naso prominente, mento diviso, la bocca aperta e labbro inferiore arricciato
BB_1938_title_recto: Head of beardless man bending down almost profile right. Nose prominent, chin cleft, mouth open with lower lip curled. Curiously realistic
BB_1938_text_recto: Looks in the reproduction as if of the Orvieto period and perhaps for one of the heads there.

BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane in costume degli anni intorno al 1500, a gambe divaricate, con lo sguardo abbassato verso sinistra, la mano destra serrata come a stringere una spada e la sinistra tesa in fuori
BB_1938_title_recto: Youth in costume of about 1500 standing lightly with feet apart as if preparing to stride tor. while looking down to left. His right hand at arm's length as if clenching pommel of sword, his left held out
BB_1938_text_recto: Looks like study for a Michael or a youthful warrior in general but I have not been able to discover the painted figure at Monte Oliveto or Orvieto or elsewhere. Comes nearest to Archangels at last-named place in fresco of the Damned... It is not likely to have served for the second youth left in the Uffizi predella representing the Epiphany.

BB_1961_title_recto: Un diavolo afferra tra le mani la testa di un nudo prostrato; un altro nudo cade sul ginocchio sinistro mentre un altro diavolo gli lega le mani dietro la schiena; iscritto "T V" nell'angolo inferiore sinistro in grafia squadrata del Cinquecento avanzato
BB_1938_title_recto: Demon hurling himself on prostrate nude whose head he seizes between his hands. Corresponds to the group in lower corner right in fresco of the Damned at Orvieto... A nude falls on his Ieft leg while his hands are being tied behind. Occurs, in same fresco, in almost middle of foreground.
BB_1938_text_recto: Lower Ieft-hand corner has the letters "T. V." in square advanced 16th century hand. Copies after the fresco rather than of drawings for it, almost contemporary, perhaps Umbrian.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di donna in profilo a sinistra, con gli occhi bassi
BB_1961_title_verso: Iscritto in grafia piuttosto infantile: "Carissimo Padre, carissimo ed amatissimo 1" e simili iscrizioni
BB_1938_title_recto: Head in profile to Ieft looking down slightly
BB_1938_title_verso: On the back in rather childish scribbling: "Carisimo Padre, carisimo ed amatissimo" and similar inscriptions
BB_1938_text_recto: Might have served for a Visitation like the one in Berlin..., but occurs repeatedly in Signorelli's works of the first decade of 16th century, e. g. Urbino Crucifixion..., Orvieto.., Cortona...A good pupil of those years could perhaps have achieved enough mastery to approach the teacher as closely as here, before sinking into provincial mannerisms, like the Papacello...

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile che ne solleva un altro da terra afferrandolo alla vita; quest'ultimo lotta, soffocando per liberarsi dalla stretta
BB_1938_title_recto: Two male nudes wrestling, one lifting the other from ground by midriff, and the other struggling to get free and choking
BB_1938_text_recto: Motive and treatment Pollajuolesque. Perhaps toward 1400. Close analogies with Volterra altar-piece of 1491.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo che lotta per alzarsi da terra, dove appoggia il ginocchio destro, mentre preme la gamba sinistra piegata contro quella di un altro nudo che lo percuote
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude struggling to get up from ground on which he rests with knee while left leg is bent and pushing against the leg of another nude who beats him
BB_1938_text_recto: Mr. Kenneth Clark in publishing this drawing correctly relates it to Orvieto frescoes and remarks that the figures do not occur there. It is possible, however, that this gave place to a drawing of which the British Museum has a faithful copy (my 2509.N.) It is less likely, but conceivable, that this same study represents an earlier phase of two nudes in the scene in hell.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo visto da tergo, a gambe divaricate, con la testa girata violentemente a destra, il pugno destro visibile sopra la spalla sinistra e la mano sinistra aperta, in basso, in un gesto di indignazione o di ripugnanza
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude from behind with legs apart turning vehemently to right with right hand clenched over Ieft shoulder and Ieft held down and spread its full span in a gesture of indignation or loathing
BB_1938_text_recto: Must have been done in connection with Orvieto frescoes, but does not seem to have been used.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di giovane donna vòlta di tre quarti verso destra, con lo sguardo vòlto in alto
BB_1938_title_recto: Head of youngish woman turned slightly to right with pupils of eyes rolled up
BB_1938_text_recto: Nearest to leftmost head in choir of Virgins at Orvieto..., but probably later.

BB_1961_title_recto: Madonna seduta, la testa inclinata in profilo verso destra, contempla Gesù e San Giovannino in atto di abbracciarsi nel suo grembo
BB_1961_title_verso: Profilo di un uomo glabro, attempato, che guarda attentamente verso sinistra
BB_1961_text_recto: Né la monumentale Madonna manifestamente ispirata dalla Madonna con Sant'Anna di Leonardo..., né lo splendido profilo appaiono in alcuna delle pitture a me note, benché siano entrambi caratteristici del Signorelli. La Madonna è abbastanza simile alla "Madonna Benson", ora nel Metropolitan Museum di New York (n. 497.13), da permetter l'ipotesi che questo disegno abbia servito ad un quadro perduto del quale la "Madonna Benson" potrebbe essere un'abbreviazione autografa del maestro. Il parallelo più prossimo al profilo sul verso è dato eh l San Giuseppe nella "Natività" di Napoli, dove però egli appare più giovane, malgrado la barba. Forse ancora più simile è l'ultima testa a sinistra nella "Crocifissione", del 1507 circa, in San Crescentino a Morra..., ma non è una somiglianza decisiva.
BB_1938_title_recto: Madonna seated with head bent in profile to right with the two Holy Children in her lap, embracing
BB_1938_title_verso: Profile head of smooth-faced elderly man looking intently to Ieft
BB_1938_text_recto: Neither the monumental Madonna, manifestly inspired by Leonardo's Virgin with Saint Anne, nor the splendid profile occurs in any paintings known to me, yet both are characteristic and typical of Signorelli. The profile comes nearest to that of Joseph in the Naples Nativity, where, however, he is younger although bearded. It is even closer to the last head left in the Morra Deposition..., but not close enough. The Madonna is closest to the one formerly in the Royal Accademy Benson Collection, almost close enough to have served for a picture of which the Benson Madonna might be an autograph abbreviation.

BB_1961_title_recto: Quattro nudi virili cornuti, con ali di pipistrello: il primo a destra si volta verso gli altri reggendo un libro aperto a lunghezza di braccio; gli altri fissano le pagine stupefatti, quello in coda aggiustandosi gli occhiali sul naso
BB_1938_title_recto: Four homed male nudes, striding along to right. The foremost turns to the others as he holds up half-open book at arm's length. They seem surprised and stare at the pages, the hindmost adjusting glasses to his nose
BB_1938_text_recto: No doubt devils intended for the Orvieto frescoes, where, however, this group does not occur. Was it perhaps for Dante illustrations?

BB_1961_title_recto: Due coppie di nudi in lotta, una di uomini ed una di donne: a destra, un uomo, visto di fronte, cerca di calmare, prendendolo per le spalle, un uomo vociferante, visto da tergo; a sinistra, una donna cérca di allontanarne un'altra dall'uomo irato; dietro a quest'ultimo, al limite destro del foglio, su scala maggiore, è accennata la metà di un viso - un occhio obliquo, un naso e metà di una piccola bocca; le linee del terreno indicano un orizzonte vicino e basso; il monogramma inferiore è interessante
BB_1938_title_recto: Four nudes. On right two males, one vociferating and the other with his hand on the shoulder of the first trying to calm him. On Ieft, one female dragging another away from the males. Extreme right a huge mask with slanting eyes and small mouth. Landscape with near and low skyline. The monogram lower left is interesting.
BB_1938_text_recto: No doubt for Orvieto frescoes, and for the Misdeeds of Antichrist rather than the Damned, but occurring in neither. Curiously reminiscent of the nudes in my 1925 and 1949. Is it only a coincidence? Seldom does Signorelli come so close as here to Pollajuolo.

BB_1961_title_recto:
Giovane nudo virile visto da tergo, col torso girato verso destra come la piccola testa arruffata ed il braccio destro indicato soltanto
fino al gomito
BB_1938_title_recto: Youthful male nude seen from behind with upper part only of right arm indicated, shaggy head in profile to right
BB_1938_text_recto: Of excellent quality and from artist's best years. Perhaps for soldier standing with arm akimbo in the fresco at Monte Oliveto Maggiore representing St. Benedict receiving Totila.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile in profilo verso destra, con la testa e le braccia atteggiate a suonare un flauto, nudo femminile visto di fronte, con un panno gettato sul braccio e la coscia sinistra, e che regge un lungo stelo e piega pensosamente la testa sulla spalla sinistra Iscritto "di Piero di Cosimo" nell'angolo inferiore sinistro
BB_1938_title_recto: Loosely sketched nude in profile right with head and arms in position of one playing the flute, and a female with drapery over Ieft arm and thigh only, holding a lily and bending her head pensively
BB_1938_text_recto: One is tempted to connect this sketch, worthy of the greatest draughtsman, with the Berlin Pan. It is larger and bolder than are the figures in even that composition. Not infrequently artists in moments of inspiration dash ahead of themselves, so to speak, by decades and land in mid-career of their successors. Thus, in some ways the contours and handling of this sketch anticipate the ageing Michelangelo. The inscription in the lower left-hand corner is probably by Baldinucci and reads "di Pier di Cosimo."

BB_1961_title_recto: Due Santi in pesanti panneggi, ambedue vòlti verso sinistra
BB_1938_title_recto: Two saints heavily draped
BB_1938_text_recto: One of these figures was done for a Francis and the other perhaps for a Joseph in some such altarpiece as the one of 1491 at Volterra...but of slightly later date.

BB_1961_title_recto: Due nudi, l'uno visto di fronte con una giovane donna a cavalcioni sulla spalla destra, l'altro visto da tergo, con un giovane nudo sulla spalla destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Two nudes, one seen from front carrying a young woman astride on his right shoulder, the other seen from back with naked youth riding on his right shoulder
BB_1938_text_recto: Patched and restored. No doubt connected with the Orvieto fresco representing the Damned where, however, these precise figures do not occur.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile con la testa fasciata in una specie di turbante, che si piega in avanti, appoggiandosi ad un'asta, verso sinistra, ma guarda verso destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Male nude in turbanlike cap, leans over to Ieft with both hands on staff and looks to right
BB_1938_text_recto: Perhaps for the Resurrection at Orvieto. This kind of drawing has been at times attributed to Timoteo Viti and even the youthful Raphael, but is far too accomplished for the first, and too hard for the second.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile dai capelli ricciuti cadenti sulle spalle, che avanza verso sinistra ad occhi chiusi come in trance, tenendo nelle mani un lungo nastro ritorto che egli solleva con la destra sopra il suo capo
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude with hair curling down to his shoulders walks with eyes closed as in trance to Ieft with right arm held up and a ribbon caught and held in his hands
BB_1938_text_recto: Perhaps this was to begin with by Signorelli, and a fine performance with Pollajuolesque pen contours. The later hatching makes it hard to decide. It is perhaps a trifle too elegant, too Peruginesque for Signorelli. Nevertheless, there is great resemblance to such a nude as the one on the extreme Ieft in the Orvieto "Crowning of the Blessed".

BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane nudo virile, quasi in profilo verso destra, con la mano sinistra protesa, la mano destra sull'anca, lo sguardo vòlto verso l'alto e la bocca aperta come a chiamare
BB_1938_title_recto: Youthful nude almost in profile right with left hand held out and right on hip, looks up as if shouting
BB_1938_text_recto: Possibly for the Crowning of the Blessed at Orvieto..., foreground right and Ieft and in the style of my 2509.H. It, however, is much vaguer as well as softer than that drawing, softer in a Raphaelesque way and nearest to drawings by Timoteo Viti.

BB_1961_title_recto: Due cavalieri che giostrano; iscritto nell'angolo superiore sinistro, di mano contemporanea: "Luca Signorelli cortonensi famoso pictor"
BB_1961_title_verso: (In direzione opposta): Cavaliere che si allontana verso sinistra
BB_1938_title_recto: Two knights jousting. In upper Ieft-hand corner the inscription in contemporary hand: "Luca Signorelli cortonensi famoso pittor."
BB_1938_title_verso: In opposed direction, knight riding away to left
BB_1938_text_recto: pricked for transfer

BB_1961_title_recto: Quattro nudi virili giacenti o accovacciati in varie posizioni
BB_1961_title_verso: Nudo accovacciato, con la testa fra le mani
BB_1938_title_recto: Four nudes lying or crouching in various position
BB_1938_title_verso: Crouching nude with his head between his hands
BB_1938_text_recto: Probably done in cennection with Orvieto frescoes. They are nearest to the prostrate figures in foreground of the Corning of the End. Never again is Signorelli so Miohelangelesque.

BB_1961_title_recto: Busto di uomo attempato, in profilo a sinistra con lo sguardo chino e la bocca semi-aperta, come sorpreso Originariamente a carboncino (ma ripassato a penna da mano posteriore)
BB_1938_title_recto: Profile bust of man in advanced middle years looking down to Ieft with mouth half open as if in surprise
BB_1938_text_recto: Probably for a Nativity dating from the first decade of 18th century. Originally black chalk and pricked but gone over with ink by later hand.

BB_1961_title_recto: Due nudi virili: quello a sinistra stringe la mano e cinge col braccio la spalla del nudo a destra, che volge la testa dall'altra parte, tenendo la mano sinistra sul fianco; dai suoi piedi partono ombre proiettate diagonalmente sul terreno
BB_1938_title_recto: Two male nudes, one with hand on his left hip turning his head to his Ieft while the other in profile right faces him coaxlngly with his Ieft arm already over the right shoulder of the first. This nude's feet and legs cast shadows to our Ieft diagonally across the ground
BB_1938_text_recto: Probably for the Resurrection at Orvieto, representing one fully awake trying to persuade another who is not yet aware of his bliss. The exact group does not occur, but perhaps the man and woman embracing (middle distance right) has taken its place.

BB_1961_title_recto: Madonna monumentale seduta presso una finestra, sotto un baldacchino, con la testa china in profilo a sinistra, verso il Bambino che siede sul suo ginocchio destro
BB_1961_title_verso: Cavaliere che brandisce una scimitarra
BB_1938_title_recto: Monumental Madonna seated by window under canopy with head bending down profile Ieft over Child, Who sits on her right knee sucking at her breast
BB_1938_title_verso: Horseman brandishing scimitar
BB_1938_text_recto: In type and feeling it comes nearest to the woman listening to the preaching of Antichrist.
BB_1938_text_verso: Poor mid-Cinquecento copy but valuable as record of a great lost picture painted about 1500.

BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane ricciuto visto da tergo, con la testa in profilo a sinistra, che sorregge con le mani ripiegate sul suo pesante mantello; in basso a destra, testa di donna piegata di lato, come su un cuscino
BB_1938_title_recto: Young man with curly locks standing in profile left wearing heavy mantle, which he holds up with folded arms. Below reclining head of sleeping young woman
BB_1938_text_recto: Resembles the woman on the right in the National Gallery Circumcision...although it was scarcely intended for that figure. Undoubtedly both are of the same date, say 1486-8.

BB_1961_title_recto: Pan ed i Pastori
BB_1961_text_recto: Copia, quasi contemporanea, di un artista senese, dell'affresco dipinto dal Signorelli verso il 1512 nel Palazzo Petrucci a Siena.
BB_1938_title_recto: Copy representing the fresco painted by Signorelli about 1512 for the Petrucci Palace, Siena
BB_1938_text_recto: Ruined by damp and outlines gone over, also some heightening with whash added later.

BB_1961_title_recto: Tre cavalieri A carboncino, il cavaliere nel mezzo ombreggiato, gli altri a solo contorno e tutti i contorni bucherellati per lo spolvero
BB_1961_text_recto: Il cavaliere nel mezzo ricorda, in posizione inversa, quello a destra della Maddalena nella "Crocifissione" affrescata dal Signorelli poco dopo il 1507 in San Crescentino a Morra
BB_1938_title_recto: Three horsemen, the central one shaded, the others in outline only
BB_1938_text_recto: Same kind as the horseman in the Morra fresco of the Crucifixion...and like that from the later years of the master, toward 1510.

BB_1961_title_recto: Gruppo di nudi estatici; nell'angolo inferiore destro, studi per la base di una colonna I nudi a sinistra a penna, sopra una linea di contorno incisa; i nudi a destra a penna, sopra una linea di contorno perforata; la base della colonna a sanguigna
BB_1961_text_recto: Probabilmente una copia da uno studio del Signorelli per l'affresco con la "Incoronazione degli Eletti" nel Duomo di Orvieto.
BB_1938_title_recto: Copy of central group in Orvieto Resurrection. Pen over an incised outline on the Ieft-hand group, over a pricked outline on the right. Underneath, studies of base of column in red chalk
BB_1938_text_recto: Similar in quality to my 2509.N-1

BB_1961_title_recto: Ninfe e Satiri: nudo femminile disteso per terra, svenuto o addormentato, con la testa e le spalle sorrette fra le gambe di un secondonudo femminile seduto, vòlto a destra verso un terzo nudo femminile: questo raccoglie oggetti circolari galleggianti in un bacile che un satiro offre avidamente; sotto a loro è inginocchiato un giovane in atto di spremere una spugna in un altro bacile posato per terra vicino ai ginocchi della donna svenuta
BB_1938_title_recto: Female nude stretched on ground, fainted or asleep, with head and shoulders supported between legs of another female nude seated and looking up to right to third female nude who plucks circular things floating in a basin offered eagerly by satyr. Under last two kneels a youth in attitude of squeezing a spunge into another basin, which rests on ground just above fainted woman's knee
BB_1938_text_recto: Study for a mythological or allegorical composition like the grisaille at the Uffizi... and dating from about 1510.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile a gambe divaricate, visto da tergo, in atto di portare un altro nudo sulle braccia
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude seen from behind with legs wide apart carrying another nude in his arms
BB_1938_text_recto: Study for demon in foreground extreme Ieft in Orvieto fresco representing the Damned

BB_1961_title_recto: Quattro figure maschili, in prospettiva digradante: dall'estrema sinistra, in primo piano, un uomo ammantato e in profilo a destra, che guarda in alto; poi un uomo nudo dalla cintola in giù, che si volge al primo, con le mani sollevate in atto di stupore; un nudo che si fa solecchio agli occhi ed un nudo a testa bassa
BB_1938_title_recto: Four male figures, the one leftmost fully draped and in profile right looking up, the one next turning to last, and naked below waist, the other two nude, one shading his eyes
BB_1938_text_recto: The attitude and expressions as well as the perspective suggest an Ascension or Assumption. The pricking may indicate that the composition being of the same scale was intended for a predella or even for an embroidery. Probably soon after 1490. The figure extreme right is almost the one with the lily in my 2509.E..., but reversed, and that is of about the date just proposed.

BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane donna ammantata che siede a occhi bassi, con la mano destra al petto e la sinistra in grembo
BB_1938_title_recto: Youngish woman seated heavily draped, looking down with right hand over bosom, and Ieft under it. Gone over with ink, perhaps by Signorelli himself.
BB_1938_text_recto:
The hatching is curiously like Michelangelo's.
The faint contrapposto of the figure marks it as dating toward 1500. Probably for a Virgin Annunciate or for one of the saints in the ceiling at Orvieto. It is not impossible that it was intended for the Madonna in the slightly earlier Descent of the Holy Spirit at Urbino.

BB_1961_title_recto: Cristo alla colonna; iscritto nell'angolo inferiore destro il monogramma "L S" che ricorre spesso in questi disegni
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Christ at the column. In the lower corner right the monogram that occurs several times on these drawings
BB_1938_text_recto: The nude has an unusually short-looking torso for the length of the legs, resulting in some measure from its recoil under the lash. These proportions may have contributed to getting it ascribed to Sebastiane del Piombo. Recognized as Signorelli's by Mancini, and as for the Flagellation at Morra... In the fresco, a work, by the way, of the master's maturest years, executed between 1508 and 1510, the figure was reversed, looking down to our Ieft instead of to right and standing on his Ieft instead of right foot. In the abbreviated studio variant of the fresco, the Franchetti panel in Venice..., Christ faces as in this sketch.

BB_1961_title_recto: Sant'Antonio da Padova a figura intera
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for full-length Saint Anthony of Padua
BB_1938_text_recto: The pose seems Umbrian, but Sogliani is eclectic enough to have felt Perugino's influence.

BB_1961_title_recto: Apostolo o Santo in piedi, con le mani una nell'altra all'altezza della cintola, visto di fronte ma con la testa girata in profilo verso destra: posa e gesto esprimono uno stupore contemplativo, forse gioioso, certamente privo di sdegno
BB_1938_title_recto: Apostle or other saint standing as if suddenly turning to right with head bent back in sharp profile, and hands folded over chest. Attitude and gesture express surprise but contemplative, perhaps happy, certainly not indignant
BB_1938_text_recto: The size and the pricking for transfer suggest a smallish picture. It is possible it was squared for enlarging not by the master at the time but afterwards by assistants who used it for an altar-piece. Perhaps earlier than the frescoes at Monte Oliveto and Orvieto, possibly for some such painting as the Urbino Crucifiiion or Pentecost, or the Berlin Meeting of the Two Holy Families.

BB_1961_title_recto: Lucrezia immerge un pugnale nel suo seno destro e sviene fra le braccia di una donna che accorre per sostenerla; nell'angolo sinistro si affaccia un'altra donna sbigottita
BB_1961_title_verso: Apollo seduto, in atto di suonare la viola; in basso, in direzione perpendicolare all'Apollo, studio per una Lucrezia sorretta dalle ancelle
BB_1961_text_recto: I panneggi tumultuosi suggeriscono la vivace predella del polittico eseguito nel 1498 per la Cappella Bichi nella Chiesa di Sant'Agostino a Siena, oggi dispersa a Dublino, National Gallery of Ireland (n. 266), e a Pollockhaws (Scozia), Raccolta Maxwell e già a Bridgewater (Somerset), Raccolta Stanley .
BB_1938_title_recto: Lucretia plunges dagger into her right breast and faints into arms of female who dashes forward to grasp her
BB_1938_title_verso: Another study for same subject and an Apollo playing on violin
BB_1938_text_recto: The tumultuous draperies suggest the predella to the scattered polyptych formerly in Sant'Agostino at Siena dating from 1498

BB_1961_title_recto: Vescovo in piedi che legge un libro
BB_1961_text_recto: 1957: Io solevo attribuire questo disegno a Cosimo Rosselli, ma sono ora convinto che Philip Pouncey ha avuto ragione a richiamarvi la mia attenzione e ad insistere sui suoi rapporti con la pala d'altare dipinta dal Signorelli nel 1484 per il Duomo di Perugia, ... e sulla importanza di questo disegno che risulta essere il primo schizzo databile del Signorelli.
BB_1938_title_recto: Bishop standing and reading in book
BB_1938_text_recto: The type of face and kind of folds are characteristic of the late work of Cosimo Rosselli. As Mr. Philip Pouncey has pointed out, this drawing was done in connection with the Ercolano in Signorelli's Perugia altar-piece of 1484. It still looks to me like the work of some one very close to Cosimo Rosselli. Is it a copy by the young Piero di Cosimo? The head would suggest it.
BB_1903_title_recto: A Bishop standing and reading in a book

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile visto da tergo, con la mano sinistra sul fianco ed un cadavere sulle spalle, del quale tiene la gamba col braccio destro
BB_1938_title_recto: Male nude seen from behind with Ieft hand on hip, his right between thighs of limp body he is carrying slung over his shoulders
BB_1938_text_recto: This body is only outlined with the style, while the carrier is highly finished with ink, water-colour, and white to imitate pink flesh...A more plastic version of my 2509.H-2..., partaking more of the qualities and notation of Signorelli as a painter than as a draughtsman.

BB_1961_title_recto: Gruppo tumultuante di cavalieri che circondano la Croce, della quale è solo visibile l'inizio del fusto, abbracciato dalla Maddalena, sotto il quale è svenuta la Vergine confortata da tre donne
BB_1938_title_recto: Design for tumultuous group of horsemen surrounding the cross, of which only the lower shaft is visible with the Magdalen embracing it, and below the group of the Virgin in a faint attended by three women
BB_1938_text_recto: This can be only one of two things: an original design for the Morra fresco of about 1510...or a later copy of such a sketch. The ink with which this later hand retouched the initial chalk lines has so effaced or disguised these lines that they no longer bear clear witness to the hand that drew them. In every probability it was Signorelli's own.

BB_1961_title_recto: Il volto del Redentore: un lungo ovale, perfettamente frontale, con i capelli spartiti nel mezzo e ricadenti in morbide onde sulle spalle, ove finiscono in riccioli
BB_1938_title_recto: The Sacred Face. Long, perfectly frontal, with hair parted over forehead and falling smoothly but in undulations down to shoulders, where it ends in curls
BB_1938_text_recto: This highly elaborate study must be a trifle later than the Boston, Oxford, and Villamarina Madonnas, which, along with faint traces of frescoes on the Bell Tower of Citta di Castello, are the earliest extant works of Signorelli, when still under Piero della Francesca's influence, before his apprenticeship to Pollajuolo. The date can scarcely be later than 1475. Although so different, this Head is reminiscent of Piero's Resurrected Christ at Borge San Sepolcro, and of his Saviour at Citta di Castello. The subject with its variants was curiously popular in the middle decades of the 15th century, particularly in the Low Countries. It would be interesting to know why.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile che ne trasporta un altro
BB_1938_title_recto: Two nudes, one carrying the other
BB_1938_text_recto: Undoubtedly for the Orvieto fresco of Damnation although not to be identified in completed work.

BB_1961_title_recto: Busto di giovane nudo, con la testa buttata all'indietro e la bocca aperta come in estasi
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude bust of young man with head thrown back and mouth open as if in ecstasy
BB_1938_text_recto: Undoubtedly for the Orvieto frescoes and probably for the head of a youth forming a group with a woman embracing another man, just under right foot of trumpeting angel Ieft in the fresco of Resurrection... Perhaps reminiscent of Perugino, as was more than one other Signorelli drawing of this period.

BB_1961_title_recto: Figura maschile distesa per terra con una gamba piegata
BB_1938_title_recto: Male figure stretched out on ground

BB_1961_title_recto: Profeta seduto che tiene un rotolo
BB_1961_text_recto: Del periodo orvietano. La testa, assai rifinita, può essere un ritratto.

BB_1961_title_recto: Figura inginocchiata, con la testa in profilo a sinistra, possibilmente per un San Girolamo in penitenza
BB_1961_text_recto: Leggermente schizzato sul rovescio della tela con la "Maddalena ai piedi del Crocifisso" (n. 8368) coeva agli affreschi nel Duomo di Orvieto. La testa e l'orecchio non potrebbero essere più caratteristici del Signorelli.

BB_1961_title_recto: Uomo che trasalisce, recandosi la mano destra al cuore ed accennando con l'indice della sinistra
BB_1961_text_recto: Questo eccellente schizzo, indubbiamente collegato con gli affreschi di Orvieto, non mi era stato mai mostrato, e ciò spiega perché non è menzionato nelle mie precedenti edizioni. Sembra eseguito direttamente dal vero.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile, col torso abbandonato in avanti
BB_1961_text_recto: Studio per il Cristo nella "Deposizione" del 1515 in Santa Croce ad Umbertide presso Perugia
BB_1938_title_recto: Nude in attitude of drooping from the shoulders. Study for the Saviour in the Umbertide Deposition of 1515

BB_1961_title_recto: Giovane guerriero
BB_1961_text_recto: Studio, alquanto stilizzato, dal vero, eseguito con ogni probabilità in relazione agli affreschi di Orvieto.

BB_1961_title_recto: Nudo virile che avanza in profilo verso sinistra, col braccio destro alzato
Una Madonna seduta e una Madonna inginocchiata che adora il Bambino
BB_1938_title_recto: Two studies, one for seated and the other for kneeling Madonna
BB_1903_title_recto: Two Studies, one for a seated and the other for a kneeling Madonna

BB_1961_title_recto: Un pastore in piedi, due inginocchiati, ed un Angelo
BB_1961_title_verso: Vescovo inginocchiato
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch for the two kneeling shepherds, for the one standing over leftmost, and for an angel in the Mancini Nativity now in the National Gallery...painted in 1496 or later
BB_1938_title_verso: Kneeling bishop

BB_1961_title_recto: Profilo a destra di uomo giovane che porta un soffice berretto rotondo
BB_1938_title_recto: Profile to right of young man wearing round cap with soft crown

BB_1961_title_recto: Ritratto di giovane sentimentale che appoggia la testa sulla mano destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Portrait of sentimental youth resting head on right hand
BB_1903_title_recto: Portrait of a sentimental Youth resting his head on his hand
