BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di giovane donna vòlta a sinistra, con lo sguardo abbassato
BB_1938_title_recto: Head of young woman turned to Ieft with eyes bent down

BB_1961_title_recto: Studio per un Cristo in croce, visto da tergo, in profilo verso destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Christ Crucified seen from back in profile to right

BB_1961_title_recto: San Bartolomeo
BB_1938_title_recto: Copy of Fra Bartolommeo's Saint Bartholomew in the Uffizi Mariage of Catherine
BB_1938_text_recto: I owe acquaintance with this and the following sheet to Mr. A.E. Popham of the British Museum

BB_1961_title_recto: Sant'Antonio da Padova a figura intera
BB_1961_title_verso: Deboli schizzi per due Santi a figura intera, quello a destra ripassato a penna
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for full-length Saint Anthony of Padua
BB_1938_title_verso: Faint sketches for two full-length saints, the one to the right gone over later with ink
BB_1938_text_recto: Inspired by Perugino.

BB_1961_title_recto: Due studi per Madonne: una seduta di profilo a destra, col Bambino che Le si stringe addosso (cfr BB nn 2531 e 2755 C); l'altra stante, in leggero contrapposto, mentre sorregge il Bambino sopra un piedistallo
BB_1938_title_recto: Two studies for Madonnas: one seated in profile to right with the Child nestling up to her (of my 2531 and 27550). The other standing in slight contrapposto and holding up the Child on a pedestal
BB_1938_text_recto: The standing Madonna looks like a sketch for the Madonna in the Cathedral of Pisa.

BB_1961_title_recto: Due studi per i panneggi ricadenti sul ginocchio di una figura seduta
BB_1938_title_recto: Two studies for drapery over knee of seated figure
BB_1938_text_recto: Very close to Credi in quality, yet obviously later and therefore very likely by Sogliani.

BB_1961_title_recto: Bambino Gesù Cartone per il Bambino Gesù nella "Madonna in una nicchia, che tiene il Bambino su un piedistallo", del Sogliani, nella Cattedrale di Pisa, assurdamente attribuita a Pierino del Vaga
BB_1938_title_recto: Cartoon for Child in the Madonna by Sogliani, absurdly ascribed to Pierino del Vaga, in the Cathedral at Pisa
BB_1903_title_recto: Cartoon for the Child in the Madonna by Sogliani, absurdly ascribed to Pierino del Vaga, in the Cathedral at Pisa

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa incantevole, di giovane donna, inclinata leggermente verso destra
BB_1938_title_recto: Charming head of young woman, slightly inclined to right

BB_1938_title_recto: Nativity with angels, Francis and Joseph, in frame with medallions representing Annunciation, and below, Dead Christ
BB_1938_text_recto: Ascribed to Credi as is the Nativity in the Olivella at Palermo so close to this, but certainly by Sogliani, and, like that, among his pleasantest achievements. Here he is already under the influence of Fra Bartolommeo. The Virgin's eyes are characteristic. One might be tempted to take this sketch for a study for the Nativity by Tommaso di Stefano in the chapel of the Villa Capponi at Arcetri, Florence, but in the last-named work we see a pupil of Credi's under the influence of Ridolfo Ghirlandajo, an artist who seems to have left Sogliani entirely untouched.
BB_1903_title_recto: The Nativity, with Angels, Francis and Joseph, in a frame with medallions representing the Annunciation, and below, a dead Christ

BB_1938_title_recto: Study of drapery for Christ as Judge
BB_1938_text_recto: One of those studies in bistre on fine linen usually ascribed to Leonardo and not easy to attribute. This one has been published by Mr. Popham (The Vasari Society for the Riproduction of Drawings by Old Masters, Oxford, University Press, II, XIII, 6) as by Fra Bartolommeo for his fresco of the Last Judgement. But the torso can scarcely be the handiwork of so good a draughtsman, and something in the face and hands almost suggests Brescianino. We may compromise on Sogliani, with similar studies by whom it may be compared. See my 2732 and 2519.

BB_1938_title_recto: Study for a Saint Luke
BB_1938_text_recto: A certain resemblance in pose between this figure and a Saint Luke on the ceiling of the Santa Fina chapel at S. Gimignano has led to its attribution to Domenico Ghirlandajo. In other respects the drawings are as different as work of the same school can be. There is no suggestion of Leonardo in the fresco, whereas the &ketch is coloured with his sentiment and his grace, the left hand is like a copy after him and the folds have his edge. It would be more plausible to ascribe it to him than to Ghirlandajo. The folds, in fact, have much more in common with those on the mantle of the Virgin in P. di Cosimo's altar-piece at Borgo San Lorenzo. Now between this painter and Tommaso the connection is enigmatically close. The angel is nearer to the one in Tommaso's Saint Sebastian in the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge, than to any of Ghirlandajo's.
BB_1903_title_recto: Study for a young Saint Luke

BB_1938_title_recto: Perspective study of basin on pedestal, almost bafflingly complex and geometrical, yet done with an artist's touch
BB_1938_text_recto:
This must be a fair example of the kind of work that absorbed Uccello's best energies.
In the small hours of the night, when his wife would ask him to go to bed, he would ejaculate for an answer: "Oh, what a glorious thing is perspective!"

BB_1938_text_recto: This, the last sheet at Berlin, and my 2774, 2776, 2777, 2778 and 2779.F...are identical in technique, quality, and kind. I have not the courage to ascribe them, as they have been traditionally ascribed, to Uccello himself. But thanks to Mr. Horne, I persuaded myself that the frescoes in the Chiostro Verde at Santa Maria Novella representing the Creation of the Animals and of Man, and the Temptation, are early works of Uccello. Between these frescoes and the drawings we are now considering there is no impassable gulf. Yet to my eye the drawings seem too inferior to even these relatively crude early frescoes to permit my believing that they were done by the same hand. For the present, and until we know more of Uccello's beginnings, it is safer to regard them as copies, made by a pupil after early sketches by Uccello.
BB_1903_title_recto: Two studies of a Young Woman seated on the ground

BB_1961_title_recto: Fides
BB_1961_text_recto: Copia del disegno presentato dal Verrocchio in gara con Paolo Pollajuolo, nell'autunno del 1469, al concorso per le Virtù che dovevano ornare i seggi del Tribunale di Mercanzia (cfr. J. Mesnil, Miscellanea D'Arte, 1903, p. 43). Miss Crutwell nel pubblicarlo (Rassegna D'Arte, 1906, pp. 8-11) ne identificò la destinazione, ma commise l'errore di prenderlo per un originale, cosa che la qualità e la grandezza rendono improbabile, perché l'originale deve essere stato più grande e certamente migliore.
BB_1938_title_recto: Study for Fides
BB_1938_text_recto: Copy of sketch by Verrocchio, made in competition with Paolo Pollajuolo in autumn of 1469 (J. Mesnil, Miscellanea d'Arte, 1903, p. 43) and identified by Miss Crutwell as for that design, only that she took it for an original which its quality and its size make improbable - the original must have been larger (Rassegna d'Arte, 1906, pp. 8-11).
